Thrombin is a potent agonist for a number of cells in and around the vascular space, including platelets, endothelial cells, and vascular smooth muscle cells. Thrombin’s ability to activate cells depends upon its proteolytic activity and appears to be largely, if not exclusively, mediated by a member of the G-protein-coupled family of receptors (1Vu T.-K.H. Hung D.T. Wheaton V.I. Coughlin S.R. Cell. 1991; 64: 1057-1068Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (2654) Google Scholar, 2Rasmussen U.B. Vouret-Craviari V. Jallat S. Schlesinger Y. Pagès G. Pavirani A. Lecocq J.-P. Pouysségur J. Van Obberghen-Schilling E. FEBS Lett. 1991; 288: 123-128Crossref PubMed Scopus (423) Google Scholar). This receptor has a characteristic structure with 7 transmembrane domains and an extracellular N terminus. Cleavage of the N terminus between residues Arg41 and Ser42 exposes a new N terminus whose initial 5 residues, SFLLR, are thought to serve as a tethered ligand, interacting with sites elsewhere in the receptor. Those sites have not been precisely mapped, but are thought to include residues Asn75 to Ser93 in the N terminus near the first transmembrane domain, as well as residues Ile244 to Ala268 in the second extracellular loop (3Bahou W.F. Coller B.S. Potter C.L. Norton K.J. Kutok J.L. Goligorsky M.S. J. Clin. Invest. 1993; 91: 1405-1413Crossref PubMed Scopus (90) Google Scholar, 4Gerszten R.E. Chen J. Ishii M. Ishii K. Wang L. Nanevicz T. Turck C.W. Vu T.-K.H. Coughlin S.R. Nature. 1994; 368: 648-651Crossref PubMed Scopus (180) Google Scholar). Following cleavage by thrombin, activated thrombin receptors undergo homologous desensitization and internalization (5Brass L.F. Ahuja M. Belmonte E. Pizarro S. Tarver A.P. Hoxie J.A. Ann. N. Y. Acad. Sci. 1994; 714: 1-11Crossref PubMed Scopus (18) Google Scholar). In theory, this mechanism for cell activation by thrombin could be used by other proteases as well, either by cleaving their own unique receptors or by cleaving the thrombin receptor at the same site as thrombin. A mutated thrombin receptor with an altered sequence preceding the thrombin cleavage site has been shown to respond to enterokinase (6Vu T.-K.H. Wheaton V.I. Hung D.T. Charo I. Coughlin S.R. Nature. 1991; 353: 674-677Crossref PubMed Scopus (468) Google Scholar), but the only known example of a distinct naturally occurring protease-sensitive receptor is the recently described PAR-2, a mouse protein that is 28% identical with the mouse thrombin receptor (7Nystedt S. Emilsson K. Wahlestedt C. Sundelin J. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1994; 91: 9208-9212Crossref PubMed Scopus (827) Google Scholar). The natural “ligand” for PAR-2 has not been identified. When expressed in Xenopus oocytes, it can be activated by trypsin, but not thrombin. Trypsin can also activate thrombin receptors (8Brass L.F. Manning D.R. Williams A. Woolkalis M.J. Poncz M. J. Biol. Chem. 1991; 266: 958-965Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar), as can granzyme A, a protease derived from T-cells (9Suidan H.S. Bouvier J. Schaerer E. Stone S.R. Monard D. Tschopp J. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1994; 91: 8112-8116Crossref PubMed Scopus (119) Google Scholar). In the present studies, we have examined the interaction between thrombin receptors and cathepsin G. Cathepsin G is of particular interest for several reasons. First, like thrombin and trypsin, cathepsin G is a serine protease. However, in contrast to trypsin, which is not normally present in the vascular space, cathepsin G is released by activated neutrophils at sites of injury and inflammation, reaching concentrations that have been estimated to be as high as 0.5 μμ (10Weksler B.B. Jaffe E.A. Brower M.S. Cole O.F. Blood. 1989; 74: 1627-1634Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). Second, cathepsin G has been shown to have two apparently contradictory effects. In some cells that express thrombin receptors, including platelets (11Selak M.A. Chignard M. Smith J.B. Biochem. J. 1988; 251: 293-299Crossref PubMed Scopus (144) Google Scholar, 12Molino M. Di Lallo M. De Gaetano G. Cerletti C. Biochem. J. 1992; 288: 741-745Crossref PubMed Scopus (24) Google Scholar, 13LaRosa C.A. Rohrer M.J. Benoit S.E. Rodino L.J. Barnard M.R. Michelson A.D. J. Vasc. Surg. 1994; 19: 306-319Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (66) Google Scholar) and porcine aortic endothelial cells (14LeRoy E.C. Ager A. Gordon J.L. J. Clin. Invest. 1984; 74: 1003-1010Crossref PubMed Scopus (63) Google Scholar, 15Totani L. Piccoli A. Pellegrini G. Di Santo A Lorenzet R. Arterioscler. Thromb. 1994; 14: 125-132Crossref PubMed Google Scholar), cathepsin G acts as an agonist, stimulating events such as aggregation and prostaglandin I2 formation and causing an increase in the cytosolic Ca2+ concentration. In other cells that express thrombin receptors, including human umbilical vein endothelial cells (10Weksler B.B. Jaffe E.A. Brower M.S. Cole O.F. Blood. 1989; 74: 1627-1634Crossref PubMed Google Scholar) and fibroblasts (16Selak M.A. Biochem. J. 1994; 297: 269-275Crossref PubMed Scopus (39) Google Scholar), cathepsin G has been reported to have no agonist effect. In all of the cases that have been examined, however, preincubation with cathepsin G has been shown to inhibit a subsequent response to thrombin, irrespective of whether cathepsin G has a primary agonist effect on those same cells (10Weksler B.B. Jaffe E.A. Brower M.S. Cole O.F. Blood. 1989; 74: 1627-1634Crossref PubMed Google Scholar, 16Selak M.A. Biochem. J. 1994; 297: 269-275Crossref PubMed Scopus (39) Google Scholar). In order to determine the underlying mechanism for these diverse effects of cathepsin G and to establish the basis for studies of other biologically relevant proteases, we have examined the interaction of cathepsin G with thrombin receptors on human platelets, umbilical vein endothelial cells, and two human megakaryoblastic cell lines: HEL cells and CHRF-288 cells. The results show that cathepsin G cleaves the N terminus of the thrombin receptor in at least two places, one at the site normally cleaved by thrombin, the other at a site closer to the first transmembrane domain. Cleavage at the latter site removes the tethered ligand domain and renders the receptors unresponsive to thrombin. When that site is altered or protected, either by mutation or by the presence of a targeted antibody, cathepsin G can activate thrombin receptors by cleaving at the same site as thrombin, exposing the tethered ligand domain. These findings account for the inhibitory effects of cathepsin G on cell responses to thrombin and define the conditions that are required for cathepsin G to act as a thrombin receptor agonist. Given the estimation that in areas of inflammation the local concentration of cathepsin G exceeds the concentration of its inhibitors, these findings also suggest that cathepsin G may play a role in the modulation of cellular responses to thrombin, even in cells that do not have a primary response to cathepsin G. As a first step, a comparison was made between the effects of cathepsin G, thrombin, and the thrombin receptor agonist peptide, SFLLRN, on platelets and human umbilical vein endothelial cells. In platelets, all three agonists caused a transient increase in cytosolic Ca2+ (Fig. 2). Exposure to thrombin caused a partial decrease in the subsequent response to SFLLRN (Fig. 2, A versus B), while preincubation of the platelets with cathepsin G completely abolished the response to thrombin (Fig. 2, A versus C). The results obtained with the endothelial cells were similar, with thrombin partially inhibiting the response to SFLLRN (Fig. 2, D versus E) and cathepsin G completely inhibiting the response to thrombin (Fig. 2, D versus F), although one difference was that in endothelial cells cathepsin G had no apparent effect on cytosolic Ca2+ even at the high concentration used (400 nm). Results similar to those obtained with platelets and endothelial cells were obtained with the HEL cells (Fig. 3) and CHRF-288 cells (not shown). In all cases, prior exposure to cathepsin G inhibited a subsequent response to thrombin. This inhibition was concentration-dependent and was half-maximal in HEL cells at 20 nM cathepsin G (Fig. 3). The inhibition was not due to cleavage of thrombin by cathepsin G since the cathepsin G inhibitor, eglin C, was added before the thrombin. Eglin C by itself had no effect on the magnitude of the thrombin response (not shown).FIG. 3Inhibition by cathepsin G of the Ca2+ response to thrombin in HEL cells. In both control and cathepsin G-treated HEL cells, the Ca2+ response to SFLLRN was half-maximal at approximately 5 μμ (Fig. 4). This suggested that the failure of the cells exposed to cathepsin G to respond to thrombin was not due to classical desensitization of the receptor, since that has been shown to affect responses to both thrombin and the agonist peptides (25Brass L.F. J. Biol. Chem. 1992; 267: 6044-6050Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). As an alternative, we considered whether cathepsin G might cleave the thrombin receptor at one or more sites that would impair responses to thrombin, but not SFLLRN. Recent studies with receptor-directed antibodies (3Bahou W.F. Coller B.S. Potter C.L. Norton K.J. Kutok J.L. Goligorsky M.S. J. Clin. Turck C.W. Vu T.-K.H. Coughlin S.R. Chen J. Ishii M. Ishii K. Wang L. Nanevicz T. Turck C.W. Vu T.-K.H. Coughlin S.R. Nature. 1994; 368: 648-651Crossref PubMed Scopus (180) Google Scholar). Since we found that cathepsin G had no effect on the EC50 for SFLLRN, we hypothesized that cathepsin G might cleave the thrombin receptor proximal to residue Asn75, leaving the remainder of the N terminus intact. To test this hypothesis, we made use of a panel of monoclonal antibodies with defined epitopes within the receptor N terminus (Fig. 1). Those antibodies differ with respect to their ability to bind to thrombin-cleaved receptors in a manner that would be predicted by the locations of their epitopes. Antibodies PC42 and PC143, which recognize the fragment cleaved from the receptor by thrombin, and antibody SPAN12, which is directed at the thrombin cleavage site between Arg41 and Ser42, bind to both intact receptors and peptide-activated receptors, but do not bind to thrombin-cleaved receptors. Antibodies ATAP2 and WEDE15, on the other hand, recognize both intact and thrombin-cleaved receptors (17Brass L.F. Pizarro S. Ahuja M. Belmonte E. Blanchard N. Stadel J. Hoxie J.A. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 2943-2952Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Fig. 5 compares the effects of cathepsin G and thrombin on the binding of the receptor-directed antibodies to platelets and endothelial cells. In each case, the antibodies were added after the cells had been incubated with the proteases. With both platelets and endothelial cells, thrombin caused a 50–60% decrease in the binding of the cleavage-insensitive antibodies, ATAP2 and WEDE15, and a 90% decrease in the binding of antibodies PC42 and SPAN12. We have shown previously using HEL and CHRF-288 cells that the loss of binding sites for antibodies ATAP2 and WEDE15 caused by thrombin reflects receptor internalization, while the loss of binding sites for antibody SPAN12 is due to receptor cleavage, which typically occurs in excess of internalization (17Brass L.F. Parton R. Brass L.F. J. Biol. Chem. 1993; 268: 13756-13763Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). In contrast to thrombin, cathepsin G caused a decrease in the binding of all four antibodies. The von Willebrand factor (vWF) mediates platelet adhesion to the vascular subendothelium by binding to collagen, other matrix constituents, and the platelet receptor glycoproteins Ib/IX and IIb/IIIa. Although substantial progress has been made in defining vWF structure-function relationships, there are conflicting data regarding the location of its collagen-binding site(s). Possible collagen-binding sites have been localized in the A1 and A3 domains of vWF. To study the proposed binding sites, we have expressed cDNA sequences encoding the A1 and A3 domains of vWF in Escherichia coli and purified the resulting proteins from bacterial inclusion bodies. In addition, a chimeric molecule containing residues 465-598 of the vWF A1 domain polypeptide (vWF-A1) fused in frame to residues 1018-1114 of the vWF A3 domain polypeptide (vWF-A3) was also expressed. Each of the three recombinant proteins purified as a monomer and contained a single disulfide bond. As previously reported (Cruz, M. A., Handin, R. I., and Wise, R. J. (1993) J. Biol. Chem. 268, 21238-21245), recombinant vWF-A1 inhibited ristocetin-induced platelet agglutination, but did not compete with vWF multimers for collagen binding. In contrast, vWF-A3 inhibited the binding of multimeric vWF to immobilized collagen, but did not inhibit ristocetin-induced platelet agglutination. Metabolically labeled vWF-A3 bound to immobilized collagen in a saturable and reversible manner with a Kdof 1.8 × 10-6M. The vWF-A1/A3 chimera was bifunctional. It inhibited vWF binding to platelet glycoprotein Ib/IX with an IC50 of 0.6 × 10-6M and inhibited vWF binding to collagen with an IC50 of 0.5-1.0 × 10-6M. These results, taken together, provide firm evidence that the major collagen-binding site in vWF resides in the A3 domain. Corino G.L. Castaldi P.A. Berndt M.C. Biochemistry. 1989; 28: 8326-8336Crossref PubMed Scopus (103) Google Scholar, 31Marti T. Rosselet S.J. Titani K. Walsh K.A. Biochemistry. 1987; 26: 8099-8109Crossref PubMed Scopus (202) Google Scholar). Given the similarities in primary and secondary structure, the A1 and A3 domains could easily have overlapping functions.Despite the data obtained with tryptic fragments of vWF (13Pareti F.I. Fujimura Y. Dent J.A. Holland L.Z. Zimmerman T.S. Ruggeri Z.M. J. Biol. Chem. 1986; 261: 15310-15315Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 15Denis C. Baruch D. Kielty C.M. Ajzenberg N. Christophe O. Meyer D. Arterioscler. Thromb. 1993; 13: 398-406Crossref PubMed Google Scholar, 17Roth G.J. Titani K. Hoyer L.W. Hickey M.J. Biochemistry. 1986; 25: 8357-8361Crossref PubMed Scopus (97) Google Scholar, 18Pareti F.I. Niiya K. McPherson J.M. Ruggeri Z.M. J. Biol. Chem. 1987; 262: 13835-13841Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 19Andrews R.K. Gorman J.J. Booth W.J. Corino G.L. Castaldi P.A. Berndt M.C. Biochemistry. 1989; 28: 8326-8336Crossref PubMed Scopus (103) Google Scholar), there is still some uncertainty regarding the existence of a collagen-binding site in the A1 domain. One early study, utilizing unpurified bacterial lysate, reported an interaction between recombinant vWF-A1 protein in the bacterial lysate and collagen (32Pietu G. Meulien P. Cherel G. Diaz J. Baruch D. Courtney M. Meyer D. Biochem. Biophys. Res. Commun. 1989; 164: 1339-1347Crossref PubMed Scopus (28) Google Scholar). Other investigators who have subsequently expressed and studied the function of purified vWF-A1 protein have reported conflicting results (33Azuma H. Dent J.A. Sugimoto M. Ruggeri Z.M. Ware J. J. Biol. Chem. 1991; 266: 12342-12347Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 34Gralnick H.R. Williams S. McKeown L. Kramer W. Krutzsh H. Gorecki M. Pinet A. Garfinkel L.I. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1992; 89: 7880-7884Crossref PubMed Scopus (58) Google Scholar, 35Sugimoto M. Ricca G. Hrinda M.E. Schreiber A.B. Searfoss G.H. Bottini E. Ruggeri Z.M. Biochemistry. 1991; 30: 5202-5209Crossref PubMed Scopus (79) Google Scholar). For example, our laboratory recently reported that a highly purified monomeric vWF-A1 protein bound to platelet GPIb/IX and heparin, but did not bind to collagen (36Cruz M.A. Handin R.I. Wise R.J. J. Biol. Chem. 1993; 268: 21238-21245Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). In addition, it has been reported that recombinant vWF from which the entire A1 domain has been deleted, which forms the normal spectrum of multimers, no longer binds to platelet GPIb/IX, but still binds to collagen (37Sixma J.J. Schiphorst M.E. Verweij C.L. Pannekoek H. Eur. J. Biochem. 1991; 688: 1-7Google Scholar).To resolve these conflicting results and to learn more about the collagen-vWF interaction, we have cloned and expressed vWF A1 and A3 domain polypeptides and compared their biochemical properties with a chimeric vWF A1 domain polypeptide containing sequences derived from the vWF A1 and A3 domains (vWF-A1/A3). The studies reported here clearly demonstrate that vWF-A3 protein and the vWF-A1/A3 chimera both bind to type I collagen. Results obtained with vWF-A1/A3 help to localize the collagen-binding sequence in the A3 domain to a sequence between amino acids 1018 and 1114. We have concluded that the vWF-A3 binding site can account for all of the interactions between multimeric vWF and type I collagen and that this site probably represents the physiologically relevant collagen-binding site in vWF.EXPERIMENTAL PROCEDURESConstruction of vWF Expression VectorsA map for each of the three vWF cDNAs expressed is shown in Fig. 1. For expression of the vWF A3 domain in Escherichia coli, a cDNA fragment encoding amino acids 908-1111 of mature vWF was constructed by mutagenesis of vWF cDNA in M13 with two oligonucleotides. Oligonucleotide 1 spanned codons 1666-1674 (28Bonthron D. Orr E.C. Mitsock L.M. Ginsburg D. Handin R.I. Orkin S.H. Nucleic Acids Res. 1986; 14: 7125-7127Crossref PubMed Scopus (96) Google Scholar) and introduced a BamHI restriction site (encoding Gly and Ser) at codons 1670 and 1671. Oligonucleotide 2 spanned codons 1870-1882 and introduced a termination codon and a HindIII restriction site. Following sequence confirmation, the vWF-A3 cDNA fragment was isolated by digestion with BamHI and HindIII and inserted into the expression vector pQE9 (QIAGEN Inc.). Insertion of the vWF-A3 fragment in pQE9 produces an amino-terminal fusion protein containing the vWF sequence fused in frame to 10 amino acids (6 histidines) contributed by the vector. vWF-A1 cDNA was prepared as described previously and used to transform pQE9 as well (36Cruz M.A. Handin R.I. Wise R.J. J. Biol. Chem. 1993; 268: 21238-21245Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar).Chimeric vWF-A1/A3 cDNA was constructed with a polymerase chain reaction-based mutagenesis strategy. In the first round of amplification, the amino-terminal half of the A1 domain (residues 475-598) and the carboxyl-terminal half of the A3 domain (residues 1018-1114) were amplified. The 3’-primer for amplifying the A1 domain was designed to contain 12 extra bases of A3 domain sequence (5’-TCGCACAGCAAACAAGACCTCGCTGGTGGA-3’ (vWF-A1 sequence is underlined)). Thus, the amplified A1 cDNA contained a short A3 sequence at its 3’-end. Similarly, A3 cDNA contained a short A1 sequence at its 5’-end (5’-AGCGAGGTCTTGGCTGTGCGATACTTG-3’ (vWF-A1 sequence is underlined)). The two chimeric cDNA fragments were then incubated together so that they were annealed via their overlapping sequences. The annealed material was used as the template for the second round of polymerase chain reaction. The chimeric DNA fragment was amplified using 5’-A1 (5’-CCTCACCTGTGAAGGATCCCAGGAGCCGGGAG-3’) and 3’-A3 (5’-CATTCCAAGCTTGAATTCATCAAGATCTAACAAATCCAGAGC-3’) primers designed to introduce BamHI and HindIII restriction sites, respectively, for cloning as described previously above. The overnight culture was diluted 1:20 and grown to A595 = 0.7. The culture was adjusted to 1.5 mM IPTG and incubated for 5 h at 37°C. The bacterial cells were lysed in the presence of 1.25 mg/ml deoxycholic acid and 7 μg/ml DNase I. The lysate was centrifuged at 12,000 × g for 15 min, and the resulting pellet was washed with lysis buffer containing 0.5% Triton X-100 and 10 mM EDTA, followed by recentrifugation.For purification of vWF-A3 protein, the washed pellet was solubilized by the addition of 7.5 M urea in 25 mM Tris-HCl, pH 8.8, and the solubilized proteins were dialyzed against 25 mM Tris-HCl, pH 8.2. The solubilized proteins were passed over a Q-Sepharose column (Pharmacia Biotech Inc.) equilibrated with 25 mM Tris-HCl, pH 8.2. vWF-A3 eluted from the column with sodium chloride. This finding provides additional evidence for proper folding of the chimeric protein and helps to localize the GPIb/IX-binding domain to the first 98 residues of the vWF A1 domain. The cysteine protease papain is synthesized as a 40-kDa inactive precursor with a 107-amino-acid N-terminal pro region. Although sequence conservation in the pro region is lower than in the mature proteases, a conserved motif (Gly-Xaa-Asn-Xaa-Phe-Xaa-Asp-36, papain precursor numbering) was found within the pro region of cysteine proteases of the papain superfamily. To determinate the function to this conserved motif, we have mutagenized at random each of the 4 residues individually within the pro region of the papain precursor. Precursor mutants were expressed in yeast, screened according to their ability to be processed through either a cis or trans reaction, into mature active papain. Three classes of mutants were found. Non-functional propapain mutants of the first class are completely degraded by subtilisin indicating that they are not folded into a native state. Mutants of the second class were neutral with respect to cis and trans processing. The third class included mutants that mostly accumulated as mature papain in the yeast vacuole. They had mutations that had lost the negatively charged Asp-36 residues and a mutation that probably introduces a positive charge, Phe-38His. The precursor of the Phe-38His mutant could be recovered by expression in a vph1 mutant yeast strain which has a vacuolar pH of about 7. The Phe-38His propapain mutant has an optimum pH of autoactivation about one pH unit higher than the wild type molecule. These results indicate that the electrostatic status of the conserved motif participates in the control of intramolecular processing of the papain precursor. Although sequence conservation in the pro region is lower than in the mature proteases, a conserved motif (Gly-Xaa-Asn-Xaa-Phe-Xaa-Asp-36, papain precursor numbering) was found within the pro region of cysteine proteases of the papain superfamily. To determinate the function to this conserved motif, we have mutagenized at random each of the 4 residues individually within the pro region of the papain precursor. Precursor mutants were expressed in yeast, screened according to their ability to be processed through either a cis or trans reaction, into mature active papain. Three classes of mutants were found. Non-functional propapain mutants of the first class are completely degraded by subtilisin indicating that they are not folded into a native state. Mutants of the second class were neutral with respect to cis and trans processing. The third class included mutants that mostly accumulated as mature papain in the yeast vacuole. They had mutations that had lost the negatively charged Asp-36 residues and a mutation that probably introduces a positive charge, Phe-38His. The precursor of the Phe-38His mutant could be recovered by expression in a vph1 mutant yeast strain which has a vacuolar pH of about 7. The Phe-38His propapain mutant has an optimum pH of autoactivation about one pH unit higher than the wild type molecule. These results indicate that the electrostatic status of the conserved motif participates in the control of intramolecular processing of the papain precursor.

TolA, -B, -Q, and -R proteins are involved in maintaining the cell envelope integrity of Escherichia coli; they have been parasitized by the group A colicins and the single strand DNA of some filamentous bacteriophages to permit them to enter the cells. TolA and TolR are anchored to the inner membrane by a single transmembrane domain, TolQ is an integral membrane protein with three transmembrane segments, and TolB has recently been found to be periplasmic although it is partially membrane-associated. The latter result suggests that TolB might interact with membrane proteins. Other lines of evidence favor the existence of a Tol complex. To further characterize this complex, we investigated which proteins interact with TolB. For this purpose, two different methods were used. First, we took advantage of the existence of a tagged TolB (TolBep) to perform immunoprecipitation under native conditions in order to preserve the putative associations of TolBep with other proteins. Secondly, in vivo cross-linking experiments with formaldehyde were performed. These two approaches led to the same result and demonstrated for the first time that a component of the Tol system, TolB, interacts with a protein located in the outer membrane, the peptidoglycan-associated lipoprotein. TolA, -B, -Q, and -R proteins are involved in maintaining the cell envelope integrity of Escherichia coli; they have been parasitized by the group A colicins and the single strand DNA of some filamentous bacteriophages to permit them to enter the cells. TolA and TolR are anchored to the inner membrane by a single transmembrane domain, TolQ is an integral membrane protein with three transmembrane segments, and TolB has recently been found to be periplasmic although it is partially membrane-associated. The latter result suggests that TolB might interact with membrane proteins. Other lines of evidence favor the existence of a Tol complex. To further characterize this complex, we investigated which proteins interact with TolB. For this purpose, two different methods were used. First, we took advantage of the existence of a tagged TolB (TolBep) to perform immunoprecipitation under native conditions in order to preserve the putative associations of TolBep with other proteins. Secondly, in vivo cross-linking experiments with formaldehyde were performed. These two approaches led to the same result and demonstrated for the first time that a component of the Tol system, TolB, interacts with a protein located in the outer membrane, the peptidoglycan-associated lipoprotein. The outer membrane of Gram-negative bacteria acts as a barrier preventing the entry of large deleterious molecules of the environment (such as detergents, proteases, and hydrophobic antibiotics). Some quite large molecules are able to cross the outer membrane, however. This is so in the case of iron siderophores and vitamin B12, which use an energy-coupled uptake system composed of a high affinity outer membrane receptor and the proteins TonB, ExbB, and ExbD (for a review, see Refs. 1Kadner R.J. Mol. Microbiol. 1990; 4: 2027-2033Crossref PubMed Scopus (181) Google Scholar, 2Braun V. Günter K. Hantke K. Biol. Metals. 1991; 4: 14-22Crossref PubMed Scopus (85) Google Scholar, 3Postle K. J. Bioenerg. Biomembr. 1993; 25: 591-601PubMed Google Scholar, 4Klebba P.E. Rutz J.M. Liu J. Murphy C.K. J. Bioenerg. Biomembr. 1993; 25: 603-611PubMed Google Scholar). Macromolecules such as colicins and the DNA of some bacteriophages parasitize this TonB-dependent transport system and another system composed of TolA, -B, -Q, and -R proteins and thus enter the cells. The exact physiological role of the Tol system has not yet been elucidated but Tol proteins are involved in maintaining the cell envelope integrity, since tol mutants are hypersensitive to drugs and detergents and since tolA and tolB mutants are leaky for periplasmic proteins (5Lazzaroni J.C. Portalier R. J. Bacteriol. 1981; 145: 1351-1358Crossref PubMed Google Scholar, 6Fognini-Lefebvre N. Lazzaroni J.C. Portalier R. Mol. & Gen. Genet. 1987; 209: 391-395Crossref PubMed Scopus (59) Google Scholar, 7Lazzaroni J.C. Fognini-Lefebvre N. Portalier R. Mol. & Gen. Genet. 1989; 218: 460-464Crossref PubMed Scopus (51) Google Scholar; for a review, see Ref. 8Webster R.E. Mol. Microbiol. 1991; 5: 1005-1011Crossref PubMed Scopus (218) Google Scholar). The Tol and TonB systems have some common features, since ExbB and ExbD are 75% homologous with TolQ and TolR, respectively (9Eick-Helmerich K. Braun V. J. Bacteriol. 1989; 171: 5117-5126Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). Moreover, these proteins have been found to have similar topologies. ExbD and TolR both have one transmembrane N-terminal domain, and their C terminus faces the periplasm (10Kampfenkel K. Braun V. J. Bacteriol. 1992; 174: 5485-5487Crossref PubMed Google Scholar, 11Kampfenkel K. Braun V. J. Biol. Chem. 1992; 268: 6050-6057Abstract Full Text PDF Google Scholar, 12Müller M.M. Vianney A. Lazzaroni J.C. Webster R.E. Portalier R. J. Bacteriol. 1993; 175: 6059-6061Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). ExbB and TolQ have three transmembrane domains, and their N terminus faces the periplasm (13Kampfenkel K. Braun V. J. Bacteriol. 1993; 175: 4485-4491Crossref PubMed Google Scholar, 14Vianney A. Lewin T. M-. Beyer Jr., W.F. Lazzaroni J.C. Portalier R. Webster R.E. J. Bacteriol. 1994; 176: 822-829Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). Furthermore, some functional cross-reactivity has been found to exist between ExbB/D and TolQ/R (15Braun V. J. Bacteriol. 1989; 171: 6387-6390Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). The first evidence that the constituents of the TonB system were able to form a complex arose from the finding that TonB was unstable in exbB exbD mutants (16Fischer E. Günter K. Braun V. J. Bacteriol. 1989; 171: 5129-5134Crossref Google Scholar, 17Skare J.T. Postle K. Mol. Microbiol. 1991; 5: 2883-2890Crossref PubMed Scopus (78) Google Scholar). TonB is anchored to the inner membrane by its N-terminal hydrophobic segment while the remainder protrudes into the periplasm (18Hannavy K. Barr G.C. Dorman C.J. Adamson J. Mazengera L.R. Gallagher M.P. Evans J.S. Levine B.A. Trayer I.P. Higgins C.F. J. Mol. Biol. 1990; 216: 897-910Crossref PubMed Scopus (100) Google Scholar, 19Roof S.K. Allard J.D. Bertrand K.P. Postle K. J. Bacteriol. 1991; 173: 5554-5557Crossref PubMed Google Scholar, 20Postle K. Skare J.T. J. Biol. Chem. 1988; 263: 11000-11007Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Karlsson et al. (21Karlsson M. Hannavy K. Higgins C.F. Mol. Microbiol. 1993; 8: 379-388Crossref PubMed Scopus (74) Google Scholar) demonstrated that the dependence of phage ϕ80 sensitivity on ExbB and -D proteins was specified by the TonB transmembrane domain. This result suggested that a functional interaction might occur between the N-terminal domain of TonB and ExbB and -D proteins inside the membrane. These indirect pieces of evidence were recently confirmed by the results of in vivo cross-linking experiments (22Skare J.T. Ahmer B.M.M. Seachord C.L. Darveau R.P. Postle K. J. Biol. Chem. 1993; 268: 16302-16308Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 23Jaskula J.C. Letain T.E. Roof S.K. Skare J.T. Postle K. J. Bacteriol. 1994; 175: 2326-2338Crossref Google Scholar). By analogy with the TonB system, the Tol system was also suspected of forming a complex. This hypothesis was supported by two different results: (i) the TolA N-terminal membrane spanning sequence was found to specify the dependence on TolQ and -R proteins (21Karlsson M. Hannavy K. Higgins C.F. Mol. Microbiol. 1993; 8: 379-388Crossref PubMed Scopus (74) Google Scholar) and (ii) Tol proteins were found to co-fractionate with contact sites between the inner and outer membranes (24Bourdineaud J.P. Howard S.P. Lazdunski C. J. Bacteriol. 1989; 171: 2458-2465Crossref PubMed Google Scholar, 25Guihard G. Boulanger P. Bénédetti H. Lloubès R. Besnard M. Letellier L. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 5874-5880Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar) and to be enriched in these sites after colicin A had been added to the cells (25Guihard G. Boulanger P. Bénédetti H. Lloubès R. Besnard M. Letellier L. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 5874-5880Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). While searching for a TolQ missense mutant suppressor, Lazzaroni et al. (26Lazzaroni J.C. Vianney A. Popot J.L. Bénédetti H. Samatey F. Lazdunski C. Portalier R. Géli V. J. Mol. Biol. 1995; 246: 1-7Crossref PubMed Scopus (84) Google Scholar) recently obtained the first direct evidence that TolQ and TolR interacted. Furthermore, Derouiche et al. (50Dérouiche R. Bénédetti H. Lazzaroni J.-C. Lazdunski C. Lloubès R. J. Biol. Chem. 1995; 270: 11078-11084Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (114) Google Scholar) present direct biochemical evidence that TolA can be chemically cross-linked to TolR and TolQ. Identifying the components of the Tol complex and understanding how they interact are essential to elucidating how the Tol system functions in the uptake of colicin or phage DNA. Furthermore, this knowledge might provide us with useful clues as to the physiological role of the Tol system. In this study, we focused on the TolB protein, which has recently been found to be a periplasmic protein although a small part of it was peripherally membrane-associated (27Isnard M. Rigal A. Lazzaroni J.C. Lazdunski C. Lloubès R. J. Bacteriol. 1994; 176: 6392-6396Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). Using two different methods, native co-immunoprecipitation of a tagged TolB protein with a monoclonal antibody and in vivo chemical cross-linking with formaldehyde, we demonstrate here that TolB and a 20-kDa protein, identified as PAL 1The abbreviations used are: PALpeptidoglycan-associated lipoproteinPAGEpolyacrylamide gel electrophoresismAbmonoclonal antibody. (peptidoglycan-associated lipoprotein), interact directly. Furthermore, we establish that PAL plays a role in the association of TolB with the membrane. This finding suggests that the underlying mechanism may involve the formation of contact sites between the inner and outer membranes of Escherichia coli. peptidoglycan-associated lipoprotein polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis monoclonal antibody. DNA Cloning—pBP was constructed by inserting the pal gene downstream of the tolB gene into the pMUIII plasmid. The pal gene was obtained by polymerase chain reaction amplification of the chromosomal pal gene of 1292 strain. On the chromosome, pal is immediately downstream of tolB, and part of its promoter is thought to be in the tolB coding sequence (36Lazzaroni J.C. Portalier R. Mol. Microbiol. 1992; 6: 735-742Crossref PubMed Scopus (96) Google Scholar). A single AseI restriction site, located 29 base pairs upstream of pal, is still present in pMUIII, and the 5′ primer was designed to initiate the amplification 32 base pairs upstream of the pal start codon in order to amplify this site. The 3′ primer was designed to place a BsaI site downstream of pal. The polymerase chain reaction product was digested with AseI and BsaI and ligated into pMUIII digested with the same enzymes to create pBP. The pal gene inserted in pBP was sequenced to ensure that no errors were introduced during the polymerase chain reaction amplification. Immunoprecipitation of TolBep with mAb 1C11—HB101, HB101 pMUI, and HB101 pFAI cells labeled with [35S]methionine and otherwise were harvested. In the case of labeled cells, the incorporation of [35S]methionine was first stopped by isotopic dilution and by adding chloramphenicol (250 μg/ml). The cells were then resuspended in 10 mm Tris, pH 7.8, 0.5 mm EDTA, and lysosyme (100 μg/ml) at 37.5 units A600/ml. After being incubated for 15 min on ice, the cells were lysed by five successive freeze and thaw cycles. DNA was digested by adding DNaseI (100 μg/ml) and MgCl2 (10 mm). In order to solubilize the membranes, Triton X-100 (1%) was added, and the sample was vigorously shaken for 1 h at 4 °C. The insoluble material was eliminated by carrying out a 15-min centrifugation at 105,000 × g. To immunoprecipitate TolBep and other putative associated proteins, Affi-Gel 10 beads (Bio-Rad) coupled to mAb 1C11 in phosphate-buffered saline buffer (137 mm NaCl, 2.68 mm KCl, 8.1 mm Na2HPO4, 1.47 mm KH2PO4, pH 7.4) were added to this extract (10 μl for 2 units A600). After a 2-h incubation at 4 °C, the immunoprecipitate was washed three times with phosphate-buffered saline containing 0.5% deoxycholate and 1% Triton X-100 and twice with 10 mm Tris, pH 7.5. Prior to SDS-PAGE and Western blotting, the immunoprecipitate was dissociated from the coupled beads by adding 16 μl of sample buffer (with no reducing agent) per 10 μl of beads and by heating 5 min at 95 °C. Obtaining the AS1 Antiserum, Directed against the Material Immunoprecipitated with the mAb 1C11—To raise an antiserum against the material immunoprecipitated by mAb 1C11, 500 units A600 of HB101 pFAI were treated as described above. After being incubated with the Affi-Gel-coupled beads, the immunoprecipitate was divided into two preparations, both of which were used to immunize a rabbit. The first preparation consisted of half of the beads, which were directly injected to the rabbit after five phosphate-buffered saline washes. The other half of the beads was washed as described in the previous section. The immunoprecipitated material was then dissociated from these beads by adding 500 μl of 200 mm Tris, pH 8.8, containing 5 mm EDTA and 5% SDS and by heating 5 min at 95 °C. This material constituted the second preparation. The rabbit was given four injections of each of the two preparations. In the first injection, the preparations were mixed with Freund’s complete adjuvant and were injected subcutaneously, whereas in the second injection (21 days after the first injection), they were mixed with Freund’s incomplete adjuvant before being injected intramuscularly. The two last injections were carried out 31 and 32 days after the first injection with no adjuvant, the one subcutaneously and the other intravenously. The rabbit was killed 40 days after the first injection. Specific Radiolabeling of TolB and PAL and Immunoprecipitation with the AS1 Antiserum—TolB and PAL proteins were specifically labeled in JC7752 pGPl-2 cells harboring either pMUIII or pBP, as described previously (29Tabor S. Richardson S.S. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1985; 82: 1074-1078Crossref PubMed Scopus (2456) Google Scholar). The incorporation of [35S]methionine was stopped by adding trichloroacetic acid (final concentration 10%). The pellet obtained after a 30-min incubation at 4 °C and a 15-min centrifugation at 18,000 × g was resuspended in TES (10 mm Tris, pH 7.4, 5 mm EDTA, 2% SDS). After boiling for 10 min, TNET (20 mm Tris, pH 7.4, 5 mm EDTA, 150 mm NaCl, 0.1% Triton X-100) was added (15:1). The soluble material obtained after a 15-min centrifugation at 18,000 × g was then immunoprecipitated overnight with Affi-Gel 10 beads coupled to the antibodies of the AS1 antiserum. To purify the antibodies, the AS1 antiserum was brought to 0.5 ammonium sulfate saturation. The pellet obtained after centrifuging for 20 min at 27,000 × g was resuspended in the same volume of 25 mm Tris, pH 8.8, 35 mm NaCl and dialyzed against the same buffer overnight. Pure IgGs were obtained by passing the preparation through a DEAE-Trisacryl column (IBF) on which they were not adsorbed. The immunoprecipitates obtained were dissociated from the beads with sample buffer containing no reducing agent and loaded onto SDS-PAGE. Adsorption of the AS1 Antiserum against TolB and PAL Proteins—Extracts of JC3417 and JC7752 pMUIII cells were prepared as described previously in the case of HB101 pFAI cells. The cell pellets corresponding to 300 units A600 were resuspended in 2.7 ml of 10 mm Tris, pH 7.8, 0.5 mm EDTA. 300 μl of AS1 antiserum was incubated overnight at 4 °C with these cell extracts. After 2 h of centrifugation at 125,000 × g, the supernatant was collected. The AS2 antiserum was adsorbed against PAL (JC3417 cells), and the AS3 antiserum was adsorbed against TolB (JC7752 pMUIII cells). In Vivo Cross-linking with Formaldehyde—Cells were grown to 1 unit A600/ml and pelleted by centrifugation. They were washed once with 10 mm potassium phosphate buffer, pH 6.8, and resuspended at 0.5 unit A600/ml in the same buffer, to which formaldehyde was added at a final concentration of 1% (w/w) as described previously by Prossnitz et al. (37Prossnitz E. Nikaido K. Ulbrich S.J. Ames G.F.-L. J. Biol. Chem. 1988; 263: 17917-17920Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar) and Skare et al. (22Skare J.T. Ahmer B.M.M. Seachord C.L. Darveau R.P. Postle K. J. Biol. Chem. 1993; 268: 16302-16308Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). The samples were incubated for the times indicated at room temperature, and the cells were then pelleted again, washed with 10 mm potassium phosphate buffer, pH 6.8, and solubilized in sample buffer. Benzon nuclease (Merck) was added (1 unit/0.8 unit A600) to eliminate DNA from the samples. Before loading on SDS-PAGE, the samples were either heated for 10 min at 37 °C to maintain the formaldehyde cross-links or heated for 20 min at 95 °C to destroy them. In each experiment, control samples were subjected to the same treatment except for the addition of formaldehyde. 0.4 unit A600 of cells were loaded per lane. Using a Tagged TolB Protein to Perform Immunoprecipitations under Native Conditions—In a previous study, the TolB protein was tagged by inserting in its C-terminal region an epitope recognized by the 1C11 monoclonal antibody (mAb 1C11) (27Isnard M. Rigal A. Lazzaroni J.C. Lazdunski C. Lloubès R. J. Bacteriol. 1994; 176: 6392-6396Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). This epitope, consisting of 14 amino acids, does not alter the function of TolB but makes its immunodetection possible as described previously in the case of other proteins (38Géli V. Lloubès R. Zaat S.A.J. van Spaendonk R.M.L. Rollin C. Bénédetti H. Lazdunski C. FEMS Microbiol. Lett. 1993; 109: 335-342Crossref PubMed Scopus (8) Google Scholar). After the tagging, the protein could furthermore be immunoprecipitated by mAb 1C11. We performed this immunoprecipitation after solubilizing the extracts of cells producing TolBep (HB101 pFAI) in 1% Triton X-100. Since Triton X-100 is a mild and nonionic detergent, we called these immunoprecipitation conditions, “native conditions.” We expected these conditions to preserve the putative associations of TolBep with other proteins and therefore to result in the co-immunoprecipitation of TolBep and its associated protein with the mAb 1C11. The immunoprecipitated material was analyzed by Western blotting with the polyclonal anti-TolA antibodies. No TolA was detected in the immunoprecipitate of HB101 pFAI cells producing TolBep (data not shown). No antibodies against TolQ and TolR proteins are available. In order to determine whether these two proteins were immunoprecipitated with TolBep, HB101 cells expressing TolBep protein and otherwise (HB101 pFAI and HB101 pMUI, respectively) were therefore labeled with [35S]methionine before their extracts were immunoprecipitated with mAb 1C11. The analysis of the immunoprecipitate by SDS-PAGE and autoradiography did not show the presence of any proteins migrating at the Mr of TolQ and TolR. A 20-kDa protein was specifically co-immunoprecipitated with TolBep, however (Fig. 1). The material obtained after immunoprecipitation by mAb 1C11 of HB101 pFAI cell extracts was used both with and without a denaturing treatment to immunize a rabbit in order to develop polyclonal antisera (AS1) directed against native and denatured conformations of TolB. The Antiserum Directed against the Material Immunoprecipitated by mAb 1C11 Recognizes TolB and PAL Proteins—When tested by Western blotting on wild-type 1292 cell extracts, the AS1 antiserum was found to strongly recognize two proteins with an apparent Mr of 43,000 and 20,000 (Fig. 2). In the JC3417 tolB mutant strain, the 43-kDa band disappeared (Fig. 2). Furthermore, the AS1 antiserum recognizes the same band as that recognized by mAb 1C11 in JC3417 pFAI cells, which corresponds to TolBep (Fig. 2). This demonstrates that the 43-kDa protein was indeed the TolB protein. The JC7752 strain is derived from 1292 and has been deleted from the DNA fragment encoding the 69 C-terminal amino acids of TolB, the pal promoter region, and the DNA region encoding the 147 N-terminal amino acids of PAL. 2J. C. Lazzaroni, personal communication. It might therefore be expected to produce a TolB truncated protein of 361 amino acids instead of 430 amino acids (i.e. a 37-kDa protein) and no PAL protein. As shown in Fig. 2, the AS1 antiserum detected a very faint band at 37 kDa and no 20-kDa protein in these cell extracts. This result indicates that the TolB truncated protein might be either unstable or poorly recognized by AS1. Furthermore, the 20-kDa protein might correspond to PAL. In order to check this possibility, the pal gene was introduced downstream of the tolB gene in the pMUIII plasmid which has a T7 ϕ10 related promoter inserted upstream of tolB (Isnard et al., 1994). JC7752 cells harboring the resulting plasmid (pBP) or pMUIII were transformed by pGP1–2 in order to produce the T7 RNA polymerase and make it possible to perform specific radiolabeling of TolB and PAL proteins (29Tabor S. Richardson S.S. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1985; 82: 1074-1078Crossref PubMed Scopus (2456) Google Scholar). As can be seen from Fig. 3, TolB is the only labeled protein in JC7752 pGPl-2 pMUIII cells, and TolB and PAL are the only labeled proteins in JC7752 pGPl-2 pBP cells. Since TolB and PAL are overproduced, they show up as double bands, corresponding to their mature and precursor forms (data not shown). TolB and PAL, the two labeled proteins in JC7752 pGPl-2 pBP cells, were immunoprecipitated by the AS1 antiserum under denaturing conditions (Fig. 3). This demonstrates that the 20-kDa protein recognized by the AS1 antiserum was indeed the PAL protein. The PAL Protein Is Co-immunoprecipitated with the Tagged TolB Protein by the mAb 1C11—Concentrated extracts of tolB– cells (JC3417) were added to the AS1 antiserum in order to block the binding of the antibodies to PAL protein. Although the resulting antiserum (AS2) still strongly recognized TolB, there was no further evidence of its binding to PAL (Fig. 4). Conversely, when the antiserum was adsorbed against TolB by adding concentrated extracts of cells expressing TolB but not PAL (JC7752 pMUIII), the resulting antiserum (AS3) recognized only the PAL protein (Fig. 4). Adding the AS1 antiserum to a saturating amount of TolB or PAL proteins therefore made it possible to obtain two separate antisera directed specifically against PAL and TolB proteins. This result indicates that TolB and PAL proteins do not have a common antigen which might be recognized by the same antibodies, but that the original AS1 antiserum comprises at least two groups of antibodies specifically directed against TolB and PAL proteins. This suggests that the material used for the immunization procedure, i.e. the mAb 1C11 immunoprecipitate of HB101 pFAI cell extracts, contained both proteins and that the 20-kDa labeled protein detected in the 1C11 immunoprecipitate of labeled HB101 pFAI cell extracts might correspond to PAL. To test this hypothesis, the mAb 1C11 immunoprecipitate of HB101 pFAI and HB101 cell extracts was analyzed by Western blotting by using the AS1 antiserum (Fig. 5). As shown in Fig. 5, PAL was immunoprecipitated with the mAb 1C11 as long as the cell extracts contained the tagged TolB (TolBep). Furthermore, the 20-kDa labeled protein obtained after immunoprecipitating HB101 pFAI cell extracts in native conditions was no longer detected in the immunoprecipitate of pal mutant cell extracts containing TolBep (JC7752 pFAI) (data not shown). These findings demonstrate that PAL is co-immunoprecipitated with TolBep by the mAb 1C11. TolB Can Be Cross-linked in Vivo with PAL—In an additional attempt to identify the proteins with which TolB associates, in vivo cross-linking experiments with formaldehyde were carried out. Wild-type cells (1292) were treated with 1% formaldehyde for 15 min, and the proteins were separated by SDS-PAGE. TolB was detected by performing Western blotting with the AS2 antiserum directed against TolB (Fig. 6). In addition to the band corresponding to the normal molecular weight of TolB (43,000), two other very close bands with an apparent Mr of 65,000 were observed. These bands were not present when the cells were not incubated with the cross-linking agent and disappeared when the cross-links were destroyed upon boiling (Fig. 6). The 65-kDa bands, therefore, appear to be specific cross-linked products in which TolB is associated, via a methyl group, with one or more proteins with a total Mr of 22,000. TolQ, -R, and -A proteins or colicin receptors at the cell surface are liable to interact with TolB. We have demonstrated above that TolB and PAL can be co-immunoprecipitated and therefore somehow interact. These proteins are therefore candidates for being cross-linked with TolB in vivo. The Mr values of TolQ (25,500), TolR (15,500), and PAL (20,000) are compatible with their possible participation in the 65-kDa complexes. To test this hypothesis, cells lacking the PAL protein and harboring the pMUIII plasmid, and thus able to produce a full-length TolB protein (JC7752 pMUIII), were treated with 1% formaldehyde and analyzed by performing Western blotting with the antibodies directed against TolB (AS2) (Fig. 7). No 65-kDa cross-linked products were detected in these cells. When the pal gene was inserted into the pMUIII plasmid (giving the pBP plasmid), thus making it possible for the JC7752 pBP cells to produce the PAL protein, the 65-kDa bands reappeared (Fig. 7). These data clearly indicate that PAL is involved in the formation of the 65-kDa complexes. Since we demonstrated above that PAL and TolB are associated, it is likely that PAL may participate directly in the 65-kDa complexes. To confirm this hypothesis, extracts of JC7752 pBP cells treated with formaldehyde were probed with the AS3 antiserum directed against PAL (Fig. 7). The 65-kDa bands revealed by these antibodies showed that PAL was present in both complexes. PAL Plays a Role in the Association of TolB with the Membrane—Isnard et al. (27Isnard M. Rigal A. Lazzaroni J.C. Lazdunski C. Lloubès R. J. Bacteriol. 1994; 176: 6392-6396Crossref PubMed Google Scholar) have recently shown that a small amount of TolB might be peripherally associated with the cell membranes. Since PAL is localized in the outer membrane, and since TolB and PAL interact, it is tempting to conclude that a fraction of TolB may be membrane-associated via PAL. To test this hypothesis, the localization of TolB was examined in cells producing (JC7752 pBP) or not producing (JC7752 pMUIII) the PAL protein. Cells were fractionated and the resulting fractions were analyzed by performing Western blotting with the AS1 antiserum. Control tests were carried out using other antisera di

Advanced glycosylation end products (AGEs) arise from glucose-derived Amadori products and have been implicated in the pathogenesis of diabetic vascular disease. We recently reported the presence of an AGE-modified form of low density lipoprotein (LDL) that circulates in high amounts in patients with diabetes or renal insufficiency and that exhibits impaired plasma clearance kinetics. We utilized AGE-specific antibodies to identify the major sites of AGE modification within protease-digested preparations of apolipoprotein B that impair the binding of the AGE-modified form of LDL by human fibroblast LDL receptors. The predominant site of AGE immunoreactivity was found to lie within a single, 67-amino acid region located 1791 residues NH2-terminal of the putative LDL receptor binding domain. These data point to the high reactivity and specificity of this site for AGE formation and provide further evidence for important structural interactions between the LDL receptor binding domain and remote regions of the apolipoprotein B polypeptide.

The TolA, TolB, TolQ, and TolR proteins are involved in maintaining the integrity of the Escherichia coli outer membrane and in the import of group A colicins and filamentous phage DNA. TolA, TolQ, and TolR are localized in the inner membrane while TolB is periplasmic, although a small amount of membrane-associated TolB is always found. In vivo cross-linking experiments with formaldehyde were performed in order to determine the proteins interacting with TolA. In wild-type strains, two specific complexes of 65 and 71 kDa, comprising TolA, were identified. These complexes were absent in a tolQ strain, while only the 65-kDa complex was absent in a tolR strain. When the tol strains were transformed with plasmids encoding TolR or TolQ, the specific complexes were restored. Moreover, immunoprecipitation experiments with the antiserum directed against TolA indicated that TolQ and TolR were co-immunoprecipitated with TolA after cross-linking. These data demonstrate that TolA interacts directly with TolR and TolQ. Two truncated TolA proteins devoid of either the C-terminal or the central domains of the protein were subjected to in vivo cross-linking. Since these two TolA derivatives still formed specific complexes with TolR and TolQ, we concluded that the TolA N-terminal domain interacted with these proteins. The TolA, TolB, TolQ, and TolR proteins are involved in maintaining the integrity of the Escherichia coli outer membrane and in the import of group A colicins and filamentous phage DNA. TolA, TolQ, and TolR are localized in the inner membrane while TolB is periplasmic, although a small amount of membrane-associated TolB is always found. In vivo cross-linking experiments with formaldehyde were performed in order to determine the proteins interacting with TolA. In wild-type strains, two specific complexes of 65 and 71 kDa, comprising TolA, were identified. These complexes were absent in a tolQ strain, while only the 65-kDa complex was absent in a tolR strain. When the tol strains were transformed with plasmids encoding TolR or TolQ, the specific complexes were restored. Moreover, immunoprecipitation experiments with the antiserum directed against TolA indicated that TolQ and TolR were co-immunoprecipitated with TolA after cross-linking. These data demonstrate that TolA interacts directly with TolR and TolQ. Two truncated TolA proteins devoid of either the C-terminal or the central domains of the protein were subjected to in vivo cross-linking. Since these two TolA derivatives still formed specific complexes with TolR and TolQ, we concluded that the TolA N-terminal domain interacted with these proteins. The TolA, -B, -Q, and -R proteins are necessary for group A colicins to be transferred from their receptors in the outer membrane to their respective targets in the inner membrane or the cytoplasm. The exact physiological role of the Tol proteins is not yet clearly defined, although these proteins have been found to play a role in maintaining the integrity of the outer membrane. The tol mutants exhibit a pleiotropic phenotype; in particular, they are highly sensitive to detergents, drugs, and dyes, and they release periplasmic proteins into the extracellular medium (1Fognini-Lefebvre N. Lazzaroni J.C. Portalier R. Mol. & Gen. Genet. 1987; 209: 391-395Crossref PubMed Scopus (58) Google Scholar, 2Webster R.E. Mol. Microbiol. 1991; 5: 1005-1011Crossref PubMed Scopus (215) Google Scholar). The Tol proteins have been parasitized to permit the group A colicins (colicins A, E, K, and N) and the single-stranded DNA of phages (M13, fd, and fl) (2Webster R.E. Mol. Microbiol. 1991; 5: 1005-1011Crossref PubMed Scopus (215) Google Scholar) to be transported through the outer membrane. The topologies of the TolA, TolQ, and TolR inner membrane proteins have been determined (3Bourdineaud J.P. Howard S.P. Lazdunski C. J. Bacteriol. 1989; 171: 2458-2465Crossref PubMed Google Scholar, 4Kampfenkel K. Braun V. J. Bacteriol. 1993; 175: 4485-4491Crossref PubMed Google Scholar, 5Levengood S.K. Beyer W.F. Webster R.E. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1991; 88: 5939-5943Crossref PubMed Scopus (117) Google Scholar, 6Müller M.M. Vianney A. Lazzaroni J.C. Webster R.E. Portalier R. J. Bacteriol. 1993; 175: 6059-6061Crossref PubMed Google Scholar, 7Vianney A. Lewin T.M. Beyer Jr., W.F. Lazzaroni J.C. Portalier R. Webster R.E. J. Bacteriol. 1994; 176: 822-829Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). TolA (421 amino acids) is a three-domain protein with an N-terminal membrane anchor (residues 14 to 34), a periplasmic central domain (230 amino acids), and a C-terminal domain involved in colicin import (8Levengood-Freyermuth S.K. Click E.M. Webster R.E. J. Bacteriol. 1993; 175: 222-228Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). The C-terminal domain has been found to interact in vitro with colicins A and E1 (9Bénédetti H. Lazdunski C. Lloubès R. EMBO J. 1991; 10: 1989-1995Crossref PubMed Scopus (77) Google Scholar). TolR (142 amino acids) has an inner membrane anchor (residues 23 to 43); it has a short N-terminal cytoplasmic region and the rest of the protein protrudes into the periplasm. TolQ (230 amino acids) comprises an N-terminal periplasmic region followed by three transmembrane segments (residues 20 to 38, 136 to 156, and 175 to 191) and a C-terminal region exposed to the cytoplasm. TolB is periplasmic, although a little of it is membrane-associated (10Isnard M. Rigal A. Lazzaroni J.C. Lazdunski C. Lloubès R. J. Bacteriol. 1994; 176: 6392-6396Crossref PubMed Google Scholar).Another system, composed of the TonB, ExbB, and ExbD proteins, is involved in the import of group β colicins (colicins B, D, I, and M) and of phage DNA (T1, T5, and ϕ80) (11Davies J.K. Reeves P. J. Bacteriol. 1975; 123: 96-101Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). The physiological function of the TonB system is related to the active transport of chelated iron (Fe(III)) and vitamin B12 through high affinity outer membrane receptors. TonB acts as an energy transducer from the inner to the outer membrane, allowing the active transport of nutrients (12Postle K. J. Bioenerg. Biomemb. 1993; 25: 591-601PubMed Google Scholar). According to the amino acid composition, TolQ and ExbB are 75% homologous and so are TolR and ExbD (13Eick-Helmerich K. Braun V. J. Bacteriol. 1989; 171: 5117-5127Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). Only 12 residues located in the N-terminal membrane anchors of TonB and TolA proteins are homologous (14Karlsson M. Hannavy K. Higgins C.F. Mol. Microbiol. 1993; 8: 379-388Crossref PubMed Scopus (74) Google Scholar). Moreover, the topologies of TonB, ExbB, and ExbD have been found to be very similar to those of TolA, TolQ, and TolR, respectively (15Roof S.K. Allard J.D. Bertrand K.P. Postle K. J. Bacteriol. 1991; 173: 5554-5557Crossref PubMed Google Scholar, 16Kampfenkel K. Braun V. J. Bacteriol. 1992; 174: 5485-5487Crossref PubMed Google Scholar, 17Kampfenkel K. Braun V. J. Biol. Chem. 1992; 268: 6050-6057Abstract Full Text PDF Google Scholar). Both TolR and TolQ, as well as ExbB and ExbD, cross-complement either exbB/exbD or tolQ/tolR double mutants (18Braun V. Hermann C. Mol. Microbiol. 1993; 8: 261-268Crossref PubMed Scopus (124) Google Scholar).Membrane fractionation analyses showed that the Tol proteins are preferentially located at the contact sites between inner and outer membranes and that their relative amounts at these sites increase after colicin A has been translocated. This suggested that TolA, -B, -Q, and -R formed a complex with a given stoichiometry (19Guihard G. Boulanger P. Bénédetti H. Lloubès R. Besnard M. Letellier L. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 5874-5880Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). The idea of a Tol protein complex also emerged from the experiments in which the TonB anchor was replaced with that of TolA: the fact that the resulting TolA-TonB polypeptide was found to function more efficiently with TolQ than with ExbB indicated that the TolA anchor interacts with TolQ within the membrane bilayer (14Karlsson M. Hannavy K. Higgins C.F. Mol. Microbiol. 1993; 8: 379-388Crossref PubMed Scopus (74) Google Scholar). Furthermore, Lazzaroni et al. (20Lazzaroni J.C. Vianney A. Popot J.L. Bénédetti H. Samatey F. Lazdunski C. Portalier R. Géli V. J. Mol. Biol. 1995; 246: 1-7Crossref PubMed Scopus (83) Google Scholar) obtained suppressor mutations in the anchor of TolR by using a mutant in a transmembrane region of TolQ which suggested that TolQ and TolR interact through their transmembrane domains.In vivo cross-linking experiments have shown that TonB interacts directly with ExbB and with the outer membrane receptor FepA (21Skare J.T. Ahmer B.M.M. Seachord C.L. Darveau R.P. Postle K. J. Biol. Chem. 1993; 268: 16302-16308Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). In the present study, in vivo cross-linking experiments were performed in order to obtain some information about the possible interaction between TolA and other cell envelope proteins. Cross-linked proteins were analyzed after being immunodetected with an anti-TolA antibody that we developed. We demonstrate that TolA interacts directly with TolQ and TolR and forms two specific complexes upon cross-linking with formaldehyde. In addition, the results of cross-linking analysis performed on two TolA truncated derivatives lacking the central or C-terminal domain of the protein demonstrate that TolA interacts with TolQ and TolR via its N-terminal domain.EXPERIMENTAL PROCEDURESBacterial Strains, Growth Conditions, and Plasmids—All the strains and plasmids used in the present study are described in Table I. In strain JC8031, the NcoI-HindIII tol cluster region, including the entire tolR gene and the 5′ part of tolA, were deleted. Cells were analyzed under exponential growth conditions. The conditions for T7 specific labeling were as described previously (22Tabor S. Richardson S.S. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1985; 82: 1074-1078Crossref PubMed Scopus (2438) Google Scholar). This plasmid no longer expressed TolR.The SphI 1930-NotI 2598 DNA fragment of pQRA (two sites located within tolA) was deleted to give pQRAΔh, and the following synthetic DNA fragment was inserted into these sites: 5′-CCCGGGAAAGGTGATGGAACCGGCTGGAGCTCTGAACGTGGATCCGGGCCCGAGCC-.This synthetic DNA consisted of two oligonucleotides encoding amino acids 8 to 25 of colicin A (the 8th and 25th codons are indicated in bold print) including the 1C11 monoclonal antibody epitope (25Géli V. Lloubès R. Zaat S.A.J. van Spaendonk R.M.L. Rollin C. Bénédetti H. Lazdunski C. FEMS Microbiol. Lett. 1993; 109: 335-342Crossref PubMed Scopus (8) Google Scholar). Webster R.E. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1991; 88: 5939-5943Crossref PubMed Scopus (117) Google Scholar)) and conserved the in-frame downstream sequence of TolA, giving the TolAI-III protein. pQRAΔc was obtained directly from pQRA by deleting the NotI 2598-ClaI DNA fragment (two unique sites, since ClaI was located in the MCS of pT7–5). Bacteriol. 1989; 171: 6600-6609Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). By exchanging the NcoI-SphI DNA fragment with a synthetic DNA fragment containing the T7 promoter, a RBS sequence, and an ATG codon (which are underlined in the following top strand oligonucleotide sequence, where the ATG in bold print corresponds to residue 67 of TolA): 5′-CATGCGCTATCTAGATTAATACGACTCACTATAGGGAGA CTAGTTAAGAAGGAGATATAGATGCCCGGCATG-.This resulted in the synthesis of a truncated TolA protein from which domain I (N-terminal) was deleted. Cells transformed with pToIAΔn were used to purify a soluble TolAII-III protein and to obtain an anti-TolA antibody.Formaldehyde Cross-linking—Chemical formaldehyde cross-linking experiments were performed as described by Prossnitz et al. (26Prossnitz E. Nikaido K. Ulbrich S.J. Ames G.F.-L. J. Biol. Chem. 1988; 263: 17917-17920Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar) and Skare et al. (21Skare J.T. Ahmer B.M.M. Seachord C.L. Darveau R.P. Postle K. J. Biol. Chem. 1993; 268: 16302-16308Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Briefly, cells were grown at 37 °C in rich medium to an OD600 of 0.7 and pelleted by centrifugation. The cell pellet was washed with ice-cold 10 mm KPi, pH 6.8, and resuspended in the same buffer to an OD600 of 0.5. Formaldehyde was added to a final concentration of 1% (w/w), and the samples were incubated for various times (10 to 30 min) at room temperature (21–22 °C) without shaking. The cross-linked samples were harvested and washed with cold 10 mm KPi, pH 6.8. The pellets were solubilized in 2× Laemmli sample buffer and either heated at 37 °C for 10 min to maintain the formaldehyde cross-links or at 96 °C for 20 min to break the chemical cross-links.TolAII-III Purification and Antibody Production—TolAII-III was purified from A5922 (pGP1-2 pTolαΔn) cells. Cells were grown in rich medium at 30 °C to an OD600 of 0.5, and the temperature was then shifted to 42 °C for 30 min and the cells were further incubated for 1 h at 30 °C. The following cytoplasmic TolAII-III extraction and purification steps were as described previously by Levengood et al. (5Levengood S.K. Beyer W.F. Webster R.E. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1991; 88: 5939-5943Crossref PubMed Scopus (117) Google Scholar). Antisera were raised against TolAII-III by performing three injections to immunize a rabbit (200 μg of protein in phosphate-buffered saline mixed with Freund’s adjuvant) over a period of 40 days.Immunodetection—After 10% SDS-polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis, the proteins were transferred to nitrocellulose (Schleicher and Scnüll, 0.2 μm) for 2–3 h. Block, primary antibody, and horseradish peroxidase-conjugated second antibody incubations were performed in phosphate-buffered saline/milk (5% non-fat dried milk), and revealed as described (27Towbin H. Staehelin T. Gordon J. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1979; 76: 4350-4354Crossref PubMed Scopus (44708) Google Scholar).Immunoprecipitation was carried out as follows and analyzed using 15% SDS-polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis and fluorography. Cells treated or not treated with formaldehyde were solubilized in TES (10 mm Tris-HCl, pH 7.5, 5 mm EDTA, 2% SDS) for 10 min at 37 °C. They were then diluted 10-fold in TNET (10 mm Tris-HCl, pH 7.5, 5 mm EDTA, 150 mm NaCl, 0.1% Triton X-100), further incubated with vigorous shaking, and centrifuged for 15 min at 18,000 × g in order to remove nonsolubilized material. The supernatant was incubated for 1 h at room temperature with anti-TolA purified IgG coupled to Affi-Gel 10 beads (Bio-Rad). The beads were then washed three times with TNET and once with 10 mm Tris-HCl, pH 8.0. In the last step, the beads were resuspended with Laemmli sample buffer without any reducing agent and heated at 96 °C for 3 min or for 20 min in order to remove the antigen or to remove the antigen and to dissociate the cross-linked proteins, respectively.RESULTSTwo Major Complexes of 65 and 71 kDa, Containing TolA, Are Specifically Immunodetected after in Vivo Cross-linking—In vivo cross-linking with 1% formaldehyde was performed in order to identify the proteins interacting with TolA. The cross-linked material was analyzed through Western blotting with an anti-TolAII-III polyclonal antibody (anti-TolA pAb) 2The abbreviations used are: pAb, polyclonal antibody; TM, transmembrane. that we developed. No signal was obtained with the anti-TolA pAb after Western blot analysis with the strain JC8031 (ΔtolRA) treated or not treated with formaldehyde (data not shown). Two major 65- and 71-kDa bands were reproducibly detected (C1 and C2 in Fig. 1) under cross-linking conditions (at 37 °C) in each of the wild-type cells we used. These complexes were obtained after a 10- to 30-min formaldehyde treatment and were destroyed by heating the samples to 96 °C for 20 min (26Prossnitz E. Nikaido K. Ulbrich S.J. Ames G.F.-L. J. Biol. Chem. 1988; 263: 17917-17920Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Furthermore, they were absent from samples not treated with formaldehyde. These cross-linked C1 and C2 TolA complexes are therefore specific. Without formaldehyde treatment, faint bands were detected at a higher Mr than TolA in 37 °C heated samples, which were not analyzed in this study. The formaldehyde-treated W3110 cells were fractionated: the two cross-linked complexes were recovered with TolA in the membrane fraction (data not shown).TolR and TolQ Are Associated with TolA in the Two Specific Complexes—The molecular masses of TolA, TolQ, and TolR were calculated and found to be 43.1, 25.5, and 15.5 kDa, respectively, and their respective migrations in SDS-polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis corresponded to 48, 24, and 17 kDa (23Sun T.P. Webster R.E. J. Bacteriol. 1987; 169: 2667-2674Crossref PubMed Google Scholar, 24Levengood S.K. Webster R.E. J. Bacteriol. 1989; 171: 6600-6609Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). Accordingly, the specific complexes of 65 and 71 kDa might correspond to TolA associated with TolR or with TolQ. In order to test this possibility, we checked whether these complexes were absent from strains tolR and tolQ.In the strain GM1, the two specific complexes were detected, while only the 71-kDa complex was observed in its tolR derivative, TPS300 (Fig. 2A). A TolR-TolA association may therefore form the 65-kDa band obtained with a wild-type strain. To check this hypothesis, the JC 8031 (ΔtolRA) strain was transformed with plasmids pQRA or pQA which encode TolQ, -R, and -A proteins or TolQ and -A proteins, respectively. The 65-kDa TolA complex was detected when TolR was produced in JC8031 (pQRA) cells, but was not restored in JC8031 (pQA) cells (Fig. 2B). This result confirms that in the same bacterial context, the production of TolR is sufficient to specify the 65-kDa complex.FIG. 2Immunoblot analysis of TolA in TPS300 and GM1 strains (A), JC8031 (pQA), and JC8031 (pQRA) strains (B), cross-linked in vivo for 10 min with 1% formaldehyde. Immunodetection was carried out with diaminobenzidine; Molecular sizes and the legend are the same as in Fig. 1.View Large Image Figure ViewerDownload Hi-res image Download (PPT)TolQ and TolR Can Be Co-immunoprecipitated with TolA after Cross-linking with Formaldehyde—To further demonstrate that TolR and TolQ interact with TolA, an additional experimental strategy was used. Because anti-TolQ and anti-TolR antibodies are unavailable, and since it was not possible to sequence the complexed proteins directly, which had their N-terminal residues blocked with formaldehyde, immunoprecipitation experiments were carried out with anti-TolA pAb after in vivo cross-linking with formaldehyde (Fig. 5). For this purpose, TPS13 (pQRAB) and TPS13 (pRAB) cells were radiolabeled with [35S]methionine during the exponential growth phase and were treated with formaldehyde. The cells were solubilized at 37 °C in TES and subjected to immunoprecipitation. The immunoprecipitates were incubated in sample buffer under two conditions: warmed up for either 20 min (at 96 °C) in order to destroy the cross-links between proteins or for 3 min (at 96 °C) to dissociate the antigens from the anti-TolA IgG (this incubation time is too short to destroy all the cross-links). In control experiments, immunoprecipitating TPS13 (pQRAB) cells untreated with formaldehyde yielded two major and several faint bands. The higher band was assigned to TolA (Fig. 5). According to Western blot immunodetections, one of the faint bands corresponded to a degradation product of TolA (clearly visible in lane C20 below TolA), while a major band migrating like TolB was not immunodetected with the anti-TolB antibody (data not shown). Immunoprecipitated samples of TPS13 (pQRAB) cells treated with formaldehyde specifically gave two proteins migrating like TolQ and TolR (Fig. 5) when the cross-linking was destroyed by 20 min of boiling. T7 specific labeling of GM1 cells harboring pGP1-2 and pQRAB or pGP1-2 and pRAB was carried out in order to identify the positions of TolQ and TolR. In similar experiments with TPS13 (pRAB) cells, no labeled protein was detected at the position corresponding to TolQ and TolR. TolQ and TolR were therefore specifically co-immunoprecipitated with TolA after the in vivo cross-linking treatment.FIG. 5Immunoprecipitation analyses with anti-TolA pAb of TPS13 (pQRAB) and TPS13 (pRAB) radiolabeled cells treated or not treated with formaldehyde and further solubilized at 37 °C in TES. Two specific bands with molecular weights corresponding to those of complexes between the TolA derivatives and TolQ or TolR were detected. The approximate m

Neuronal Cdc2-like kinase is a heterodimer of Cdk5 and a 25-kDa subunit which is derived from a brain-specific 35-kDa novel protein, p35 (Lew, J., Huang, Q.-Q., Qi, Z., Winkfein, R. J., Aebersold, R., Hunt, T., and Wang, J. H. (1994) Nature 371, 423-426). Three truncated forms of p35 including the one corresponding to the 25-kDa subunit of the kinase have been expressed in Escherichia coli and shown to activate a bacteria-expressed Cdk5 with equal efficacy. The shortest truncated form of p35, p21, spanning amino acid residues 88 to 291, has been used to reconstitute active Cdk5 kinase and to characterize the activation reaction. The purified kinase displays similar specific enzyme activity and similar phosphorylation site specificity as the neuronal Cdc2-like kinase purified from bovine brain. Bovine brain extract contains Cdk5 uncomplexed with p35 or p25 which has also been found to be activated by p21 or p25. The results substantiate the previous suggestion that p35 is a specific Cdk5 activator. Several observations suggest that, unlike other well characterized Cdc2-like kinases whose activities depend on the phosphorylation of the catalytic subunits at a specific site by a distinct kinase, the reconstituted Cdk5/p21 does not depend on the phosphorylation of Cdk5 for activity. The reconstitution of the highly active Cdk5 kinase was achieved without requiring any other kinase in the reconstitution reaction. The possibility of autophosphorylation of Cdk5 on the putative activation site has been ruled out as no phosphorylation occurred on Cdk5 during the enzyme reaction. The rate and extent of the kinase reconstitution were not significantly affected by Mg2+ATP. The regulation of cell division cycle in eukaryotes is governed by a universal mechanism in which a family of closely related kinases play rate-limiting functions at discrete phases of the cell cycle (for reviews, see Refs. 1Murray A.W. Kirschner M.W. Science. 1989; 246: 614-621Crossref PubMed Scopus (512) Google Scholar, 2Hunt T. Curr. Opin. Cell Biol. 1989; 1: 268-274Crossref PubMed Scopus (168) Google Scholar, 3Draetta G. Biochem. 1992; 61: 441-470Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). Huang Q.-Q. Qi Z. Winkfein R.J. Aebersold R. Hunt T. Wang J.H. Nature. 1994; 371: 423-426Crossref PubMed Scopus (540) Google Scholar). The mRNA transcript of p35 has been shown to be specifically expressed in the central nervous system. The primary structure of p35 shows only limited homology to members of the cyclin family; yet, the protein appears to perform a cyclin-like role in neuronal Cdc2-like kinase. A bacteria-expressed, truncated form of p35 has been found to activate a bacteria-expressed Cdk5. In the present study, we demonstrate the activation of Cdk5 by a number of bacterially expressed, truncated forms of p35, including one corresponding to the 25-kDa subunit of neuronal Cdc2-like kinase purified from bovine brain, and carry out detailed characterization of the kinase activation reaction. The study has revealed a major difference between the mechanism of Cdk5 activation and that of Cdc2 or Cdk2 activation. Although the amino acid sequence of Cdk5 contains a phosphorylatable residue, serine, at the position corresponding to the positive regulatory threonine of Cdc2 or Cdk2, the activation of Cdk5 does not appear to be dependent on the presence of a Cdk activating kinase. The active form of the kinase does not catalyze autophosphorylation of Cdk5, thus ruling out the possibility that the specific serine residue is phosphorylated by an autocatalytic reaction. The cell pellets were suspended in 20 ml of 50 mM Tris-HCl (pH 7.4) buffer containing 2 mM EDTA, 1% Tween 20, 1 mM DTT, 0.25 mM phenylmethylsulfonyl fluoride, and 1 μg/ml each of leupeptin, aprotinin, and pepstatin. Antibodies against Cdk5 and the p35 derivatives were rabbit polyclonal antibody preparations raised against the bacteria-expressed Cdk5 and 21-kDa fragment of p35, respectively. The expression of GST-fused Cdk5 and p35, as well as p25, p23, and p21 truncated forms of p35 (Fig. 1) were attempted in E. coli strain BL21 (DE3). The bacteria lysates were centrifuged to separate into a soluble and a particulate fraction, and expression of the recombinant proteins was analyzed by SDS-PAGE and immunoblot. The expression of the full-length p35 fusion protein was not successful; essentially no fusion protein was detectable in the bacteria lysate (data not shown). Most of the expressed truncated forms of p35 were found in the insoluble fraction. In all cases, the soluble recombinant proteins appeared to have undergone considerable proteolytic degradation. Lowering the induction temperature from 37°C to room temperature or decreasing the protein induction time to 1 h did not significantly affect the extent of the protein degradation. Attempts to express the full-length p35 using a different vector, PQE30 (QIAGEN), was also unsuccessful. The expressed proteins were purified from the soluble fractions of bacteria lysates by glutathione affinity column chromatography. As shown previously (51Lew J. Huang Q.-Q. Qi Z. Winkfein R.J. Aebersold R. Hunt T. Wang J.H. Nature. 1994; 371: 423-426Crossref PubMed Scopus (540) Google Scholar), the expressed Cdk5 fusion protein did not exhibit any kinase activity by itself, nor did any of the p35-related fusion proteins. Protein kinase activity, however, could be readily detected upon mixing Cdk5 with the fusion proteins of the truncated forms of p35, and the fusion proteins of p21, p23, and p25 showed similar activity in Cdk5 activation (Fig. 2 A). To achieve maximal activation, the mass ratio of activating proteins to Cdk5 of 8:1 was used in these experiments, and the protein mixtures were preincubated for 30 min before kinase assay. Dose-dependent activation of Cdk5 by p21 indicated that close to maximal activation could be approached at a mass ratio of Cdk5/p21 of 1:1.5 (Fig. 2 B). The optimal activation of Cdk5 by the truncated forms of p35 also requires preincubation of the proteins. For example, the time course of the kinase reaction of a mixture of Cdk5 and p21 displays low kinase activity and pronounced upward curvature indicative of a slow activation of the kinase during the reaction. If the two proteins have been incubated for 1 h before the kinase reaction is initiated, a linear initial time course with greatly increased kinase activity will result (Fig. 2 C). Since our attempts in bacteria expression of the full-length p35 had not been successful, a similar reconstitution experiment with the full-length protein was not possible. p25 corresponds to the 25-kDa subunit of the purified bovine brain neuronal Cdc2-like kinase which exhibits specific kinase activities similar to or higher than those of the fully activated Cdc2 and Cdk2 kinases.
