We demonstrate unusual features of the intracellular processing of endothelin-1 (ET-1) and its receptor ETA, the receptor subtype that mediates contraction of vascular smooth muscle cells. First, we show that in stably transfected CHO cells expressing ETA, binding of an ET-1 ligand induces rapid endocytosis of cell surface ETA. Receptor endocytosis was measured both by immunofluorescence and by radioiodinated antibodies specific for ETA. Second, we demonstrate that ET-1 remains intact for up to 2 h after endocytosis and, as judged by co-immunoprecipitation, internalized 125I-ET-1 remains bound to ETA receptors. We hypothesize that internalized ET-1, bound to ETA receptors, continues to activate a signal-transducing G protein, thus accounting for the prolonged period of contraction induced in smooth muscle cells by a single administration of ET-1. We demonstrate unusual features of the intracellular processing of endothelin-1 (ET-1) and its receptor ETA, the receptor subtype that mediates contraction of vascular smooth muscle cells. First, we show that in stably transfected CHO cells expressing ETA, binding of an ET-1 ligand induces rapid endocytosis of cell surface ETA. Receptor endocytosis was measured both by immunofluorescence and by radioiodinated antibodies specific for ETA. Second, we demonstrate that ET-1 remains intact for up to 2 h after endocytosis and, as judged by co-immunoprecipitation, internalized 125I-ET-1 remains bound to ETA receptors. We hypothesize that internalized ET-1, bound to ETA receptors, continues to activate a signal-transducing G protein, thus accounting for the prolonged period of contraction induced in smooth muscle cells by a single administration of ET-1.

A heme-binding protein has been isolated and characterized from both the hemolymph and oocytes of the blood-sucking insect, Rhodnius prolixus. The protein from both sources is identical in most aspects studied. The Rhodnius heme-binding protein (RHBP) is composed of a single 15-kDa polypeptide chain coiled in a highly α-helical structure which binds non-covalently one heme/polypeptide chain. This RHBP is not produced by limited degradation of hemoglobin from the vertebrate host, since specific polyclonal antibodies against it do not cross-react with rabbit hemoglobin, and since it differs from hemoglobin in having a distinct amino-acid composition and NH2-terminal sequence. The spectrum of the dithionite-reduced protein has peaks at 426, 530, and 559 nm and resembles that of a b-type cytochrome.RHBP from hemolymph is not saturated with heme and promptly binds heme added to the solution. The oocyte protein, on the other hand, is fully saturated and is not capable of binding additional heme. The Rhodnius heme-binding protein (RHBP) is composed of a single 15-kDa polypeptide chain coiled in a highly α-helical structure which binds non-covalently one heme/polypeptide chain. This RHBP is not produced by limited degradation of hemoglobin from the vertebrate host, since specific polyclonal antibodies against it do not cross-react with rabbit hemoglobin, and since it differs from hemoglobin in having a distinct amino-acid composition and NH2-terminal sequence. The spectrum of the dithionite-reduced protein has peaks at 426, 530, and 559 nm and resembles that of a b-type cytochrome. RHBP from hemolymph is not saturated with heme and promptly binds heme added to the solution. The oocyte protein, on the other hand, is fully saturated and is not capable of binding additional heme.

Immortalized brown adipocyte cell lines derived from a mouse hibernoma express all three β-adrenergic receptor subtypes, including β3-adrenergic receptor (AR). In response to norepinephrine, cAMP production by plasma membranes from four clonal cell lines was stimulated to levels comparable with brown adipocytes isolated from interscapular brown adipose tissue (72.8-89.6 versus 97.8 pmol cAMP/min/mg of protein, respectively). All cell lines responded to the highly selective β3-adrenergic receptor agonist CL316,243 by stimulating adenylyl cyclase activity (3-10-fold over basal). β1-, β2-, and β3-adrenergic receptor mRNA was detected by Northern blotting and/or reverse transcriptase-polymerase chain reaction. Competition binding assays with the antagonists CGP20712A and 125I-cyanopindolol showed the proportions of β1AR and β2AR in immortalized cells to be similar to brown adipocytes from tissue (cells: 35%β1AR, 65%β2AR; brown adipocytes from tissue: β1AR 41%, 59%β2AR). Expression of brown fat-specific mitochondrial uncoupling protein (Ucp) was stimulated by β-adrenergic agonists in two of the four cell lines. The ability of individual βAR subtypes to regulate Ucp expression was examined with combinations of selective β-adrenergic agonists and antagonists. Expression of Ucp could be induced by any of the β-adrenergic receptor subtypes. However, the greatest response was obtained by stimulating all three β-adrenergic receptor subtypes simultaneously (100 μM isoproterenol). Incubation of membranes from cultured cells or brown adipocytes from tissue with CL316,243 at an optimal concentration (5 μM) did not prevent norepinephrine from further stimulating adenylyl cyclase activity, suggesting that the combined activation of β1AR/β2AR, plus β3AR, together produced an additive cAMP response. Multiple forms of adenylyl cyclase were identified in brown and white adipocyte cell lines and tissues. Northern blot analysis detected adenylyl cyclase types 5, 6, and 10. Screening of reverse transcriptase-PCR products by DNA sequencing confirmed the identities of these forms and lower levels of additional isoforms, raising the possibility that β-adrenergic receptor subtypes in adipocytes couple to distinct adenylyl cyclases. Because these cell lines display functional and phenotypic similarities to interscapular brown adipocytes, they will be a useful model to study the regulation of β-adrenergic receptor expression and function, and the control of Ucp expression and activity. Heme in aqueous solutions actively promotes free radical reactions leading to degradation of biological molecules. The blood-sucking insect Rhodnius prolixus has a heme-binding protein (RHBP) in its hemolymph (Oliveira, P. L., Kawooya, J. K, Ribeiro, J. M. C., Meyer, T., Poorman, R., Alves, E. W., Walker, F., Padovan, G. J., and Masuda, H. (1994) J. Biol. Chem. 270, 10897-10901. Here we show that this protein inhibits heme-dependent peroxidation of both linolenic acid liposomes and lipophorin, the main lipoprotein of insect hemolymph. The oxidized lipophorin is functionally impaired, being defective both in its capacity to be loaded with phospholipids from the fat body as well as in its ability to deliver phospholipids to the growing oocytes. RHBP prevents the heme-induced oxidative damage to lipophorin. It is proposed that in vivo RHBP binds the heme derived from digestion of blood hemoglobin, suppressing the generation of activated oxygen species and protecting the insect against oxidative stress throughout the feeding cycle.

Cdc42Hs and Rac1 are members of the Ras superfamily of small molecular weight (p21) GTP binding proteins. Cdc42Hs induces filopodia formation in Swiss 3T3 fibroblasts while Rac1 induces membrane ruffling. Rac1 also activates superoxide production by the components (cytochrome b, p40, p67phox, and p47phox) of the neutrophil oxidase. To isolate target proteins involved in these signaling pathways, we have probed proteins from neutrophil cytosol immobilized on nitrocellulose with Cdc42Hs labeled with [γ-32P]GTP. Cdc42Hs probe detected binding protein(s) of 66-68 kDa in neutrophil cytosol. Rac1 probe also detected the 66-68-kDa proteins, suggesting the possibility that p67phox may be a binding protein for both of these p21 proteins. Indeed, Cdc42Hs and Rac1 were found to bind specifically to purified recombinant p67phox but not the other oxidase components. A 68-kDa Cdc42Hs binding protein was purified from neutrophil cytosol and found to be related to the recently described p65pak kinase from brain. These results suggest that the p68 kinase and p67phox are targets for Cdc42Hs and Rac1 in neutrophils. The Ras superfamily of small molecular (p21) GTP binding proteins play fundamental roles in cellular physiology, including the control of cell proliferation, protein trafficking, and actin-based cell morphology (Hall, 1990Hall A. Science. 1990; 249: 635-640Crossref PubMed Scopus (669) Google Scholar). These GTP binding proteins cycle between GTP-bound (on) and GDP-bound (off) states. Regulatory proteins such as GTPase activating proteins (e.g.n-chimaerin) (Diekmann et al., 1991Diekmann D. Brill S. Garrett M.D. Totty N. Hsuan J. Hall C. Monfries C. Lim L. Hall A. Nature. 1991; 351: 400-402Crossref PubMed Scopus (352) Google Scholar) and GDP/GTP exchange proteins (e.g. Dbl) (Hart et al., 1991Hart M.J. Eva A. Evans T. Aaronson A. Cerione R. Nature. 1991; 354: 311-314Crossref PubMed Scopus (335) Google Scholar) determine the degree to which any particular p21 is in the on state. Cdc42Hs and Rac1 are members of the Rho family, which is thought to be involved in controlling cell morphology (Hall, 1992Hall A. Mol. Biol. Cell. 1992; 3: 475-479Crossref PubMed Scopus (171) Google Scholar). Cdc42Hs microinjection induces filopodia formation in Swiss 3T3 cells (Kozma et al., 1995Kozma R. Ahmed S. Best A. Lim L. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1995; 15: 1942-1952Crossref PubMed Scopus (876) Google Scholar), and Rac1 microinjection induces membrane ruffling (Ridley et al., 1992Ridley A.J. Paterson H.F. Johnston C.L. Diekmann D. Hall A. Cell. 1992; 70: 401-410Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (3032) Google Scholar). Rac1 has also been shown to activate the neutrophil oxidase (Abo et al., 1991Abo A. Pick E. Hall A. Totty N. Teahan C.G. Segal A.W. Nature. 1991; 353: 668-670Crossref PubMed Scopus (754) Google Scholar; Knaus et al., 1991Knaus U.G. Heyworth P.G. Evans T. Curnutte J.T. Bokoch G.M. Science. 1991; 254: 1512-1515Crossref PubMed Scopus (538) Google Scholar), possibly by mediating complex formation of p67phox 1( 1The abbreviations used are: phoxneutrophil oxidaseGSTglutathione S-transferaseBSAbovine serum albuminDTTdithiothreitolPBSphosphate-buffered salinePAGEpolyacrylamide gel electrophoresisPipes1,4-piperazinediethanesulfonic acidMes4-morpholinepropanesulfonic acid. ) and p47phox (and p40phox (Wientjes et al., 1993Wientjes F.B. Hsuan J.J. Totty N.F. Segal A.W. Biochem. J. 1993; 296: 557-561Crossref PubMed Scopus (255) Google Scholar)) with the membrane-bound cytochrome b (Segal and Abo, 1993Segal A.W. Abo A. Trends Biochem. Sci. 1993; 18: 43-47Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (560) Google Scholar). The downstream target(s) for Cdc42Hs or Rac1 in the morphological pathways is not known. However, recent work has identified specific targets for p21 signaling pathways. Ras binds to Raf kinase, relocalizing Raf to the plasma membrane upon cell stimulation (Stokoe et al., 1994Stokoe D. Macdonald S.G. Caldwaller K. Symons M. Hancock J.F. Science. 1994; 264: 1463-1466Crossref PubMed Scopus (831) Google Scholar Leevers et al., 1994Leevers S.J. Paterson H.F. Marshall C.J. Nature. 1994; 369: 411-414Crossref PubMed Scopus (874) Google Scholar). Manser et al. (1994) have isolated a brain protein kinase, p65, by purifying a Rac1/Cdc42Hs-[γ-32P]GTP binding activity. Brain p65pak kinase is activated by Rac1 and Cdc42Hs and is therefore a novel target for these p21 proteins. neutrophil oxidase glutathione S-transferase bovine serum albumin dithiothreitol phosphate-buffered saline polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis 1,4-piperazinediethanesulfonic acid 4-morpholinepropanesulfonic acid. To identify Cdc42Hs and Rac1 targets that may be involved in the pathways described above, we have probed proteins in neutrophil cytosol immobilized on nitrocellulose with p21-[γ-32P]GTP. Using this technique, 66-68-kDa proteins were detected. We speculated that one of these proteins might by either p67phox or a p65-related protein. Cdc42Hs-[γ-32P]GTP was found to bind specifically to purified recombinant p67phox, as did Rac1. During the course of the present work, Rac1 was shown to bind specifically to p67phox (Diekmann et al., 1994Diekmann D. Abo A. Johnstone C. Segal A.W. Hall A. Science. 1994; 265: 531-533Crossref PubMed Scopus (342) Google Scholar). The 66-68-kDa proteins were found to be related to the brain p65. Thus, this study identifies two targets for Cdc42Hs and Rac1 in neutrophils: a 68-kDa kinase and p67phox . Nature. 1994; 367: 40-46Crossref PubMed Scopus (1278) Google Scholar) was cloned by introducing a BamHI site immediately preceding the initiating methionine and then cloning a BamHI- EcoRI fragment into pGEX-2T. Protein was quantified by the method of Bradford, 1976Bradford M.M. Anal. Biochem. 1976; 72: 248-254Crossref PubMed Scopus (210775) Google Scholar. For one-dimensional analysis, recombinant, neutrophil, and brain proteins were prepared in sample buffer (125 mM Tris-HCl, pH 6.8, 4% SDS, 20% glycerol, 0.14 Mβ-mercaptoethanol, 0.1% bromphenol blue) and boiled for 2-3 min before being separated on 10% SDS-PAGE. For two-dimensional analysis, proteins were mixed with an equal volume of lysis buffer (9.5 M urea, 10 mM lysine, 5%β-mercaptoethanol, 2% Nonidet P-40 containing 4% ampholines, pH 5-7, and 1% ampholines, pH 3.5-10) and separated on tube gels containing the same ampholines by electrophoresis overnight at 300 V and then for 1 h at 1000 V. Tube gels were then equilibrated in sample buffer for 1 h and loaded onto 10% SDS-PAGE. One- and two-dimensional gels were transferred to nitrocellulose using a Bio-Rad semi-dry blotter in transfer buffer (4.8 mM Tris, 3.9 mM glycine, and 0.375% SDS). For dot blotting, proteins (5-20 μl) were applied directly on 1-2-cm2 nitrocellulose filters. After protein transfer, filters were incubated in renaturation buffer (3% BSA, 0.1% Triton X-100, 0.5 mM MgCl2, 5 mM DTT) for 2 h. p21 probes were prepared by incubating Cdc42Hs and Rac1 (1μg) with 1 μl of [γ-32P]GTP (DuPont NEN; 6000 Ci/mmol, 10 mCi/ml, 1.6 M) or 2 μl of [α-32P]GTP (DuPont NEN; 3000 Ci/mmol, 10 mCi/ml, 0.8 M) in 50 μl of exchange buffer (50 mM NaCl, 25 mM Mes, pH 6.5, 25 mM Tris-HCl, pH 7.5, 1.25 mM EDTA, 1.25 mg/ml BSA, 1.25 mM DTT) for 10 min at room temperature. [α-32P]GDP probes were generated by loading with [α-32P]GTP and allowing the p21-GTP complex to hydrolyze the γ-phosphate group for 60-90 min at room temperature. Probes were used immediately on preparation by diluting into Petri dishes containing 4 ml of binding buffer (50 mM NaCl, 25 mM Mes, pH 6.5, 25 mM Tris-HCl, pH 7.5, 1.25 mM MgCl2, 1.25 mg/ml BSA, 1.25 mM DTT, 0.5 mM GTP). Filters were incubated with p21 probes for 5 min at room temperature before being washed six times for 5 min each in wash buffer (50 mM NaCl, 25 mM Mes, pH 6.0, 5 mM MgCl2, 0.25% Triton X-100) on ice. After washing, the filters were quickly dried by placing on Whatman 3MM paper and then exposed to Kodak X-Omat film for 5-25 h. Quantitative p21 binding analysis was carried out by cutting out 1 cm2 of nitrocellulose and determining the amount of radioactivity by scintillation counting. p68 protein purified as described below (100 ng) was incubated for 10 min with 50 μCi of [γ-32P]ATP (Amersham Corp., 5000 Ci/mmol, 10 mCi/ml) in kinase buffer (50 mM Hepes, pH 7.0, 5 mM MgCl2, 5 mM MnCl2, 1 mM DTT, 0.05% Triton X-100), and the reaction was stopped by the addition of 2 × sample buffer and boiling for 3 min. Samples were then loaded onto 10% SDS-PAGE and electrophoresed for 50 min at 180 V or until the dye front containing free label was run off the bottom of the gel. The gel was then dried and exposed to Kodak X-Omat film for 10 min. p68 protein was purified in five steps using the Cdc42Hs binding assay described above. (i) Neutrophil cytosol (280 ml, containing 20 mg/ml protein) was applied to a Q-Sepharose column (Pharmacia Biotech Inc.) equilibrated with 10 mM Pipes, 100 mM KCl, 3 mM NaCl, 4 mM MgCl2 (pH 7.0) containing 6% sucrose and protease inhibitors (1 mM pepstatin and 100 μM Nα- p-tosyl-L-lysine chloromethyl ketone). Protein was eluted with a linear gradient of NaCl (0.1-1 M) in the above buffer, and 10-ml fractions were collected. Binding protein eluted at between 0.2-0.3 M NaCl. Six fractions were pooled and diluted 3-fold in ice-cold water. (ii) The above pool (180 ml) was applied to a heparin-agarose column, equilibrated as above, and proteins eluted with a linear NaCl gradient (0.1-1 M) in the same buffer. Binding protein eluted between 0.3 and 0.4 M NaCl. Five fractions of 5 ml were pooled, and the volume was reduced to 5 ml using polyethylene glycol by dialysis for 3 h at 4°C. (iii) After filtration to clear the protein sample, it was loaded onto a Superose 12-gel filtration column (Pharmacia), equilibrated as before, and 1.3-ml fractions were collected in the above buffer. (iv) A 1-ml chelating Sepharose column was prepared by applying 10 column volumes of 100 mM ZnCl2; the protein sample was applied, the column was washed in buffer Z (100 mM NaCl, 0.5 mM MgCl2, 0.05% Triton X-100) containing 25 mM Tris, pH 7.5, and elution was carried out in buffer Z containing 25 mM Mes, pH 6.0. (v) Protein was loaded onto a Cdc42Hs-G12V-GTP glutathione-Sepharose affinity column in the presence of 1 mM GTP. For these experiments, Cdc42Hs was not cleaved with thrombin, leaving the GST component as an affinity tag. The column was washed in 5 ml of buffer Z containing 25 mM Mes, pH 6.0, and proteins were eluted in 1 column volume fractions of buffer Z containing 25 mM Tris, pH 8.5, or freshly prepared 5 mM glutathione, 50 mM Tris, pH 8.0. p67phox antibody was a gift from Dr. Franz Wientjies. p65pak and GST antibodies were raised in rabbits using purified recombinant protein from Escherichia coli. The immunization procedure consisted of injection of fusion protein (100 μg) in complete Freund's adjuvant, followed by boosts (every 4 weeks) of fusion protein (100 μg) in incomplete Freund's adjuvant. Rabbits were bled 1 week after the third boost and after subsequent injections. Antibodies were purified on affinity columns of the recombinant protein. Affinity-purified p67phox antibodies have been previously described (Wientjes et al., 1993Wientjes F.B. Hsuan J.J. Totty N.F. Segal A.W. Biochem. J. 1993; 296: 557-561Crossref PubMed Scopus (255) Google Scholar). Proteins were transferred to nitrocellulose using a semi-dry blotter as described above. Filters were then blocked and washed as previously described (Ahmed et al., 1994Ahmed S. Lee J. Wen L-P. Zhao Z. Ho J. Best A. Kozma R. Lim L. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 17642-17648Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar) before incubation with primary antibody (1 in 10,000 dilution for the p67phox antibody and 1 in 500 for p65pak in PBS, 0.1% Tween, 1% non-fat milk). Filters were washed in PBS, 0.1% Tween (5 × 5 min) before incubation with secondary antibody; DAKO peroxidase-conjugated Swine Anti-rabbit immunoglobulins, diluted 1 in 1,000 in PBS, 0.1% Tween, 1% non-fat milk, and staining visualized using enhanced chemiluminescence (Amersham) was as described by the manufacturer. After phosphorylation, both recombinant GST-p65pak and p68 were incubated for 60 min at 4°C with either 5 μl of affinity-purified p65pak antibody or preimmune serum (in 50 mM Tris, pH 7.5, 25 mM NaCl, 0.5 mM MgCl2, 0.05% Triton X-100, 1 mM DTT; final volume, 100 μl). A 50% slurry in the same buffer (v/v) of protein A-Sepharose beads (Sigma, 100 μl) was then added, and incubation continued for a further 60 min. The protein A-Sepharose beads were sedimented by packing in a spin column, and the unbound material and radioactivity was removed by discarding the supernatant. The column was then washed three times with 750 μl of PBS, 0.1% Triton X-100. 50 μl of sample buffer (2×) was then added to the beads followed by incubation at 95°C for 10 min. The beads were then spun down, and the supernatant containing protein was analyzed by one-dimensional SDS-PAGE. To detect potential Cdc42Hs targets, proteins in neutrophil cytosol were separated on SDS-PAGE, transferred to nitrocellulose, renatured, and probed with Cdc42Hs-[γ-32P]GTP. Proteins with molecular masses of 66-68 kDa were detected (Fig. 1). Partial purification of Cdc42Hs binding activity by DEAE chromatography revealed two distinct protein bands (not shown). Cdc42Hs-[γ-32P]GTP detects proteins in brain cytosol of a similar size, which are most probably the recently characterized p65pak kinase (Manser et al., 1994Manser E. Leung T. Salihuddin H. Zhao Z-s. Lim L. Nature. 1994; 367: 40-46Crossref PubMed Scopus (1278) Google Scholar). This interaction was specific to the GTP-bound state of Cdc42Hs as (i) Cdc42Hs-GDP at 10-fold higher concentration did not compete with the probe, and (ii) Cdc42Hs-[α-32P]GDP did not detect the neutrophil (or brain) binding proteins (Fig. 1). Rac1-[γ-32P]GTP also reacted with proteins of around 68 kDa from neutrophils (Fig. 1) and brain (not shown). However, the signals were approximately 5-fold weaker when Rac1 was used as a probe, suggesting that it binds less tightly than Cdc42Hs (Fig. 1, lane3; note longer exposure for Rac1). A very weak signal at 48 kDa was also seen with Rac1 (Fig. 1, lane3) and with Cdc42Hs, but this was variable. On the basis of these characteristics, we speculated that the p66-68 Cdc42Hs binding proteins in neutrophils might be either p67phox or a member of the p65pak family of kinases, which are abundant in brain (Manser et al., 1994Manser E. Leung T. Salihuddin H. Zhao Z-s. Lim L. Nature. 1994; 367: 40-46Crossref PubMed Scopus (1278) Google Scholar), and p48 might be p47phox . Purified recombinant neutrophil oxidase components (5 μg) were immobilized on nitrocellulose after SDS-PAGE and then probed with Cdc42Hs-[γ-32P]GTP. Recombinant p67phox, but not p47phox or native cytochrome b protein, was detected with this Cdc42Hs probe. However, p67phox was not detected with Rac1-[γ-32P]GTP (Fig. 2 A). To increase the sensitivity of the assay for Rac1, proteins were directly dot blotted onto nitrocellulose, thus avoiding the denaturation caused by running in SDS-PAGE. Using this method of immobilizing protein, with Rac1-[γ-32P]GTP as probe, signals were obtained for p67phox (2.5-7.5 μg) but not for p47phox, p40, cytochrome b, BSA, or the recombinant phosphatidylinositol kinase p85 subunit (Fig. 2 B). Similarly, with Cdc42Hs as probe, signals were not seen for p47phox or p40phox (not shown). The strength of signal obtained with Rac1 as probe increased, with an increase in p67phox protein amounts between 2.5 and 7.5 μg. As with the 66-68-kDa binding proteins in neutrophil cytosol, Rac1-GDP did not inhibit the Rac1-[γ-32P]GTP interaction with p67phox, and signals were not obtained for p67phox with Rac1-[α-32P]GDP as probe (not shown). Taken together, these data establish the use of this dot-blotting technique to detect protein-protein interactions eliminating the SDS-PAGE step, which denatures proteins. The specificity of these interactions were determined by using the Q61L GTPase negative mutants of Cdc42Hs and Rac1, RhoA and p65. Ras-Q61L has increased effector function in terms of transformation ability and Ras-GTPase activating protein interaction (Brownbridge et al., 1993Brownbridge G.G. Lowe P.N. Moore K.J.M. Skinner R.H. Webb M.R. J. Biol. Chem. 1993; 268: 10914-10919Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Rac1-Q61L is a more potent activator of neutrophil oxidase (Xu et al., 1993Xu X.M. Barry D.C. Bokoch G.M. FASEB J. 1993; 7 (abstr.): 1294Google Scholar) and membrane ruffling3( 2S. Ahmed and A. Best, manuscript in preparation. ) and binds the Rac1-GTPase activating protein n-chimaerin more tightly than wild-type or Rac1-G12V proteins (Ahmed et al., 1994Ahmed S. Lee J. Wen L-P. Zhao Z. Ho J. Best A. Kozma R. Lim L. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 17642-17648Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Rac1-Q61L probe gave a stronger signal than wild-type protein for interaction with p67phox (compare Fig. 3B with 2 B; see below for quantitation), as did Cdc42Hs-Q61L probe (not shown). These mutant p21 proteins only generated a signal with p47phox when it was present at high amounts. The Q61L mutation also increased the binding of Rac1 to p66-68 from neutrophil or brain cytosol (data not shown). RhoA, a member of this subfamily of Ras-related GTP binding proteins, did not bind p67phox under these conditions (Fig. 3 C). Further evidence for the specificity of the Rac1 and Cdc42Hs interaction with p67phox was obtained by carrying out dot blots in the presence of p65, which includes the Rac1/Cdc42Hs binding domain, as a competitor. p65pak interacts specifically with GTP-bound states of Rac1 and Cdc42Hs with high affinity (nM). 2 μM p65pak binding domain inhibited Cdc42Hs-Q61L (Fig. 3 D) and Rac1-Q61L (not shown) from interacting with p67phox, while 2 μM GST was without effect. To quantify the interactions between Rac1 and p67phox, the nitrocellulose filters were radioassayed rather than being exposed to film. To detect Rac1 binding by this technique, amounts of p67phox greater than 2 μg of protein had to be used. Fig. 4 A shows that there was a linear increase in Rac1-Q61L binding as the amount of p67phox protein was increased. p47phox bound low levels, just above background, of Rac1-Q61L, but this was not dependent on the amount of p47phox over the range studied. To quantify the difference between Rac1 and Rac1-Q61L in strength of binding to p67phox, both probes were used in the same experiment, and the filters were radioassayed. p67phox bound approximately 17-fold more Rac1-Q61L than Rac1 (Fig. 4 B). Initially, to investigate whether p66-68 were related to p65pak, we carried out a two-dimensional gel Cdc42Hs binding analysis of proteins in neutrophil and brain cytosol. The major binding proteins in brain have been shown to be p65pak and possibly related proteins (Manser et al., 1994Manser E. Leung T. Salihuddin H. Zhao Z-s. Lim L. Nature. 1994; 367: 40-46Crossref PubMed Scopus (1278) Google Scholar). Proteins in neutrophil and brain cytosol were analyzed on isoelectric focusing tube gels, followed by SDS-PAGE, blotted onto nitrocellulose, and probed with Cdc42Hs (Fig. 5). The locations of the binding proteins in brain and neutrophils were very similar, with the proteins having similar molecular masses (around 68 kDa) and basic isoelectric points. Two major protein spots were detected for brain and neutrophil cytosol. Additional protein spots with more acidic isoelectric points were also seen with longer exposure (not shown) and probably represent phosphorylated forms of the same protein or isoforms. Next, we purified p68 using column chromatography and Cdc42Hs-[γ-32P]GTP binding assays, with affinity purification as the last step (Fig. 6). The yield of protein eluted from Cdc42Hs columns was low with the bulk of protein either flowing through the column or remaining bound to resin (Fig. 6, lane6). p48 was found to copurify with p68, and its level varied from batch to batch of neutrophil cytosol. We believe p48 is a breakdown product of p68, but further work will be necessary to establish its origin. p68 possessed kinase activity as seen by its ability to autophosphorylate. The kinase activity was stimulated by Rac1 (Fig. 7).Figure 7:Kinase activity of p68. Lane1, Coomassie Blue stain of partially purified p68. Lanes2-4, kinase activity as seen by autophosphorylation of p68. Lane2, in the absence of additions. Lane3, in the presence of Rac1-GDP. Lane4, in the presence of Rac1-GTP. p68 was partially purified (approximately 80%) by Q-Sepharose/heparin-agarose/gel filtration. Chelating Sepharose was incubated with 50 μCi of [γ-32P]ATP for 10 min, and then the sample was analyzed on 10% SDS-PAGE and the gel was dried down and exposed to film for 10 min.View Large Image Figure ViewerDownload Hi-res image Download (PPT) To examine whether p68 was related to p67phox or p65, specific affinity-purified antibodies were used. Neutrophil cytosol, p67phox, and purified p68 were separated by 10% SDS-PAGE and transferred to nitrocellulose. p67phox antibodies detected recombinant p67phox and a protein of similar size in neutrophil cytosol but not p68. p65pak antibodies detected p68 and a band of similar size in neutrophil cytosol but not p67phox or p48 (Fig. 8 A). p65pak antibodies also detected a protein of approximately 68 kDa in brain cytosol. Thus, the p68 protein from neutrophil cytosol is closely related to p65. To show that the p68 kinase activity was not due to a contaminating 68 kDa protein, a purified p68 fraction and recombinant GST-p65pak were incubated in parallel with [γ-32P]ATP for 15 min followed by incubation with purified anti-p65pak antibodies (or GST antibodies), and proteins were precipitated using protein A-Sepharose beads. Anti-p65pak antibodies were able to precipitate both the autophosphorylated p68 and GST-p65pak (Fig. 8 B). Anti-p65pak antibodies also precipitated Cdc42Hs binding activity with p68 and GST-p65pak (not shown). Neutrophil cytosol contains Rac1 binding proteins of 66-68 and p48 kDa that bind preferentially to the GTP-bound state of this p21. The possibility that these binding proteins were p67phox and p47phox was addressed by probing purified proteins immobilized on nitrocellulose with Rac1-[γ-32P]GTP. Interestingly, p67phox was found to bind specifically to Rac1 but not to RhoA. The NADPH oxidase components, p40, p47phox, and cytochrome b, did not bind Rac1. p67phox bound approximately 17-fold more of the GTPase negative mutant protein Rac1-Q61L than Rac1, which correlates with the increased potency of Rac1-Q61L to activate neutrophil oxidase (Xu et al., 1993Xu X.M. Barry D.C. Bokoch G.M. FASEB J. 1993; 7 (abstr.): 1294Google Scholar). During the course of this work, Diekmann et al. (1994) demonstrated that Rac1 interacted specifically with p67phox by using GST fusion proteins and glutathione-Sepharose to examine protein-protein interactions. In general, our results are in agreement with those presented by Diekmann et al. (1994). However, in their study, Rac1-Q61L did not interact more strongly with p67phox than wild-type Rac1. This could be explained by differences in the sensitivity of the assays employed or the exact conditions used. We have also shown here that purified native cytochrome b and p40phox are not Rac1 binding proteins. Thus, out of all of the components of the neutrophil oxidase, p67phox is the sole target for Rac1. In preliminary experiments, we have mapped a Rac1 binding site of p67phox very near its polyproline domain4( 3S. Ahmed and R. Kozma, unpublished data. )(SH3 binding site), which is thought to interact with p47phox . This may suggest that one purpose of the Rac1-p67phox interaction is to influence the ability of p67phox to bind p47phox . Further work on the formation of the complex will be required to elucidate the exact mechanism by which Rac1 activates superoxide production by the neutrophil oxidase. As with Rac1, Cdc42Hs was found to bind specifically to the 66-68-kDa proteins in neutrophil cytosol and purified p67phox but not the other oxidase components. Cdc42Hs does not activate the oxidase in vitro (Kwong et al., 1993Kwong C.H. Malech H.L. Rotrosen D. Leto T.L. Biochemistry. 1993; 32: 5711-5717Crossref PubMed Scopus (93) Google Scholar), and this suggests that p21 binding to p67phox is not in itself sufficient to cause activation. What then is the function of the Cdc42Hs-p67phox interaction? One possibility is that p67phox could have a function in neutrophils other than being a component of the oxidase. Microinjection of Cdc42Hs induces distinct morphological effects, such as filopodia formation and loss of stress fibers in Swiss 3T3 fibroblasts (Kozma et al., 1995Kozma R. Ahmed S. Best A. Lim L. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1995; 15: 1942-1952Crossref PubMed Scopus (876) Google Scholar). These events are associated with a redistribution of actin polymers. It is therefore possible that p67phox could be a target for Cdc42Hs in a morphological pathway of neutrophils. If this is the case, p67phox could link activation of the neutrophil oxidase with morphological events that are essential for phagocytosis. The demonstration that p67phox is a Cdc42Hs binding protein suggests novel functions for this protein that will require further investigation. The experiments presented here investigating the ability of Cdc42Hs or Rac1 to bind to purified oxidase components utilized microgram quantities of p67phox . Since the abundance of p67phox in neutrophil cytosol is approximately 0.2%,3 it can be estimated that 200 ng is present in the SDS-PAGE analysis of Cdc42Hs and Rac1 binding proteins. This amount of purified recombinant p67phox is not detected even in our dot-blotting assay with Rac1-Q61L as probe while 100 ng of p68 or p65pak is detected. It is therefore likely that the p68 kinase is the major component of the Cdc42Hs and Rac1 binding signals seen in neutrophil cytosol with separation on SDS-PAGE. The relationship between the p66- and p68-kDa proteins in neutrophil cytosol and p65pak was investigated by carrying out a two-dimensional gel analysis of Cdc42Hs binding proteins. Two major protein spots were detected with similar isoelectric points. An almost identical pattern of Cdc42Hs binding proteins was seen when brain cytosol was examined, suggesting that neutrophil protein(s) may be related if not identical to the brain p65. Indeed, purified p68 protein from neutrophil cytosol had kinase activity and could be immunoprecipitated in an autophosphorylated form by anti-p65pak antibodies. To confirm the relationship between p65pak and p68, affinity-purified antibodies were used in Western analysis. p68 was detected by p65pak antibodies but not by p67phox antibodies, demonstrating that p68 is closely related to brain p65. We are presently sequencing peptides of p68 to establish the amino acid sequence identity of this protein to p65. Unlike p68, p48 was not detected by anti-p65pak antibodies, and therefore further work will be necessary to establish its identity. In conclusion, we have been able to identify two targets for the GTP binding proteins Cdc42Hs and Rac1 in neutrophils: a p68 kinase and p67phox . We thank members of the Segal laboratory for the supply of purified proteins and the Glaxo-Singapore Research Fund and Wellcome Trust for financial support.

Activation of the human NADPH oxidase requires the interaction of at least four cytosolic proteins and one membrane-bound heterodimeric protein. Src homology 3 (SH3) domains and their proline-rich counterstructures have been shown to play an important role in protein-protein interactions. Because it was found that the cytosolic oxidase components p67phox, p47phox, and p40phox reside in a complex in resting neutrophils, we studied the role of SH3 domains in their interaction by use of an overlay technique. Wild-type and mutated 35S-labeled p67phox and p47phox were used to detect immobilized cytosolic proteins on a protein blot. A specific association of native p67phox to blotted p47phox and blotted p40phox was found. These interactions were not disturbed by deleting the only proline-rich region (amino acids 227–231) in p67phox. We also found a specific association of native p47phox with blotted p67phox. Deletions in a putative SH3-binding region of p47phox completely abrogated the interaction with p67phox. Other results suggest that the C terminus of p47phox exposes this SH3-binding domain for interaction with p67phox. Similar results were obtained when the binding of cytosolic p67phox to wild-type or mutated p47phox were studied in solution. Interestingly, mutants of p47phox unable to bind to p67phox were fully capable of supporting superoxide production under cell-free activation conditions. We conclude that an interaction between the C-terminal proline-rich region of p47phox and the second SH3 domain of p67phox is not required for oxidase activity in the cell-free assay. Src homology 3 (SH3) domains and their proline-rich counterstructures have been shown to play an important role in protein-protein interactions. These interactions were not disturbed by deleting the only proline-rich region (amino acids 227–231) in p67phox. We also found a specific association of native p47phox with blotted p67phox. The NADPH oxidase of phagocytic cells is an electron transport system that catalyzes the one-electron reduction of oxygen to superoxide (O2⨪), a process essential for the host defense against invading micro-organisms (1Smith R.M. Curnutte J.T. Blood. 1991; 77: 673-686Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). For an active NADPH oxidase, at least five different proteins are required: the membrane-bound cytochrome b558 (consisting of the subunits gp91phox and p22phox) and three cytosolic proteins, p47phox, p67phox, and a low molecular weight GTP-binding protein, either Rac-1 (in macrophages) or Rac-2 (in neutrophils) (2Abo A. Pick E. Hall A. Totty N. Teahan C.G. Segal A.W. Nature. 1991; 353: 668-670Crossref PubMed Scopus (765) Google Scholar, 3Knaus U.G. Heyworth P.G. Kinsella B.T. Curnutte J.T. Bokoch G.M. J. Biol. Chem. 1992; 267: 23575-23582Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Recently, a fourth cytosolic oxidase component has been found, p40phox, which is probably involved in stabilizing p67phox (4Wientjes F.B. Hsuan J.J. Totty N.F. Segal A.W. Biochem. J. 1993; 296: 557-561Crossref PubMed Scopus (260) Google Scholar, 5Tsunawaki S. Mizunari H. Nagata M. Tatsuzawa O. Kuratsuji T. Biochem. Biophys. Res. Commun. 1994; 199: 1378-1387Crossref PubMed Scopus (96) Google Scholar). Upon cell activation, all three cytosolic Phox proteins translocate to the plasma membrane to form the membrane-bound NADPH oxidase (4Wientjes F.B. Hsuan J.J. Totty N.F. Segal A.W. Biochem. J. 1993; 296: 557-561Crossref PubMed Scopus (260) Google Scholar, 6Ambruso D.R. Bolscher B.G.J.M. Stokman P.M. Verhoeven A.J. Roos D. J. Biol. Chem. 1990; 265 (Correction): 924-930J. Biol. Chem. 1990; 265 (Correction): 19370-19371Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 7Clark R.A. Volpp B.D. Leidal K.G. Nauseef W.M. J. Clin. Invest. 1990; 85: 714-721Crossref PubMed Scopus (327) Google Scholar, 8Heyworth P.G. Curnutte J.T. Nauseef W.M. Volpp B.D. Pearson D.W. Rosen H. Clark R.A. J. Clin. Invest. 1991; 87: 352-356Crossref PubMed Scopus (308) Google Scholar). P40phox is not essential for oxidase activity, as is illustrated by a complete reconstitution of oxidase activity in a cell-free assay containing purified cytochrome b558, recombinant p47phox, p67phox, and Rac protein (9Uhlinger D.J. Inge K.L. Kreck M.L. Tyagi S.R. Neckelmann N. Lambeth J.D. Biochem. Biophys. Res. Commun. 1992; 186: 509-516Crossref PubMed Scopus (33) Google Scholar, 10Rotrosen D. Yeung C.L. Katkin J.P. J. Biol. Chem. 1993; 268: 14256-14260Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Sechler J.M.G. Nauseef W.M. Clark R.A. Gallin J.I. Malech H.L. J. 1993; 296: 557-561Crossref PubMed Scopus (260) Google Scholar). In addition, p47phox and p67phox as well as p22phox possess proline-rich regions that are putative SH3 counterstructures (15Parkos C.A. Dinauer M.C. Walker L.E. Allen R.A. Jesaitis A.J. Orkin S.H. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1988; 85: 3319-3323Crossref PubMed Scopus (244) Google Scholar, 16Ren R. Mayer B.J. Cicchetti P. Baltimore D. Science. 1993; 259: 1157-1161Crossref PubMed Scopus (1022) Google Scholar). It is known that the cytosolic components of the NADPH oxidase reside in a complex of 240–300 kDa in the cytosol of resting neutrophils (17Park J.-W. Ma M. Ruedi J.M. Smith R.M. Babior B.M. J. Biol. Chem. 1992; 267: 17327-17332Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 18Park J.-W. Benna J.E. Scott K.E. Christensen B.L. Chanock S.J. Babior B.M. Biochemistry. 1994; 33: 2907-2911Crossref PubMed Scopus (86) Google Scholar). Recently, Finan et al. (19Finan P. Shimizu Y. Gout I. Hsuan J. Truong O. Butcher C. Bennett P. Waterfield M.D. Kellie S. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 13752-13755Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar) showed an interaction between the second SH3 domain of p67phox and p47phox that could be inhibited by peptides resembling the proline-rich region in p47phox. Other investigators have shown that neither of the two SH3 domains of p67phox are required in the cell-free oxidase system, but both are essential for restoration of oxidase activity in Epstein-Barr virus-transformed β lymphocytes that lack p67phox (20De Mendez I. Garrett M.C. Adams A.G. Leto T.L. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 16326-16332Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar) Src homology 3 guanosine 5′-3-O-(thio)triphosphate polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis glutathione S-transferase polymerase chain reaction 4-morpholineethanesulfonic acid chronic granulomatous disease Here, we report that the proline-rich region of p47phox is essential for the interaction with p67phox but not for oxidase activity in the cell-free system. In addition, the C-terminal 13 amino acids of p47phox seem to be important for exposing this proline-rich domain. The proline-rich region in p67phox is not required for interaction with either p47phox or p40phox. Materials—Guanosine 5′-3-O-(thio)triphosphate (GTP7S) and NADPH were purchased from Boehringer (Mannheim, Germany). Reagents and molecular weight markers for SDS-polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis (SDS-PAGE) were from Bio-Rad. BA84 nitrocellulose sheets for Western blotting were obtained from Schleicher & Schuell. Antibodies used in this study were monoclonal antibodies 449 and 48, directed against p22phox and gp91phox, respectively (21Verhoeven A.J. Bolscher B.G.J.M. Meerhof L.J. Van Zwieten R. Keijer J. Weening R.S. Roos D. Blood. 1989; 73: 1686-1694Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). Rabbit antisera specific for either p47phox or p67phox were raised against the C-terminal 12 residues of these proteins. The rabbit antiserum directed against p40phox was a kind gift of Dr. F. Wientjes (Division of Molecular Medicine of University College, London). Goat antiserum directed against glutathione S-transferase (GST) was purchased from Pharmacia (Uppsala, Sweden). Goat-anti-rabbit-IgG, conjugated to horseradish peroxidase, was produced in our institute (CLB, Amsterdam). Rabbit-anti-goat-IgG, conjugated to horseradish peroxidase, was obtained from Sigma. The ECL chemiluminescence kit with luminol was from Amersham International (Amersham, Buckinghamshire, United Kingdom). X-Omat AR diagnostic films were from Kodak. Taq polymerase and dNTPs for PCR were obtained from Promega. The TNT T7-coupled reticulocyte lysate system was purchased from Promega, and the “translational grade” [35S]methionine was from Amersham International. Isolation and Fractionation of Leukocytes—Human neutrophils were isolated from 30 buffy coats of 500-ml blood donations of healthy donors, as described (22Roos D. De Boer M. Methods Enzymol. 1986; 132: 225-243Crossref PubMed Scopus (142) Google Scholar). Subsequently, neutrophils were fractionated by sonication and sucrose-gradient centrifugation as described (23Bolscher B.G.J.M. Van Zwieten R. Kramer I-J.M. Weening R. Verhoeven A.J. Roos D. J. Clin. Invest. 1989; 83: 757-763Crossref PubMed Scopus (54) Google Scholar). For immunodetection, 10 μg of plasma-membrane protein and 20 μg of cytosol protein were dissolved in SDS sample buffer (62.5 mM Tris, pH 6.8, 10% (w/v) SDS, 5% (v/v) 2-mercaptoethanol) and were separated on a 10% polyacrylamide gel according to Laemmli (24Laemmli U.K. Nature. 1970; 227: 680-685Crossref PubMed Scopus (207227) Google Scholar) in a Bio-Rad Mini-Protean II gel apparatus. Western blotting was performed in a mini-Trans-Blot cell according to the manufacturer’s (Bio-Rad) recommendations. Detection of proteins was performed as previously described (25Leusen J.H.W. De Boer M. Bolscher B.G.J.M. Hilarius P.M. Weening R.S. Ochs H.D. Roos D. Verhoeven A.J. J. Clin. Invest. 1994; 95: 2120-2126Crossref Google Scholar). When the blot was stained for two sets of proteins, the nitrocellulose was stripped with 62.5 mM Tris, pH 6.7, 2% SDS, and 100 mM 2-mercaptoethanol after the first immunodetection. Preparation of Rac-2-enriched Cytosol Fraction—Neutrophil cytosol was diluted 5-fold in 10 mM MES buffer, pH 6.8, containing 1 mM EGTA and the protease inhibitors leupeptin (100 μμ) and phenylmethylsulfonyl fluoride (20 μg/ml) and was incubated with ½ volume of CM-Sepharose (Pharmacia), head-over-tail for 1 h at 4 °C (26Bolscher B.G.J.M. Denis S.W. Verhoeven A.J. Roos D. J. Biol. Chem. 1990; 265: 15782-15787Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). The unbound fraction was used as a source of Rac protein in the cell-free assay and was free of p47phox and p67phox as confirmed by immunodetection. Expression of Recombinant p47phox and p67phox—After reverse transcription of RNA extracted from mononuclear leukocytes obtained from six healthy donors, the cDNA of p47phox and p67phox was obtained by PCR and cloned into the pGEX-2T expression vector (Pharmacia), which produces fusion proteins with GST. To improve the efficiency in the regions high in G + C content, 10% 7-deaza-2′-dGTP (Promega) was added in the PCR for p47phox. PCR primers corresponding to each end of the cDNA encoding p47phox contained EcoRI sites, and primers for p67phox contained 5′-EcoRI and 3′-HindIII sites to facilitate cloning. The deletion in p47Δ1, lacking amino acid residues 236–350, was created when the pGEX-p47wt construct was digested with StuI and NheI, which cleave at nucleotide positions 716 and 1206, respectively. The deleted sequence was replaced by two PCR products, the first containing nucleotides 716–1039, with StuI and HindIII sites, and the second containing nucleotides 1060–1206, with HindIII and NheI sites. Instead of the expected amino acid 343–350 deletion, an in-frame deletion of amino acids 236–350 was obtained. The truncated protein p47Δ2, with the C-terminal 13 amino acids removed, was constructed by digesting pGEX-p47wt with SstII and NheI, which cleave at nucleotide positions 1117 and 1206, respectively. The deleted sequence was replaced by complementary synthetic oligonucleotides (5′-GGCCGAGCGCCGACCTCATCCTGAACCGCTGAG-3′ (sense) and 5-CTAGCTCAGCGGTTCAGGATGAGGTCGGCGCTCGGCCGC-3′ (antisense)), which served to link these noncompatible ends and to introduce a stopcodon (underlined). The p47Δ3 and p47Δ4 mutants, lacking amino acids residues 367–380 and 367–390, respectively, were engineered by digesting pGEX-p47wt with NaeI and NheI, which cleave at nucleotide positions 1098 and 1206, respectively. The deleted sequences were replaced by complementary synthetic oligonucleotides (GGCTGTGCCAAGCACCAAGCGGAAGCTGGCGTCTGCCGTCTGAG (sense) and CTAGCTCAGACGGCAGACGCCAGCTTCCGCTTGGTGCTTGGCTCAGCC (antisense) for p47Δ3 and GGCAGTGCGTTGAAGGCCTG (sense) and CTAGCAGGCCTTCAAGGCACTGCC (antisense) for p47Δ4. The deletion of the proline-rich region 227–231 in p67Δ was accomplished by PCR amplification of nucleotides 586–703 with primers GAAGGATTACCTAGGC (sense) and TGAAGATCTCTGGGGTTTTCTCAGCTGCCTGTGG (antisense), containing AvrII and BglII sites (bold print), respectively. The antisense oligonucleotide introduced the deletion of nucleotides 769–784. After digestion with AvrII and BglII, the PCR product and the pGEX-p67 vector were ligated. All pGEX constructs were analyzed by sequencing with the Sequenase version 2.0 system (U. S. Biochemical Corp.). Expression of GST-fusion proteins was performed in Escherichia coli DH5α as previously described (27Smith D.B. Johnson K.S. Gene (Amst.). 1988; 67: 31-40Crossref PubMed Scopus (5047) Google Scholar). The concentration of the various GST-fusion proteins was estimated by measuring GST activity with 1 mM 1-chloro-2,4-dinitrobenzene and 1 mM reduced glutathione in 100 mM potassium phosphate buffer (pH 6.5). Absorbance changes were read at 335 nm. In Vitro Translation—The PGEX inserts encoding p47wt, p47Δ2, p67wt, and p67Δ were cloned into the pGEM-3Zf-vector (Promega) by use of the EeoRI and HindIII sites. For in vitro translation, 1 μg of pGEM plasmid was used in the TNT T7-coupled reticulocyte-lysate translation system (Promega). Translation was performed in the presence of L-[35S]methionine at 30 °C for 90 min, according to the manufacturer’s instructions. To confirm successful protein synthesis, 1/10 of the in vitro translation mixture was subjected to SDS-PAGE followed by autoradiography. Overlay Technique (28)—Neutrophil cytosol and plasma membrane fractions or recombinant proteins were separated by SDS-PAGE and transferred to nitrocellulose. The blot was blocked with 5% w/v low-fat milk powder, 1% (w/v) bovine serum albumin, and 100 mM L-methionine in phosphate-buffered saline for 1 h and washed twice in phosphate-buffered saline and twice in oxidase buffer (10 mM Hepes, 75 mM NaCl, 170 mM sucrose, 1 mM MgCl2, 0.5 mM EGTA, and 2 mM NaN3, pH 7.0). The in vitro translation mixture was 100-fold diluted in oxidase buffer and added to the blot during 2 h at room temperature. Subsequently, the blot was washed five times in oxidase buffer, dried, and subjected to autoradiography for 2–5 days. Binding of GST-p47phox Proteins to Cytosolic p67phox—GST-p47wt, GST-p47Δ1–4, or GST alone (about 50 μg of protein) were incubated in oxidase buffer with 40 μl of 50% (v/v) glutathione-agarose and normal or A47° neutrophil cytosol (900 μg of protein) in the presence or absence of 100 μμ SDS and 10 μμ GTPγS for 1.5 h at 4 °C (total volume 1.5 ml). After washing the beads three times with incubation buffer, the proteins were eluted from the beads with Laemmli sample buffer and subjected to SDS-PAGE on a 10% minigel and immunoblotted for p67phox as described (25Leusen J.H.W. De Boer M. Bolscher B.G.J.M. Hilarius P.M. Weening R.S. Ochs H.D. Roos D. Verhoeven A.J. J. Clin. Invest. 1994; 95: 2120-2126Crossref Google Scholar). Cell-free Oxidase Assay—Measurement of NADPH oxidase activity in cell-free preparations was performed by the superoxide dismutase-sensitive reduction of cytochrome c in a Perkin-Elmer spectrophotometer (model Lambda 2). The contents of six cuvettes measured in parallel were stirred continuously and were thermostated at 28 °C. Plasma membranes (10 μg of protein) were mixed with a Rac-2-enriched cytosol fraction and recombinant p47phox (GST-p47) and recombinant p67phox (GST-p67). The mixture was incubated in 0.8 ml of oxidase buffer containing 60 μμ cytochrome c. After 2 min of incubation, NADPH-oxidase assembly was induced by addition of SDS (100 μμ) and GTPγS (10 μμ). After 5 min, NADPH (250 μμ) was added, and the rate of cytochrome c reduction was measured at 550 nm. Interaction of p47phox and p67phox with Neutrophil Fractions—Because the cytosolic oxidase components p47phox and p67phox are known to interact with the membrane-bound cytochrome b558 (7Clark R.A. Volpp B.D. Leidal K.G. Nauseef W.M. J. Clin. Invest. 1990; 85: 714-721Crossref PubMed Scopus (327) Google Scholar, 8Heyworth P.G. Curnutte J.T. Nauseef W.M. Volpp B.D. Pearson D.W. Rosen H. Clark R.A. J. Clin. Invest. 1991; 87: 352-356Crossref PubMed Scopus (308) Google Scholar), we aimed to study this interaction with an overlay technique. Therefore, neutrophil plasma-membrane proteins were separated by SDS-PAGE and transferred to nitrocellulose. The blot was then incubated with in vitro generated p47phox or p67phox, which had incorporated [35S]methionine. As Fig. 1 shows, no binding to gp91phox or p22phox was detected by either cytosolic protein (panels A and B, lanes 1). This result might indicate that the cytosolic proteins do not interact with cytochrome b558 in resting cells. Therefore, also plasma membranes isolated from phorbol 12-myristate 13-acetate-stimulated neutrophils were used. Again, no binding was detected with either subunit of cytochrome b558 (Fig. 1, panels A and B, lanes 3). However, the overlay with labeled p47phox showed a weak binding to a 67-kDa band (panel A, lane 3), which also stained with an antiserum against p67phox (panel D, lane 3). The overlay with labeled p67phox showed two weak bands at 47 and 40 kDa (panel B, lane 3), which also stained with antisera directed against p47phox and p40phox (panel D, lane 3). Probably, these bands are the cytosolic oxidase proteins, translocated to the plasma membrane upon neutrophil activation. When cytosol of resting neutrophils was investigated with this technique, a 67-kDa band was clearly detected in the overlay with p47phox (Fig. 1, panel A, lane 2). In addition, 47- and 40-kDa bands were present in the overlay with p67phax (Fig. 1, panel B, lane 2). Again, the antisera against the three cytosolic Phox components detected proteins with the same mobility (Fig. 1, panel D, lane 2). Overlay with Neutrophil Cytosol from CGD Patients—To establish the identity of the proteins in the neutrophil cytosol that bound labeled p47phox and p67phox, we used cytosol from neutrophils of CGD patients, lacking either p47phox (A47O) or p67phox (A67O) Fig 2, panel A, shows that labeled p67phox bound to both 47- and 40-kDa bands in neutrophil cytosol from a healthy donor (lane 1) but only weakly to a band at 40 kDa in cytosol from the A47° patient (lane 2). In the cytosol of the A67O patient, the 47-kDa band was clearly detected, but the 40-kDa band appeared to be almost absent (lane 3). This agrees with the finding that p40phox is diminished or absent in A67° CGD patients (4Wientjes F.B. Hsuan J.J. Totty N.F. Segal A.W. Biochem. J. 1993; 296: 557-561Crossref PubMed Scopus (260) Google Scholar, 5Tsunawaki S. Mizunari H. Nagata M. Tatsuzawa O. Kuratsuji T. Biochem. Biophys. Res. Commun. 1994; 199: 1378-1387Crossref PubMed Scopus (96) Google Scholar). When the binding of p47phox was studied in these cytosol fractions (Fig. 2B), a 67-kDa band was found in the blotted cytosol of a healthy donor and of a CGD patient lacking p47phox but not of an A67° patient. Again, the bands were verified by immunostaining (Fig. 2C). Effect of Antibodies on the Overlay—To study the regions of the proteins important in these interactions, we first investigated whether antisera directed against the last 12 residues of p47phox and p67phox could interfere Fig 3 snows a blot of recombinant p47phox and p67phox as fusion proteins with the 26-kDa GST (GST-p47 and GST-p67, respectively). When blotted GST-p47 was preincubated with an anti-p47 antiserum and overlaid with labeled p67phox, no effect of the antiserum was observed (lane 3). However, when labeled p47phox was preincubated with the antiserum, binding to GST-p67 on the blot was almost completely blocked (lane 6). In contrast, the anti-p67phox antiserum did not interfere with the binding of p67phox to p47phox (lanes 4 and 5) To verify the presence of recombinant protein in all lanes, the blot was also immunostained (right part of Fig. 3). Deletion Mutants of p47phox and p67phox—To investigate the regions important for the binding between p47phox and p67phox in more detail, four deletion mutants of p47phox and one deletion mutant of p67phox were constructed. Fig. 4A shows a schematic representation of the deleted regions with respect to the SH3 domains and proline-rich stretches that might act as SH3-binding domains. The mutated proteins were expressed as fusion proteins to GST, purified, and subjected to SDS-PAGE followed by protein staining. The result is shown in Fig. 4B. The observed shifts in mobility agree with the deletions. Effect of Deletions in p47phox on Interaction with p67phox—Blotted GST-p47wt and deletion mutants were overlaid with labeled p67phox. Fig. 5A shows normal binding of p67phox to GST-p47wt and GST-p47Δ1, reduced binding to GST-p47Δ2, and no binding to GST-p47Δ3 and GST-p47Δ4. These results are in agreement with the recent finding of Finan et al. (19Finan P. Shimizu Y. Gout I. Hsuan J. Truong O. Butcher C. Bennett P. Waterfield M.D. Kellie S. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 13752-13755Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar) that the SH3-binding domain of p47phox binds directly to p67phox. Panel β of Fig. 5 shows that blotted GST-p67 can bind to p47wt but not to p47Δ2. This result agrees with the blocking by the anti-p47 antibody in Fig. 3. Apparently, the C-terminal part of p47phox is important in the binding to p67phox, especially when p47phox is in solution. Because the overlay technique requires that one of the proteins is denatured, we also performed binding experiments with both p47phox and p67phox in solution. Fig. 6 shows the binding of cytosolic p67phox to GST-p47wt, GST-p47 deletion mutants, or GST alone in the presence or absence of SDS and GTPγS. Without these activators, the results were similar to the overlay experiments. GST-p47wt and GST-p47Δ1 bound a considerable amount of p67phox, whereas GST-p47Δ2 bound much less p67phox, and GST-p47Δ3 and Δ4 did not bind any p67phox (Fig. 6A). With SDS and GTPγS, these last two deletion mutants showed an increased binding of p67phox, but this was also observed with GST alone (Fig. 6B). To rule out the possibility that most of the p67phox in the cytosol was already complexed to cytosolic p47phox and therefore not able to participate in binding to the GST fusion proteins, we repeated the experiment with A47° cytosol, with the same results as described above. Effect of Deletion of Proline-rich Domain of p67phox—The deletion mutant of p67phox was tested in the overlay assay; the result is shown in Fig. 7. Panel A shows neutrophil cytosol of healthy donors on a blot, overlaid with p67wt (lane 1) or p67Δ (lane 2). Both proteins bound to p47phox and p40phox. Also, when GST-p67wt and GST-p67Δ were blotted and probed with 35S-labeled p47phox, no difference was observed between the interactions of p47phox with the wild type or the deletion mutant of p67phox (Fig. 7, right panel). Cell-free Oxidase Assay with Recombinant Proteins—We measured the rate of superoxide production induced by the recombinant proteins GST-p47 and GST-p67 in a cell-free system with plasma membranes and a crude cytosol fraction as a source of Rac-2 protein. The results are shown in Fig. 8. Only p47Δ1, lacking a large part of the second SH3 domain, showed a significantly reduced potency of inducing superoxide production (about 24% of the control value). All other deletion mutants exhibited a normal oxidase-inducing activity. It is well established that so-called SH3 domains are involved in protein-protein interactions (13Koch C.A. Anderson D. Moran M.F. Ellis C. Pawson T. Science. 1991; 252: 668-674Crossref PubMed Scopus (1438) Google Scholar, 14Musacchio A. Gibson T. Lehto V.P. Saraste M. FEBS Lett. 1992; 307: 55-61Crossref PubMed Scopus (235) Google Scholar). The counter structure for these SH3 domains has been identified as proline-rich stretches found in various proteins (16Ren R. Mayer B.J. Cicchetti P. Baltimore D. Science. 1993; 259: 1157-1161Crossref PubMed Scopus (1022) Google Scholar). Both p47phox and p67phox of the NADPH oxidase contain two SH3 domains and one putative SH3-binding domain. Of the two membrane-bound cytochrome b558 subunits, only p22phox contains such a putative SH3-binding domain, comprising residues 149–162. We aimed at studying the interaction of the cytosolic oxidase proteins with the membrane-bound cytochrome b558 by using an overlay technique, as described in Ref. 19Finan P. Shimizu Y. Gout I. Hsuan J. Truong O. Butcher C. Bennett P. Waterfield M.D. Kellie S. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 13752-13755Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar. However, neither p47phox nor p67phox bound to either p22phox or gp91phox on a blot (Fig. 1). Possibly, regions on both subunits of cytochrome b558 are required for a stable interaction with the cytosolic proteins. This concurs with the observation that single mutations in either subunit of cytochrome b558 can lead to total absence of translocation of p47phox and p67phox upon cell activation. This was shown for an X91+ CGD patient with a Asp500 → Gly substitution in gp91phox (25Leusen J.H.W. De Boer M. Bolscher B.G.J.M. Hilarius P.M. Weening R.S. Ochs H.D. Roos D. Verhoeven A.J. J. Clin. Invest. 1994; 95: 2120-2126Crossref Google Scholar) and for an A22+ CGD patient with a Pro156 → Gln substitution in a proline-rich region of p22phox (29Leusen J.H.W. Bolscher B.G.J.M. Hilarius P.M. Weening R.S. Kaulfersch W. Seger R.A. Roos D. Verhoeven A.J. J. Exp. Med. 1994; 180: 2329-2334Crossref PubMed Scopus (90) Google Scholar). This latter finding is confirmed by the results of Sumimoto et al. (30Sumimoto H. Kage Y. Nunoi H. Sasaki H. Nose T. Fukumaki Y. Ohno M. Minakami S. Takeshige K. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1994; 91: 5345-5349Crossref PubMed Scopus (256) Google Scholar), who found an interaction between the SH3 domains of p47phox and the proline-rich region of p22phox, both expressed as fusion proteins with GST. The Pro156 → Gln substitution abolished this interaction. The cytosolic oxidase components p47phox and p67phox appear to reside in a complex of 240–300 kDa in the cytosol of resting neutrophils (17Park J.-W. Ma M. Ruedi J.M. Smith R.M. Babior B.M. J. Biol. Chem. 1992; 267: 17327-17332Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 18Park J.-W. Benna J.E. Scott K.E. Christensen B.L. Chanock S.J. Babior B.M. Biochemistry. 1994; 33: 2907-2911Crossref PubMed Scopus (86) Google Scholar). We studied this interaction by using an overlay technique; soluble p47phox bound to a 67-kDa protein in blotted neutrophil cytosol that was absent from p67phox deficient cytosol, and soluble p67phox bound to a blotted 47- and 40-kDa protein. The former band was absent in p47phox-deficient cytosol, and the latter band was described as the novel cytosolic oxidase component p40phox that is thought to play a role in stabilizing p67phox (4Wientjes F.B. Hsuan J.J. Totty N.F. Segal A.W. Biochem. J. 1993; 296: 557-561Crossref PubMed Scopus (260) Google Scholar, 5Tsunawaki S. Mizunari H. Nagata M. Tatsuzawa O. Kuratsuji T. Biochem. Biophys. Res. Commun. 1994; 199: 1378-1387Crossref PubMed Scopus (96) Google Scholar). To explore the regions of p47phox and p67phox that play a role in these interactions, we studied the effect of antibodies directed against the C termini of p47phox and p67phnx, and we constructed deletion mutants of these proteins. An antiserum directed against the C terminus of p67phox had no effect, but an antiserum directed against the last 12 residues of p47phox blocked the binding of soluble p47phox to recombinant p67phox immobilized on a blot almost completely (Fig. 3). However, this antiserum had no effect on the binding of soluble p67phox to blotted recombinant p47phox (denatured by SDS), although the antiserum did bind to this denatured p47phox. This suggests that the C terminus of p47phox has no primary function in the binding to p67phox. This was confirmed by the experiments with the truncated protein p47Δ2, which lacks the last 13 residues. Soluble p67phox bound to blotted p47Δ2, but binding of soluble p47Δ2 to blotted GST-p67 was not detected (Fig. 5). Deletion of a large part of the second SH3 domain of p47phox in p47Δ1 had no effect on the interaction with p67phox. However, the putative SH3-binding domain of p47phox is essential for the interaction with p67phox, as demonstrated with p47Δ3 and p47Δ4. These mutated proteins lack a part of the proline-rich region of p47phox, which was mapped by Finan et al. (19Finan P. Shimizu Y. Gout I. Hsuan J. Truong O. Butcher C. Bennett P. Waterfield M.D. Kellie S. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 13752-13755Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar), with use of synthetic peptides as being the counterstructure in p47phox of the C-terminal SH3 domain of p67phox. In addition, our results indicate that the last 13 amino acids of p47phox are required to expose its proline-rich region for binding to p67phox. Similar results were obtained with an assay that allows interaction between p47phox and p67phox both in solution (Fig. 6A), which strongly suggests that the proline-rich region of p47phox is the only important domain for interaction with p67phox The addition of SDS and GTPγS as cell-free activators did not change the characteristics of the binding of p47p to p67phox, although a specific binding of p67phox was observed (Fig. 6B). It has been suggested by Wientjes et al. (4Wientjes F.B. Hsuan J.J. Totty N.F. Segal A.W. Biochem. J. 1993; 296: 557-561Crossref PubMed Scopus (260) Google Scholar) that the interaction between p40phox and p67phox is based on the SH3 domain of p40phox and a proline-rich region PPPRPKTP (residues 227–234) of p67phox. To test this hypothesis, we constructed p67Δ, lacking residues 227–231, and used it in an overlay experiment with blotted neutrophil cytosol (Fig. 7). However, no effect of this deletion on the binding of p67phox to p40phox or p47phox was observed. Also, this deletion had no effect on the potency of p67phox to induce superoxide production (Fig. 8). Because no other proline-rich regions are present in p67phox, the nature of the binding between p40phox and p67phox remains to be elucidated. Interestingly, no correlation was found for the p47phox mutants between the ability to bind p67phox and the superoxide-inducing capacity in the cell-free assay. For instance, p47Δ1, which bound p67phox normally, induced only little superoxide production (Fig. 8). This latter effect might be explained by a defective association with the SH3-binding domain in p22phox because the second SH3 domain is largely removed in this p47phox mutant. For p47Δ3 and p47Δ4, the opposite is true; they did not interact with p67phox, but they did induce a normal superoxide production in the cell-free assay (Fig. 8). Hence, the proline-rich region of p47phox, important for p67phox binding, is not required in the assembled NADPH oxidase. This strongly suggests that a complex of the cytosolic Phox proteins is not required for activity in the cell-free system. However, our studies do not exclude that during activation of the NADPH oxidase regions become exposed that mediate other interactions between p47phox and p67phox. In conclusion, the interaction between the cytosolic Phox proteins can conveniently be studied with the overlay technique as a model for the resting situation in the human cytosol. However, a complex of cytosolic Phox proteins does not seem to be required for activity in the cell-free assay. Obviously, it would be interesting to test in intact cells the mutated p47phox proteins that have been found in this study to be deficient in p67phox binding. These studies are currently carried out in our laboratory.

The TATA-binding protein (TBP) plays a key role in transcription initiation. Several negative cofactors (NC1, NC2, and Dr1) are known to interact with TBP in a manner that prevents productive interactions of transcription factors TFIIA and TFIIB with promoter-bound TBP. To gain insights into the regulatory interplay on the surface of TBP, we have employed mutant forms of TBP to identify amino acid residues important for interactions with the negative regulatory cofactor NC2 and the general factor TFIIB. The results show the involvement of distinct domains of TBP in these interactions. Residues (Lys-133, Lys-145, and Lys-151) in the basic repeat region are important for interactions with NC2, as well as with TFIIA (Buratowski, S., and Zhou, H. (1992) Science 255, 1130-1132; Lee, D. K., DeJong, J., Hashimoto, S., Horikoshi, M., and Roeder, R. G. (1992) Mol. Cell. Biol. 12, 5189-5196), whereas a residue (Leu-189) in the second stirrup-like loop spanning S2’ and S3’ is required for interaction with TFIIB. In addition, we demonstrate that NC2 is identical to the previously cloned negative cofactor Dr1. The implications of these results for TBP structure and function are discussed. The TATA-binding protein (TBP) plays a key role in transcription initiation. Several negative cofactors (NC1, NC2, and Dr1) are known to interact with TBP in a manner that prevents productive interactions of transcription factors TFIIA and TFIIB with promoter-bound TBP. To gain insights into the regulatory interplay on the surface of TBP, we have employed mutant forms of TBP to identify amino acid residues important for interactions with the negative regulatory cofactor NC2 and the general factor TFIIB. The results show the involvement of distinct domains of TBP in these interactions. Residues (Lys-133, Lys-145, and Lys-151) in the basic repeat region are important for interactions with NC2, as well as with TFIIA (Buratowski, S., and Zhou, H. (1992) Science 255, 1130-1132; Lee, D. K., DeJong, J., Hashimoto, S., Horikoshi, M., and Roeder, R. G. (1992) Mol. Cell. Biol. 12, 5189-5196), whereas a residue (Leu-189) in the second stirrup-like loop spanning S2’ and S3’ is required for interaction with TFIIB. In addition, we demonstrate that NC2 is identical to the previously cloned negative cofactor Dr1. The implications of these results for TBP structure and function are discussed.

Humans possess five classes of alcohol dehydrogenase (ADH), including forms able to oxidize ethanol or formaldehyde as part of a defense mechanism, as well as forms acting as retinol dehydrogenases in the synthesis of the regulatory ligand retinoic acid. However, the mouse has previously been shown to possess only three forms of ADH. Hybridization analysis of mouse genomic DNA using cDNA probes specific for each of the five classes of human ADH has now indicated that mouse DNA cross-hybridizes to only classes I, III, and IV. With human class II or class V ADH cDNA probes, hybridization to mouse genomic DNA was very weak or undetectable, suggesting either a lack of these genes in the mouse or a high degree of mutational divergence relative to the human genes. cDNAs for murine ADH classes I and III have previously been cloned, and we now report the cloning of a full-length mouse class IV ADH cDNA. In Northern blot analyses, mouse class IV ADH mRNA was abundant in the stomach, eye, skin, and ovary, thus correlating with the expression pattern for the mouse Adh-3 gene previously determined by enzyme analysis. In situ hybridization studies on mouse stomach indicated that class IV ADH transcripts were abundant in the mucosal epithelium but absent from the muscular layer. Comparison of the expression patterns for all three mouse ADH genes indicated that class III was expressed ubiquitously, whereas classes I and IV were differentially expressed in an overlapping set of tissues that all contain a large component of epithelial cells. This expression pattern is consistent with the ability of classes I and IV to oxidize retinol for the synthesis of retinoic acid known to regulate epithelial cell differentiation. The results presented here indicate that the mouse has a simpler ADH gene family than the human but has conserved class IV ADH previously shown to be a very active retinol dehydrogenase in humans. Amino acid sequence comparisons between the five classes of human ADH have revealed interclass sequence identities in the 57-69% range, indicating divergence from a common progenitor about 450 million years ago during early vertebrate evolution (Satre et al., 1994Satre M.A. gombi-Knight M. Duester G. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 15606-15612Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). All classes of vertebrate ADH as well as all other medium chain ADHs (i.e. 35-40 kDa) found in bacteria, yeast, plants, and invertebrates have arisen from duplication and divergence of a primordial class III ADH gene, which encodes a glutathione-dependent formaldehyde dehydrogenase found ubiquitously in all organisms analyzed (Koivusalo et al., 1989Koivusalo M. Baumann M. Uotila L. FEBS Lett. 1989; 257: 105-109Crossref PubMed Scopus (288) Google Scholar; Danielsson and Jörnvall, 1992Danielsson O. Jörnvall H. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S.
