Methods Clathrin cage binding assays were carried out as described (3Ye W. Lafer E.M. J. Neurosci. Res. 1995; 41: 15-26Crossref PubMed Scopus (70) Google Scholar, 35Lindner R. Ungewickell E. Biochemistry. 1991; 30: 9097-9101Crossref PubMed Scopus (18) Google Scholar), except that all the GST-fusion proteins were used at 20 μM, clathrin was used at 1.8 μM (corresponding to molarity of triskelia; 1.2 mg/ml), and all of the binding reactions were carried out in isolation buffer (0.1 M MES, 1 mM EGTA, 0.5 mM MgCl2, 0.1 mM PMSF, pH 6.7). The samples were analyzed by SDS-PAGE followed by Coomassie Blue staining and Western blot analysis. The Western blots were stained with a monoclonal antibody against GST (“GST (12Keen J.H. J. Cell Biol. 1987; 105: 1989-1998Crossref PubMed Scopus (125) Google Scholar)” from Santa Cruz Biotechnology, Inc.) and visualized utilizing the ECL detection method, as described (27Zhou S. Tannery N.H. Yang J. Puszkin S. Lafer E.M. J. Biol. Chem. 1993; 268: 12655-12662Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). The distribution of the GST-fusion proteins between the pellet and supernatant fractions was quantitated using the Millipore BioImage system with 3cx scanner. Values given in the text for the percent fusion protein bound represent: the percent fusion protein in the pellet in the sample containing clathrin - the percent fusion protein in the pellet in the parallel reaction not containing clathrin. GST-AP-3, GST-C58 kDa, GST-M42 kDa, GST-C16 kDa, and GST were each bound to glutathione-Sepharose (Pharmacia Biotech Inc.) (3Ye W. Lafer E.M. J. Neurosci. Res. 1995; 41: 15-26Crossref PubMed Scopus (70) Google Scholar). Rather then eluting the bound proteins with glutathione, each resin was then equilibrated with ice-cold isolation buffer (0.1 M MES, 1 mM EGTA, 0.5 mM MgCl2, pH 6.7) containing 0.1 mM PMSF and 0.01% gelatin. 0.4 mg/ml clathrin triskelia in isolation buffer were incubated with an equal volume of each resin at 4°C for 2 h with rocking. The resins were pelleted by a 5-s microcentrifugation, and the supernatants were removed. The supernatants were labeled F for flow-through in Fig. 2 and correspond to the unbound material. The resins were washed six times with an equal volume of ice-cold isolation buffer containing 0.1 mM PMSF and 0.01% gelatin. The last wash was found to be free of clathrin by Western blot analysis using the clathrin heavy chain-specific monoclonal antibody F21-5, indicating that all nonspecifically bound material was removed. The beads were then eluted by boiling for 5 min in an equal volume of 1 × SDS sample buffer, followed by a 5-s microcentrifugation, and the supernatants were removed. These supernatants were labeled B for bound material in Fig. 2. All of the samples were analyzed by SDS-PAGE, followed by Coomassie Blue staining and Western blot analysis using the clathrin heavy chain-specific monoclonal antibody F21-5 with the ECL detection system. A parallel set of experiments was carried out using 0.4 mg/ml BSA instead of clathrin triskelia in the incubation mix to ensure that the resins did not nonspecifically bind to proteins in the solution. These blots were blocked with 0.10% gelatin instead of BSA and stained with a monoclonal anti-BSA antibody (Sigma B2901). 3 μM clathrin triskelia were dialyzed overnight at 4°C against isolation buffer with the addition of 20 μM of either GST, GST-AP-3, GST-C58 kDa, GST-M42 kDa, GST-C16 kDa, GST-N33 kDa, or GST, as indicated in the figure legend to Fig. 3. Following a 3-min centrifugation at 13,600 × g to remove nonspecific aggregates, newly assembled clathrin cages were pelleted by ultracentrifugation for 20 min at 100,000 × g. The pellet (P) and supernatant (S) fractions were analyzed by SDS-PAGE, followed by Coomassie Blue staining and Western blot analysis using the anti-clathrin heavy chain-specific monoclonal antibody F21-5. The distribution of clathrin heavy chain between the pellet and supernatant fractions was quantitated using the Millipore BioImage system with 3cx scanner. For the quantitative assembly plot (Fig. 4), assays were carried out as described above, except that the concentration of test assembly protein was varied, as indicated on the plot. Each point on the plot represents the average of triplicate determinations. The morphology of the products of the assembly assays using either 20 μM GST-AP-3, 20 μM GST-C58 kDa, or 20 μM GST were evaluated by negative staining electron microscopy, as described (3Ye W. Lafer E.M. J. Neurosci. Res. 1995; 41: 15-26Crossref PubMed Scopus (70) Google Scholar).Figure 4:The 58-kDa C-terminal region of AP-3 assembles clathrin as efficiently as full-length AP-3. Quantitative assembly assays were carried out as described under “Experimental Procedures.” 3 μM clathrin triskelia were dialyzed overnight at 4°C against isolation buffer with the addition of one of the following test assembly proteins at the concentrations indicated in the figure: GST-AP-3 (closed circle), GST-C58 kDa (open circle), GST-C16 kDa (closed square), GST-M42 kDa (closed triangle), or GST (×). Each data point represents the mean from three experiments with the error bars representing the standard deviations derived from three experiments.View Large Image Figure ViewerDownload Hi-res image Download (PPT) Previous studies had demonstrated that bacterially expressed AP-3 could bind to clathrin cages, whereas the 33-kDa N-terminal region of AP-3 (amino acid residues 1-304) could not bind to clathrin cages (3Ye W. Lafer E.M. J. Neurosci. Res. 1995; 41: 15-26Crossref PubMed Scopus (70) Google Scholar). Consequently, we examined the ability of the 58 kDa C-terminal region (amino acid residues 305-901), the 42 kDa central region (amino acid residues 305-744), and the 16 kDa C-terminal region (amino acid residues 745-901) of AP-3 to bind to preassembled clathrin cages (Fig. 1). In this assay, the ability of the indicated GST fusion proteins to co-sediment with the pre-assembled clathrin cages was monitored by Western blot analysis with an anti-GST monoclonal antibody, and subjected to a quantitative analysis, as described under “Experimental Procedures.” Consistent with previous observations (3Ye W. Lafer E.M. J. Neurosci. Res. 1995; 41: 15-26Crossref PubMed Scopus (70) Google Scholar) we found 88% binding of GST-AP-3 (lanes 1-4) (positive control) and 0.2% binding of GST-N33 kDa (lanes 5-8) (negative control) to the clathrin cages. In experiments utilizing the newly expressed domains, we found 86% GST-C58 kDa (lanes 9-12), 42% GST-M42 kDa (lanes 13-16), and 51% GST-C16 kDa (lanes 17-20) bound to the clathrin cages. The GST negative control showed 0% binding to the clathrin cages (lanes 21-24). We conclude that the 58-kDa C-terminal region, the 42-kDa central region, and 16-kDa C-terminal region of AP-3 all bind to clathrin cages. Previously, we showed that the bacterially expressed 33-kDa N-terminal region of AP-3 could bind to clathrin triskelia, but could not assemble clathrin triskelia into cages or bind to preassembled clathrin cages (3Ye W. Lafer E.M. J. Neurosci. Res. 1995; 41: 15-26Crossref PubMed Scopus (70) Google Scholar). This suggested that binding to clathrin triskelia and clathrin cages were not functionally equivalent. In the present study, we examined the ability of the 58-kDa C-terminal region, the 42-kDa central region, and the 16-kDa C-terminal region of AP-3 to bind to clathrin triskelia. For these experiments, we coupled proteins GST-AP-3, GST-C58 kDa, GST-M42 kDa, GST-C16 kDa, and GST to glutathione-Sepharose. A solution of clathrin triskelia, or as a control a solution of BSA, was incubated with each resin. The resins were washed to remove nonspecifically bound protein, followed by solubilization of the bound material by boiling each resin in SDS-sample buffer. The flow-through (labeled F) and bound (labeled B) fractions were analyzed by SDS-PAGE (Fig. 2). The gels in the top panel were stained for total protein with Coomassie Blue, and the gels in the bottom panel were transferred to nitrocellulose and stained with either an anti-clathrin heavy chain-specific monoclonal antibody (lanes 1-10) or anti-BSA monoclonal antibody (lanes 11-20). Note that the GST fusion proteins also eluted from the resins by boiling in SDS-sample buffer and showed up in the Coomassie Blue-stained gels. None of the resins retained the BSA (lanes 11-20), indicating that the resins did not nonspecifically bind to proteins. In experiments utilizing GST-AP-3 and GST-C58 kDa resins, all the clathrin triskelia were found in the bound fractions (lanes 1-4). This confirmed that GST-AP-3 can bind to clathrin triskelia and demonstrated that GST-C58 kDa can bind to clathrin triskelia. In experiments utilizing GST-M42 kDa resin, clathrin triskelia were found both in the flow-through fraction (lane 5) and bound fraction (lane 6). This indicated binding between clathrin triskelia and GST-M42 kDa. In experiments utilizing either GST-C16 kDa, or GST (negative control), essentially all of the clathrin triskelia were found in the flow-through fractions (lanes 7-10), indicating that clathrin triskelia did not bind to either of these proteins under these assay conditions. We also increased the concentration of clathrin in the assay by a factor of 3 (1.2 mg/ml) and were still unable to detect any binding of clathrin triskelia to GST-C16 kDa. It had been shown previously that bacterially expressed GST-AP-3 could assemble clathrin triskelia into cages, whereas the bacterially expressed 33-kDa N-terminal region of AP-3 was insufficient for clathrin assembly (3Ye W. Lafer E.M. J. Neurosci. Res. 1995; 41: 15-26Crossref PubMed Scopus (70) Google Scholar). In order to further localize the regions of AP-3 required for clathrin assembly, we compared the ability of GST-AP-3, GST-C58 kDa, GST-M42 kDa, GST-C16 kDa, GST-N33 kDa, and GST to assemble clathrin triskelia into clathrin cages. In this assay, we monitored clathrin assembly as the movement of clathrin from a 100,000 × g soluble form (triskelia) to a 100,000 × g insoluble form (cages) following dialysis with a test assembly protein (Fig. 3). In the gel displayed, it is clear that clathrin moves from the supernatant to the pellet in the presence of GST-AP-3 (lanes 1 and 2) or GST-C58 kDa (lanes 3 and 4), indicative of clathrin assembly. However, no movement of clathrin is seen from the supernatant to the pellet in the presence of GST-M42 kDa (lanes 5 and 6), GST-C16 kDa (lanes 7 and 8), or GST-N33 kDa (lanes 9 and 10), compared with the negative control GST (lanes 11 and 12). When these experiments were carried out over a wider range of protein concentrations, and subjected to a quantitative analysis (Fig. 4), it was found that the 58-kDa C-terminal region of AP-3 assembles clathrin as well as the full-length protein. No significant clathrin assembly was found by GST-M42 kDa, GST-C16 kDa, GST-N33 kDa, or GST. A hallmark of factor-dependent clathrin assembly is the homogeneity of the cages formed. Analysis of the morphology of the cages assembled in the experiment shown in Fig. 3 is presented in Fig. 5. It is apparent that no cages were formed with GST (Fig. 5 A) and that both GST-AP-3 (Fig. 5 B) and GST-C58 kDa (Fig. 5 C) assembled clathrin triskelia into a homogeneous population of clathrin cages. We conclude that the 58-kDa C-terminal region of AP-3 is sufficient to assemble clathrin triskelia into clathrin cages. The results of the study presented here were integrated with the previously published studies, to prepare a summary of structure-function relationships for AP-3 (Fig. 6). These relationships are diagrammed against the distribution of acidic and basic residues in the primary structure of AP-3. Previously, it was reported that the 33-kDa N-terminal region of AP-3 contained a high affinity binding site for specific inositol polyphosphates, with similar binding parameters as full-length AP-3 (33Ye W. Ali N. Bembenek M. Shears S.B. Lafer E.M. J. Biol. Chem. 1995; 270: 1564-1568Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (160) Google Scholar). We show that the 58-kDa C-terminal region of AP-3 is able to bind to clathrin triskelia and assemble them into a homogeneous population of clathrin cages and will also bind to preassembled clathrin cages. We also show that the clathrin triskelia binding, clathrin cage binding, and clathrin assembly activities of the 58-kDa C-terminal region of AP-3 are essentially indistinguishable from that of the full-length protein. We found that the 42-kDa central region of AP-3 can bind to both clathrin triskelia and to clathrin cages, but cannot assemble clathrin triskelia into clathrin cages. We found that the 16-kDa C-terminal region of AP-3 can bind to clathrin cages, but cannot bind to clathrin triskelia or assemble clathrin triskelia into clathrin cages. We noted that the clathrin binding activities of the 42-kDa central region and 16-kDa C-terminal region are weaker than the corresponding activity of either the 58-kDa C-terminal region or full-length AP-3. Previous efforts had mapped a clathrin binding site within the N-terminal 33 kDa of AP-3 (1Murphy J.E. Pleasure I.T. Puszkin S. Prasad K. Keen J.H. J. Biol. Chem. 1991; 266: 4401-4408Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 2Morris S.A. Schroder S. Plessmann U. Weber K. Ungewickell E. EMBO J. 1993; 12: 667-675Crossref PubMed Scopus (92) Google Scholar). However, although the N-terminal 33 kDa of AP-3 is able to bind to clathrin triskelia (1Murphy J.E. Pleasure I.T. Puszkin S. Prasad K. Keen J.H. J. Biol. Chem. 1991; 266: 4401-4408Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 3Ye W. Lafer E.M. J. Neurosci. Res. 1995; 41: 15-26Crossref PubMed Scopus (70) Google Scholar), it does not promote their assembly into clathrin cages (1Murphy J.E. Pleasure I.T. Puszkin S. Prasad K. Keen J.H. J. Biol. Chem. 1991; 266: 4401-4408Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 3Ye W. Lafer E.M. J. Neurosci. Res. 1995; 41: 15-26Crossref PubMed Scopus (70) Google Scholar) or bind to preassembled clathrin cages (3Ye W. Lafer E.M. J. Neurosci. Res. 1995; 41: 15-26Crossref PubMed Scopus (70) Google Scholar). It appears that the smallest functional unit that carries out all of the reported clathrin binding and assembly properties of AP-3, essentially as well as the full-length protein, is the 58-kDa C-terminal region. The data presented in this study allow us to consider alternative interpretations to previously published studies. In clathrin cage binding assays utilizing a partial trypsin digestion of AP-3, bands with apparent molecular masses of 148, 107, and 33 kDa were found to co-sediment with preassembled clathrin cages (2Morris S.A. Schroder S. Plessmann U. Weber K. Ungewickell E. EMBO J. 1993; 12: 667-675Crossref PubMed Scopus (92) Google Scholar). Sequencing of the digestion products revealed that the 33-kDa fragment corresponded to the 33-kDa N-terminal region of AP-3 and that the 107-kDa apparent molecular mass fragment began at amino acid 304. The interpretation presented was that the 33-kDa N-terminal region bound specifically to the cages and that the 107-kDa apparent molecular mass fragment was only retained by the cages due to a noncovalent association with the 33-kDa N-terminal fragment. Our demonstration of clathrin cage binding by the 58-kDa C-terminal region, the 42-kDa central region, and the 16-kDa C-terminal region, coupled with the lack of clathrin cage binding by the 33-kDa N-terminal region (3Ye W. Lafer E.M. J. Neurosci. Res. 1995; 41: 15-26Crossref PubMed Scopus (70) Google Scholar), suggest an alternative interpretation of these proteolysis studies. Possibly it was the 107-kDa apparent molecular mass fragment that was bound specifically to the cages, and the 33-kDa N-terminal fragment was only retained by the cages due to a noncovalent association with the 107-kDa apparent molecular mass fragment. Similarly, in the clathrin triskelia binding assays in which it was shown that the 33-kDa N-terminal region could bind to clathrin triskelia, some retention by the clathrin-Sepharose of a 135-kDa apparent molecular mass fragment and a 100-kDa apparent molecular mass fragment were also observed (1Murphy J.E. Pleasure I.T. Puszkin S. Prasad K. Keen J.H. J. Biol. Chem. 1991; 266: 4401-4408Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). It was suggested that the 100-kDa apparent molecular mass fragment was not bound directly to the clathrin triskelia, but was retained by a noncovalent association with the 33-kDa N-terminal fragment. Our data allow one to consider the possibility that both the 33-kDa N-terminal fragment and 100-kDa apparent molecular mass fragment were specifically retained by the clathrin-Sepharose. Analysis (27Zhou S. Tannery N.H. Yang J. Puszkin S. Lafer E.M. J. Biol. Chem. 1993; 268: 12655-12662Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 36Garnier J. Osguthorpe D.J. Robson B. J. Mol. Biol. 1978; 120: 97-120Crossref PubMed Scopus (3417) Google Scholar) of the amino acid sequence of AP-3 (23Zhou S. Sousa R. Tannery N.H. Lafer E.M. J. Neurosci. 1992; 12: 2144-2155Crossref PubMed Google Scholar) revealed clear divisions between the characteristics of the ~30-kDa N-terminal region and the ~60-kDa C-terminal region. The ~60-kDa C-terminal region has an unusual self-repeating primary structure, a preponderance of acidic residues, an unusually high proline, serine, threonine, and alanine content, and is predicted to have a high content of irregular secondary structure. The ~30-kDa N-terminal region of AP-3 has an amino acid composition typical of a globular protein, with a roughly equal balance of acidic and basic residues, and is predicted to have a high alpha helix content. It was suggested that AP-3 has an essentially neutral ~30-kDa N-terminal domain with an amino acid composition typical of a globular structure and an acidic ~60-kDa C-terminal domain with a highly repetitive and redundant amino acid composition (23Zhou S. Sousa R. Tannery N.H. Lafer E.M. J. Neurosci. 1992; 12: 2144-2155Crossref PubMed Google Scholar, 27Zhou S. Tannery N.H. Yang J. Puszkin S. Lafer E.M. J. Biol. Chem. 1993; 268: 12655-12662Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). These data were consistent with published proteolysis studies (1Murphy J.E. Pleasure I.T. Puszkin S. Prasad K. Keen J.H. J. Biol. Chem. 1991; 266: 4401-4408Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar), which had shown that limited digestion with a number of different proteases generated a stable ~30-kDa fragment, which was later shown (2Morris S.A. Schroder S. Plessmann U. Weber K. Ungewickell E. EMBO J. 1993; 12: 667-675Crossref PubMed Scopus (92) Google Scholar) to correspond to the 33-kDa N-terminal region. Other investigators (2Morris S.A. Schroder S. Plessmann U. Weber K. Ungewickell E. EMBO J. 1993; 12: 667-675Crossref PubMed Scopus (92) Google Scholar) proposed a further division within the 58-kDa C-terminal region into a 42-kDa central acidic domain and a 16-kDa C-terminal domain. These assignments were based on the identification of these regions as products of partial proteolysis reactions (1Murphy J.E. Pleasure I.T. Puszkin S. Prasad K. Keen J.H. J. Biol. Chem. 1991; 266: 4401-4408Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 2Morris S.A. Schroder S. Plessmann U. Weber K. Ungewickell E. EMBO J. 1993; 12: 667-675Crossref PubMed Scopus (92) Google Scholar) and the finding that the 16-kDa C-terminal region was more basic, and had a higher proline content, than any other part of the protein. The results of this study lend additional support to the assignment of a 33-kDa N-terminal domain and a 58-kDa C-terminal domain. The 33-kDa N-terminal domain is a high affinity receptor for inositol polyphosphates (33Ye W. Ali N. Bembenek M. Shears S.B. Lafer E.M. J. Biol. Chem. 1995; 270: 1564-1568Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (160) Google Scholar) and also binds to clathrin triskelia (1Murphy J.E. Pleasure I.T. Puszkin S. Prasad K. Keen J.H. J. Biol. Chem. 1991; 266: 4401-4408Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 3Ye W. Lafer E.M. J. Neurosci. Res. 1995; 41: 15-26Crossref PubMed Scopus (70) Google Scholar). The 58-kDa C-terminal domain is a fully functional clathrin binding and assembly domain. Evidence supporting the further subdivision of the 58-kDa C-terminal domain into a 42-kDa central domain, and a 16-kDa C-terminal domain, is more tenuous at this time. We found that each of these proteins is less stable than the 33-kDa N-terminal or 58-kDa C-terminal regions. For example, we were able to identify conditions under which we could stably prepare both the 33-kDa N-terminal region and the 58-kDa C-terminal region free of GST. However, we were not able to identify conditions, even with extensive testing, under which we could prepare stable 42-kDa central region and 16-kDa C-terminal region free of GST (data not shown). The reported binding properties of these fragments are interesting, but their meaning is subject to several possible interpretations. For example, it is possible that the 42-kDa central region, and the 16-kDa C-terminal region, each contain a distinct binding site for clathrin cages. Alternatively, it is possible that in the 58-kDa C-terminal region, residues from both the 42-kDa central region and 16-kDa C-terminal region contribute to a single clathrin binding and assembly site. When expressed and studied separately, the residues can make sufficient contacts to account for the clathrin binding observed in this study, but not to carry out clathrin assembly. Distinguishing between these various possibilities may require the elucidation of the three-dimensional structure of AP-3. This study raises two intriguing and important questions. Why is there is a binding site for clathrin triskelia in the 33-kDa N-terminal domain, when the 58-kDa C-terminal domain binds and assembles clathrin as well as the full-length protein? How does an inositol polyphosphate binding site in the 33-kDa N-terminal domain modulate the clathrin assembly activity which we show here is present in the 58-kDa C-terminal domain? While at this point in time we can only speculate, it is interesting to consider that the 33-kDa N-terminal domain may function as a regulatory domain, and the 58-kDa C-terminal domain may function as a clathrin assembly domain. In this light, it is provocative that the 33-kDa N-terminal domain binds to a site on clathrin triskelia that either becomes inaccessible or changes conformation upon assembly of the triskelia into cages. Answers to these interesting questions await future studies.

Chloroplasts contain a 21-kDa co-chaperonin polypeptide (cpn21) formed by two GroES-like domains fused together in tandem. Expression of a double-domain spinach cpn21 in Escherichia coli groES mutant strains supports growth of bacteriophages γ and T5, and will also suppress a temperature-sensitive growth phenotype of a groES619 strain. Each domain of cpn21 expressed separately can function independently to support bacteriophage γ growth, and the N-terminal domain will additionally suppress the temperature-sensitive growth phenotype. These results indicate that chloroplast cpn21 has two functional domains, either of which can interact with GroEL in vivo to facilitate bacteriophage morphogenesis. Purified spinach cpn21 has a ring-like toroidal structure and forms a stable complex with E. coli GroEL in the presence of ADP and is functionally interchangeable with bacterial GroES in the chaperonin-facilitated refolding of denatured ribulose-1,5-bisphosphate carboxylase. Cpn21 also inhibits the ATPase activity of GroEL. Cpn21 binds with similar efficiency to both the α and β subunits of spinach cpn60 in the presence of adenine nucleotides, with ATP being more effective than ADP. The tandemly fused domains of cpn21 evolved early and are present in a wide range of photosynthetic eukaryotes examined, indicating a high degree of conservation of this structure in chloroplasts. The role of the Ras-related GTP-binding protein, Rab1B, in intracellular trafficking of β-amyloid precursor protein (βAPP) was studied in cultured 293 cells. βAPP is processed via one of two alternative routes. In the major secretory pathway, βAPP is cleaved by α-secretase within the region comprising the β-amyloid peptide (Aβ), resulting in release of a soluble NH2-terminal exodomain (APPα) and a 3-kDa peptide (p3) derived from the carboxyl-terminal tail. In the alternative amyloidogenic pathway, βAPP is cleaved by β-secretase, with the release of a truncated exodomain (APPβ) and an intact Aβ peptide. When βAPP751 was coexpressed with Rab1B(wt) or dominant-negative Rab1B mutants (Rab1BN121I or Rab1BS22N) there was a marked decrease in conversion of the immature Endo-H sensitive form of βAPP751 (108 kDa) to the mature O-glycosylated form of βAPP751 (130 kDa) in cells expressing the mutant forms of Rab1B. The block in Golgi-dependent processing of βAPP was accompanied by inhibition of secretion of APPS (APPα). A similar decrease in secretion of APPS (APPα+ APPβ) was observed in cells that were coexpressing Rab1BN121I with the “Swedish” variant of βAPP751 (i.e. βAPP SW751), which undergoes increased amyloidogenic processing. Coincident with the decline in APPS secretion, the cells coexpressing βAPP SW751 with Rab1BN121I showed a 90% decrease in Aβ secretion. The data indicate that Rab1B plays a key role in endoplasmic reticulum → Golgi transport of βAPP, and that βAPP must pass through a late Golgi compartment before entering either the α-secretase or the amyloidogenic β-secretase pathway. The results also suggest that mutant versions of other Rab proteins that function in different parts of the exocytic and endocytic pathways may be useful in defining the specific routes of βAPP transport involved in the biogenesis of Aβ. Four unlinked fatty acid activation (FAA) genes encoding acyl-CoA synthetases have been identified in Saccharomyces cerevisiae and characterized by noting the phenotypes of isogenic strains containing all possible combinations of faa null alleles. None of these genes is required for vegetative growth when acyl-CoA production by the fatty acid synthetase (Fas) complex is active. When Fas is inhibited by cerulenin, exponentially growing cells are not viable on media containing a fermentable carbon source unless supplemented with fatty acids such as myristate, palmitate, or oleate. The functionally interchangeable FAA1 and FAA4 genes are responsible for activation of these imported fatty acids. Analysis of lysates prepared from isogenic FAA1FAA4 and faa1Δfaa4Δ strains indicated that Faa1p and Faa4p together account for 99% of total cellular myristoyl-CoA and palmitoyl-CoA synthetase activities. Genetic complementation studies revealed that rat liver acyl-CoA synthetase (RLACS) rescues the viability of faa1Δfaa4Δ cells in media containing a fermentable carbon source, myristate or palmitate, plus cerulenin. Rescue is greater at 37°C compared with 24°C, paralleling the temperature-dependent changes in RLACS activity in vitro as well as the enzyme's ability to direct incorporation of tritiated myristate and palmitate into cellular phospholipids in vivo. Complementation by RLACS is blocked by treatment of cells with triacsin C (1-hydroxy-3-(E, E, E,2’,4’,7’-undecatrienylidine)triazene). Even though Faa1p, Faa4p, and RLACS are all able to activate imported myristate and palmitate in S. cerevisiae, the sensitivity of Faa4p and RLACS, but not Faa1p, to inhibition by triacsin C suggests that the rat liver enzyme is functionally more analogous to Faa4p than to Faa1p. Finally, an assessment of myristate and palmitate import into FAA1FAA4 and faa1Δfaa4Δ strains, with or without episomes that direct overexpression of Faa1p, Faa4p or RLACS, indicated that fatty acid uptake is not coupled to activation in S. cerevisiae. α2A−- and α2B-adrenoreceptors (AR), identified by Northern blotting in rat myometrium, showed a differential expression during the course of pregnancy. Indeed, the α2A−-AR transcript was present at mid-pregnancy, whereas high levels of α2B-AR mRNA could be detected at term. The role of these subtypes in modulating β2-AR-stimulated adenylyl cyclase activity was investigated on myometrial membranes from mid-pregnancy and term. At nanomolar concentrations of clonidine (full α2-AR agonist) or oxymetazoline (partial α2A−-AR agonist), adenylyl cyclase activity was inhibited by up to 50 ± 7% at mid-pregnancy or 75 ± 7% at term, whereas at micromolar concentrations, α2-AR agonists potentiate adenylyl cyclase activity by 140-170% at mid-pregnancy. Both inhibitory and stimulatory components of this biphasic response were blocked by yohimbine, a selective α2-AR antagonist. Preincubation of myometrial membranes with Gi2 and/or Gi3 antisera eliminated α2-AR mediated attenuation or potentiation of isoproterenol-stimulated adenylyl cyclase, thus indicating that both the inhibitory and stimulatory components are mediated via Gi2 and Gi3. In addition, type II and IV adenylyl cyclases were identified by Northern blotting in the pregnant rat myometrium. Altogether these data strongly suggest that the α2A−-AR at mid-pregnancy potentiates adenylyl cyclase types II and IV through βγ released from Gi2 and Gi3 proteins, whereas the α2B-AR expression at term may be related to persistent inhibition. α2A−- and α2B-adrenoreceptors (AR), identified by Northern blotting in rat myometrium, showed a differential expression during the course of pregnancy. To determine which factors may regulate the DNA binding and transcriptional properties of retinoic acid receptors (RARs and RXRs), we investigated the sensitivity of reporter genes bearing various retinoic acid response elements (RAREs) to protein phosphatases (PPases) inhibition. PPases inhibition by okadaic acid led to an increase of the reporter genes activity in a RARE-dependent and ligand-independent manner and was dependent on the type of response element used. Overexpression of protein phosphatases 2A and 1 (PP2A and PP1) decreased the inducibility of the reporter genes tested. Nuclear extracts from okadaic acid-treated COS cells displayed an 2-5-fold increased level of receptor binding to RAREs in vitro, suggesting that PPases inhibition increased the DNA binding activity of retinoid receptors. Treatment of receptors extracted from COS cells by alkaline phosphatase and partially purified PP1 and PP2A decreased their DNA binding activity, but heterodimers bound to DNA were not sensitive to phosphatase treatment. Reconstitution experiments showed that phosphorylation of both receptors increased the DNA binding activity of RXR/RAR heterodimers. Taken together, these data show that the modulation of the phosphorylation state of RARs and RXRs represents an other level of regulation of the retinoid signaling pathway. Using a high performance liquid chromatography (HPLC)-based assay, we have demonstrated that isolated oat etioplasts convert the linear tetrapyrrole biliverdin IXα to (3E)-phytochromobilin, the proposed precursor of the chromophore of the plant photoreceptor phytochrome. In addition to (3E)-phytochromobilin, the synthesis of a second phytochromobilin was detected by its ability to functionally assemble with recombinant oat apophytochrome A. The structure of this new pigment has been determined to be the 3Z isomer of phytochromobilin by absorption and 1H NMR spectroscopy. Like (3E)-phytochromobilin, assembly of HPLC-purified (3Z)-phytochromobilin with apophytochrome yielded a holoprotein that is spectrally indistinguishable from native oat phytochrome A. However, the postchromatographic conversion of (3Z)- to (3E)-phytochromobilin appears to be responsible for this result. Kinetic HPLC analyses have demonstrated that (3Z)-phytochromobiIin is synthesized prior to the 3E isomer by oat etioplasts. We therefore propose that (3Z)-phytochromobilin is the immediate product of biliverdin IXα reduction by the enzyme phytochromobilin synthase. This implicates the presence of an isomerase that catalyzes the conversion of (3Z)- to (3E)-phytochromobilin, the immediate precursor of the phytochrome A chromophore. The phytochrome photoreceptor performs a vital role in a plant’s adaptive response to its light environment (1Sage L.C. Pigment of the Imagination: A History of Phytochrome Research. Academic Pres, San Diego1992Google Scholar, 2Kendrick R.E. Kronenberg G.H.M. Photomorphogenesis in Plants. 2nd Ed. Martinus Nijhoff Publishers, Dordrecht, The Netherlands1994Crossref Google Scholar). Comprised of linear tetrapyrrole chromophore that is covalently attached to a polypeptide of about 124 kDa, phytochrome functions as a detector of red and far-red wavelengths of light (3Furuya M. Annu. Rev. Plant Physiol. Plant Mol. Biol. 1993; 44: 617-645Crossref Scopus (294) Google Scholar). The molecular basis of phytochrome action depends upon the ability to photointerconvert between two stable isomers, the red light absorbing form of phytochrome, Pr, 1The abbreviations used are: Prthe red light absorbing form of phytochromePfrthe far-red light absorbing form of phytochromeBVbiliverdin IXαHPLChigh performance liquid chromatographyMOPS3-(N-morpholino)propanesulfonic acidPCBphycocyanobilinPEBphycoerythrobilinPΦβphytochromobilinTESN-tris(hydroxymethyl)methyl-2-aminoethanesulfonic acid and the far-red light absorbing form, Pfr. Genet. 1991; 25: 389-409Crossref PubMed Scopus (284) Google Scholar). These molecular properties enable this unique photoreceptor family to modulate many aspects of plant growth and development in response to both light quality and quantity in the natural environment. the red light absorbing form of phytochrome the far-red light absorbing form of phytochrome biliverdin IXα high performance liquid chromatography 3-(N-morpholino)propanesulfonic acid phycocyanobilin phycoerythrobilin phytochromobilin N-tris(hydroxymethyl)methyl-2-aminoethanesulfonic acid The biosynthesis of phytochrome requires two pathways, one for the apoprotein and another for phytochromobilin (PΦβ), the immediate precursor of the protein-bound chromophore (5Terry M.J. Wahleithner J.A. Lagarias J.C. Arch. Biochem. Biophys. 1993; 306: 1-15Crossref PubMed Scopus (95) Google Scholar). These two components are brought together in the plant cytosol where the mature photoreceptor is assembled. While the chemical structure of the protein-bound phytochrome chromophore has been known for some time (6Lagarias J.C. Rapoport H. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 1980; 102: 4821-4828Crossref Scopus (261) Google Scholar, 7Rudiger W. Thummler F. Cmiel E. Schneider S. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1983; 80: 6244-6248Crossref PubMed Google Scholar), the structure of PΦβ was only recently verified (8Cornejo J. Beale S.I. Terry M.J. Lagarias J.C. J. Biol. Chem. 1992; 267: 14790-14798Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). In that study, a pigment with the 3E-PΦβ structure (see Fig. 1) was isolated from the red alga Porphyridium cruentum and shown to properly assemble with recombinant oat apophytochrome A. The resulting holophytochrome exhibited a spectrophotometric signature that was indistinguishable from that of oat phytochrome isolated from dark grown seedlings. Based on these investigations, we proposed that 3.E-PΦβ is the immediate precursor of the phytochrome chromophore. Until now, the intermediacy of 3E-PΦβ in the pathway of phytochrome chromophore biosynthesis has been primarily based upon an indirect coupled assay in which its production was detected after assembly with apophytochrome (9Terry M.J. Lagarias J.C. J. Biol. Chem. 1991; 266: 22215-22221Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). That study demonstrated that PΦβ is derived from biliverdin IXα (BV; see Fig. 1 for structure), a conversion that is accomplished by the plastid-localized enzyme, PΦβ synthase. In this report, we present direct experimental evidence for the conversion of BV to 3.E-PΦβ by oat etioplast preparations using a newly developed HPLC assay. These studies reveal that 3Z-PΦβ pigment is also produced during the incubation of BV with etioplasts (see Fig. 1 for structure). Based upon these investigations and the kinetics of the synthesis of the two PΦβ isomers, a revised pathway for the biosynthesis of the phytochrome chromophore is proposed. Bilin Preparations—For all biochemical assays, reagent grade biliverdin IXα was prepared from bilirubin (Vega Biochemicals, Tucson, AZ) as described previously (10Elich T.D. McDonagh A.F. Palma L.A. Lagarias J.C. J. Biol. Chem. 1989; 264: 183-189Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). For 1H NMR spectroscopy and data shown in Fig. 4, BV was further purified by HPLC as described under “HPLC Analyses.” 3E-PΦβ was purified from P. cruentum as described previously (8Cornejo J. Beale S.I. Terry M.J. Lagarias J.C. J. Biol. Chem. 1992; 267: 14790-14798Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 11Terry M.J. Maines M.D. Lagarias J.C. J. Biol. Chem. 1993; 268: 26099-26106Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). The molar absorption coefficient of 64,600 m–1 cm–1 at 386 nm in 2% HCl in methanol was used to estimate the concentration of the 3E-PΦβ standard used for HPLC analyses (12Weller J.-P. Gossauer A. Chem. Ber. 1980; 113: 1603-1611Crossref Scopus (69) Google Scholar). Etioplast Isolation—Oat seeds (Avena sativa L. cv Garry) were germinated and grown in the dark on vermiculite for 6 days at 25 °C. Shoot tissue was homogenized at 4 °C in a precooled Waring blender with an equal volume to fresh weight tissue of cold homogenization medium (50 mm MOPS/KOH buffer, pH 8.0, containing 500 mm sucrose, 1 mm MgCl2, and 142 mm 2-mercaptoethanol). The homogenate was filtered through four layers of cheesecloth and two layers of Miracloth and centrifuged at 8000 × g for 1 min. The pellet was resuspended in homogenization medium lacking 2-mercaptoethanol but including 0.2% (w/v) bovine serum albumin. This suspension was centrifuged at 100 × g for 1 min to remove cell debris. The supernatant was removed and centrifuged at 1500 × g for 2 min to give a pellet containing mostly intact plastids. Plastids were kept as a pellet on ice until required. Phytochromobilin Synthase Assay—Plastids were resuspended in PΦβ synthase assay buffer (20 mm TES, 10 mm HEPES/NaOH buffer, pH 7.7, containing 500 mm sorbitol, 1 mm phenylmethanesulfonyl fluoride, 0.5 mm dithiothreitol, and 2 μμ leupeptin) containing 3000 units/ml catalase and an NADPH regenerating system (1.2 mm NADP+, 9.3 mm glucose 6-phosphate, and 1.5 units/ml glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase). The reaction was initiated by addition of 1 mm BV in Me2SO to give a final concentration of 10 μμ BV. Reaction mixtures were incubated at 28 °C in the dark for various lengths of time. Reaction volumes were routinely 2.5 or 5 ml for analytical assays, 40 ml for preparative assays, and 1 ml for kinetic measurements. Argon was typically used to remove oxygen from the reaction tubes both prior to and at hourly intervals throughout the assay. Following completion of the incubation period, samples were centrifuged at 39,000 × g for 15 min to remove the plastids. Bilins were partially purified on a C18 Sep-Pak cartridge (Waters-Millipore Corp., Milford, MA) using the following procedure. Prior to application of the assay supernatant, the Sep-Pak cartridge was washed with acetonitrile, water, and 50 mm N-methylmorpholine/acetate buffer, pH 7.7. After application of the extract, the Sep-Pak cartridge was then sequentially washed with 50 mm N-methylmorpholine/acetate buffer, pH 7.7 (2 × 3 ml), 0.1% (v/v) trifluoroacetic acid (2 × 3 ml), and acetonitrile/0.1% trifluoroacetic acid (20:80; 2 × 2 ml). The crude bilin mixture was typically eluted with 3 ml acetonitrile/0.1% trifluoroacetic acid (60:40) and dried in vacuo. Holophytochrome Assembly Assay—Recombinant apophytochrome was prepared from the yeast Saccharomyces cerevisiae strain 29A containing the full-length oat phytochrome (phyA3) cDNA plasmid pM-phyA3 as described previously (13Li L. Lagarias J.C. J. Biol. Chem. 1992; 267: 19204-19210Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). All phytochrome reconstitution experiments were performed under green safelight in a final volume of 500 μl of assembly buffer (25 mm Tris/HCl buffer, pH 7.8, containing 25% (v/v) ethylene glycol, 1 mm dithiothreitol, 1 mm EDTA, and 1 mm phenylmethanesulfonyl fluoride). Crude and HPLC-purified bilin preparations were added by diluting stock solutions in Me2SO by 100-fold to give an final bilin concentration of approximately 5 μμ. Apophytochrome was added from a 17.5 μg/ml stock in assembly buffer (described above). The final concentrations of apophytochrome and bilins in specific experiments are given in the appropriate figure legend. Following incubation for 15 min on ice, samples were centrifuged at 5 °C for 15 min at 200,000 × g before measurement of phytochrome difference spectra. HPLC Analyses—Crude bilin samples were analyzed by C18 reverse phase HPLC using a Varían 5000 liquid Chromatograph and a Beckman Ultrasphere ODS column (5 μm; 10 mm × 250 mm). The mobile phase solvent consisted of ethanol/acetone/water/acetic acid (48/34717/1; v/v/v/v) with a flow rate of 4 ml/min. The column eluate was monitored at 380 nm with an Varian UV100 flow through absorbance detector. Peak areas were quantitated using a Hewlett Packard 3390A integrator. Before injection, all samples were dissolved in the HPLC solvent and centrifuged at 14,000 rpm for 15 s. HPLC-purified bilins were concentrated by diluting 1 to 4 with 0.1% (v/v) trifluoroacetic acid and applying to a C18 Sep-Pak cartridge. After washing with 0.1% trifluoroacetic acid, bilins were eluted with acetonitrile/0.1% trifluoroacetic acid (60: 40). The purified bilins were then dried in vacuo prior to spectroscopic analysis and/or reconstitution experiments. Spectroscopic Measurements—All absorbance measurements and phytochrome difference spectra were obtained using a Hewlett Packard 8450A UV-visible diode array spectrophotometer. Absorption spectra of 3Z- and 3E-PΦβ were taken in acetonitrile/0.1% trifluoroacetic acid (60:40; v/v) or 2% HCl in methanol at room temperature. Phytochrome difference spectra were measured at 5 °C as described previously (14Lagarias J.C. Kelly J.M. Cyr K.L. Smith Jr., W.O. Photochem. Photobiol. 1987; 46: 5-13Crossref Scopus (105) Google Scholar). 500 MHz 1H NMR spectra were obtained in pyridine-d5 (100.0 atom % D; Sigma catalog no. 23,699-3) at 28 °C using a GE Omega 500 spectrometer at the UCD NMR Facility. Protein Assay—Protein concentrations were determined using the BCA protein assay (Pierce) with bovine serum albumin as a standard (15Smith P.K. Krohn R.I. Hemanson G.T. Mallia A.K. Gartner F.H. Provenzano M.D. Fujimoto E.K. Goeke N.M. Olsen B.J. Klenk D.C. Anal. Biochem. 1985; 150: 76-85Crossref PubMed Scopus (18792) Google Scholar). Oat and Cucumber Etioplasts Synthesize 3E-PΦβ from BV—The conversion of biliverdin IXα (BV) to phytochromobilin (PΦβ) by oat etioplast preparations was analyzed using essentially the same reverse phase HPLC conditions described for the analysis of phycobilin biosynthesis (16Beale S.I. Cornejo J. J. Biol. Chem. 1991; 266: 22333-22340Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). As shown in Fig. 2 (trace b), BV elutes as a peak with a retention time of approximately 17 min on this HPLC system. After incubation with plastids for 1 h at 28 °C in the presence of an NADPH regenerating system, BV is converted to a new pigment with a retention time of 28 min (Fig. 2, trace c). This 28-min peak was not observed in samples where either BV (Fig. 2, trace a) or plastids (Fig. 2, trace b) were omitted from the incubation medium. These results indicate that the new pigment is formed by the de novo conversion of BV by plastid enzyme activities. As shown in Fig. 2 (traces d and e), the retention time of this new pigment is identical with that of 3E-PΦβ (see structure in Fig. 1). In addition, the absorption spectrum of the new pigment is indistinguishable from that of 3E-PΦβ (data not shown). Based on these results and phytochrome reconstitution experiments (see next section), it is clear that the new pigment is 3E-PΦβ. To compare with previous studies (9Terry M.J. Lagarias J.C. J. Biol. Chem. 1991; 266: 22215-22221Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar), cucumber etioplast preparations were similarly analyzed with the above HPLC system. These studies confirmed that BV is converted to 3E-PΦβ in this tissue as expected (data not shown). Under similar experimental conditions, however, cucumber etioplasts yielded a reduced amount of 3.E-PΦβ by comparison with oat etioplasts (data not shown). For this reason, subsequent investigations have exclusively utilized oat etioplasts to study the enzymatic conversion of BV to 3E-PΦβ. A Second Phytochromobilin Is Also Synthesized by Oat Etioplasts—To further confirm the identity of the 3E-PΦβ peak produced by incubation of BV with plastids, phytochrome reconstitution experiments were performed. This entailed incubation of the HPLC-purified pigment with recombinant apophytochrome and determination of a phytochrome difference spectrum. Since previous studies have shown that BV does not assemble with apophytochrome (13Li L. Lagarias J.C. J. Biol. Chem. 1992; 267: 19204-19210Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar), the BV peak was similarly analyzed as a negative control. These experiments revealed that both peaks yielded photoactive holophytochromes, thereby indicating that a second PΦβ was co-fractionating with BV on our HPLC system. As shown in Fig. 3, injection of larger amount of sample onto a preparative C18 column proved effective in partially resolving these co-eluting pigments (labeled as peaks b and c). These two components and two other pigment fractions, one that elutes at 3 min (peak a) and the other at 25 min (peak d), were individually collected and analyzed using the phytochrome assembly assay. The results of these phytochrome reconstitution experiments are shown in the lower panel of Fig. 3. As observed in the experiment described above, two pigment fractions yielded photoactive holophytochrome. Moreover, the difference spectra were essentially indistinguishable from that of phytochrome isolated from etiolated oat seedlings (i.e. with maxima at 666 nm and minima at 730 nm). Further spectrophotometric analyses using more concentrated samples of these holophytochrome species confirmed this result (data not shown). Owing to the observations that peak d represents 3E-PΦβ (see above discussion) and authentic 3E-PΦβ is a biologically active phytochrome chromophore precursor (8Cornejo J. Beale S.I. Terry M.J. Lagarias J.C. J. Biol. Chem. 1992; 267: 14790-14798Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar), the functional assembly of peak d was expected. The identity of peak b is addressed in the subsequent discussion. Reconstitution experiments were also performed with the other two peaks; however, in both cases very low amounts of photoactive holophytochrome were produced (Fig. 3, panels a and c). Since peak c was identified as BV (data not shown), the small amount of holophytochrome produced is probably due to a small amount of contamination from the novel PΦβ in peak b. The reason for the small amount of holophytochrome obtained with peak a was not further investigated. The Second Phytochromobilin Is 3Z-PΦβ—The difference spectrum of the peak b-derived holophytochrome species and the earlier retention time of this pigment compared with 3EPΦβ both support the hypothesis that peak b is 3Z-PΦβ (see Fig. 1 for structure). The 3Z isomers of the phycobiliprotein chromophore precursors, phycocyanobilin (PCB) and phycoerythrobilin (PEB), both elute earlier than their corresponding 3E isomers on a similar HPLC system (16Beale S.I. Cornejo J. J. Biol. Chem. 1991; 266: 22333-22340Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). The absorption spectrum of HPLC-purified peak b is also consistent with this interpretation. As shown in Fig. 4, both absorption maxima of peak b are blue-shifted relative to those of 3.E-PΦβ in acetonitrile/0.1% aqueous trifluoroacetic acid (60:40, v/v) solvent. The absorption maxima of synthetic 3Z-PΦβ and 3Z-PCB dimethyl esters show similar blue shifts compared with their corresponding 3E isomers (12Weller J.-P. Gossauer A. Chem. Ber. 1980; 113: 1603-1611Crossref Scopus (69) Google Scholar). When the spectra of peak b and 3E-PΦβ were compared in 2% HCl in methanol, however, the absorption spectra of peak b and 3E-PΦβ are indistinguishable. To address this apparent discrepancy with the literature, the peak b sample was reanalyzed by HPLC after dissolving in 2% HCl in methanol. This analysis revealed that peak b is unstable in the solvent and in part converts to 3.E-PΦβ (data not shown). Based on all of the above information taken together, it appears reasonable that peak b is 3Z-PΦβ. To ascertain the chemical composition of peak b, its 1H NMR spectrum in pyridine-d5 was determined and is presented in Fig. 5. Detailed analysis of this spectrum indicates that peak b consists of three bilin components. In addition to the new PΦβ pigment, two of these components proved to be known bilins (i.e. BV and 3E-PΦβ). BV was expected to be a component of this mixture, since the BV peak (i.e. peak c) partially overlaps peak b in our HPLC system. 3.E-PΦβ appears to have arisen by a post-chromatographic chemical interconversion of the new PΦβ, a hypothesis that has been confirmed by HPLC (see “Discussion”). The three pigments are present in unequal amounts in the peak b NMR sample, an observation that has greatly facilitated the assignments of specific resonances to individual bilin components. The relative intensities of bilin-specific resonances indicates a molar ratio of 20% BV, 25% 3E-PΦβ, and 55% new PΦβ in the peak b mixture. The complete assignments of the 1H NMR spectra of the three components of peak b are summarized in Table I. All resonances attributable to BV and 3E-PΦβ were made by respective comparison with published data (8Cornejo J. Beale S.I. Terry M.J. Lagarias J.C. J. Biol. Chem. 1992; 267: 14790-14798Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 17Beale S.I. Cornejo J. J. Biol. Chem. 1991; 266: 22341-22345Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar) and our own NMR measurements of purified BV in pyridine-d5 (data not shown). Without exception, the chemical shift positions of all proton signals for both bilins agreed with those of their purified counterparts within 0.01 ppm. Both homonuclear spin decoupling experiments and comparison with the 1H NMR spectra of other known bilins contributed to the interpretation of the spectrum of the new PΦβ component. The new bilin possesses the characteristic NMR signature of an ethylidene-containing dihydrobilatriene (i.e. two methyl doublets at 1.44 and 1.95 ppm). Homonuclear spin decoupling experiments shown in Fig. 6 and chemical shift positions of the coupled resonances support the assignment of the two doublets to the 2- and 3 2M. T. McDowell and J. C. Lagarias, unpublished results.-methyl groups, respectively. These experiments indicated that the 1.95 ppm methyl doublet is J-coupled to the doublet of quartets in the aromatic region at 5.79 ppm, while the 1.44 ppm doublet is coupled with the quartet in the methine region at 3.31 ppm. Double irradiation of the 3.31 ppm quartet also collapsed the 1.50 ppm doublet to a singlet, which confirms the assignment of this methyl group resonance to the 2-methyl group of 3E-PΦβ (Fig. 6). Open table in a new tab The C2 hydrogen signal is the only spectral feature attributable to the bilin α-ring that is the same for both PΦβs. By contrast, the 32-methyl group of the new PΦβ lies considerably downfield from that of 3E-PΦβ (i.e. 1.95 ppm versus 1.69 ppm), while the 31-ethylidene hydrogen to which it is coupled resonates upfield (i.e. 5.79 ppm versus 6.33 ppm). The relative chemical shift of these two resonances is known to be a good indicator of the configuration of the ethylidene double bond (8Cornejo J. Beale S.I. Terry M.J. Lagarias J.C. J. Biol. Chem. 1992; 267: 14790-14798Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 16Beale S.I. Cornejo J. J. Biol. Chem. 1991; 266: 22333-22340Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). As summarized in Table II, the chemical shifts of the 32- and 31-resonances for the new PΦβ are in good agreement with those of other (3Z)-ethylidene-containing linear tetrapyrroles. The upfield chemical shift of the 21-methyl group of the new bilin relative to that of 3E-PΦβ also supports the assignment of the 3Z configuration. With the sole exception of the two PEB isomers in pyridine-d5, the 21-methyl groups of the 3Z isomers occur at higher fields when compared in the same NMR solvent (see Table II). Slight shifts were also observed in the C5 and C10 methine bridge resonances and two of the four pyrrole ring methyl groups. Aside from these differences, the NMR spectra of both PΦBs are otherwise identical (Table I). Open table in a new tab 3Z-PΦβ Biosynthesis Precedes That of 3E-PΦβ—The synthesis of two PΦβ isomers raises the obvious question: which PΦβ isomer is synthesized first? To address this question, oat etioplasts were incubated with BV as described under “Experimental Procedures” with the following changes to improve PΦβ synthase activity; 5 mm sodium ascorbate replaced the 0.5 mm dithiothreitol, and the pH of the reaction was lowered to 7.3. The HPLC mobile phase used for this experiment was changed to ethanol/acetone/100 mm formic acid (25/65/10;v/v/v). This change improved resolution of 3Z-PΦβ from BV and therefore allowed quantitation of the two bilins (data not shown). Fig. 7 shows the kinetics of 3Z- and 3E-PΦβ synthesis following the incubation of BV with oat etioplasts. For each time course experiment, the molar ratio of the three bilins (i.e. BV, 3E-PΦβ, and 3Z-PΦβ) was estimated by dividing the individual peak areas by the published molar absorption coefficient for each bilin. After normalization to the amount of BV present at the start of the incubation, these values were plotted as a function of incubation time (Fig. 7). This analysis clearly indicates that 3Z-PΦβ is produced prior to any detectable 3.E-PΦβ. At the 30-min time point, the level of 3EPΦβ was below the limit of detection, while 3Z-PΦβ was readily detectable. The inset to Fig. 7 shows that 3E-PΦβ appears only after an extended incubation period, during which time the level of the 3Z isomer remains roughly constant. These observations support the hypothesis that 3Z-PΦβ is the precursor of 3E-PΦβ. The reverse phase HPLC assay described here corroborates the hypothesis that 3E-PΦβ is a metabolic intermediate in the biosynthesis of the phytochrome chromophore as proposed earlier (9Terry M.J. Lagarias J.C. J. Biol. Chem. 1991; 266: 22215-22221Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 8Cornejo J. Beale S.I. Terry M.J. Lagarias J.C. J. Biol. Chem. 1992; 267: 14790-14798Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). In addition, these studies show that a second PΦβ is produced during the incubation of BV with oat etioplast preparations. Initially detected by its functional assembly with apophytochrome, this new pigment has been identified to be 3Z-PΦβ by 1H NMR spectroscopy. Kinetic measurements presented here are consistent with the conclusion that the 3Z isomer of PΦβ is synthesized prior to the 3E isomer. This interpretation is supported by several other observations. First, recent biochemical investigations to further purify PΦβ synthase from oat etioplasts have yielded enzyme fractions that only convert BV to 3Z-PΦβ, which suggests that the 3Z isomer is the primary product of BV reduction by PΦβ synthase.2 Second, a bilin reductase that catalyzes the analogous reduction of a vinyl pyrrole moiety has been identified in the phycobiliprotein-containing red alga Cyanidium caldarium (17Beale S.I. Cornejo J. J. Biol. Chem. 1991; 266: 22341-22345Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). The product of this enzyme, which reduces 15,16-dihydro-BV, is the 3Z isomer of PEB. Based on evolutionary considerations, this observation lends support to the proposal that 3Z-PΦβ is the direct product of BV reduction in plants. Third, it is well established that 3E bilin isomers are thermodynamically more stable than their corresponding 3Z isomers. Synthetic 3Z-PCB dimethyl ester quantitatively converts to the 3E isomer in hot methanol, and, in acidic solvents, an equilibrium mixture of the two isomers is produced (25Gossauer A. Tetrahedron. 1983; 39: 1933-1941Crossref Scopus (18) Google Scholar). Although the isomerization of synthetic 3Z-PΦβ dimethyl ester was not previously reported (12Weller J.-P. Gossauer A. Chem. Ber. 1980; 113: 1603-1611Crossref Scopus (69) Google Scholar), the present investigation indicates that 3Z-PΦβ does interconvert to the 3E isomer in two solvent systems (i.e. pyridine-d5 and 2% HCl in methanol). These arguments support the proposed biosynthetic scheme shown in Fig. 8, in which the conversion of BV to 3E-PΦβ occurs in two steps. In the first step, we envisage that BV reduction to 3Z-PΦβ is mediated by the enzyme PΦβ synthase. Since the analogous 3Z to 3E interconversions in the pathway of phycobilin biosynthesis in the red alga Cyanidium are enzyme-mediated (16Beale S.I. Cornejo J. J. Biol. Chem. 1991; 266: 22333-22340Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 17Beale S.I. Cornejo J. J. Biol. Chem. 1991; 266: 22341-22345Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 26Beale S.I. Cornejo J. J. Biol. Chem. 1991; 266: 22328-22332Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar), we favor the hypothesis that the second step is accomplished by an enzyme that we propose to name PΦβ isomerase. One of the interesting properties of 3Z-PΦβ is that while the absorption spectrum of the free pigment differs from that of 3E-PΦβ, the phytochrome difference spectra after assembly to oat apophytochrome A is indistinguishable for the two isomers. This result suggests that both PΦβs yield structurally identical holophytochromes, although this conclusion will require additional experiments, which are beyond the scope of this investigation. It is possible that the Z isomer itself does not assemble with apophytochrome A, but that its assembly requires isomerization to the E isomer. This hypothesis can now be tested directly using a fluorescence-based kinetic assay for holophytochrome assembly, which has recently been developed in our laboratory. 3L. Li, J. T. Murphy, and J. C. Lagarias, manuscript in preparation. A reduced ability (or inability) of 3Z-PΦβ to assemble with apophytochrome would be consistent with its role as an intermediate in the synthesis of the phytochrome chromophore precursor 3E-PΦβ. However, we would like to emphasize that only assembly to phytochrome A has been examined in this study. Other apophytochromes, such as B-E (27Sharrock R.A. Quail P.H. Genes & Dev. 1989; 3: 1745-1757Crossref PubMed Scopus (700) Google Scholar, 28Clack T. Mathews S. Sharrock R.A. Plant Mol. Biol. 1994; 25: 413-427Crossref PubMed Scopus (568) Google Scholar), may utilize the 3Z-PΦβ isomer as the immediate precursor of the protein-bound chromophore. Nevertheless, recent studies have shown that the assembly of 3E-PCB to recombinant tobacco phytochrome β proceeds with an apparent rate constant very similar to that reported for phytochrome A from oat (29Kunkel T. Tomizawa K.I. Kern R. Furuya M. Chua N.H. Schäfer E. Eur. J. Biochem. 1993; 215: 587-594Crossref PubMed Scopus (69) Google Scholar). This suggests that 3E-PΦβ is the natural precursor of the chromophores of both phytochromes A and B. We thank Babak Djifroudi for the synthesis of BV and for assistance in the development of conditions for bilin purification in the early stages of this project.

For rapid single-step purification of recombinant rhodopsin, a baculovirus expression vector was constructed containing the bovine opsin coding sequence extended at the 3′-end by a short sequence encoding six histidine residues. Recombinant baculovirus-infected Spodoptera frugiperda cells produce bovine opsin carrying a C-terminal histidine tag (v-opshis6x). The presence of this tag was confirmed by immunoblot analysis. Incubation with 11-cis-retinal produced a photosensitive pigment (v-Rhohis6x) at a level of 15–20 pmol/106 cells. The histidine tag was exploited to purify v-Rhohis6x via immobilized metal affinity chromatography. Optimized immobilized metal affinity chromatography yielded a binding capacity of ≥35 nmol of v-Rhohis6x per ml of resin and purification factors up to 500. Best samples were at least 85% pure, with an average purity of 70% (A280 nm/α500 nm = 2.5 ± 0.4, n = 7). Remaining contamination was largely removed upon reconstitution into lipids, yielding rhodopsin proteoliposomes with a purity over 95%.Spectral analysis of v-Rhohis6x showed a small but significant red shift (501 ± 1 nm) compared to wild type rhodopsin (498 ± 1 nm). The pKa of the Meta I ↔ Meta II equilibrium in v-Rhohis6x is down-shifted from 7.3 to 6.4 resulting in a significant shift at pH 6.5 toward the Meta I photointermediate. Both effects are reversed upon increasing the ionic strength. FT-IR analysis of the Rho → Meta II transition shows that the corresponding structural changes are identical in wild type and v-Rhohis6x. For rapid single-step purification of recombinant rhodopsin, a baculovirus expression vector was constructed containing the bovine opsin coding sequence extended at the 3′-end by a short sequence encoding six histidine residues. Recombinant baculovirus-infected Spodoptera frugiperda cells produce bovine opsin carrying a C-terminal histidine tag (v-opshis6x). The presence of this tag was confirmed by immunoblot analysis. Incubation with 11-cis-retinal produced a photosensitive pigment (v-Rhohis6x) at a level of 15–20 pmol/106 cells. The histidine tag was exploited to purify v-Rhohis6x via immobilized metal affinity chromatography. Optimized immobilized metal affinity chromatography yielded a binding capacity of ≥35 nmol of v-Rhohis6x per ml of resin and purification factors up to 500. Best samples were at least 85% pure, with an average purity of 70% (A280 nm/α500 nm = 2.5 ± 0.4, n = 7). Remaining contamination was largely removed upon reconstitution into lipids, yielding rhodopsin proteoliposomes with a purity over 95%. Spectral analysis of v-Rhohis6x showed a small but significant red shift (501 ± 1 nm) compared to wild type rhodopsin (498 ± 1 nm). The pKa of the Meta I ↔ Meta II equilibrium in v-Rhohis6x is down-shifted from 7.3 to 6.4 resulting in a significant shift at pH 6.5 toward the Meta I photointermediate. Both effects are reversed upon increasing the ionic strength. FT-IR analysis of the Rho → Meta II transition shows that the corresponding structural changes are identical in wild type and v-Rhohis6x. Rhodopsin is the major component of the outer segments of the vertebrate rod photoreceptor cell. This visual pigment consists of an integral membrane protein to which a chromophore, 11-cis-retinal, is covalently linked via a protonated Schiff base. Rhodopsin triggers the conversion of photon energy (light) into a graded membrane potential. The absorption of a photon leads to a number of discrete conformational changes in the protein moiety of the pigment (sequel of photointermediates → photocascade), finally resulting in the exposure of G-protein binding sites at the cytoplasmic surface of the protein. In the past decade, research has focused on analyzing the relationship between the structure of the receptor and its functional properties. Heterologous expression of the protein in combination with site-specific mutagenesis has become an attractive way to study this relationship. Several expression systems capable of in vitro biosynthesis of opsin have been described (1Oprian D.D. Molday R.S. Kaufman R.J. Khorana H.G. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1987; 84: 8874-8878Crossref PubMed Scopus (387) Google Scholar, 2Janssen J.J.M. VanDeVen W.J.M. VanGroningen-Luyben W.A.H.M. Roosien J. Vlak J.M. DeGrip W.J. Mol. Biol. Rep. 1988; 13: 65-71Crossref PubMed Scopus (27) Google Scholar, 3Khorana H.G. Knox B.E. Nasi E. Swanson R. Thompson D.A. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1988; 85: 7917-7921Crossref PubMed Scopus (82) Google Scholar, 4Nathans J. Weitz C.J. Agarwal N. Nir I. Papermaster D.S. Vision Res. 1989; 29: 907-914Crossref PubMed Scopus (42) Google Scholar, 5Zozulya S.A. Gurevich V.V. Zvyaga T.A. Shirokova E.P. Dumler I.L. Garnovskaya M.N. Natochin M.Y. Shmukler B.E. Badalov P.R. Protein Eng. 1990; 3: 453-458Crossref PubMed Scopus (17) Google Scholar). Expression levels in these systems are usually quite low compared to total cell protein (<0.5%) and even to total membrane protein. For most analyses, recombinant rhodopsin therefore has to be extensively purified. Several methods have been described for the purification of recombinant rhodopsin (1Oprian D.D. Molday R.S. Kaufman R.J. Khorana H.G. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1987; 84: 8874-8878Crossref PubMed Scopus (387) Google Scholar, 4Nathans J. Weitz C.J. Agarwal N. Nir I. Papermaster D.S. Vision Res. 1989; 29: 907-914Crossref PubMed Scopus (42) Google Scholar, 6DeCaluwé G.L.J. VanOostrum J. Janssen J.J.M. DeGrip W.J. Methods Neurosci. 1993; 15: 307-321Crossref Scopus (22) Google Scholar). These methods often have the disadvantage that the obtained samples are still contaminated to a various extent with proteins derived from the cells, used for recombinant protein production (4Nathans J. Weitz C.J. Agarwal N. Nir I. Papermaster D.S. Vision Res. 1989; 29: 907-914Crossref PubMed Scopus (42) Google Scholar, 6DeCaluwé G.L.J. VanOostrum J. Janssen J.J.M. DeGrip W.J. Methods Neurosci. 1993; 15: 307-321Crossref Scopus (22) Google Scholar). Quite pure preparations can be obtained using immunoaffinity chromatography (1Oprian D.D. Molday R.S. Kaufman R.J. Khorana H.G. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1987; 84: 8874-8878Crossref PubMed Scopus (387) Google Scholar). However, this approach is expensive (monoclonal antibody, peptides for elution), laborious (antibody production, purification, and coupling), and fairly inefficient (low column capacity, recovery only in the order of 50%). Hence, this procedure is not very suitable for production of larger amounts (1–10 mg of purified protein) required for structural studies (crystallization, FT-IR spectroscopy, 1The abbreviations used are: FT-IRFourier transform infraredIMACimmobilized metal affinity chromatographyv-Rhowild-type regenerated opsin produced in vitro by recombinant baculovirusv-Rhohisg6xC-terminally histidine-tagged regenerated opsin produced in vitro by recombinant baculovirusDoMdodecyl-β-1-maltosidePIPES1,4-piperazinediethanesulfonic acid;MES,4-morpholineethanesulfonic acidHEPPS4-(2-hydroxyethy1)-1-piperazinepropanesulfonic aciddsdouble-strandedNTAnitrilotriacetic acidPAGEpolyacrylamide gel electrophoresis NMR spectroscopy).
