VanOostrum J. Janssen J.J.M. DeGrip W.J. Methods Neurosci. 1993; 15: 307-321Crossref Scopus (22) Google Scholar, 7Janssen J.J.M. DeCaluwé G.L.J. DeGrip W.J. FEBS Lett. 1990; 260: 113-118Crossref PubMed Scopus (19) Google Scholar). Thus far, we have used concanavalin A-Sepharose affinity chromatography to purify rhodopsin produced in this system (6DeCaluwé G.L.J. VanOostrum J. Janssen J.J.M. DeGrip W.J. Methods Neurosci. 1993; 15: 307-321Crossref Scopus (22) Google Scholar), which, combined with reconstitution into proteoliposomes, yields reasonably pure preparations (60–80%). However, it is quite inefficient. Because of contaminating viral glycoproteins, the column capacity for recombinant rhodopsin is small, and a laborious elution profile has to be applied. Here we report on an alternative approach, using a histidine tag engineered onto the C terminus of bovine opsin. Histidine tagging for purification of recombinant proteins by means of IMAC has been used for a number of proteins both in prokaryotic (8Gentz R. Certa U. Takaes B. Matile H. Döbeli H. Pink R. Mackay M. Bone N. Scafi J.G. EMBO J. 1988; 7: 225-230Crossref PubMed Scopus (42) Google Scholar, 9Hochuli E. Bannwarth W. Dbbeli H. Gentz R. Stüber D. Bio/Technology. 1988; 6: 1321-1325Crossref Scopus (964) Google Scholar, 10Smith M.C. Furman T.C. Ingolia T.D. Pidgeon C. J. Biol. Chem. 1988; 263: 7211-7215Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar) and eukaryotic (11Janknecht R. DeMartynoff G. Lou J. Hipskind R.A. Nordheim A. Stunnenberg H.G. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1991; 88: 8972-8976Crossref PubMed Scopus (414) Google Scholar) expression systems, including recombinant baculovirus (12Chen X. Brash A.R. Funk C.D. Eur. J. Biochem. 1993; 214: 845-852Crossref PubMed Scopus (64) Google Scholar, 13Wang M. Bentley W.E. Vakharia V. Biotechnol. Bioeng. 1994; 43: 349-356Crossref PubMed Scopus (25) Google Scholar, 14Reddy R.G. Yoshimoto T. Yamamoto S. Funk C.D. Marnett L.J. Arch. Biochem. Biophys. 1994; 312: 219-226Crossref PubMed Scopus (23) Google Scholar). None of these proteins, however, belonged to the superfamily of heptahelical G-protein-coupled membrane receptors of which rhodopsin is a member. Membrane proteins have to be solubilized with the help of specific detergents which may impair affinity techniques. Hence, we have evaluated IMAC for purification of recombinant rhodopsin. Here we will demonstrate that an adapted IMAC allows relatively simple, highly efficient single-step purification of histidine-tagged rhodopsin with an excellent purification factor (≥500). The procedure we developed is directly applicable to other membrane (receptor) proteins. Interestingly, the C-terminally located histidine tag slightly influences spectral properties (3 nm red-shift) and photocascade (downshift of the pKa of the Meta I ↔ Meta II equilibrium) of rhodopsin, however, without perturbing the structural changes accompanying the photocascade. The effects are fully reversible at higher ionic strength and probably represent unexpected electrostatic effects on selected rhodopsin properties. Materials—Dodecyl-β-1-maltoside (DoM) and nonyl-β-1-glucoside were prepared as described previously (15DeGrip W.J. Bovee-Geurts P.H.M. Chem. Phys. Lipids. 1979; 23: 321-335Crossref Scopus (139) Google Scholar). PIPES, HEPPS and MES buffers were purchased from Research Organics Inc., Trolox from Aldrich, and leupeptin from Sigma. AgCl windows were obtained from Fisher Scientific Co. Construction of the Histidine Tag Transfer Vector (pAcJAC2)—A unique BamHI restriction sequence was engineered in front of the stop codon at the 3′-end of the cDNA-encoding bovine opsin (16Nathans J. Hogness D.S. Cell. 1983; 34: 807-814Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (482) Google Scholar) using the Bio-Rad MutaGene kit (Bio-Rad) according to the manufacturer’s instructions. This changed the original 3′-end coding sequence from 5′caa gtg gcg cct gcc taa gccc-3′ to 5′-caa gtg gat cct gcc taa gccc-3′ (Fig. 1B). Into this BamHI site we inserted a short synthetic dsDNA sequence with BamHI overhangs using the two complementary oligonucleotides 5′-gatcctcaccatcaccatcaccactagt-3′ and 5′-gatcactagtggtgatggtgatggtgag-3′. The resulting transfer vector, designated pAcJAC2 (Fig. 1A), encodes bovine opsin carrying 6 histidines at the C terminus (Fig. 1B). The sequence was confirmed by dideoxysequencing. We used pAcJAC2 to generate a recombinant baculovirus as described previously (17Janssen J.J.M. Mulder W.R. DeCaluwé G.L.J. Vlak J.M. DeGrip W.J. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 1991; 1089: 68-76Crossref PubMed Scopus (27) Google Scholar). Regeneration and Purification of v-Rhohis6x—Baculovirus propagation, transfection, isolation of recombinant virus, and Sf9 insect cell culture are performed as described previously (17Janssen J.J.M. Mulder W.R. DeCaluwé G.L.J. Vlak J.M. DeGrip W.J. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 1991; 1089: 68-76Crossref PubMed Scopus (27) Google Scholar, 18Summers M.D. Smith G.E. Texas Exp. Station Bull. 1987; 1555Google Scholar). Viral infection was performed at a multiplicity of infection of 5. Cells were harvested 3 days post-infection by centrifugation (4,000 × g, 10 min, 4 °C). Regeneration of v-opshis6x into v-Rhohis6x was accomplished in total cellular membrane preparations. Briefly, cell pellets were resuspended in buffer A (6.5 mm PIPES, 10 mm EDTA, 5 mm dithioerythritol, and 100 ng/ml leupeptin, pH 6.5) at 108 cells/ml and lysed upon homogenization (Potter-Elvehjem-tube). Homogenized cells were centrifuged (30,000 × g, 20 min, 4 °C), and the pellet was resuspended in buffer β (20 mm PIPES, 130 mm NaCl, 10 mm KCl, 3 mm MgCl2, 2 mm CaCl2, 0.1 mm EDTA, and 100 ng/ml leupeptin, pH 6.5). All subsequent manipulations were performed in a nitrogen atmosphere and under dim red light (Schott-Jena, RG 645 cut-off filter). Retina lipids were added in 100-fold molar excess over v-opshis6x, followed by 11-cis-retinal in a small volume of dimethylformamide (10-fold molar excess over v-opshis6x) and solid dodecyl-β-1-maltoside (DoM) to 0.5 mm. Samples were rotated for 2 h at room temperature and centrifuged (30,000 × g, 20 min, 4 °C). v-Rhohis6x was solubilized from the pellet in the same buffer that was used to bind v-Rhohis6x to the Ni2+ nitrilotriacetic acid agarose resin (Ni2+-NTA; Qiagen). Several buffers were evaluated for the IMAC. Buffer C consisted of 20 mm HEPPS, 0.5 M NaCl, 0.1 mm phenylmethylsulfonyl fluoride, 100 ng/ml leupeptin, 1 mm imidazole, 50 μμ Trolox, and 20 mm DoM (pH 8.0). Buffer D was identical with buffer C, except for 10 mm imidazole instead of 1 mm. Buffer E was identical with buffer C, except for buffer and pH: PIPES (pH 6.5) was used instead of HEPPS (8.0). The regenerated pellets were incubated with these buffers (1 ml/108 cells) for 2 h at room temperature to solubilize v-Rhohis6x. Extracts were centrifuged (30,000 × g, 20 min, 4 °C) to remove insoluble material, and glycerol was added to a concentration of 15% (w/v). The solubilized v-Rhohis6x was then applied to the Ni2+-NTA column at a flow rate of 1–2 ml/h for 16 h at 4 °C under continuous recycling. This flow rate was maintained throughout the entire procedure. Typically, we used a column volume of 1 ml for the v-Rhohis6x extract from 1–2 × 109 infected insect cells. Unbound material was eluted from the column with the same buffer that was used for loading of the sample except that it was supplemented with 15% (w/v) glycerol and 20 mm nonylglycose instead of 20 mm DoM (10 column volumes). This was followed by a second rinse using the same buffer, but now containing 25 mm imidazole (4 volumes). The bound v-Rhohis6x was then eluted from the column using the same buffer (C, D, or E) supplemented with 100 mm imidazole and containing 20 mm nonylglucose instead of DoM and 130 mm instead of 500 mm NaCl (6 volumes). Reconstitution of Purified v-Rhohis6x into Retina Lipids—Retina lipids were extracted from illuminated bovine retinae using standard procedures (19Hendriks T. Klompmakers A.A. Daemen F.J.M. Bonting S.L. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 1976; 433: 271-281Crossref Scopus (46) Google Scholar). The lipids were stored at –80 °C in the dichloromethane/methanol extract. Their concentration was determined by a modified Fiske-Subbarow phosphate assay (20Broekhuyse R.M. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 1968; 152: 307-315Crossref PubMed Scopus (289) Google Scholar). The aliquot required for reconstitution is dried with argon gas, dissolved in a small volume of methanol, and then diluted with buffer β containing 20 mm nonylglucose. Purified v-Rhohis6x was concentrated to 3–10 nmol/ml on an Omega 30K filter (Filtron, Northborough, MA) and mixed with 1 volume of retina lipid extract (100-fold molar excess). This mixture was layered on top of a sucrose step gradient (10%, 20%, and 45% (w/w) in 3 × diluted buffer B) and spun overnight (100,000 × g, ≥ 16 h, 4 °C). Reconstituted v-Rhohis6x was collected from the 20% and/or 45% interface. Collected proteoliposomes were either diluted with the required buffer, and used for analysis, or with distilled water, pelleted (80,000 × g, 1 h, 4 °C), and stored at –80 °C until further use. Immunoblot Analysis—Proteins were separated on a 12.5% SDS-polyacrylamide gel (21Laemmli U.K. Nature. 1970; 227: 680-685Crossref PubMed Scopus (207537) Google Scholar), transferred to nitrocellulose (Schleicher and Schull BA85, pore size 85), and probed with monoclonal or polyclonal antibodies (17Janssen J.J.M. Mulder W.R. DeCaluwé G.L.J. Vlak J.M. DeGrip W.J. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 1991; 1089: 68-76Crossref PubMed Scopus (27) Google Scholar). The anti-opsin antibodies Rho-1D4 (monoclonal) and CERNJS858 (polyclonal) have been described before (22Molday R.S. MacKenzie D. Biochemistry. 1983; 22: 653-660Crossref PubMed Scopus (355) Google Scholar, 23DeGrip W.J. Progr. Retinal Res. 1985; 4: 137-180Crossref Scopus (21) Google Scholar) and were used in 1:1000 dilution. The anti-histidine tag antiserum was obtained from Cappel, Organon Teknika N.V., Turnhout, Belgium and was also used 1:1000. UV/Vis Spectroscopy and Photolysis—UV/Vis spectroscopy to determine absorbance band shape and λmax was routinely performed at pH 6.5 in buffer β supplemented with 20 mm DoM using a Perkin-Elmer λ15 recording spectrophotometer. Detergent was added to prevent light-scattering artifacts. The spectrum of detergent-solubilized samples was recorded, after addition of 1 M hydroxylamine to 50 mm, before and after illumination (5 min, 300-watt light bulb, KG1 heat filter, Schott, Mainz, FRG). For accurate determination of the λmax, difference spectra were used (illuminated spectrum subtracted from the “dark” one). The late photointermediates Meta I, Meta II, and Meta III were studied at 10 °C in proteoliposomes of v-Rhohis6x, using isotonic solutions buffered with 20 mm PIPES (pH 6.5–7.0), 20 mm MES (pH 5.5–6.0), or 20 mm HEPPS (pH 7.5–9.5) (24Cotton R.G.H. Mutat. Res. 1993; 285: 125-144Crossref PubMed Scopus (241) Google Scholar). The photocascade was triggered by illumination for 15 s (Schott OG530 cut-off filter), and spectra were recorded every 3 minutes. After 30 min, hydroxylamine was added to 50 mm to convert all photoproducts into opsin and retinaloxime, and remaining rhodopsin was bleached away by a 5-min illumination. Fourier Transform Infrared (FT-IR) Difference Spectroscopy—FT-IR spectra of the rhodopsin → Meta II transition were recorded in principle as described previously (25Rothschild K.J. Gillespie J. DeGrip W.J. Biophys. J. 1987; 51: 345-350Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (50) Google Scholar, 26DeGrip W.J. Gray D. Gillespie J. Bovee-Geurts P.H.M. VanDenBerg E. Lugtenburg J. Rothschild K.J. Photochem. Photobiol. 1988; 48: 497-504Crossref PubMed Scopus (69) Google Scholar). Briefly, 1 nmol samples were deposited on AgCl windows by isopotential spin-drying (27DeGrip W.J. Gillespie J. Rothschild K.J. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 1985; 809: 97-106Crossref PubMed Scopus (48) Google Scholar). The resulting films were hydrated with 3 μl of MES buffer (pH 5.5), covered with another AgCl window, sealed with Teflon tape, and mounted into a variable temperature cell (Specac P/N21500, Kent, UK). FT-IR spectra were recorded on a Mattson Cygnus 100 spectrometer (Madison, WI) equipped with a liquid nitrogen-cooled, narrow band MCT detector. Sample hydration was monitored by the ratio between the peak absorbance near 3400 cm–1 (OH stretching mode of water) and near 2900 cm–1 (CH stretching mode of protein and lipids). Rhodopsin → Meta II difference spectra were recorded at 10 °C. Spectra were taken at 8 cm–1 resolution in 5-min blocks before and after illumination at (1280 scans/spectrum). Each sample was illuminated for 30 s in the spectrometer under computer control using a 12-V 20-watt halogen lamp equipped with Schott KG1 and OG530 cut-off filters. Difference spectra were computed by subtracting spectra before illumination from spectra taken after illumination, using the EXPERT-IR software (Mattson). Construction of the Histidine Tag Transfer Vector pAcJAC2 and Generation of Recombinant Virus—In order to introduce a tag consisting of six histidines at the C terminus of bovine opsin, the transfer vector pAcJAC2 was constructed (Fig. 1A). pAcJAC2 is derived from the baculovirus transfer vector pAcDZ1 (28Zuidema D. Schouten A. Usmany M. Maule A.J. Belsham G.J. Roosien J. Klinge-Roode E.C. VanLent J.W.M. Vlak J.M. J. Gen. Virol. 1990; 71: 2201-2209Crossref PubMed Scopus (76) Google Scholar). A short synthetic sequence encoding a histidine tag followed by a stop codon was introduced at the C terminus using two complementary oligonucleotides (Fig. 1B). As a result, the two alanine residues at the C terminus of opsin (Ala-346 and Ala-348) were substituted by an aspartic acid and the first histidine residue, respectively (Fig. 1B). These substitutions concern residues, which are not highly conserved. Also, the aspartic acid residue introduced should partly counterbalance the additional charge carried by the histidine tag. In pAcJAC2, opsin biosynthesis is controlled by the polyhedrin promoter while the small heat shock promoter of hsp70, drives the biosynthesis of β-galactosidase, which functions as a reporter enzyme (17Janssen J.J.M. Mulder W.R. DeCaluwé G.L.J. Vlak J.M. DeGrip W.J. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 1991; 1089: 68-76Crossref PubMed Scopus (27) Google Scholar, 28Zuidema D. Schouten A. Usmany M. Maule A.J. Belsham G.J. Roosien J. Klinge-Roode E.C. VanLent J.W.M. Vlak J.M. J. Gen. Virol. 1990; 71: 2201-2209Crossref PubMed Scopus (76) Google Scholar). Expression of v-opshis6x using Recombinant Virus AcNPV/opshis—Protein samples derived from recombinant virus-infected Sf9 cells were analyzed by immunoblot, using a polyclonal antiserum elicited against bovine opsin (Fig. 2A). Wild-type virus-infected Sf9 cells are used as a negative control, and native bovine opsin and wild-type v-ops as positive controls (Fig. 2A, lanes 1, 2, and 4). The presence of the histidine tag in v-opshis6x was confirmed by the following observations: 1) only v-opshis6x is recognized by the histidine tag antibody (see below), 2) the apparent molecular mass of v-opshis6x is larger (by about 2 kDa) than that of native opsin and v-ops (Fig. 2A, lane 3 versus lanes 2 and 4), 3) v-opshis6x does not react with the monoclonal antibody 1D4 (Fig. 2B, lane 1 versus 2), since the C-terminal histidine tag extension eliminates the epitope for this antibody (29Molday R.S. Progr. Retinal Res. 1989; 8: 173-209Crossref Scopus (68) Google Scholar). Hence, recombinant virus AcNPV/opshis directs expression of a fully intact histidine-tagged v-ops. The expression level varies between 20 and 30 pmol/106 cells, which is comparable to wild-type v-ops (6DeCaluwé G.L.J. VanOostrum J. Janssen J.J.M. DeGrip W.J. Methods Neurosci. 1993; 15: 307-321Crossref Scopus (22) Google Scholar). Regeneration and Purification of v-Rhohis6x—To convert expressed v-opshis6x into v-Rhohis6x, we incubated total membranes, harvested at 3 days post-infection from infected Sf9 cells, with 11-cis-retinal. Spectral analysis of regenerated samples showed that this resulted in 18 ± 2 pmol of v-Rhohis6x per 106 cells (n = 7). For purification by IMAC, regenerated samples were solubilized using DoM as a detergent and loaded onto a Ni2+-NTA agarose column. This column appeared to bind v-Rhohis6x with high capacity. Proteins, which have natural affinity for metal ions are bound as well. A variety of washing and elution conditions have been tested to remove this contamination as much as possible without sacrificing binding capacity of the column and recovery of v-Rhohis6x. Eluted fractions were analyzed by SDS-PAGE (protein pattern), immunoblotting (anti-rhodopsin CERNJS858 antiserum), and by UV/Vis spectroscopy (A500 to detect and quantify v-Rhohis6x; ratio A280/A500 as a purity indicator). Typical results are presented in Fig. 3 and Table I. Lane 1 in Fig. 3, A, B, and C, presents the total extract of Sf9 membranes after regeneration. Only by immunoblot analysis can glycosylated v-opshis6x be identified (arrow) together with a minor amount of unglycosylated species (arrowhead). The nonbound, flow-through fraction shows a very similar protein pattern (lane 2), except that most v-Rhohis6x has bound, since only minimal amounts of the glycosylated form are detected in this fraction. Additional washings with extraction buffer (buffer C) elute a complex protein population (Fig. 3, lanes 3 and 4), probably representing aspecifically or very weakly bound proteins. The nonglycosylated v-opshis6x is already strongly present in these fractions (Fig. 3, β and C, lanes 2–4, arrowhead) and apparently is not very well retained by the column. Protein contamination, weakly interacting with the column, could be eluted by raising the imidazole concentration to 25 mM (Fig. 3, lane 5). Under these conditions, a minor amount of v-Rhohis6x was eluted. Most of the specifically bound v-Rhohis6x, however, only was eluted upon raising the imidazole concentration to 100 mM (Fig. 3, lane 6). This fraction also contains a minor amount of nonglycosylated species and is still contaminated by several other minor bands (Fig. 3A, lane 6, open arrowheads).Table IGeneral characteristics of v-Rhohis6× purification by IMAC as determined by UV/Vis spectroscopyConditionBuffer CBuffer ESolubization (%)100 ± 20100 ± 8Nonbound (%)8 ± 55 ± 6Recovery (%)84 ± 480 ± 5A280/A5002.7 ± 0.42.4 ±0.4 Open table in a new tab The amount of nonglycosylated v-opshis6x in the DoM extract and column fractions varied between different experiments, but it was always present at immunodetectable levels (data not shown). In addition, immunoblots showed the presence of a third opsin species (Fig. 3B, lanes 1–4) which on SDS-PAGE gels migrated between the glycosylated and nonglycosylated v-opshis6x. This species did not react with the anti-histidine tag antibody (Fig. 3C, lanes 1–4). We were unable to detect this band in the final purified v-Rhohis6x fraction (Fig. 3B, lane 6). An overview of IMAC results obtained under two conditions, as determined by spectroscopic analysis, is given in Table I. Nearly complete binding of v-Rhohis6x to the Ni2+-NTA agarose was attained. At pH 8.0 (buffer C), a pH at which IMAC is usually performed, an average recovery of 84% was achieved with a purification factor of at least 450. An attempt to reduce contamination by weakly binding proteins, by applying the membrane extract in the presence of a higher imidazole concentration (10 mM; buffer D), resulted in a much higher loss of v-Rhohis6x and in fact lowered the purification factor (not shown). Finally, the performance of the procedure we developed at pH 8.0, was evaluated at pH 6.5, since rhodopsin and most of its mutants are thermally much more stable at the latter pH. This actually improved the purification factor to at least 500, without significant reduction in recovery (Table I, buffer E). At pH 6.5, best v-Rhohis6x samples had a purity of 80–85% (A280/A500 ratio of 2.0–2.1), and the average purity of combined fractions was 70–75%. The maximal capacity of the Ni2+-NTA agarose column for v-Rhohis6x has not been determined exactly but is at least 35 nmol/ml bed volume. The efficiency of this IMAC procedure is spectrally illustrated in Fig. 4A. Curve 1 represents the total membrane extract applied to the column, while curve 2 presents the spectrum of the combined purified v-Rhohis6x fractions. The contamination in the v-Rhohis6x fraction obtained after IMAC resides in several minor bands. These are largely removed upon subsequent reconstitution of v-Rhohis6x into retina lipid proteoliposomes, which represent a more native-like environment, we routinely use to analyze functional properties of recombinant rhodopsin (6DeCaluwé G.L.J. VanOostrum J. Janssen J.J.M. DeGrip W.J. Methods Neurosci. 1993; 15: 307-321Crossref Scopus (22) Google Scholar). Bovee-Geurts P.H.M. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 1983; 734: 168-179Crossref Scopus (26) Google Scholar). The resulting v-Rhohis6x proteoliposomes contain at least 95% rhodopsin on a protein base and are suitable for all functional analyses (Fig. 3A, lane 8) Spectral Properties and Photocascade of v-Rhohis6x—Curve 2 in Fig. 4A is a typical absorbance spectrum of the combined v-Rhohis6x fractions obtained after IMAC purification. Illumination of v-Rhohis6x “bleaches” the main absorbance band at 500 nm, and we used difference spectra to calculate the λmax more accurately. Unexpectedly, the absorbance band of v-Rhohis6x turns out to be slightly red-shifted (λmax = 501 ± 1 nm, n = 7) relative to wild-type (λmax = 498 ± 1 nm) (Fig. 4S). This slight but significant red shift has been observed in all samples produced so far, both before and after IMAC purification. Transfection of PC12-variant RS1 cells with an Egr-1 expression construct has previously been shown to stimulate phenylethanolamine N-methyltransferase (PNMT) promoter activity, thus suggesting a putative role of Egr-1 as a factor regulating PNMT gene expression. To elucidate the physiological implication of this finding, the effects of phorbol 12-myristate 13-acetate (PMA) on PNMT promoter activity and Egr-1 expression were examined. PMA stimulated luciferase expression in RS1 cells transfected with a rat PNMT promoter-luciferase reporter gene construct, and also elevated both Egr-1 mRNA and Egr-1 protein levels in the untransfected cells. Further study on the concentration dependence of PMA action showed that the stimulation of luciferase expression correlated with the elevation of Egr-1 mRNA level. Finally, the stimulatory action of PMA on luciferase expression was dramatically diminished in the cells transfected with a mutant construct in which the Egr-1 binding site in PNMT promoter was mutated. These findings suggest that PMA-stimulated PNMT gene expression requires the enhancement of Egr-1 expression, thus providing further evidence for the physiological role of Egr-1 in the regulation of PNMT gene expression in the adrenergic cell. PMA stimulated luciferase expression in RS1 cells transfected with a rat PNMT promoter-luciferase reporter gene construct, and also elevated both Egr-1 mRNA and Egr-1 protein levels in the untransfected cells. Further study on the concentration dependence of PMA action showed that the stimulation of luciferase expression correlated with the elevation of Egr-1 mRNA level. Finally, the stimulatory action of PMA on luciferase expression was dramatically diminished in the cells transfected with a mutant construct in which the Egr-1 binding site in PNMT promoter was mutated. These findings suggest that PMA-stimulated PNMT gene expression requires the enhancement of Egr-1 expression, thus providing further evidence for the physiological role of Egr-1 in the regulation of PNMT gene expression in the adrenergic cell. Regulation of phenylethanolamine N-methyltransferase (PNMT, 1The abbreviations used are: PNMTphenylethanolamine N-methyltransferasePMAphorbol 12-myristate 13-acetateMe2SOdimethyl sulfoxidebpbase pair(s)ACTHadrenocorticotropic hormone1The abbreviations used are: PNMTphenylethanolamine N-methyltransferasePMAphorbol 12-myristate 13-acetateMe2SOdimethyl sulfoxidebpbase pair(s)ACTHadrenocorticotropic hormone EC 2.1.1.28), the enzyme catalyzing the conversion of norepinephrine to epinephrine, has been extensively investigated to elucidate the mechanism regulating the biosynthesis of epinephrine, a potent mediator released from the adrenal medulla for maintaining the internal homeostasis, which also has been implicated in a variety of cardiovascular disorders. The examination of the proximal promoter/regulatory region of the PNMT gene has shown that there are two potential Egr-1 binding elements located at –45 bp and –165 bp upstream of the transcription start site, thus raising the possibility that PNMT gene expression may be modulated through the interaction of Egr-1 with PNMT promoter. We have recently shown that PNMT gene expression is markedly enhanced by transfection of RS1 cells with an Egr-1 expression construct, and that this enhancement is markedly reduced by mutation of the Egr-1 consensus binding element in the PNMT promoter (42Ebert S.N. Balt S.L. Hunter J.P.B. Gashler A. Sukhatme V. Wong D.L. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 20885-20898Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). However, because Egr-1 protein is considered to be overexpressed in the cells transfected with the Egr-1 expression construct, the involvement of endogenous Egr-1 in the regulation of PNMT gene expression still remains to be elucidated. To elucidate the physiological role of Egr-1 in the regulation of PNMT gene expression, we examined the effect of phorbol 12-myristate 13-acetate (PMA), which is known to stimulate the expression of endogenous Egr-1 gene, on PNMT promoter activity in RS1 cells transfected with a rat PNMT promoter-luciferase gene construct, and found that the reporter gene expression was markedly enhanced by treatment of the transfected cells with PMA. Furthermore, PMA was also shown to enhance endogenous Egr-1 mRNA level in RS1 cells, and this enhancement of Egr-1 mRNA expression was tightly correlated with that of reporter gene expression. These findings provide further evidence for the physiological role of Egr-1 as a factor regulating PNMT gene expression in the adrenergic cell. Cell Culture—RS1 cells were isolated by hygromycin selection from PC12 cells transfected with a plasmid containing the rat glucocorticoid receptor cDNA and the hygromycin resistance gene, and established as a subline of PC12 cells as described previously (42Ebert S.N. Balt S.L. Hunter J.P.B. Gashler A. Sukhatme V. Wong D.L. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 20885-20898Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Cells were maintained as monolayer cultures on a 100-mm culture dish in 10 ml of Dulbecco’s modified Eagle’s medium supplemented with 5% bovine calf serum, 5% horse serum, gentamycin sulfate (50 μg/ml), and hygromycin β (100 units/ml) at 37 °C in a 93% air, 7% CO2 atmosphere. Plasmids—PNMT promoter-luciferase gene construct pRP863LUC, the promoterless luciferase construct pbsLUC, the mutant PNMT promoter-luciferase gene construct pRPmutALUC, and the β-galactosidase expression plasmid pON405 were generated as described previously (42Ebert S.N. Balt S.L. Hunter J.P.B. Gashler A. Sukhatme V. Wong D.L. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 20885-20898Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). The wild-type PNMT promoter-luciferase gene construct pRP863LUC contains two Egr-1 consensus elements at –45 and –165 bp and a glucocorticoid response element at –513 bp within its promoter/regulatory sequences. To generate the Egr-1 plasmid pbsEgr1–303, the 303-bp cDNA fragment was isolated from the Egr-1 expression plasmid pCMVEgr-1 (43Gupta M.P. Gupta M. Zak R. Sukhatme V.P. J. Biol. Chem. 1991; 266: 12813-12816Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar) by restriction digestion with EcoRl and BglII, and then inserted into the EcoRI-BamHI sites of pBluescript SK. Transient Transfection—RS1 cells were plated on a collagen-coated 24-well cluster plate at a density of 2 × 105 cells/well, and transfected with 1 μg/ml of the PNMT promoter-luciferase gene construct, pRP863LUC, at 24 h after plating using calcium phosphate precipitation by the method of Wigler et al. (44Wigler M. Pellicer A. Silverstein S. Axel R. Urlaub G. Chasin L. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1979; 76: 1373-1376Crossref PubMed Scopus (835) Google Scholar) with modifications (42Ebert S.N. Balt S.L. Hunter J.P.B. Gashler A. Sukhatme V. Wong D.L. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 20885-20898Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). The transfected cells were incubated for 20 h in 1 ml of the culture medium after exposure to 15% dimethyl sulfoxide (Me2SO) for 2 min, and then treated with PMA in the medium for different time periods in a humidified incubator. PMA was stored as stock solution dissolved in Me2SO, and this solution was directly added to the cell cultures or diluted with the culture medium before use. The final concentration of Me2SO in the cell cultures was less than 0.4%. To monitor transfection efficiency, β-galactosidase expression plasmid pON405 (0.2 μg/ml) was simultaneously transfected into the cells, and β-galactosidase activity was then determined. No significant difference in the transfection efficiency was observed under the experimental conditions used here. Luciferase Assay—Cells were washed twice with phosphate-buffered saline after discarding the medium by aspiration, and lysed by adding 120 μl of the cell lysis buffer and subjecting them to a freeze-thaw cycle. The lysates were centrifuged at 13,000 × g for 10 min at 4 °C in an Eppendorf Microfuge, and luciferase activity in 20 μl of the cell lysates was determined using the Luciferase Assay System. A calibration curve for luciferase expression was generated using purified firefly luciferase, and the cell extracts were appropriately diluted to measure the enzyme activity within the linear range. Total protein in the cell extracts was measured by the method of Bradford (45Bradford M.M. Anal. Biochem. 1976; 72: 248-254Crossref PubMed Scopus (214148) Google Scholar) using bovine immunoglobulin G as a standard. Hybridization Probes—To generate an antisense Egr-1 riboprobe, the plasmid pbsEgr1–303 was linearized by restriction digestion with XhoI, and the transcription was then carried out with T3 RNA polymerase at 37 °C for 60 min in the reaction mixture containing [α-32P]rUTP as described previously (47Wong D.L. Lesage A. White S. Siddall B. Dev. Brain Res. 1992; 67: 229-236Crossref PubMed Scopus (15) Google Scholar). A sense Egr-1 RNA was generated using T7 RNA polymerase and the pbsEgr1–303 linearized with XbaI. Similarly, an antisense glyceraldehyde-3′-phosphate dehydrogenase riboprobe (376 bp) was generated using T3 RNA polymerase and a commercially available DNA pTRI-GAPDH-rat as a template. After digesting with DNase I, the transcripts were isolated from the mixture by the method described previously (48Bordonaro M. Saccomanno C.F. Nordstrom J.L. BioTechniques. 1994; 16: 428-430PubMed Google Scholar). RNA Preparation and RNase Protection Assay—Total RNA was prepared from RS1 cells by a single-step purification method (46Ausubel F.M. Brent R. Kingston R.E. Moore D.D. Seidman J.G. Smith J.A. Struhl K. Current Protocols in Molecular Biology.1st Ed. John Wiely & Sons, New York1989Google Scholar), and the expression of Egr-1 mRNA was then determined by ribonuclease protection assay (47Wong D.L. Lesage A. White S. Siddall B. Dev. Brain Res. 1992; 67: 229-236Crossref PubMed Scopus (15) Google Scholar) with modifications (48Bordonaro M. Saccomanno C.F. Nordstrom J.L. BioTechniques. 1994; 16: 428-430PubMed Google Scholar). Briefly, total RNA (10 μg) was hybridized with 32P-labeled riboprobe (1 × 105 dpm, specific activity = 8.4 × 107 dpm/µg) at 45 °C overnight, and digested in 300 μl of ribonuclease mixture containing ribonuclease1 A (2 μg/ml) and ribonuclease T1 (0.5 units/ml) at 37 °C for 60 min. Ribonucleases in the incubation mixture were inactivated by digestion with proteinase K followed by the addition of guanidine thiocyanate, and the protected RNA fragments were then separated by denaturing polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis. Autoradiograms were prepared from the gels, and the signals were quantified by computerized densitometry using Image 1.36 software (NIH). Sense Egr-1 mRNA standards were also run through the entire procedure to determine the linear range, and the autoradiogram within the linear range was selected for densitometric analysis. Glyceraldehyde-3′-phosphate dehydrogenase mRNA level in each sample was also determined concurrently using the 32P-labeled glyceraldehyde-3′-phosphate dehydrogenase riboprobe (1 × 104 dpm, specific activity = 1.7 × 106 dpm/µg), and Egr-1 mRNA level was expressed relative to glyceraldehyde-3′-phosphate dehydrogenase mRNA level. Gel Mobility Shift Assay—Nuclear extracts were prepared from RS1 cells treated with PMA as described previously (42Ebert S.N. Balt S.L. Hunter J.P.B. Gashler A. Sukhatme V. Wong D.L. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 20885-20898Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar), and gel mobility shift assay was performed according to the method of Muller (49Muller M.T. J. Virol. 1987; 61: 858-865Crossref PubMed Google Scholar) with adaptations (42Ebert S.N. Balt S.L. Hunter J.P.B. Gashler A. Sukhatme V. Wong D.L. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 20885-20898Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). The oligonucleotide (21 bp) containing the consensus sequence of the Egr-1 binding element was labeled with [γ-32P]αTP at the 5′ end using T4 polynucleotide kinase. The 32P-labeled oligonucleotide probe was mixed with nuclear extracts (10 μg of protein) in 25 μl of the binding solution, and then incubated for 60 min on ice. The reaction mixture was analyzed by polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis. For gel mobility shift assay with antibodies, the antibodies (1 μg of protein) were directly added to the binding mixture. Chemicals—[α-32P]rUTP and [γ-32P]dATP were purchased from DuPont NEN. The anti-Egr-1 antibodies (588, 675, and C-19) and the anti-Sp-1 antibody (PEP2) were obtained from Santa Cruz Biotechnology, Inc. (Santa Cruz, CA). The In Vitro Transcription Kit was from Stratagene (La Jolla, CA). The glyceraldehyde-3′-phosphate dehydrogenase-template DNA, pTRI-GAPDH-rat, was from Ambion (Austin, TX). The Luciferase Assay System and ribonucleases were from Promega, Inc. (Madison, WI). Purified firefly luciferase, proteinase K, and PMA were from Sigma. Other chemicals used here were commercially available reagent grade or ultrapure grade. Data Analysis—All data are presented as the mean ± S.E., and the statistical significance of the difference between two groups was determined using Student’s t test. A p value of <0.001 was accepted as a statistically significant difference. Effect of PMA on PNMT Promoter Activity—RS1 cells were transfected with the rat PNMT promoter-luciferase gene construct pRP863LUC, and the effect of PMA on PNMT promoter activity was then examined by measuring luciferase expression. As shown in Fig. 1, luciferase activity was rapidly and markedly enhanced by treatment of the transfected cells with 80 nM PMA, and a significant increase in the enzyme activity was already apparent at 2 h after exposure to the drug. Luciferase activity reached maximum level at 6 h, remained at the same level through 12 h, and decreased gradually to basal level by 36 h. In contrast, luciferase activity was only slightly altered by exposure of these transfected cells to the vehicle (0.4% Me2SO). PMA was also shown to stimulate the reporter gene expression in a concentration-dependent manner. As shown in Fig. 2, the significant enhancement of luciferase expression was observed by treatment of the cells with 4 nM PMA, and the maximum stimulation was obtained at about 40 nM PMA. These results indicated that PMA stimulated PNMT promoter activity in RS1 cells. Effect of PMA on the Egr-1 Gene Expression—Total RNA was prepared from cells treated with PMA, and Egr-1 mRNA level was determined to examine the effect of PMA on Egr-1 gene expression in RS1 cells. As shown in Fig. 3, PMA caused a marked and transient increase in Egr-1 mRNA level. A significant increase in the Egr-1 mRNA level was observed at 30 min, and the maximum increase was observed at 60 min after exposure to PMA, followed by the rapid decrease to basal level by 4 h. In addition, the effect of PMA on Egr-1 protein expression was also examined using gel mobility shift assay. Nuclear extracts were prepared from the cells, and incubated with the radiolabeled oligonucleotide probe containing the Egr-1 binding element at –165 bp (designated site A) in the PNMT promoter. As shown in Fig. 4, the oligonucleotide probe formed two major DNA-protein binding complexes with the nuclear extracts (bands 1 and 2). The intensity of lower band (band 2) was enhanced when the probe was incubated with the nuclear extract prepared from the cells treated with PMA (80 nM) for 1 h (lane 3). By comparison, the intensity of band 2 observed with the nuclear extracts prepared from the cells treated with PMA for 4 h (lane 4) was lower, but still significantly higher than its intensity observed with the nuclear extracts obtained from the untreated cells (lane 2). The intensity of band 2 was not significantly different from the control level when the probe was incubated with the extracts obtained from the cells treated with PMA for 8 h or longer (lanes 5–7). If the same nuclear extracts were incubated with the probe containing the Egr-1 binding element at –45 bp (site B) in the PNMT promoter, the same DNA-protein complexes were observed, although the intensities of these bands were much lower in comparison with those obtained using the site A probe (data not shown). These results indicated that PMA could stimulate the expression of nuclear protein which could bind preferentially to the Egr-1 binding site A in the PNMT promoter. Based on previous findings (42Ebert S.N. Balt S.L. Hunter J.P.B. Gashler A. Sukhatme V. Wong D.L. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 20885-20898Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar), it seemed reasonable to assume that this newly expressed protein in the PMA-treated cells might be Egr-1.FIG. 4Effect of PMA on Egr-1 protein expression in RS1 cell. 32P-Labeled oligonucleotide probe containing the consensus sequence of Egr-1 binding element (site A) was incubated with (lanes 2–7) or without (lane 1) nuclear extracts prepared from the untreated cells (lane 2) or the cells treated with PMA (80 nM) for 1 (lane 3), 4 (lane 4), 8 (lane 5), 16 (lane 6), and 24 h (lane 7), and the gel mobility shift assay was performed as described in the text.View Large Image Figure ViewerDownload Hi-res image Download (PPT) To verify that Egr-1 protein was a component of this DNA-protein complex, the effects of antibodies against Egr-1 proteins on DNA-protein complex were examined. As shown in Fig. 5, the addition of anti-Egr-1 antibody 588 (lane 2) or C-19 (lane 3), which recognize the carboxyl terminus of the 80–82-kDa form of Egr-1 protein, to the binding mixture caused a supershift of the slow migrating complex, thus decreasing the intensity of lower band (band 2, lanes 2 and 3). In contrast, neither the migration pattern nor the intensity of this band was altered with the anti-Egr-1 antibody 675, which recognizes only the 88-kDa form of Egr-1 (lane 4). On the other hand, none of these anti-Egr-1 antibodies caused any supershift or reduction in intensity of the slow-migrating band (band 1) formed with nuclear extracts prepared from the PMA-treated cells (lanes 2–4). However, when the anti-SP1 antibody PEP2 was included in the binding mixture, a supershift of the fast-migrating complex (band 1), which has previously been shown to contain SP1 protein as a component (42Ebert S.N. Balt S.L. Hunter J.P.B. Gashler A. Sukhatme V. Wong D.L. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 20885-20898Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar), was clearly observed (lane 5). These results indicated that Egr-1 protein was rapidly and transiently induced by treatment of the cells with PMA, and this newly expressed Egr-1 protein seemed to bind preferentially to the Egr-1 binding element site A in the PNMT promoter. Correlation of Egr-1 Expression with PNMT Gene Activation—To answer the critical question of whether the changes in Egr-1 expression observed here were directly related to the activation of PNMT promoter, the stimulatory actions of different concentrations of PMA on Egr-1 mRNA expression as well as luciferase expression were determined, and the correlation between these two parameters was examined by linear regression analysis. As shown in Fig. 6A, the treatment of RS1 cells with PMA caused the elevation of Egr-1 mRNA level as well as the enhancement of luciferase expression in a concentration-dependent manner. Both Egr-1 mRNA expression and luciferase expression were significantly enhanced by 4 nM PMA, and reached the maximum level at 40 nM. Within the concentration range used here, the elevation of Egr-1 mRNA level caused by PMA was clearly shown to be highly correlated (r = 0.99) with that of luciferase expression (Fig. 6B). In previous studies (26Kharbanda S. Nakamura T. Stone R. Hass R. Bernstein S. Datta R. Sukhatme V.P. Kufe D. J. Clin. Invest. 1991; 88: 571-577Crossref PubMed Scopus (92) Google Scholar, 27Hass R. Brach M. Gunji H. Kharbanda S. Kufe D. Biochem. Pharmacol. 1992; 44: 1569-1576Crossref PubMed Scopus (23) Google Scholar), the expression of Egr-1 mRNA in U-937 leukemia cells has been shown to be enhanced by treatment of the cells with a phorbol ester 12-O-tetradecanoylphorbol-13-acetate, and this enhancement of Egr-1 mRNA has also been shown to be reduced by pretreatment of the cells with a synthetic glucocorticoid dexamethasone. In view of these findings, it seemed reasonable that the stimulatory action of PMA on luciferase activity as well as its stimulatory action on Egr-1 mRNA expression observed in RS1 cells might be repressed by dexamethasone, if the enhancement of Egr-1 expression was a prerequisite for the stimulation of PNMT gene expression. As shown in Fig. 7, both the stimulation of Egr-1 mRNA expression in the untransfected cells and that of luciferase expression in the transfected cells were repressed in the same extent by pretreatment of the cells with dexamethasone. These results suggested that the elevation of Egr-1 expression caused by PMA might be directly related to the stimulation of PNMT promoter activity. As further evidence for the relationship between Egr-1 expression and PNMT gene expression, the cells were transfected with the mutant PNMT promoter-luciferase reporter gene construct pRPmutALUC, in which the consensus sequence of Egr-1 binding site A at –165 bp in the PNMT promoter region was mutated, and the effect of PMA on the reporter gene expression in these transfected cells was examined. As shown in Fig. 8, the stimulatory action of PMA on luciferase expression was markedly reduced in the cells transfected with the mutant construct. Less than 2-fold increase in the luciferase expression was observed at 80 nM PMA, which was twice as high as the concentration required to cause the maximum stimulation of luciferase expression in the cells transfected with the wild-type construct. These results provided additional evidence for the correlation of Egr-1 expression with the stimulation of PNMT promoter activity in the RS1 cell. Previous study has shown that the expression of luciferase reporter gene is markedly enhanced by cotransfecting PC12-variant RS1 cells with the PNMT promoter-luciferase gene construct and the Egr-1 expression construct, thus suggesting that the transcription factor Egr-1 can activate PNMT gene expression in the adrenergic cell (42Ebert S.N. Balt S.L. Hunter J.P.B. Gashler A. Sukhatme V. Wong D.L. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 20885-20898Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). However, since Egr-1 protein is presumably overexpressed beyond its physiological range by introducing the exogenous gene construct into the cells, a role of Egr-1 as an intrinsic factor regulating PNMT gene expression still remains to be elucidated. To further examine a possible relationship between Egr-1 expression and PNMT gene expression in RS1 cells, the expression of endogenous Egr-1 was stimulated with a phorbol ester PMA in the cells transfected with PNMT promoter-luciferase reporter gene construct, and the PNMT promoter activity was determined by measuring the reporter gene expression. Luciferase expression was shown to be markedly and transiently enhanced by treatment of the cells with PMA (Fig. 1), and this enhancement was observed in a concentration-dependent manner (Fig. 2). In contrast, PMA failed to cause any significant effect on luciferase expression in the cells transfected with the promoterless luciferase construct under the same conditions (data not shown). Thus, PMA seems to enhance the reporter gene expression through its specific action on the PNMT promoter. The effect of PMA on Egr-1 mRNA expression was examined to verify the possibility that the stimulation of PNMT promoter observed here is mediated by Egr-1. Treatment of the cells with PMA was shown to cause a marked and transient increase in the Egr-1 mRNA level (Fig. 3). Similarly, the expression of Egr-1 protein was significantly enhanced by treatment of the cells with PMA (FIG. 4, FIG. 5). Thus, the elevation of Egr-1 mRNA level caused by PMA is confirmed to be accompanied by the enhancement of Egr-1 protein expression in the RS1 cell. Previous study has shown that several DNA-protein complexes were obtained when the oligonucleotide probe containing the consensus sequence of Egr-1 binding site A was incubated with nuclear extracts prepared from RS1 cells, and the intensity of each complex was specifically enhanced with the nuclear extracts prepared from the cells transfected with the functional Egr-1 expression construct (42Ebert S.N. Balt S.L. Hunter J.P.B. Gashler A. Sukhatme V. Wong D.L. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 20885-20898Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). In contrast, the present study showed that two major DNA-protein complexes (bands 1 and 2) were obtained when the same probe was incubated with the nuclear extracts, and one of these complexes (band 2) specifically increased in intensity with the nuclear extracts prepared from the PMA-treated cells (Fig. 4). Further study using specific antibodies against SP1 protein or Egr-1 proteins showed that the fast-migrating complex (band 2), the intensity of which was markedly enhanced by treatment of the cells with PMA, contained the 80–82-kDa Egr-1 protein, and the slow-migrating complex (band 1) contained the SP1 protein (Fig. 5). Thus, PMA seems to specifically stimulate the Egr-1 expression. These results further indicate that the elevation of Egr-1 protein as well as Egr-1 mRNA level occurs prior to the enhancement of luciferase expression, thereby consistent with the interpretation that PMA enhances Egr-1 expression, leading to the activation of PNMT promoter in the RS1 cell. As further evidence that the stimulation of both Egr-1 expression and PNMT promoter activity was not merely coincidental and unrelated, the concentration-dependent effect of PMA on Egr-1 mRNA expression as well as PNMT promoter activity was examined to determine whether the elevation of luciferase expression was related to Egr-1 mRNA level. Both luciferase expression and Egr-1 mRNA expression increased as a function of PMA concentration (Fig. 6A), and these changes were shown to be tightly correlated (Fig. 6B). The effect of dexamethasone on luciferase expression as well as Egr-1 mRNA expression was examined, since the previous studies have suggested that the phorbol ester-induced stimulation of Egr-1 mRNA expression could be inhibited by dexamethasone (26Kharbanda S. Nakamura T. Stone R. Hass R. Bernstein S. Datta R. Sukhatme V.P. Kufe D. J. Clin. Invest. 1991; 88: 571-577Crossref PubMed Scopus (92) Google Scholar, 27Hass R. Brach M. Gunji H. Kharbanda S. Kufe D. Biochem. Pharmacol. 1992; 44: 1569-1576Crossref PubMed Scopus (23) Google Scholar). Dexamethasone caused the repression of PMA-stimulated luciferase expression in the transfected cells, similar in extent to that of PMA-induced Egr-1 mRNA expression in the untransfected cells (Fig. 7). These findings suggest that dexamethasone causes the inhibition of PMA-stimulated luciferase expression as a consequence of inhibiting the stimulatory action of PMA on Egr-1 expression, thus providing further evidence that the elevation of Egr-1 mRNA level is directly related to that of luciferase expression. While the inhibitory actions of dexamethasone reported here seem to contradict an additional increase in the reporter gene expression which we have reported earlier (42Ebert S.N. Balt S.L. Hunter J.P.B. Gashler A. Sukhatme V. Wong D.L. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 20885-20898Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar), in fact, this is not the case. In the previous study, Egr-1 expression and hence, luciferase expression induced by Egr-1 from the PNMT promoter, was determined by the Egr-1 expression plasmid. Dexamethasone caused an additional increase in luciferase expression presumably through the glucocorticoid response element located at –513 bp in the PNMT promoter. In contrast, the inhibitory action of dexamethasone on the reporter gene expression is exerted through the inhibition of PMA-induced activation of endogenous Egr-1 expression. By limiting the amount of Egr-1, dexamethasone thereby limits the transcriptional activity from the PNMT promoter. Mutation of the consensus sequence of the binding element in the promoter region of the gene is one of the most effective methods to verify the involvement of transcription factor in the regulation of that gene. We have previously shown that mutation of the consensus sequence of Egr-1 binding site A can markedly reduce both the binding of Egr-1 protein to the DNA sequence and luciferase expression in the cells cotransfected with the mutant PNMT promoter-luciferase reporter gene construct and the Egr-1 expression construct (42Ebert S.N. Balt S.L. Hunter J.P.B. Gashler A. Sukhatme V. Wong D.L. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 20885-20898Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). In the present study, the effect of PMA on luciferase expression in the cells transfected with this mutant construct was examined to obtain additional evidence for the involvement of Egr-1 in the mechanism underlying the stimulatory action of PMA on the PNMT promoter observed here. In contrast to the cells transfected with the wild-type construct, the stimulation of luciferase expression by PMA treatment was markedly reduced in the cells transfected with the mutant construct (Fig. 8). This finding provides the most convincing evidence that the stimulatory action of PMA on the reporter gene expression is the result of increasing the availability and binding of Egr-1 protein to its target sequence in the PNMT promoter. The observations presented here indicate that a phorbol ester, PMA, causes the enhancement of luciferase expression in RS1 cells transfected with the PNMT promoter-luciferase reporter gene construct, and that the stimulation of the PNMT promoter activity caused by PMA is attributed to its stimulatory action on the Egr-1 expression. It is therefore reasonable that the transcription factor Egr-1 plays a physiologically important role as one of the intrinsic factors regulating the PNMT gene expression in the adrenergic cell. Moreover, the present study provides further evidence supporting our previous hypothesis that the PNMT gene is one of the specific target genes for the transcription factor Egr-1. However, it still remains to be elucidated whether other transcription factor(s) may be involved in the regulation of PNMT gene expression, and if these factor(s) and Egr-1 may be working in concert. Further studies to address these critical questions are in progress.

Biologically active amidated gastrin is synthesized by carboxyl-terminal α-amidation of a glycine-extended progastrin post-translational processing intermediate (G-Gly). Although plasma levels of G-Gly are equivalent to those of gastrin, G-Gly has essentially no acute effect on gastric acid secretion. However, we have observed that inhibition of gastrin amidation leads to increased plasma concentrations of G-Gly and enhanced gastric acid secretion. We hypothesized, therefore, that G-Gly might have a chronic effect to increase H+,K+-ATPase expression in gastric parietal cells. In the present studies, we observed that a 2-day preincubation with G-Gly significantly enhanced histamine-stimulated [14C]aminopyrine uptake by isolated canine gastric parietal cells but acutely administered G-Gly had no effect. On Northern blot analysis, both G-Gly and gastrin dose-dependently increased H+,K+-ATPase α-subunit gene expression with maximal induction (225 ± 35 and 170 ± 29% of basal, mean ± S.E.) achieved at concentrations of 10–9 m G-Gly and 10–8 m gastrin, respectively. Using an H+,K+-ATPase α-subunit gene-luciferase chimeric reporter construct transfected into primary cultured parietal cells, we observed that both G-Gly and gastrin increased luciferase activity in a manner similar to that obtained by Northern blot analysis. L365,260, a specific gastrin/CCKB receptor antagonist, completely reversed the stimulation of luciferase activity induced by gastrin but had no effect on G-Gly-stimulated activity. Gastrin increased [Ca2+]i, although G-Gly did not, however, genistein (a tyrosine kinase inhibitor) significantly reduced induction of luciferase activity by both G-Gly and gastrin. Specific binding of 125I-Leu15-G2–17-Gly to gastric parietal cells was dose-dependently displaced by G2–17-Gly but not by gastrin nor L365,260. Gastrin peptides truncated at the carboxyl- (G1–13) and amino terminus (G5–17-Gly) both induced H+,K+-ATPase α-subunit gene expression and inhibited 125I-Leu15-G2–17-Gly binding, but were less potent than G2–17-Gly. These data indicate that G-Gly may have a functional role in potentiating gastric acid secretagogue action via enhanced expression of the gene responsible for H+ generation through action at a novel receptor that can be distinguished from the gastrin/CCKB receptor. Thus, both the substrate and product of the terminal progastrin processing reaction appear to have complementary functions in regulation of gastric acid secretion. Gastrin, the major hormonal regulator of gastric acid secretion, is synthesized by α-amidation of a glycine-extended progastrin post-translational processing intermediate (G-Gly) (1Sugano K. Aponte G.W. Yamada T. J. Biol. Chem. 1985; 260: 11724-11729Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 2Hilsted L. Regul. Pept. 1991; 36: 323-343Crossref PubMed Scopus (26) Google Scholar). In previous studies we have observed that G-Gly is co-secreted with gastrin from antral G-cells in response to stimulation (3Sugano K. Park J. Dobbins W.O. Yamada T. Am. J. Physiol. 1987; 253: G502-G507PubMed Google Scholar) and achieves plasma levels roughly equivalent to those of gastrin (4DelValle J. Sugano K. Yamada T. Gastroenterology. 1989; 97: 1159-1163Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (29) Google Scholar, 5Hilsted L. Hansen C.P. Am. J. Physiol. 1988; 255: G665-G669PubMed Google Scholar). Although G-Gly has essentially no acute effect on gastric acid secretion (6Matsumoto M. Park J. Sugano K. Yamada T. Am. J. Physiol. 1987; 252: G315-G319Crossref PubMed Google Scholar, 7Hilsted L. Hint K. Christiansen J. Rehfeld J.F. Gastroenterology. 1988; 94: 96-102Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (33) Google Scholar), we observed that inhibition of gastrin amidation, resulting in increased tissue and plasma concentrations of G-Gly, had the effect of increasing both basal and maximal gastric acid secretion despite normal plasma concentrations of gastrin (8Dickinson C.J. Marino L. Yamada T. Am. J. Physiol. 1990; 258: G810-G814PubMed Google Scholar). Moreover, we have recently reported the presence of receptors selective for G-Gly that mediate cellular growth (9Seva C. Dickinson C.J. Yamada T. Science. 1994; 265: 410-412Crossref PubMed Scopus (311) Google Scholar). In view of these observations, we undertook the present studies to explore the possibility that G-Gly might have a physiological function in acid secretory events through actions independent of those of gastrin.
