Cell Isolation—Gastric parietal cells were prepared from canine fundic mucosa as described previously (10Soll A.H. J. Clin. Invest. 1978; 61: 370-380Crossref PubMed Scopus (240) Google Scholar, 11Campbell V.W. Yamada T. J. Biol. Chem. 1989; 264: 11381-11386Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Briefly, cells were dispersed from stripped fundic mucosa by sequential exposure to collagenase I (0.35 mg/ml, Sigma) and ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid (EDTA) (1 mM). After washing with Hanks’ balanced salt solution, parietal cells were enriched by centrifugal elutriation. For further purification, elutriated parietal cells were centrifuged through density gradients generated with 50% percoll (Pharmacia Biotech Inc.). The cell fraction banding at ρ = 1.05 consisted of more than 95% parietal cells, as determined by hematoxylin and eosin and by periodic acid-Schiff reagent staining. Northern Blot Analysis—Purified parietal cells suspended in Earle’s balanced salt solution (EBSS) 1The abbreviations used are: EBSSEarle’s balanced salt solutionUBCPubiquitin carboxyl-terminal precursorbpbase pair(s) containing 0.1% bovine serum albumin were incubated with the peptides under study for 1 h at 37 °C in 95% O2, 5% CO2. Total RNA was isolated by a modification of the method of Chomczynski (12Chomczynski P. Sacchi N. Anal. Biochem. 1987; 162: 156-159Crossref PubMed Scopus (62909) Google Scholar). Aliquots of RNA (10 μg) were electrophoresed on a 1.25% formaldehyde-agarose gel, blotted to a nylon membrane (maximum strength NYTRAN, Schleicher & Schuell), and hybridized to a H+,K+-ATPase α-subunit cDNA probe which was labeled with 32P by random priming. The blot was then re-hybridized to a 32P-labeled ubiquitin carboxyl-terminal precursor (UBCP) cDNA probe after stripping. The cDNAs used as probes for Northern blots were the 2247-bp BamHI fragment of canine H+,K+-ATPase α-subunit cDNA cloned in our laboratory (13Song I. Mortell M.P. Gantz I. Brown D.R. Yamada T. Biochem. Biophys. Res. Commun. 1993; 196: 1240-1247Crossref PubMed Scopus (13) Google Scholar) and the AccI-PstI fragment of the human UBCP cDNA lacking ubiquitin sequences (14Lund P.K. Moats-Staats B.M. Simmons J.G. Hoyt E. D'Ercoles A.J. Martin F. Van Wyk J.J. J. Biol. Chem. 1985; 260: 7609-7613Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar) (a gift from Dr. P. Kay Lund, University of North Carolina). Earle’s balanced salt solution ubiquitin carboxyl-terminal precursor base pair(s) Relative quantification of a gene-specific mRNA was achieved by digital densitometry on a Loats Image Analysis System (Westminster, MD) as described previously (11Campbell V.W. Yamada T. J. Biol. Chem. 1989; 264: 11381-11386Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Levels of H+,K+-ATPase α-subunit mRNA (3.5 kb) were normalized by comparison with the mRNA levels of UBCP (600 bp), which have been established as suitable controls in this system. Luciferase and β-Galactosidase Analysis—Construction of luciferase plasmids. Employing a 6-kb canine H+,K+-ATPase α-subunit gene (13Song I. Mortell M.P. Gantz I. Brown D.R. Yamada T. Biochem. Biophys. Res. Commun. 1993; 196: 1240-1247Crossref PubMed Scopus (13) Google Scholar) as a template for polymerase chain reaction, we synthesized a 653-bp fragment containing 34 bp of the first exon and 619 bp of the 5′-flanking region of the canine H+,K+-ATPase α-subunit gene. This fragment includes the promoter element (the 5′-GCTCCGCCTC-3′ sequence, bases –54 to –45 relative to the cap site) through which Sp1 confers basal transcriptional activity (15Muraoka A. Kaise M. Yamada T. Gastroenterology. 1994; 106: A145Google Scholar). An H+,K+-ATPase α-subunit gene-luciferase vector chimera (pGL-dHK) was constructed by insertion of the 653-bp fragment into the NheI/BglII sites of a pGL-2 basic luciferase vector (GeneLight™ plasmid, Promega, Madison, WI). Cell Culture and Transfection—Purified parietal cells (0.8 × 106 cells/well) were cultured in Ham’s F-12-Dulbecco’s modified Eagle’s medium (1:1) containing 50 μg/ml gentamycin, 50 units/ml penicillin G, and 2% dimethyl sulfoxide (Me2SO) in 12-well dishes coated with 1:5 diluted growth factor reduced Matrigel (Collaborative Biochemical Products, Bedford, MA) for 16 h using a modification of the method of Chew (16Chew C.S. Ljungstrom M. Smolka A. Brown M.R. Am. J. Physiol. 1989; 256: G254-G263PubMed Google Scholar). Cells were then washed twice in Opti-MEM I (Life Technologies, Inc.) containing 2% Me2SO, 50 μg/ml gentamycin, and 50 units/ml penicillin G for transient transfection. Parietal cells were incubated for 24 h in Opti-MEM-Lipofectin mixture (4:1) containing pGL-dHK and pCMV-βGal vector (a gift from Dr. M. Ubler of the University of Michigan). Luciferase and β-Galactosidase Assays—Transfected parietal cells were washed with Ham’s F-12-Dulbecco’s modified Eagle’s medium (1:1) and incubated with various test reagents for 2 h. After washing cells with Dulbecco’s phosphate-buffered saline, 100 µl of luciferase lysis buffer was added to each well and a 60-µl aliquot of the resultant supernatnat was mixed with 100 µl of luciferase assay reagent (Promega, Madison, WI). Luminescent intensity was measured for 10 s (Lumt LB9501, Lumat, Berthed, Germany) and luciferase activity expressed in relative light unites. β-Galactosidase activity from the co-transfected pCMV-βGal vector was quantified by measuring luminescent light which was derived from 20 µl of the supernatant incubated in 100 µl of Lumi-Gal 530 (Lumigen, Southfiled, MI) at 37 C for 1 h (17Beale E.G. Deeb E.A. Bio/Technology. 1992; 12: 320-323Google Scholar). Luminescent intensity representing β-galactosidase activity was measured for 2 s, and the luciferase activity of each sample was normalized for transfection efficiency by comparison to β-galactosidase activity. Samples in each experiment were analyzed in duplicate. Receptor Binding Assays—Leu15-G2–17-Gly was iodinated using an adaptation of the chloramine-T method as described previously (6Matsumoto M. Park J. Sugano K. Yamada T. Am. J. Physiol. 1987; 252: G315-G319Crossref PubMed Google Scholar, 9Seva C. Dickinson C.J. Yamada T. Science. 1994; 265: 410-412Crossref PubMed Scopus (311) Google Scholar). Isolated gastric parietal cells (2 × 106) were incubated for 1.5 h at 37 °C with 125I-Leu15-G2–17-Gly and various cold ligands in Hanks’ buffer containing 0.1% bovine serum albumin, 0.03% bacitracin, and 0.03% bovine trypsin inhibitor, then washed and centrifuged at 500 × g. Specific binding was calculated as the difference between the total amount of label bound and the amount of label remaining bound in the presence of 1 μμ Leu15-G2–17-Gly. Nonspecific binding amounted to roughly 20% of the total amount of label binding in the absence of any added Leu15-G2–17-Gly. In a second set of experiments Leu15-G2–17-Gly was also labeled with 125I-Bolton-Hunter reagent according to the method of Langone (18Langone J.J. Methods Enzymol. 1980; 70: 221-247Crossref PubMed Scopus (58) Google Scholar). Intracellular Calcium Ion Concentration ([Ca2+]i) Measurement—[Ca2+]i in parietal cells was measured as described previously (19DelValle J. Tsunoda Y. Williams J.A. Yamada T. Am. J. Physiol. 1992; 262: G420-G426PubMed Google Scholar). Highly purified parietal cells (>95%) were incubated in 2 × 10–6 m fura-2/AM for 30 min at 37 °C in EBSS containing 0.1% bovine serum albumin, washed by centrifugation at 500 × g, and resuspended in EBSS. Fura-2/AM-loaded parietal cells (1 × 106) were transferred to a quartz cuvette into which the peptides under study were added directly. Fluorescence ratio (340/380 nm) was measured with a dual wavelength modular fluorometer (Spex-Fluorolog 2, Spex Industries, Edison, NJ). Aminopyrine Uptake—The accumulation of [14C]laminopyrine was used as an indicator of acid production by parietal cells (6Matsumoto M. Park J. Sugano K. Yamada T. Am. J. Physiol. 1987; 252: G315-G319Crossref PubMed Google Scholar, 20Soll A.H. Am. J. Physiol. 1980; 238: G366-G375PubMed Google Scholar). A 1-ml aliquot of acutely isolated parietal cells (2 × 106) in EBSS was incubated with 0.1 μCi of [14C]aminopyrine and the various peptide under study. After a 20-min incubation at 37 °C, the cells were centrifuged and the radioactivity of the cell pellet was determined. For longer term studies, parietal cells (0.4 × 106 cells/well) were cultured in Ham’s F-12-Dulbecco’s modified Eagle’s medium (1:1) with or without added Leu15-G2–17-Gly (10–9 M) in 12-well dishes coated with 1:5 diluted growth factor reduced Matrigel for 2 days. Parietal cells were washed once with EBSS and incubated with 0.1 mCi of [14C]aminopyrine and various reagents for 60 min. Parietal cells were lysed with 500 μl of 1% Triton X-100 and the radioactivity of lysate was quantified in a liquid scintillation counter. Statistics—Statistical analysis was performed using Student’s t test. p values <0.05 were considered to be significant. On the basis of our previous studies, we reasoned that although acute administration of G-Gly might not stimulate gastric acid secretion, more prolonged exposure could potentiate acid secretion mediated by other secretagogues. Thus, we cultured gastric parietal cells for 2 days with Leu15-G2–17-Gly and examined basal and histamine-stimulated acid production. Preincubation with a physiological concentration of Leu15-G2–17-Gly (10–9 m) significantly increased histamine-stimulated [14C]aminopyrine uptake, whereas basal uptake was not significantly altered (Fig. 1A). We also confirmed our previous observations that Leu15-G2–17-Gly had no acute effect on basal or secretagogue-stimulated acid secretion in our system (Fig. 1B). We postulated that the mechanisms by which prolonged increases in G-Gly concentrations in vivo are associated with increased acid secretion (8Dickinson C.J. Marino L. Yamada T. Am. J. Physiol. 1990; 258: G810-G814PubMed Google Scholar) might be mediated by an increase in H+,K+-ATPase gene expression. As shown in Fig. 2, Northern blot analysis demonstrated that G17-NH2 and Leu15-G2–17-Gly induced H+,K+-ATPase α-subunit mRNA. A linear transformation of the densitometric analysis of the Northern blots indicated that both G17-NH2 and Leu15-G2–17-Gly significantly increased H+,K+-ATPase α-subunit mRNA levels in a dose-dependent manner. Leu15-G2–17-Gly achieved maximal induction (225 ± 34% of basal, mean ± S.E., n = 7) at 10–9 m, and G17-NH2 reached its peak (170 ± 9% of basal, mean ± S.E., H = 7) at 10–8 m. The half-maximally effective concentrations (EC50) of Leu15-G2–17-Gly and G17-NH2 were estimated to be 5 × 10–11 m and 1.5 × 10–9 m, respectively, suggesting that Leu15-G2–17-Gly was approximately 30 times more potent than G17-NH2 in inducing H+,K+-ATPase α-subunit expression. Higher concentrations of Leu15-G2–17-Gly (>10–8 m) and G17-NH2 (10–7 m) resulted in a decline from peak levels of H+,K+-ATPase α-subunit mRNA. We next examined the effects of G-Gly and gastrin on the transcriptional activity of the H+,K+-ATPase α-subunit gene promoter using a luciferase reporter construct. Both Leu15-G2–17-Gly and G17-NH2 significantly increased luciferase activity in a dose-dependent manner similar to that obtained by Northern blot analysis (Fig. 3A). Leu15-G2–17-Gly achieved maximal induction of luciferase activity (219 ± 58% basal, mean ± S.E., n = 7) at 10–9 m, and G17-NH2 attained its peak (177 ± 34% of basal, mean ± S.E., n = 7) at 10–8 m. The EC50 values for Leu15-G2–17-Gly and G17-NH2 were estimated to be 5 × 10–11 m and 1 × 10–9 m, respectively. In separate experiments, we explored the nature of the receptor/ligand interaction mediating the observed effects of gastrin and G-Gly on H+,K+-ATPase α-subunit gene expression. CCK8, which is equipotent with G17-NH2 in its affinity for gastrin/CCKB receptors (21Soll A.H. Amirian D.A. Thomas L.P. Reedy T.J. Elashoff J.D. J. Clin. Invest. 1984; 73: 1434-1447Crossref PubMed Scopus (194) Google Scholar), significantly induced luciferase activity. Maximal induction with CCK8 (197 ± 57% basal, mean ± S.E., n = 7) was obtained at 10–7 m, which was a concentration 10-fold higher than the concentration of G17-NH2 that achieved similar results (Fig. 3B). G5–17-Gly, which lacks the amino-terminal three amino acids of G2–17-Gly, also induced luciferase activity (Fig. 3B), however, the concentration at which G5–17-Gly attained maximal induction (189 ± 54% basal, mean ± S.E., n = 7) was 100-fold higher than that of Leu15-G2–17-Gly. G1–13, which has the identical amino-terminal sequence as G17-NH2 but lacks the carboxyl-terminal tetrapeptide amide, is not active as an acid secretagogue and does not bind to gastrin/CCKB receptors (7Hilsted L. Hint K. Christiansen J. Rehfeld J.F. Gastroenterology. 1988; 94: 96-102Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (33) Google Scholar, 22Pauwels S. Dockray G.J. Walker R. Marcus S. Gastroenterology. 1985; 89: 49-56Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (8) Google Scholar, 23Cabero J.L. Rehfeld J.F. Mardh S. Acta Physiol. Scand. 1989; 136: 301-307Crossref PubMed Scopus (9) Google Scholar). However, this amino-terminal fragment of gastrin also induced luciferase activity and maximal induction (160 ± 31% basal, mean ± S.E., n = 7) was achieved by 10–7 m (Fig. 3B). To determine whether the effects of gastrin peptides on H+,K+-ATPase α-subunit gene expression were mediated via gastrin/CCKB receptors, we utilized L365,260, a specific gastrin/CCKB receptor antagonist (24Chang R.S.L. Lotti V.J. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1986; 83: 4923-4926Crossref PubMed Scopus (600) Google Scholar, 25Bock M.G. DiPardo R.M. Evans B.E. Rittle K.E. Whitter W.L. Veber D.F. Anderson P.S. Freidinger R.M. J. Med. Chem. 1989; 32: 16-32Crossref PubMed Scopus (342) Google Scholar). L365,260 (10–5 m) completely inhibited the induction of luciferase activity stimulated by the carboxyamidated peptides G17-NH2 (10–8 m) and CCK8 (10–7 m) (Fig. 4). In contrast, L365,260 (10–5 m) failed to inhibit luciferase activity induced by 8-bromo-cAMP, Leu15-G2–17-Gly, or G1–13. To determine whether gastric parietal cells possess a selective receptor for G-Gly, we undertook binding studies with 125I-Leu15-G2–17-Gly. Specific binding of 125I-Leu15-G2–17-Gly was dose-dependently displaced by Leu15-G2–17-Gly, G5–17-Gly, and G1–13 (Fig. 5). The estimated half-maximal inhibitory binding concentrations (IC50) of the peptides, Leu15-G2–17-Gly (3 × 10–8 m), G5–17-Gly (1.5 × 10–7 m), and G1–13 (2 × 10–7 m), were consistent with their relative potencies in the stimulation of luciferase activity. In contrast, G17-NH2 (10–6 m), CCK8 (10–6 m), and L365,260 (10–6 m) did not displace 125I-Leu15-G2–17-Gly binding to gastric parietal cells. 125I-Bolton-Hunter labeled Leu15-G2–17-Gly, which contains a bulky non-peptide moiety on the amino terminus, did not bind to gastric parietal cells despite its ability to bind carboxyl-terminal-specific antisera directed against G-Gly peptides. Mobilization of intracellular Ca2+ is an essential signal transduction mechanism that mediates the effects of gastrin through gastrin/CCKB receptors in gastric parietal cells (19DelValle J. Tsunoda Y. Williams J.A. Yamada T. Am. J. Physiol. 1992; 262: G420-G426PubMed Google Scholar, 26Yamada T. Chiba T. DelValle J. Campbell V. Walsh J.H. Gastrin. Raven Press, New York1993: 151-168Google Scholar). As reported previously, G17-NH2 (10–8 m) significantly increased [Ca2+]i in parietal cells. In contrast, G2–17-Gly did not change [Ca2+]i at concentrations as high as 10–8 m (Fig. 6), suggesting that mobilization of Ca2+ does not mediate the effects of G-Gly on H.+,K+-ATPase α-subunit gene expression. However, preincubation (30 min) with genistein (5 × 10–5 m), a tyrosine kinase inhibitor (27Akiyama T. Ishida J. Nakagawa S. Ogawara H. Watanabe S. Itoh N. Shibuya N. Fukami Y. J. Biol. Chem. 1987; 262: 5592-5595Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar), significantly reduced luciferase activity induced by both Leu15-G2–17-Gly and G1–13 (Fig. 7). Moreover, induction by G17-NH2 as well as CCK8 was also reversed by genistein. In contrast, genistein had no effect on 8-bromo-cAMP-induced luciferase activity.FIG. 7Effects of genistein on luciferase levels induced by gastrin peptides. Primary cultured canine parietal cells transfected with pGL-dHK were preincubated with (hatched bars) or without (solid bars) a tyrosine kinase inhibitor genistein (2 × 10–5 m) and stimulated with various ligands (10–3 m 8-bromo-cAMP, 10–7 m CCK8, 10–8 m G17-NH2, 10–7 m G1–13, and 10–9 m G2–17-Gly) for 2 h.View Large Image Figure ViewerDownload Hi-res image Download (PPT) Many brain-gut peptide hormones require a carboxyl-terminal α-amide moiety to achieve full biological potency. These α-carboxyamidated peptides are synthesized from their glycine-extended processing intermediates by the action of peptidylglycine α-amidating monooxygenase (EC 1.14.17.3) (28Eipper B.A. Mains R.E. Annu. Rev. Physiol. 1988; 50: 333-344Crossref PubMed Scopus (240) Google Scholar). Gastrin, the major hormonal regulator of gastric acid secretion, also requires an α-carboxyamidated terminus for full potency as an acid secretagogue (29Tracy H.J. Gregory R.A. Nature. 1964; 204: 935-938Crossref PubMed Scopus (197) Google Scholar, 30Morley J.S. Tracy H.J. Gregory R.A. Nature. 1965; 207: 1356-1359Crossref PubMed Scopus (182) Google Scholar, 31McGuigan J.E. Thomas H.F. Gastroenterology. 1972; 62: 553-558Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (16) Google Scholar), and G-Gly is converted to biologically active gastrin via the action of peptidylglycine α-amidating monooxygenase in gastric antral G-cells (1Sugano K. Aponte G.W. Yamada T. J. Biol. Chem. 1985; 260: 11724-11729Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 2Hilsted L. Regul. Pept. 1991; 36: 323-343Crossref PubMed Scopus (26) Google Scholar, 32Dickinson C.J. Yamada T. J. Biol. Chem. 1991; 266: 334-338Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Although G-Gly is co-secreted with gastrin from G-cells (3Sugano K. Park J. Dobbins W.O. Yamada T. Am. J. Physiol. 1987; 253: G502-G507PubMed Google Scholar) and achieves plasma levels roughly equivalent to those of gastrin (4DelValle J. Sugano K. Yamada T. Gastroenterology. 1989; 97: 1159-1163Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (29) Google Scholar, 5Hilsted L. Hansen C.P. Am. J. Physiol. 1988; 255: G665-G669PubMed Google Scholar, 33Ciccotosto G.D. Shulkes A. Am. J. Physiol. 1992; 263: G802-G809PubMed Google Scholar), its physiological relevance other than to serve as the immediate precursor for gastrin has remained obscure. Acutely administered G-Gly is a weak stimulant of gastric acid secretion in vitro (10,000-fold less potent than gastrin) (6Matsumoto M. Park J. Sugano K. Yamada T. Am. J. Physiol. 1987; 252: G315-G319Crossref PubMed Google Scholar) and has no activity in vivo (7Hilsted L. Hint K. Christiansen J. Rehfeld J.F. Gastroenterology. 1988; 94: 96-102Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (33) Google Scholar). However, in previous in vivo studies, we demonstrated that inhibition of gastrin amidation leading to increased tissue and plasma concentrations of G-Gly resulted in increased basal and stimulated gastric acid secretion without a change in plasma levels of amidated gastrin (8Dickinson C.J. Marino L. Yamada T. Am. J. Physiol. 1990; 258: G810-G814PubMed Google Scholar). In our studies we were able to reproduce these disparate findings when we observed that a 2-day preincubation with G-Gly significantly increased histamine-stimulated acid production in cultured gastric parietal cells, whereas a short 20-min exposure to G-Gly had no effect. Thus, there appears to be an effect of prolonged exposure to G-Gly that results in enhanced parietal cell function that is not observed under acute condition. We hypothesized that the mechanism(s) responsible for the chronic effects of G-Gly might be mediated by induction of the gene encoding H+,K+-ATPase, the critical enzyme in H+ production (34Sachs G. Johnson L.R. Physiology of the Gastrointestinal Tract. Second Ed. Raven Press, New York1987: 865-881Google Scholar). Indeed, we observed that physiological concentrations of G-Gly induce gastric H+,K+-ATPase α-subunit gene expression, as evidenced by the dose-response relationship between G-Gly and induction of gene expression obtained by Northern blots and luciferase assays. Since luciferase assays generally indicate the transcriptional activities of a test gene (35Alam J. Cook J.L. Anal. Biochem. 1990; 188: 245-254Crossref PubMed Scopus (396) Google Scholar), our data suggest that the proximal 619-bp segment in the 5′-flanking region of the H+,K+-ATPase α-subunit gene contains the responsive DNA element that mediates its inducibility by G-Gly and gastrin. Gastrin/CCKB receptors mediate the gastric acid secretagogue effects of gastrin (20Soll A.H. Am. J. Physiol. 1980; 238: G366-G375PubMed Google Scholar) and gastrin/CCKB receptor antagonists reverse this effect. In the present study, specific inhibition of gastrin/CCKB receptors by L365,260 also reversed the induction of H+,K+-ATPase α-subunit expression mediated by CCK8 and gastrin. In concert with this finding was observation that gastrin increased parietal cell [Ca2+]i which is an essential signal transduction mechanism generated by peptide action at gastrin/CCKB receptor (19DelValle J. Tsunoda Y. Williams J.A. Yamada T. Am. J. Physiol. 1992; 262: G420-G426PubMed Google Scholar, 26Yamada T. Chiba T. DelValle J. Campbell V. Walsh J.H. Gastrin. Raven Press, New York1993: 151-168Google Scholar). In contrast, the gastrin/CCKB receptor antagonist, L365,260, failed to inhibit G-Gly induced H+,K+-ATPase α-subunit gene expression and G-Gly did not mobilize [Ca2+]i even at high concentrations. Additionally, specific binding of 125I-Leu15-G-2–17-Gly to parietal cells was dose-dependently displaced by Leu15-G2–17-Gly, but not by G17-NH2 (10–6 m), CCK8 (10–6 m), nor L365,260 (10–6 m). Therefore receptors mediating the effects of G-Gly appear to be separate and distinct from those mediating the effects of gastrin. These observations are consistent with our previous report of selective G-Gly receptors that mediate cellular effects that can be distinguished from those of gastrin (9Seva C. Dickinson C.J. Yamada T. Science. 1994; 265: 410-412Crossref PubMed Scopus (311) Google Scholar). Genistein (27Akiyama T. Ishida J. Nakagawa S. Ogawara H. Watanabe S. Itoh N. Shibuya N. Fukami Y. J. Biol. Chem. 1987; 262: 5592-5595Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar), a specific tyrosine kinase inhibitor, reversed induction of luciferase activity by G-Gly and gastrin. Thus, G-Gly may induce H+,K+ATPase α-subunit gene expression via a novel subtype of gastrin receptor that is directly or indirectly linked to tyrosine kinase activity. We attempted to examine the ligand binding properties of the apparent G-Gly receptor on parietal cells by using aminoand carboxyl-terminally altered G-Gly peptides for both binding and transcriptional induction assays. Although both aminoand carboxyl-terminally truncated G-Gly peptides (G5–17-Gly and G1–13, respectively) demonstrated the ability to induce H+,K+-ATPase α-subunit gene expression, their potencies were diminished 100-fold relative that of G2–17-Gly. Similar qualitative results were obtained in studies examining the displacement 125I-Leu15-G2–17-Gly from parietal cells; however, the EC50 of the various ligands in the binding displacement studies did not correspond to the EC50 values for transcriptional induction. The broad dose range for binding displacement indicates multiple affinity states for the G-Gly receptor as suggested in previous studies with AR42-J pancreatic cancer cell lines 2C. Seva, C. J. Dickinson, and T. Yamada, unpublished data. with the highest affinity receptor having a Kd (~10–10 m) as measured by Scatchard analysis (9Seva C. Dickinson C.J. Yamada T. Science. 1994; 265: 410-412Crossref PubMed Scopus (311) Google Scholar), similar to the EC50 for transcriptional induction. Taken together our data suggest the requirement of both carboxyl- and amino-terminal ends of G17-Gly for full potency in action at the G-Gly receptor. Further studies are required for confirmation of this hypothesis. Our studies provided unique insight into the functional significance of the terminal products of prohormone post-translational processing. Through a cascade of reactions, many prohormones are processed to glycine-extended intermediates which serve as the substrates for the peptide α-amidation reaction. Whereas, in the past, this reaction was thought to be the biological activation step for carboxyl-terminally amidated peptides such as gastrin, our data suggest that the intermediate glycine-extended peptides may themselves have independent biological activities that are distinct from those of the amidated products. In the case of gastrin, G-Gly appears to complement the acid secretary action of gastrin by inducing the expression of H+,K+-ATPase, and it does so in concentrations which are equivalent to those of the circulating peptide. The physiological importance of this effect can be seen in our previous in vivo studies demonstrating that in the face of peptide α-amidation inhibition and diminished tissue concentrations of gastrin, acid secretory levels are, if anything, enhanced. At least part of this effect appears to be mediated by induction of H+,K+-ATPase expression. However, it is also possible that growth promoting effects of G-Gly peptides which we have previously reported (9Seva C. Dickinson C.J. Yamada T. Science. 1994; 265: 410-412Crossref PubMed Scopus (311) Google Scholar) may also play a role in this phenomenon, perhaps by increasing the number of parietal cells, although this remains to be determined. In any event, the importance of both the substrate and product of the terminal α-amidating prohormone post-translational processing reactions must be considered in physiological systems.

Keratinocyte growth factor (KGF), a member of the fibroblast growth factor family of related proteins, is expressed by stromal fibroblasts and acts on epithelial cells in a paracrine fashion. To understand the mechanisms responsible for regulating normal KGF expression and how these might be altered in disease, the 5′-flanking region of this gene was cloned. The presence of two KGF transcription initiation sites was suggested by ribonuclease protection assay and confirmed by primer extension analysis. Examination of the genomic DNA sequence revealed the presence of the putative promoter sequences TATTTA and CCAAT, located 31 and 50 base pairs upstream, respectively, from the first of the two mRNA start points, and putative initiator sequences surrounding each transcription start site. Transient transfection into murine NIH/3T3 fibroblasts demonstrated that the region required for basal level KGF promoter activity was located between bases –225 and +190. Inclusion of sequences between –1503 and –775 markedly reduced promoter activation, indicating the presence of negative regulatory element(s) in this region. A similar pattern of promoter activation was detected in human fibroblasts and in murine C2C12 myoblasts. In contrast, no chloramphenicol acetyltransferase activity was observed in macrophages and epithelial and lymphoid cells transfected with the same constructs. Northern blot analysis revealed a strong correlation between KGF RNA expression and promoter activation in all cells tested. Activation of the KGF promoter could be induced by the proinflammatory cytokines interleukin 1 and interleukin 6 and by the adenylate cyclase activator forskolin. Taken together, these results indicate the existence of cis-acting element(s) responsible for selective activation of the KGF promoter only in cells that express KGF mRNA and may provide a mechanistic basis for KGF gene expression during inflammation. Increased cell division caused by prolonged exposure to steroid hormones or chronic inflammation is associated with an increased risk of cancer (9Preston-Martin S. Pike M.C. Ross R.K. Jones P.A. Henderson B.E. Cancer Res. 1990; 50: 7415-7421PubMed Google Scholar). Therefore, interference with the mechanisms that regulate normal KGF expression may also play a role in tumorigenesis. In order to further elucidate the elements responsible for regulating KGF expression, we have cloned the human KGF promoter region, characterized its basal activity in mesenchymal cells, and demonstrated its transcriptional activation by interleukin 1 (IL1), interleukin 6 (IL6), and forskolin. Isolation of Genomic DNA Clones Containing the KGF Promoter Region—An amplified human placental genomic DNA library (Clontech, Palo Alto, CA) was used to isolate clones containing the 5′-region of the KGF gene. The library was constructed from 8–22-kilobase (kb) fragments of a partial Sau3A digest of placental DNA inserted into the BamHI site of the EMBL3-SP6/T7 1 cloning vector. Plaque lifts of 1 × 106 recombinants were hybridized with a 324-base pair (bp) BamHI/EcoRI 32P-labeled fragment derived from the 5′-end (bp 145–465) of a human KGF cDNA clone (2Finch P.W. Rubin J.S. Miki T. Ron D. Aaronson S.A. Science. 1989; 245: 752-755Crossref PubMed Scopus (818) Google Scholar). Filters were washed with 0.1 × SSC, 0.1% SDS at 60 ºC for 2 × 30 min. Positive plaques were identified by autoradiography and purified through secondary and tertiary rounds of screening. DNA Sequencing—A 1.67-kb EcoRI genomic DNA fragment, which contained 145 bp of sequence corresponding to the previously determined 5′-end of the human KGF cDNA (2Finch P.W. Rubin J.S. Miki T. Ron D. Aaronson S.A. Science. 1989; 245: 752-755Crossref PubMed Scopus (818) Google Scholar) and 1.5 kb 5′ to the transcription start sites was subcloned into pBluescript II KS (Stratagene Cloning Systems, La Jolla, CA) and a series of overlapping nested deletions prepared by exonuclease III digestion (10Henikoff S. Methods Enzymol. 1987; 155: 156-165Crossref PubMed Scopus (676) Google Scholar). The nucleotide sequences of both strands of this fragment were determined using the dideoxy chain termination method (11Sanger F. Nicklen S. Coulson A.R. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1977; 74: 5463-5467Crossref PubMed Scopus (52769) Google Scholar) using modified T7 DNA polymerase (Sequenase Version 2.0 DNA sequencing kit, U. S. Biochemical Corp.) and [α-35S] dATP (DuPont NEN, Boston, MA). The sequence was compiled and analyzed using the MacVector 4.0 DNA sequence analysis program (Eastman Kodak Co., Rochester, NY). Ribonuclease Protection Analysis (RPA) of the KGF Transcript—A series of consecutive genomic fragments corresponding to the 5′-region of the KGF cDNA (2Finch P.W. Rubin J.S. Miki T. Ron D. Aaronson S.A. Science. 1989; 245: 752-755Crossref PubMed Scopus (818) Google Scholar) were subcloned into the pGEM 3Zf(-) transcription vector (Promega, Madison, WI). Labeled antisense transcripts were synthesized in vitro using either T7 or SP6 RNA polymerase and [α-32P]UTP (800 Ci/mmol, DuPont NEN). Samples of 10 μg of total cellular RNA were hybridized at 42 °C overnight with 1 × 105 cpm of the purified labeled transcripts. Hybrids were digested for 40 min. at 30 °C with RNases A and T1 (12Melton D.A. Kreig P.A. Regabliati M.R. Maniatis T. Zinn K. Green M.R. Nucleic Acids Res. 1984; 12: 7035-7056Crossref PubMed Scopus (4060) Google Scholar). Protected fragments were separated on 6% Polyacrylamide, 8 M urea gels and detected by autoradiography. Primer Extension Assays—A 21-nucleotide antisense primer, corresponding to bases 134–114 of the human KGF cDNA sequence (2Finch P.W. Rubin J.S. Miki T. Ron D. Aaronson S.A. Science. 1989; 245: 752-755Crossref PubMed Scopus (818) Google Scholar), was end-labeled with [γ-32P]ΑTP (3,000 Ci/mmol, DuPont NEN) and T4 polynucleotide kinase to a specific activity of 1 × 108 cpm/µg. Samples of 15 μg of total cellular RNA were hybridized with radiolabeled oligonucleotide (0.7 ng) by heating at 58 °C for 20 min in 10 ml of 50 mm Tris-HCl (pH 8.3 at 42 °C), 50 mm KCl, 10 mm MgCl2, 10 mm dithiothreitol, 1 mm dNTP, and 0.5 mm spermidine. After cooling to room temperature, 1 unit of avian myeloblastosis virus reverse transcriptase (Promega, Madison, WI) in 10 ml of the same buffer was added to the mixture, and the reaction continued at 42 °C for 30 min. After completion of the reaction, samples were phenol-extracted, precipitated with ethanol, and dissolved in 99% formamide, 10 mm EDTA, 0.1% xylene cyanol, 0.1% bromphenol blue. Construction of KGF:CAT Plasmids—A series of plasmids were prepared in which 191 bp of genomic DNA 3′ relative to the first start site of KGF transcription (corresponding to the remainder of exon 1A) and various amounts of DNA 5′ to the transcription start were inserted immediately upstream from the chloramphenicol acetyltransferase (CAT) reporter gene in the plasmid vector pCAT-Enhancer (Promega, Madison, WI). This vector contains an SV40 enhancer element downstream from the CAT reporter gene to allow verification of putative promoter sequences. Genomic DNA fragments for subcloning were prepared by PCR amplification using the following oligonucleotides: for the 5′-ends of the KGF inserts, 5′-ATAAGCTTAAGGTATTTATCGAAAAGCCC-3′ (bases –25 to –5), 5′-ATAAGCTTCTTCTAACTGCTTCAGAACCA-3′ (bases –225 to –205), 5′-ATAAGCTTCAAGTATAATACAACTGCTA-3′ (bases –280 to –260), 5′-ATAAGCTTCAATGTGAAACCATTTCCTCC-3′ (bases –755 to –775), 5′-ATAAGCTTTTGGTCTACATGCACCACCTG-3′ (bases –1144 to –1164), and 5′-ATAAGCTTTAGGAATTCTGAGCCTGCTCA-3′ (bases –1483 to –1503), and for the 3′-end of all four vectors, 5′-ATCTGCAGTTGCTAACAGCTGGATATATA-3′ (bases 171–190). The remaining deletion constructs were similarly generated. Amplified fragments were digested with HindIII and PstI and inserted 5′ to the CAT reporter gene using the same restriction endonuclease sites in the vector’s multiple cloning site. Cell Culture—M426 embryonic lung, 151 and 152 neonatal foreskin, and 202 and M413 dermal fibroblasts of human origin, and murine NIH/3T3 fibroblasts and C2C12 myoblasts were grown in Dulbecco’s modified Eagle’s medium (Life Technologies, Inc.) supplemented with 10% fetal bovine serum, 50 mm glutamine, 50 units/ml penicillin, and 50 µg/ml streptomycin. Human epithelial cells (HeLa cervix carcinoma, A549 lung carcinoma, and A101 melanoma, MCF-7 breast carcinoma, EJ bladder carcinoma, and SK-Hep 1 hepatoma) were grown in Dulbecco’s modified Eagle’s medium supplemented with 10% calf serum, 50 mm glutamine, 50 units/ml penicillin, and 50 μg/ml streptomycin. Human Β lymphoblastoid cell lines (LBW25 and LBW26) (50Taylor K.A. Wetzel S. Lyles D.S. Pollok B.A. J. Virol. 1994; 68: 6421-6431Crossref PubMed Google Scholar), K562 erythroleukemia cells, Raji Burkitt lymphoma cells, and THP1 macrophages were grown in RPMI 1640 supplemented as above. Transfection—Adherent cells were grown to approximately 50% confluency in 100-mm Petri dishes while suspension cells were cultured in 75-cm2 tissue culture flasks and plated at 1 × 106 cells/ml. Cells were transfected with the cationic lipopolyamine reagent Transfectam (Promega, Madison, WI) following the manufacturer’s instructions. CAT Assay—Transfected cells were washed twice with 10 ml of phosphate-buffered saline and resuspended in 200 ml of 0.25 M Tris-HCl, pH 8.0. Cell lysates were prepared by three freeze-thaw cycles and divided into two aliquots: the first aliquot was heat-inactivated at 65 °C for 10 min and then assayed for CAT activity as described (13Sleigh M.J. Anal. Biochem. 1986; 156: 251-256Crossref PubMed Scopus (297) Google Scholar). The second aliquot was used in the determination of β-galactosidase activity as described by Rosenthal (14Rosenthal N. Methods Enzymol. 1987; 152: 704-720Crossref PubMed Scopus (403) Google Scholar), using o-nitrophenyl-β-D-galactosidase as substrate. RNA Preparation and Northern Hybridization Analysis—Total RNA and Northern blot analysis were performed as described in Ref. 38Chedid M. Rubin J.S. Csaky K.G. Aaronson S.A. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 10753-10757Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar. Probes used in hybridizations were labeled with [32P]dCTP by random priming and correspond to the exon I of the human kGF gene (15Kelley M.J. Pech M. Seuanez H.N. Rubin J.S. O'Brien S.J. Aaronson S.A. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1992; 89: 9287-9291Crossref PubMed Scopus (25) Google Scholar) and the full coding sequence of the murine gene. 2P. W. Finch, G. R. Cunha, J. S. Rubin, J. Wong, and D. Ron, manuscript in preparation. As control for loading and transfer of RNAs, blots were hybridized with a cDNA probe corresponding to the full coding sequence of the human glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate dehydrogenase gene (16Adams M.D. Dubnick M. Kerlavage A.R. Moreno R. Kelley J.M. Utterback T.R. Nagle J.W. Fields C. Venter J.C. Nature. 1992; 355: 632-634Crossref PubMed Scopus (726) Google Scholar). Isolation and Characterization of the Human KGF Promoter Region—A 324-bp probe derived from the 5′-end (bp 145–469) of a human KGF cDNA clone (2Finch P.W. Rubin J.S. Miki T. Ron D. Aaronson S.A. Science. 1989; 245: 752-755Crossref PubMed Scopus (818) Google Scholar) was used to identify KGF clones in a human placental genomic DNA library. Restriction endonuclease analysis revealed that one of these clones contained an insert of approximately 15 kb, which could be excised from the vector using the XhoI sites in the vector multiple cloning site. The insert contained one internal BamHI site such that digestion with XhoI and BamHI together liberated fragments of 8.0 and 7.5 kb (Fig. 1). Nucleotide sequence analysis demonstrated that the internal BamHI site in the cloned insert corresponded to the unique BamHI site located at position 469 in the KGF cDNA sequence (2Finch P.W. Rubin J.S. Miki T. Ron D. Aaronson S.A. Science. 1989; 245: 752-755Crossref PubMed Scopus (818) Google Scholar). The 7.5-kb BamHI/XhoI fragment contained sequences 5′ to the BamHI site (Fig. 1). Polymerase chain reaction was used to compare the structure of the cloned genomic fragment with that of the KGF cDNA. A pair of oligonucleotide primers, designed to amplify bp 1–477 of the KGF cDNA, amplified an approximately 1100-bp fragment from the genomic template (data not shown), suggesting the presence of a 650-bp intron. By sequence analysis, the intron was found to be located between nucleotides 179 and 180 in the KGF cDNA (2Finch P.W. Rubin J.S. Miki T. Ron D. Aaronson S.A. Science. 1989; 245: 752-755Crossref PubMed Scopus (818) Google Scholar) and to conform to the consensus G(T/A)G sequence for 5′-donor and 3′-acceptor splice sites (17Mount S.M. Nucleic Acids Res. 1982; 10: 459-472Crossref PubMed Scopus (2783) Google Scholar). All the genes encoding FGF family members consist of three exons encoding the primary translation product, with the intervening introns always present in the same position with respect to the protein coding sequences (15Kelley M.J. Pech M. Seuanez H.N. Rubin J.S. O'Brien S.J. Aaronson S.A. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1992; 89: 9287-9291Crossref PubMed Scopus (25) Google Scholar, 18Abrahams J.A. Whang J.L. Tumolo A. Mergia A. Friedman J. Gospodarowicz D. Fiddes J.C. EMBO J. 1986; 5: 2523-2528Crossref PubMed Scopus (480) Google Scholar, 19Moore R. Casey G. Brookes S. Dixon M. Peters G. Dickson C. EMBO J. 1986; 5: 919-924Crossref PubMed Scopus (146) Google Scholar, 20Yoshida T. Miyagawa K. Odagiri H. Sakamoto H. Little P.F.R. Terada M. Sugimara T. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1987; 84: 7305-7309Crossref PubMed Scopus (186) Google Scholar, 21Zhan X. Bates B. Hu X. Goldfarb M. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1988; 8: 3487-3495Crossref PubMed Scopus (296) Google Scholar, 22Wang W-P. Lehtoma K. Varban M.L. Krishnan I. Chiu I-M. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1989; 9: 2387-2395Crossref PubMed Scopus (48) Google Scholar). Therefore, to avoid confusion, we have designated the newly identified KGF exon as exon 1A and will refer to the second exon (the first encoding protein sequence) as exon 1B (Fig. 1). Identification of the KGF Gene Transcription Initiation Sites—In order to determine whether the isolated genomic fragment contained the KGF promoter region, it was necessary to determine the KGF transcription start point(s). To map the 5′-end of the KGF transcript we initially used RPA with antisense RNA probes to four consecutive KGF genomic DNA fragments. Probe 1 corresponded to a 350-bp EcoRI/BglII. fragment containing the terminal 5′ 145 bp of a previously isolated cDNA clone (2Finch P.W. Rubin J.S. Miki T. Ron D. Aaronson S.A. Science. 1989; 245: 752-755Crossref PubMed Scopus (818) Google Scholar) and so would be protected to at least this extent. Probes 2–4 corresponded to consecutive BglII, BglII/BssHII, and BssHII/EcoRI fragments of approximately 350, 550, and 450 bp, respectively (Fig. 1). An antisense probe corresponding to the 324-bp EcoRI/BamHI fragment of KGF cDNA (bp 469–145) was included as a positive control. Labeled probes were hybridized with 10 pg of total RNA isolated from M426 fibroblasts or normal breast tissue. As demonstrated in Fig. 2, antisense RNA probe 1 yielded two RNase-resistant duplexes of approximately 150 and 165 bp. In contrast, the 324-bp antisense probe to the KGF cDNA was fully protected (Fig. 2). The same protection pattern for each probe was detected using the normal breast RNA, albeit to a lesser extent. This demonstrated that the signal obtained by hybridization with M426 RNA was not artifactual and could be reproduced using RNA isolated from a normal tissue. None of the antisense RNA probes to the other genomic fragments were protected by hybridization to either M426 or the breast RNA (data not shown). Primer extension was used to determine whether the boundary identified by RPA represented the first KGF exon. A radiolabeled 21-nucleotide antisense primer (corresponding to bp 134–114 of the KGF cDNA sequence) was hybridized to M426 RNA and extended with avian myeloblastosis virus reverse transcriptase. Two cDNAs of 136 and 154 bp were detected (Fig. 3), establishing that the exon border detected by RPA represented the 5′-terminus of the KGF transcript. These experiments indicated that the isolated genomic DNA fragment contained the promoter region of the KGF gene. DNA Sequence Analysis of the KGF Promoter Region—The nucleotide sequence of the KGF promoter region is presented in Fig. 4. This sequence consists of 775 bp 5′ to the first transcription initiation site (designated +1) and 191 bp 3′ to this site. Most eukaryotic genes transcribed by RNA polymerase II contain a TATA sequence and a pentanucleotide sequence, CCAAT, commonly found 30 and 50–100 bp, respectively, upstream from the transcription start points (23Breathnack R. Chambon P. Annu. Rev. Biochem. 1981; 50: 349-383Crossref PubMed Scopus (3298) Google Scholar, 24Johnson P.F. McKnight S.L. Annu. Rev. Biochem. 1989; 58: 799-839Crossref PubMed Scopus (830) Google Scholar). Inspection of the KGF promoter regulatory sequence revealed the presence of the putative transcriptional promoter sequences, TATTTA and CCAAT, located 31 and 50 bp respectively, upstream of the first mRNA start site. Many genes have initiator (Inr) elements at the transcriptional start points, in addition to or in place of the TATA element, which help direct efficient and accurate transcription (25Smale S.T. Schmidt M.C. Berk A.J. Baltimore D. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1990; 87: 4509-4513Crossref PubMed Scopus (353) Google Scholar). The sequence surrounding each KGF transcription start point is consistent (5 of 7 bp for the first and 4 of 7 bp for the second) with the consensus Inr element, CTCANTCT, in which transcription is initiated at the internal Ala residue (25Smale S.T. Schmidt M.C. Berk A.J. Baltimore D. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1990; 87: 4509-4513Crossref PubMed Scopus (353) Google Scholar). Several transcriptional regulatory consensus sequences were identified within this region (Fig. 4), including binding sites for coupling factor 1 (bases –159 to –164) (26Riggs K.J. Merrell K.T. Wilson G. Calame K. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1991; 11: 1765-1769Crossref PubMed Scopus (59) Google Scholar) and nuclear factor-A1 (bases –131 to –137) (27Kemler I. Schreiber E. Muller M.M. Matthias P. Schaffner W. EMBO J. 1989; 8: 2001-2008Crossref PubMed Scopus (94) Google Scholar). Two potential binding sites for NF-IL6, which mediates the activation of target genes by IL1, IL6, and other inflammatory mediators (28Akira S. Isshiki H. Sugita T. Tanabe O. Kinoshita S. Nishio Y. Nakajima T. Hirano T. Kishimoto T. EMBO J. 1990; 9: 1897-1916Crossref PubMed Scopus (1212) Google Scholar), were also present. One of these, at bases –257 to –265, exactly matches the consensus, while the other, at bases –38 to –46, has one mismatch. A potential cyclic AMP response element (bases –39 to –46) as well as binding sites for activator protein-1 (bases –8 to –14 and –285 to –291) and activator protein-2 (bases –142 to –149) were also present, which differed by 1 bp from their respective consensus sequences (29Roesler W.J. Vandenbark G.R. Hanson R.W. J. Biol. Chem. 1988; 263: 9063-9066Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 30Lee W. Mitchell M. Tijan R. Cell. 1987; 49: 741-752Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (1365) Google Scholar). Other putative transcriptional regulatory sequences identified within this region include two half palindromic estrogen response elements (bases –39 to –43 and –574 to –578) (31Beato M. Cell. 1989; 56: 335-344Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (2852) Google Scholar), two half-palindromic glucocorticoid response elements (bases –178 to –183 and –1379 to –1385) (31Beato M. Cell. 1989; 56: 335-344Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (2852) Google Scholar), and a binding site for a silencer factor (bases –313 to –320) (32Weissman J.D. Singer D.S. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1991; 11: 4228-4234Crossref PubMed Scopus (18) Google Scholar). KGF Gene 5′-Flanking Sequences Drive Expression of a CAT Reporter Gene—In order to determine promoter activity and identify important regulatory domains within the 5′-flanking sequence of the KGF gene, a series of KGF:CAT fusion plasmids were constructed (Fig. 5). The 5′-ends of these constructs were –1503, –1164, –775, and –225 bp respectively, relative to the position of the first transcription start point. The 3′-end of each insert was +190 bp, 8 bp 5′ to the intron/exon junction of the first noncoding exon 1A of the KGF gene. These constructs were transfected into the mouse embryonic fibroblast cell line, NIH/3T3, and CAT activity was measured. For comparison, cells were also transfected with two control CAT plasmids, one in which transcription was driven by the SV40 promoter and one that was promoterless. The results of multiple transfection experiments indicated that the –225/+190 construct gave the maximal level of CAT activity, 5.7-fold higher than the promoterless CAT plasmid (Fig. 5). The –775/+190 construct gave slightly lower CAT activity, indicating that the region between –225 and +190 was sufficient to confer basal level activity to the KGF promoter in NIH/3T3 fibroblasts. Transfection of the –1503/+190 and –11647+190 fusion constructs resulted in lower levels of CAT activity (65 and 75%, respectively) compared with the –225/+190 construct. This suggested the presence of one or more negative cis-regulatory elements located between bp –1503 and –775. Selective Activation of KGF CAT Promoter Constructs—Recognizing that our analysis of the human KGF promoter region had been thus far carried out using mouse fibroblasts, we wanted to extend the study of KGF promoter activity to human cell types. The –225/+190 KGF:CAT construct was therefore used to transfect four human fibroblast cell lines (151 and 152 (established from neonatal foreskin) and 202 and M413 (adult dermal fibroblasts)) and six epithelial cell lines (EJ (bladder carcinoma), A101 (melanoma), A549 (lung carcinoma), HeLa (cervical carcinoma), MCF-7 (breast carcinoma), and SKHEP-1 (liver carcinoma)). A similar degree of CAT activation was directed by the –225/+190 KGF promoter construct in human fibroblasts to that obtained in NIH73T3 cells (Fig. 6A). CAT activity of deletion constructs –1503/+190, –1164/+190, and –775/+190 was also comparable between human and mouse fibroblasts (data not shown). This indicates that the basal KGF promoter region is subject to similar regulation in both human and murine fibroblasts. In contrast, no CAT activity was detected in extracts of any of the epithelial cells (Fig. 6A). Control experiments, in which the activity of the SV40 CAT control construct was between 10- and 40-fold over basal level, demonstrated that efficient transfection of these cells was achieved. Using Northern hybridization analysis we were able to demonstrate that KGF promoter activation correlated with expression of KGF mRNA. As shown in Fig. 6B, the major 2.4-kb KGF transcript was present in each of the fibroblasts but in none of the epithelial cells. In order to determine whether the KGF promoter was active in other cell types besides fibroblasts, human and murine cell lines of different origin were transfected with the –225/+190 KGF:CAT construct and tested for basal level promoter activation. Since this construct provided full basal level promoter activation without the interference of negative regulatory elements, it was used in all subsequent experiments. Among the cells tested, activation of KGF:CAT promoter constructs was detected in C2C12 myoblasts (Fig. 7A). Furthermore, C2C12 myoblasts also expressed KGF RNA (Fig. 7B). No CAT activity or KGF transcripts were observed in monocytes (THP1), erythroleukemia (K-562), Burkitt lymphoma (Raji), or Epstein-Barr virus immortalized Β lymphoblastoid cell lines (LBW25 and LBW26) (Fig. 7B). Therefore, activation of the basal KGF promoter displays the same specificity for fibroblasts and myoblasts as KGF mRNA expression. Activation of the KGF Promoter by IL1, IL6, and Forskolin—In a previous report we demonstrated that IL1 and IL6 elevated the levels of KGF RNA in human fibroblasts (38Chedid M. Rubin J.S. Csaky K.G. Aaronson S.A. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 10753-10757Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). In order to investigate whether these cytokines could also activate the KGF promoter, NIH 3T3 fibroblasts were transiently transfected with the –225/+190 construct and stimulated with IL1 or IL6 for 40 h. As shown in Fig. 8, treatment with either cytokine significantly increased the level of CAT activity in these transfectants. No synergism was observed when cells were concomitantly treated with IL1 and IL6, suggesting that both cytokines may activate the KGF promoter via a common mechanism. No elevation in CAT activity was observed when cells transfected with a promoterless control plasmid were treated with either cytokine. The presence of a putative cAMP response element in the KGF promoter region suggested that transcription of the KGF gene could be modulated by alterations in intracellular cAMP levels. To test this hypothesis, NIH 3T3 cells transiently transfected with the –225/+190 construct were treated with forskolin (FSK), a potent activator of adenylate cyclase. Forskolin promoted a strong increase in CAT activity, indicating that an elevation in the levels of cAMP may result in the activation of the KGF promoter in fibroblasts (Fig. 8). Similar results were obtained in C2C12 myoblasts (data not shown). In this study, we reported the isolation and characterization of genomic clones containing the 5′-flanking region of the human KGF gene. We have demonstrated that a basal promoter region between bases –225 and +190 was sufficient to drive the expression of a CAT reporter gene in fibroblasts and myoblasts. This would appear to indicate that this region contains a binding site(s) for a cis-acting regulatory element(s) responsible for conferring expression upon the KGF gene. Alternatively, basal KGF expression might be dependent on a number of different DNA binding factors, combinations of which are present in fibroblasts and myoblasts. KGF:CAT constructs that include sequences between bp –1503 and –775 have decreased promoter activity compared with the basal KGF promoter. This suggests the presence of inhibitory elements in the distal promoter region that may play a role in regulating basal levels of gene expression in the absence of inducing signals (33Zinn K. DiMaio D. Maniatis T. Cell. 1983; 34: 865-879Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (590) Google Scholar, 34Melton D.W. McEwan C. McKie A.B. Ried A.M. Cell. 1986; 44: 319-328Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (92) Google Scholar, 35Short J.M. Wynshaw-Boris A. Short H.P. Hanson R.W. J. Biol. Chem. 1986; 261: 9721-9726Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 36Das H. Leff T. Breslow J.L. J. Biol. Chem. 1988; 263: 11452-11458Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 37Hebst R.S. Friedman N. Darnell J.E. Babiss L.E. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1989; 83: 7653-7657Google Scholar). The KGF promoter region contains the putative transcriptional promoter sequences, TATTTA and CCAAT, located 31 and 50 bp, respectively, upstream of the first mRNA start site. The TATA box is associated with the formation of stable preinitiation complexes that first involves the TATA binding protein, TFIID (39Sawadogo M. Sentenac A. Annu. Rev. Biochem. 1990; 59: 711-754Crossref PubMed Scopus (310) Google Scholar). Through subsequent recruitment and positioning of other elements of the transcription machinery, the TATA box contributes to efficient and accurate transcription that initiates at precise downstream start points. Many promoters also contain Inr sequences in the vicinity of transcription initiation that appear to be essential for accurate transcription (25Smale S.T. Schmidt M.C. Berk A.J. Baltimore D. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1990; 87: 4509-4513Crossref PubMed Scopus (353) Google Scholar). The sequences surrounding both KGF transcription start sites are also homologous to the consensus Inr (25Smale S.T. Schmidt M.C. Berk A.J. Baltimore D. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1990; 87: 4509-4513Crossref PubMed Scopus (353) Google Scholar). Thus, transcription from the KGF promoter may rely on both TATA binding and a functional Inr. The KGF transcript is highly expressed in the dermis of cutaneous wounds, suggesting that KGF may be important for the controlled migration and proliferation of epidermal keratinocytes associated with wound healing (7Werner S. Peters K.G. Longaker M.T. Fuller-Pace F. Banda M.J. Williams L.T. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1992; 89: 6896-6900Crossref PubMed Scopus (537) Google Scholar). Furthermore, KGF is overexpressed in certain chronic inflammatory diseases 3P. W. Finch, unpublished data. and may contribute to the repair of epithelial tissue injured during prolonged inflammatory episodes. Transcription of the KGF gene is induced by the action of IL1 and IL6 (38Chedid M. Rubin J.S. Csaky K.G. Aaronson S.A. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 10753-10757Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar), two of the major mediators of natural immunity and tissue repair (40Dinarello C.A. FASEB J. 1988; 2 (1988): 108-115Crossref PubMed Scopus (1309) Google Scholar, 41Le J. Vilcek J. Lab. Invest. 1989; 61: 588-602PubMed Google Scholar). Because these cytokines likely play a critical role in mediating acute inflammation associated with normal wound healing as well as in the pathogenesis of a number of chronic inflammatory diseases (42Hirano T. Clin. Immunol. Immunopathol. 1992; 62: S60-S65Crossref PubMed Scopus (202) Google Scholar, 43Dinarello C.A. Wolff S.M. N. Engl. J. Med. 1993; 328: 106-113Crossref PubMed Scopus (951) Google Scholar), further understanding of the mechanisms by which they induce KGF gene expression may have important clinical implications. NF-IL6 is a transcriptional activator induced by IL6 and IL1 and is implicated in the activation of genes involved in acute phase reaction, hemopoiesis, and inflammation (28Akira S. Isshiki H. Sugita T. Tanabe O. Kinoshita S. Nishio Y. Nakajima T. Hirano T. Kishimoto T. EMBO J. 1990; 9: 1897-1916Crossref PubMed Scopus (1212) Google Scholar, 44Poli V. Mancini F.P. Cortese R. Cell. 1990; 63: 643-653Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (459) Google Scholar). The presence of sequences that are homologous to the consensus NF-IL6 response element within the proximal KGF promoter region (bases –257 to –265 and –38 to –46) suggests a mechanism through which the action of IL1 and IL6 could lead to induction of KGF gene expression. Support for this concept was provided by the demonstration that both cytokines induced KGF transcriptional activity in a promoter construct (-280/+190) that contained putative NF-IL6 sites. In contrast, no response to either cytokine was observed when a promoterless construct was transfected into fibroblasts or myoblasts. The fact that IL1 and IL6 did not synergize suggests that both cytokines may activate the KGF promoter via a common mechanism, perhaps mediated by NF-IL6. Taken together, these results may provide the basis for the mechanism responsible for the modulation of KGF RNA expression and promoter activation by IL1 and IL6 not only in vitro but also during inflammatory processess in vivo. Transfection experiments demonstrated that the KGF promoter is active in fibroblasts and myoblasts but inactive in certain hematopoietic and epithelial cells. Additionally, a strong correlation between promoter activation and KGF RNA expression was observed in all the cells tested. These results are consistent with in situ hybridization data of KGF gene expression during development in which KGF mRNA was detected not only in mesenchymal cells of a large number of organs and tissues but also in the myotomes of the somites and transiently in cleaved muscles (Ref. 45Mason J.J. Fuller-Pace F. Smith R. Dickson C. Mech. Dev. 1994; 45: 15-30Crossref PubMed Scopus (262) Google Scholar).2 In contrast, the KGF signal was not detected in epithelial or immune cells, consistent with our data for KGF promoter activation. While KGF mRNA was detected in early myotomal cells and myoblasts of the developing muscle masses, it was not expressed by differentiated myotubes (45Mason J.J. Fuller-Pace F. Smith R. Dickson C. Mech. Dev. 1994; 45: 15-30Crossref PubMed Scopus (262) Google Scholar). While the exact role of KGF in myogenesis is unclear, our results provide the ability to study the control of KGF gene expression during myoblast differentiation using the C2C12 myoblast differentiation pathway (46Crescenzi M. Crouch D.H. Tato F. J. Cell Biol. 1994; 125: 1137-1145Crossref PubMed Scopus (48) Google Scholar). Such studies may provide important insights into the role of KGF during this process. Expression of KGF mRNA in rat prostate and mouse seminal vesicle stromal cells is androgen-responsive, suggesting that KGF mediates the indirect control of epithelial cell proliferation by steroid hormones in these organs (8Yan G. Fukabori Y. Nikolaropoulos S. Wang F. McKeehan W.L. Mol. Endocrinol. 1992; 6: 2123-2128Crossref PubMed Scopus (257) Google Scholar, 47Aland E.T. Rubin J.S. Young P. Chedid M. Ron D. Aaronson S.A. Cunha G.R. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1994; 91: 1074-1078Crossref PubMed Scopus (181) Google Scholar). However, we were unable to identify a consensus glucocorticoid response element (31Beato M. Cell. 1989; 56: 335-344Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (2852) Google Scholar) in the KGF promoter regulatory region that could mediate this induction by androgens. It has been reported that transcriptional control by steroid hormone receptors can be mediated from half-palindromic recognition sequences by cooperation with adjacent cis-acting promoter elements (48Tora L. Gaub M.P. Mader S. Dierich A. Bellard M. Chambon P. EMBO J. 1988; 7: 3771-3778Crossref PubMed Scopus (129) Google Scholar, 49Gaub M-P. Bellard M. Scheuer I. Chambon P. Sassone-Corsi P. Cell. 1990; 63: 1267-1276Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (419) Google Scholar). In this regard, there is a sequence present at bases –178 to –183, which differs by 1 bp from the consensus half-palindromic glucocorticoid response element, as well as two half palindromic estrogen-response motifs present at bases –39 to –43 and –574 to –578. It is possible that the androgen and estrogen receptors contribute to the control of KGF expression through these sites by cooperation with other transcriptional factors binding adjacent promoter elements. In summary, we have isolated and characterized the basal KGF promoter region that can drive expression of a CAT reporter gene in fibroblasts and myoblasts. Several possible sites for interaction of transcription factors with cis-acting regulatory regions have been identified that may mediate the modulation of KGF gene transcription by proinflammatory cytokines (Ref. 38Chedid M. Rubin J.S. Csaky K.G. Aaronson S.A. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 10753-10757Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, this paper). Further characterization of these and other regulatory sites using DNase I protection analysis, gel mobility shift assays, and site-directed mutagenesis will identify which of these putative sites are important for basal and cell-specific KGF gene expression and which sites play a role in KGF induction by various extracellular signals. This will lead to a detailed understanding of the normal mechanisms that control KGF expression and may provide insight into aberrant KGF expression in chronic inflammatory and neoplastic disease. We thank Dr. Steven Tronick for helpful discussions and support and Dr. Kathleen A. Taylor for providing Epstein-Barr virus-immortalized cell lines and helpful suggestions.

Abstract The androgen receptor (AR) is a nuclear transcription factor that is essential for development of the male urogenital tract. In the current work, we have characterized the mouse androgen receptor suppressor (mARS). A single, 20-base pair, region (TCCCCCCACCCACCCCCCCT) was sufficient for suppression in chloramphenicol acetyltransferase assays. Northern analysis indicated that translational regulation is not necessary for the suppression. Analysis of the AR mRNA half-life indicated that the mARS does not affect AR RNA degradation. Gel mobility assays showed that the mARS is bound by multiple proteins that can recognize single-stranded DNA and RNA. In addition, differing proteins are expressed in distinct tissues. Purification of some of these proteins has shown that a doublet of 33 and 35 kDa binds to the G-rich strand and that a 52-kDa protein binds to the C-rich strand. Southwestern blots have confirmed that these proteins are indeed recognized by the mARS. The results of these experiments indicate that the AR 5′-untranslated region contains a suppressor element that can be bound by multiple proteins. The mARS appears to be acting either by altering transcription initiation or blocking transcription elongation. Characterization of this suppressor may provide insight into the physiological means by which the AR is regulated.

The role of protein kinase C (PKC) in the regulation of the β3-adrenergic receptor (β3-AR) gene was examined in murine 3T3-F442A adipocytes, which express this receptor subtype at a high level. We also investigated the involvement of this kinase in the modulation of β3-AR gene expression by insulin. Long term exposure of 3T3-F442A adipocytes to phorbol 12-myristate 13-acetate (PMA) decreased β3-AR mRNA content in a time- and concentration-dependent manner, with maximal changes observed at 6 h (6.5-fold decrease) and at 100 nM PMA. This inhibition was selective for β3-AR transcripts, since β1- and β2-AR mRNA content remained unchanged. Also, (-)-[125I]cyanopindolol saturation and competition binding experiments on adipocyte membranes indicated that PMA induced an ~2-fold decrease in β3-AR expression, while that of the two other subtypes was not affected. This correlated with a lower efficacy of β3-AR agonists to stimulate adenylyl cyclase. Conversely, long term exposure to PMA did not alter adenylyl cyclase activity in response to guanosine 5’- O-(3-thiotriphosphate) or forskolin. The inactive phorbol ester 4α-phorbol 12,13-didecanoate did not repress β3-AR mRNA levels. Inhibition of β3-AR mRNA by PMA was suppressed by the PKC-selective inhibitor bisindolylmaleimide, and was not observed in PKC-depleted cells, indicating that PKC was involved in this response. mRNA turnover experiments showed that the half-life of β3-AR transcripts was not affected by long term PMA exposure. When 3T3-F442A adipocytes were pretreated with PMA for 24 h to down-regulate PKC, or with bisindolylmaleimide, the insulin-induced inhibition of β3-AR mRNA levels was reduced by 44-67%. These findings demonstrate that sustained PKC activation exerts a specific control of β3-AR gene expression and is involved, at least in part, in the modulation by insulin of this adrenergic receptor subtype. The α chain of the interleukin-2 receptor (IL-2Rα) is a key regulator of lymphocyte proliferation. To analyze the mechanisms controlling its expression in normal cells, we used the 5’-flanking region (base pairs −2539/+93) of the mouse gene to drive chloramphenicol acetyltransferase expression in four transgenic mouse lines. Constitutive transgene activity was restricted to lymphoid organs. In mature T lymphocytes, transgene and endogenous IL-2Rα gene expression was stimulated by concanavalin A and up-regulated by IL-2 with very similar kinetics. In thymic T cell precursors, IL-1 and IL-2 cooperatively induced transgene and IL-2Rα gene expression. These results show that regulation of the endogenous IL-2Rα gene occurs mainly at the transcriptional level. They demonstrate that cis-acting elements in the 5’-flanking region present in the transgene confer correct tissue specificity and inducible expression in mature T cells and their precursors in response to antigen, IL-1, and IL-2. In a complementary approach, we screened the 5’ end of the endogenous IL-2Rα gene for DNase-I hypersensitive sites. We found three lymphocyte specific DNase-I hypersensitive sites. Two, at −0.05 and −5.3 kilobase pairs, are present in resting T cells. A third site appears at −1.35 kilobase pairs in activated T cells. It co-localizes with IL-2-responsive elements identified by transient transfection experiments. The α chain of the interleukin-2 receptor (IL-2Rα) is a key regulator of lymphocyte proliferation. Together with the data obtained from the analysis of the human gene, our results suggest that the IL-2Rα promoter proximal region mediates early responses to antigen or IL-1, while previously unrecognized elements further upstream are required for the later IL-2-induced rise in IL-2Rα transcription. To assess if the 5’-flanking region of the mouse IL-2Rα gene that we have analyzed by transient transfection of the cell line PC60 contains the cis-acting elements required for correct tissue-specific and inducible expression of IL-2Rα gene in normal cells, we have generated transgenic mice in which this region controls the expression of the bacterial CAT gene. We chose CAT as a reporter gene, despite the fact that it does not lend itself to analysis at the single-cell level (unless its expression is driven by very strong promoters), because previous reports had shown that CAT expression could be detected in normal lymphoid tissues (32Philip R. Liggitt D. Philip M. Dazin P. Debs R. J. Biol. Chem. 1993; 268: 16087-16090Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 33Miller A.E. Ennist D.L. Ozato K. Westphal H. Methods (Orlando). 1991; 2: 248-260Google Scholar, 36Brombacher F. Schäfer T. Weissenstein U. Tschopp C. Andersen E. Bürki K. Baumann G. Int. Immunol. 1994; 6: 189-197Crossref PubMed Scopus (35) Google Scholar). In a complementary approach, we have screened a 11.9-kb region around the promoter of the IL-2Rα gene for DNase-I hypersensitive sites (DHS). DHS have been associated with sequences that control the transcriptional activity of neighboring genes, whereas general sensitivity to nuclease attack has been used to define open chromatin domains around genes that are transcriptionally active or can be activated upon stimulation or differentiation (37Elgin S.C.R. J. Biol. Chem. 1988; 263: 19259-19262Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 38Laemmli U.K. Kas E. Poljak L. Adachi Y. Curr. Opin. Genet. Dev. 1992; 2: 275-285Crossref PubMed Scopus (306) Google Scholar). DHS can be ubiquitous or cell type-specific. The latter class includes DHS that are present in cells in which the associated locus is silent but will be transcribed upon stimulation or differentiation, as well as DHS whose appearance correlates with gene expression. Generally, tissue-specific DHS map within or close to, cis-acting regulatory elements that behave as cell type-specific enhancers or locus control regions. Recently, it has been demonstrated that ubiquitous DHS may mark the boundary of an active chromatin segment by isolating other transcription units from the effect of enhancer elements (40Chung J.H. The construct was isolated by agarose gel electrophoresis, purified using glass powder (Geneclean, Bio 101 Inc., La Jolla, CA), and dissolved in injection buffer (10 mM Tris, pH 7.4; 0.1 mM EDTA). One to two pl of DNA at 3 μg/ml were injected into pronuclei of fertilized oocytes derived from NMRI mice (IFFA-Credo, Les Oncins, France). Injected oocytes were transferred to foster mothers. The presence of the transgene in the offspring was assessed by Southern blot analysis (see below) of genomic DNA isolated from mouse tails (42Beermann F. Hummler E. Schmid E. Schütz G. Mech. Dev. 1993; 42: 59-65Crossref PubMed Scopus (15) Google Scholar) and digested with TaqI. A fragment of 2.6 kb indicated the presence of the transgene, while a fragment of around 6.0 kb was derived from the endogenous IL-2Rα gene. Comparison of the intensity of these two bands, evaluated with a PhosphorImager (Molecular Dynamics, Sunnyvale, CA), allowed estimation of transgene copy number. Transgenic founders were crossed to NMRI mice. 6-12-week-old transgenic mice or nontransgenic littermates of either sex were used for the experiments. For the DNase-I hypersensitivity experiments, we used 2-3-month-old C57Bl/6 mice (IFFA-Credo). Lymph node and spleen cells were prepared by gentle homogenization. Spleen cells were sedimented onto Ficoll (Pharmacia Biotech Inc.). These cells were used either directly (not cultured) or cultured at 1 ˣ 106 cells/ml with ConA (2.5 μg/ml, Sigma) for different times. Where specified, IL-2 was added at the indicated concentrations. T cells were purified by incubating cell suspensions from lymph nodes or spleen either with anti-CD4 (GK1.5) and anti-CD8 (53-6.7) mAb or with an anti-Thy1.2 (A15) mAb coupled to magnetic microbeads (MACS® Miltenyi Biotec GmbH, Bergisch-Gladbach, Germany) followed by two rounds of magnetic sorting with a magnetic cell separation device (MACS Miltenyi Biotec GmbH) (43Milteny S. Müller W. Weichel W. Radbruch A. Cytometry. 1990; 11: 231-238Crossref PubMed Scopus (1445) Google Scholar). B cells were recovered in the flow-through. Cells were used either directly (not cultured) or after 80 h of culture at 1 ˣ 106 cells/ml with LPS (30 μg/ml; Escherichia coli 0127:B8, Life Technologies, Inc.) or with plastic-bound anti-CD3 mAb (145-C11), as described previously (44Soldaini E. MacDonald H.R. Nabholz M. Eur. J. Immunol. 1992; 22: 1707-1711Crossref PubMed Scopus (8) Google Scholar). CD4-CD8- thymocytes were purified from thymi of 6-week-old mice, using a combination of complement-mediated cytotoxicity and magnetic bead depletion with goat anti-rat Ig-coated Dynabeads, as described previously (19Wilson A. Corthésy P. Reichenbach P. MacDonald H.R. Nabholz M. Eur. J. Immunol. 1994; 24: 1729-1735Crossref PubMed Scopus (19) Google Scholar). Cells were cultured at 4 ˣ 105/ml with PMA (3 ng/ml) and ionomycin (62.5 ng/ml) (Calbiochem, San Diego, CA) for 48 h in 96-well flat bottomed plates (Costar, Cambridge, MA). Where indicated IL-1β at 1 ng/ml and/or IL-2 at 200 units/ml were added. Anti-mouse IL-2 mAb S4.B6.1 (45Zurawski S.M. Mosmann T.R. Benedik M. Zurawski G. J. Immunol. 1986; 137: 3354-3360PubMed Google Scholar) was added to all the cultures, while anti-mouse IL-2Rα mAb 5A2 (46Moreau J.-L. Nabholz M. Diamantstein T. Malek T. Shevach E. Thèze J. Eur. J. Immunol. 1987; 17: 929-935Crossref PubMed Scopus (86) Google Scholar) was added only to cells cultured without IL-2. Bone marrow was prepared by flushing femur and hip bones with ice-cold PBS through a 26-gauge needle. Thymic stroma and lymphocytes were separated by gently squeezing total thymus in a loose-fitting glass homogenizer. Mouse kidney epithelial cells were prepared as described elsewhere (47Braun M. McCormack A. Webb G. Batchelor R. Eur. J. Immunol. 1993; 23: 1462-1468Crossref PubMed Scopus (26) Google Scholar).
