Immunol. 1992; 22: 1707-1711Crossref PubMed Scopus (8) Google Scholar). IL-1 and IL-2 were human recombinant proteins, kindly provided by GLAXO (Geneva, Switzerland). For immunofluorescence analysis of IL-2Rα surface expression, the rat anti-mouse IL-2Rα mAb PC61 (48Lowenthal J.W. Corthésy P. Tougne C. Lees R. MacDonald H.R. Nabholz M. J. Immunol. 1985; 135: 3988-3994PubMed Google Scholar) was used, either conjugated with FITC, biotinylated, or as culture supernatant. PE-conjugated streptavidin or FITC-conjugated goat anti-rat Ig were used as second-step reagents (Caltag Laboratories, San Francisco, CA). The purity of MACS-purified cells before and after culture was assessed by staining cells with PE-conjugated anti-CD4 (Becton Dickinson, Mountain View, CA) plus PE-conjugated anti-CD8 (Boehringer Mannheim) and FITC-conjugated F(ab’)2 sheep anti-mouse Ig (Silenus Laboratories, Hawthorn, Australia). Samples were analyzed with a FACScan flow cytometer (Becton Dickinson) using the LYSYS II program. Protein extracts from fresh and cultured cells were prepared, and CAT activity was measured as described in Ref. 21Plaetinck G. Combe M.-C. Corthésy P. Sperisen P. Kanamori H. Honjo T. Nabholz M. J. Immunol. 1990; 145: 3340-3347PubMed Google Scholar, except that extracts were heated at 60°C for 10 min before the assay. Tissues were flash frozen in dry ice and ethanol and stored at −80°C. Samples were homogenized in 250 mM Tris-HCl, pH 7.8, freeze-thawed 3 times, and centrifuged for 15 min at 10,000 rpm. Supernatants were heated at 60°C for 10 min and centrifuged for another 10 min at the same speed. Protein concentration was determined by the Bio-Rad protein assay (Bio-Rad). CAT reactions were run at 37°C overnight. CAT activity was expressed as percentage of [14C]chloramphenicol converted to acetylated forms, as evaluated by PhosphorImager scanning. RNA was prepared by guanidinium thiocyanate extraction (49Chomczynski P. Sacchi N. Anal. Biochem. 1987; 162: 156-159Crossref PubMed Scopus (63147) Google Scholar). RNase protection assays were performed as described previously using mouse IL-2Rα and β-actin probes, which, when hybridized with mRNA, generate RNase-resistant fragments of 414 and 138 nucleotides, respectively (19Wilson A. Corthésy P. Reichenbach P. MacDonald H.R. Nabholz M. Eur. J. Immunol. 1994; 24: 1729-1735Crossref PubMed Scopus (19) Google Scholar). To make cells permeable to DNase-I, we treated them with lysolecithin as described by Miller et al.(50Miller M.R. Castellot J.J.J. Pardee A.B. Biochemistry. 1978; 17: 1073-1080Crossref PubMed Scopus (137) Google Scholar). Cells were washed with PBS and resuspended to 108/ml in buffer A (150 mM sucrose, 80 mM KCl, 35 mM Hepes, pH 7.4, 5 mM potassium phosphate, pH 7.4, 5 mM MgCl2, 0.5 mM CaCl2). One-third volume of a solution of 1 mg/ml of lysolecithin (Fluka Chemie AG, Buchs, Switzerland) in buffer A was added, and cells were incubated at 37°C for 70 s. Permeabilization was stopped by adding 20 volumes of ice-cold PBS. Cells were pelleted and resuspended to 108/ml in ice-cold buffer A containing 2 mM CaCl2. Aliquots of 107 cells were incubated with different amounts of DNase-I (Pharmacia) for 1 min at 20°C. Nuclease digestion was stopped by the addition of 1 volume of stop solution (20 mM EDTA, 1% SDS, 0.5 mg/ml proteinase K). Samples were incubated for at least 2 h at 37°C before extraction with phenol/chloroform/isoamylalcohol. Nucleic acids were ethanol-precipitated from the aqueous phase and redissolved in Tris EDTA buffer. Their concentration was estimated by measuring A260. An aliquot was fractionated on a 0.8% agarose gel to check the quality of the DNA and the effect of DNase-I digestion. 60-80 μg of DNA from each sample were digested to completion with the indicated restriction enzymes and electrophoresed in 0.8-1% agarose gels in Tris borate buffer at 1-1.5 V/cm. DNA was transferred to polyvinylidene difluoride-based membranes (ImmobilonTM transfer membranes, Millipore Corp., Bedford, MA) according to the indications of the manufacturer. To screen for DHS, we prepared probes using IL-2Rα genomic fragments C or D (see Fig. 6) as templates, with the random priming kit supplied by Boehringer Mannheim. Membranes were hybridized with QuickhybTM solution (Stratagene, La Jolla, CA) according to the protocol supplied by the manufacturer at 65°C. Filters were autoradiographed for 1-7 days at −70°C with intensifying screens. To detect TcR rearrangements, blots were hybridized with an antisense RNA probe (86T1) specific for the constant region of the TcR β gene (51Hedrick S.M. Nielsen E.A. Kavaler J. Cohen D.I. Davis M.M. Nature. 1984; 308: 153-156Crossref PubMed Scopus (509) Google Scholar) labeled by in vitro transcription with Riboprobe® Systems (Promega, Madison, WI). We have previously shown that the mouse IL-2Rα gene 5’-flanking region from bp −2539 to +93 confers a pattern of expression on a linked bacterial CAT gene that closely resembles that of the endogenous IL-2Rα gene in the rodent T cell line PC60 (21Plaetinck G. Combe M.-C. Corthésy P. Sperisen P. Kanamori H. Honjo T. Nabholz M. J. Immunol. 1990; 145: 3340-3347PubMed Google Scholar). We therefore used this construct, referred to as IL-2Rα-CAT, to generate transgenic mice. Five transgenic mice (out of 40 live births) were identified by Southern blot analysis. They carried between two and 29 copies of the transgene (Fig. 1). All founders transmitted the transgene to offspring at a constant copy number. As expected, the transgenic mice appeared normal with regard to behavior, lifespan, and physiology. They contained normal numbers of lymphocytes with normal subset distributions (data not shown). The responses of the lymphocytes in in vitro culture conditions were indistinguishable from those of cells from nontransgenic littermates. To determine in which tissues the IL-2Rα-CAT transgene was expressed, organs were taken from mice of each transgenic line and analyzed. CAT activity was undetectable in extracts (100-500 μg) of liver, kidney, heart, brain, and ovary of any transgenic line (data not shown). Lack of transgene expression in these tissues correlates with the absence of IL-2Rα+ cells observed by Takacs et al.(52Takacs L. Osawa H. Törö I. Diamantstein T. Clin. Exp. Immunol. 1985; 59: 37-44PubMed Google Scholar) by immunohistochemistry. No constitutive CAT activity was detected in lymph nodes of any line, whereas one line (1028) expressed activity in the spleen. The transgene was also expressed in the bone marrow of two lines (1028 and 1041) and in the thymus of four out of the five transgenic lines (). Levels of CAT activity in thymi of different transgenic lines correlated with transgene copy number (r2 = 0.93; see Table I). Unexpectedly, when thymic lymphocytes and stroma were separated, constitutive CAT activity was found in the stroma fraction but not in the lymphocytes (data not shown, see “Discussion”).Table ITissue distribution of IL-2Rα-CAT transgene expressionCAT activity in 100 μg of protein extracted from different organs. Since mature T cells express IL-2Rα only after activation (8Robb R.J. Munck A. Smith K.A. J. Exp. Med. 1981; 154: 1455-1474Crossref PubMed Scopus (792) Google Scholar), we analyzed the inducibility of the IL-2Rα-CAT transgene in lymph node and spleen cells from mice of the different transgenic lines before and after stimulation with ConA and IL-2. The effectiveness of the stimulation was checked by FACS analysis of IL-2Rα cell surface expression (see footnote to Table II). More than 85% of the stimulated cells from spleen and lymph nodes were IL-2Rα+ and CD4+ or CD8+ (data not shown). As shown in Table II, CAT activity was induced in both cell populations in four transgenic lines. Levels of expression did not correlate with transgene copy number, suggesting that the site at which the integration of the transgene occurred affects its transcriptional efficiency. The only line (1018) in which transgene expression was not inducible was the one without detectable constitutive CAT activity in the thymus (see Table I). Its transgene may have been integrated into transcriptionally inactive chromatin. This line was not further analyzed. Cells taken fresh (Table II) or after culture without stimuli (data not shown) did not have detectable CAT activity, with the exception of spleen cells from mice of line 1028, which also displayed constitutive CAT activity in total spleen extracts (Table I).Table II- Open table in a new tab When we compared the time course of transgene expression to that of the endogenous IL-2Rα gene, we found a very similar pattern (Fig. 2). CAT activity and surface IL-2Rα expression were detectable after 16 h of culture and increased until 72 h. By 6 days of culture, both activities had fallen to substantially lower levels. Nossal G.J.V. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1987; 84: 5399-5403Crossref PubMed Scopus (55) Google Scholar). To determine whether expression of the IL-2Rα-CAT transgene showed the same specificity, we purified T and B cells from lymph nodes and cultured them on plastic-bound anti-

Collagen type IV [α1(IV)2α2(IV)] is the basic structural component of all basement membranes. The two subunit genes COL4A1 and COL4A2 are found closely linked in the human and murine genomes and are transcribed divergently from a common promoter. Previously, activating elements had been detected within both genes which are indispensable for efficient transcription. An additional negative regulatory element has now been identified within the third intron of the COL4A2 gene which is able to inhibit transcription of both COL4 genes from their shared promoter, as well as the nonrelated herpes simplex virus thymidine kinase promoter. The element exerts its inhibitory effect largely independently from its relative orientation and distance from the initiation site of transcription. Therefore, the element represents a silencer, which is named the “COL4 silencer.” The minimal functional silencer could be narrowed down by deletion mapping to a sequence element located within intron 3 of the COL4A2 gene. This motif is specifically recognized by a nuclear protein, named “SILBF,” and the binding site of which was determined by footprinting assays. Mutation studies and deletion analysis proved that the presence of this sequence element and its interaction with SILBF is not only essential but also sufficient for the silencing function. We assume that the COL4 silencer plays an important role in the control of overall expression and the balance of divergent transcription of both COL4 genes. Constructs and Fragments—Numbering of all fragments from human collagen IV genes correponds to entry HSC0L4AI2 in the EMBL data base. The construct pTKCAT is identical with pBLCAT2 (53Luckow B. Schütz G. Nucleic Acids Res. 1987; 155490Crossref PubMed Scopus (1401) Google Scholar), and pNACAT and pBNaSACAT have been described previously (23Schmidt C. Fischer G. Kadner H. Genersch E. Kühn K. Posch] E. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 1993; 1174: 1-10Crossref PubMed Scopus (37) Google Scholar). The fragments SE (SphI-EcoRI, 1041–2184), SH (SphI-HindIII, 1041–1557), HE (HindIII-EcoRI, 1557–2184), SA (SphI-ApaI, 1041–1169), AAH (αpaI-HindIII, 1169–1557), AA (αpaI-αpaI, 1169–1317), and AH (ApaI-HindIII, 1317–1557) were isolated from clone p361 (11Pöschl E. Pollner R. Kühn K. EMBO J. 1988; 7: 2687-2695Crossref PubMed Scopus (121) Google Scholar), cloned upstream of the HSV-TK promoter of pTKCAT, and resulted in the clones shown in Fig. 1B. Series of unidirectional deletions from either side were generated by treatment with ExoIII and mung bean nuclease following the supplier’s protocol (Stratagene) in clone pAH containing fragment AH subcloned in vector pBSIIsk– (Stratagene). The end points of deletion were determined by sequencing, and fragments were inserted in pTKCAT as described above and resulted in the clones shown in Fig. 1C. For the construction of pAH-NACAT and pAH-BNaSACAT, the fragment AH was generated by polymerase chain reaction amplification with complementary oligonucleotides introducing additional SphI and SalI sites at the 5′- and 3′-termini, respectively. The product was cloned in pBNACAT and pBNaSACAT digested with SphI and SalI. Fragment Sil (1412–1484) was generated by polymerase chain reaction with complementary oligonucleotides introducing HindIII and EcoRI sites at the 5′- and 3′-termini, respectively. The product was cloned into the vector pBSIIsk– (Stratagene) resulting in pBS-Sil. pSil-TKCAT contains the HincII-BamHI insert of pBS-Sil cloned into the SalI and BamHI restricted pTKCAT. pSil-NACAT was constructed by cloning the SmaI-HincII insert of pBS-Sil into the blunt-ended HindIII site of pNACAT. Deletions were introduced in the constructs pAHdSil-NACAT (deletion of 1412–1484) and pAHdAH2-NACAT (deletion of 1427–1450) by a polymerase chain reaction-based strategy (51Pöschl E. Mayer U. Block D. Fox J. Timpl R. EMBO J. 1994; 13: 3741-3747Crossref PubMed Scopus (86) Google Scholar) introducing a HindIII or EcoRV site at the site of deletion, respectively. Fragment AH2 (1427–1450) was generated by annealing corresponding complementary synthetic oligonucleotides and subcloning into the SmaI site of pBSIIsk– (pBS-AH2). Oligonucleotide CANP-GCF, representing the binding site of GCF in the CANP gene, was taken from Ref. 43Kageyama R. Pastan I. Cell. 1989; 59: 815-825Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (207) Google Scholar, and fragment CTC contains the binding site of CTCBF (24Fischer G. Schmidt C. Opitz J. Cully Z. Kühn K. Pöschl E. Biochem. J. 1993; 292: 687-695Crossref PubMed Scopus (40) Google Scholar). Fragment MCS represents the polylinker region of pUC18. Mutations of AH2 were generated by annealing two corresponding complementary oligonucleotides and subsequent cloning in pBSIIsk– and pNACAT. Fischer G. Pöschl E. Kühn K. Aren. N. Y. Acad. Sci. 1990; 580: 44-54Crossref PubMed Scopus (22) Google Scholar, 23Schmidt C. Fischer G. Kadner H. Genersch E. Kühn K. Posch] E. Biochim. Biophys. J. 1993; 292: 687-695Crossref PubMed Scopus (40) Google Scholar). Nuclear Extracts and Gel Retardation Assays—Nuclear extracts from cultured HT1080, EW, and Jurkat cells, as well as isolated nuclei of HeLa cells (Computer Cell Culture Center, Mons, Belgium) were prepared as described (24Fischer G. Schmidt C. Opitz J. Cully Z. Kühn K. Pöschl E. Biochem. J. 1993; 292: 687-695Crossref PubMed Scopus (40) Google Scholar). Nuclear extracts were fractionated by successive chromatography on heparin-agarose and DNA-cellulose as described (52Genersch E. Eckerskorn C. Lottspeich F. Herzog C. Kühn K. Pöschl E. EMBO J. 1994; 14: 791-800Crossref Scopus (73) Google Scholar). Briefly, SILBF was detected in fraction HA/500 (heparin-agarose, elution at 500 mM KCl) and CT/250 (DNA-cellulose, elution at 250 mM KCl). Fragments used in gel retardation assays were isolated from the corresponding clones (pBS-Sil, pBS-AH, pBS-AH2) by digestion with BamHI and HindIII, and fragments were labeled at the 5′-termini with polynucleotide kinase and [γ-32P]αTP. Gel retardation assays and competition assays were done as described previously (24Fischer G. Schmidt C. Opitz J. Cully Z. Kühn K. Pöschl E. Biochem. J. 1993; 292: 687-695Crossref PubMed Scopus (40) Google Scholar). Footprinting reactions were performed as described (50Henninhausen L. Lubon H. Methods Enzymol. 1987; 152: 721-735Crossref PubMed Scopus (165) Google Scholar). The XhoI-XbaI insert of pBS-Sil was used, and fragments were 5′-end-labeled either at the XhoI (upper strand) or XbaI site (lower strand) and incubated with fraction CT/250. The reaction products after DNase I digestion were purified and separated on sequencing gels. Dideoxy sequencing reactions were performed with clone pBS-Sil and primers KS (upper strand) and SK (lower strand). A Silencing Element Is Located in the Third Intron of the COL4A2 Gene—First indications of the presence of a negatively acting element were obtained during transfection studies with reporter gene constructs containing different fragments from the COL4A2 gene combined with the HSV-TK promoter linked to the chloramphenicol acetyltransferase (CAT) gene (11Pöschl E. Pollner R. Kühn K. EMBO J. 1988; 7: 2687-2695Crossref PubMed Scopus (121) Google Scholar). The organization of the COL4 gene locus is shown in Fig. 1A, and initial experiments for the localization of this element are summarized in Fig. 1B. The fragment SE, comprising a region from the first intron and extending to the third intron of the COL4A2 gene, was positioned upstream of the HSV-TK promoter in both orientations (pSE-TKCAT, pES-TKCAT) and was tested by transient transfection assays in human HT1080 cells (Fig. 1B). The activity was reduced to background levels (12% and 9%) when compared with the activity of the basic construct pTKCAT, set arbitrarily as 100%, and the promoterless construct p0CAT, as 8% (Fig. 1C). Fragments SH (pHS-TKCAT), AAH (pAAH-TKCAT, pHAA-TKCAT), and AH (pAH-TKCAT, pHA-TKCAT) also retained inhibitory activity, whereas fragments HE, SA, and AA revealed no effect on the transcription from the HSV-TK promoter. Therefore, a strong negatively acting element is localized within the fragment AH (ApeaI-HindIII, 1317–1557). The position of the inhibitory element was further narrowed down by deletion mapping of the fragment AH. Unidirectional deletions of the fragment AH were generated and combined with pTKCAT resulting in the constructs shown in Fig. 1C. All constructs were tested by transient transfection assays in HT1080 cells. The fragment in construct pHA(171)-TKCAT and all larger fragments retained inhibitory activity, whereas fragments in pHA(92)-TKCAT and pHA(71)-TKCAT lost inhibitory capacity on the HSV-TK promoter. Deletions of sequences upstream of position 1409 did not impair the silencing activity, as seen with pAH(148)-TKCAT and all constructs containing larger fragments. Deletion of sequences located more upstream in constructs pAH(126)-TKCAT, pAH(102)-TKCAT, pAH(72)-TKCAT, and pAH(40Jackson M.E. J. Cell Sci. 1991; 100: 1-7Crossref PubMed Google Scholar)-TKCAT resulted in a complete loss of inhibitory capacity. Therefore, functionally essential sequences must be located between position 1409 and position 1488. The fragment Sil (1412–1484) was selected for a more detailed analysis of the negatively acting element (see Fig. 5). The effect of the element is largely independent of its orientation relative to the initiation site of transcription, as can be seen in the constructs pHA-TKCAT and pAH-TKCAT, which reveal no significant difference in activities. Earlier experiments have shown that the silencing effect is moderately modulated by the distance from the start site of transcription (data not shown) and also exerts its effect when placed downstream of the transcription unit of the reporter gene (11Pöschl E. Pollner R. Kühn K. EMBO J. 1988; 7: 2687-2695Crossref PubMed Scopus (121) Google Scholar). These characteristics resemble typical features of enhancers (41Khoury G. Gruss P. Cell. 1983; 33: 313-314Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (309) Google Scholar) and silencers (42Brand A.H. Breeden L. Abraham J. Sternglanz R. Nasmyth K. Cell. 1985; 41: 41-48Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (301) Google Scholar), and, therefore, the element was named “COL4 silencer.” The COL4 silencer had been originally identified (11Pöschl E. Pollner R. Kühn K. EMBO J. 1988; 7: 2687-2695Crossref PubMed Scopus (121) Google Scholar) and localized (see Fig. 1) on the basis of its effect on transcription of the heterologous HSV-TK promoter. In order to elucidate its contribution to the regulation of collagen IV genes, the silencer, represented by fragment AH, was inserted in reporter constructs detecting transcription from the shared COL4 promoter either in the α1(IV) or α2(IV) direction as described previously (23Schmidt C. Fischer G. Kadner H. Genersch E. Kühn K. Posch] E. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 1993; 1174: 1-10Crossref PubMed Scopus (37) Google Scholar). pNACAT contains the promoter and the first intron of COL4A2 with the CAT reporter gene linked to the second exon (see Fig. 5). pBNaSACAT contains the promoter, first exon with deleted translational start site, and part of the first intron of the COL4A1 gene, with the second exon of COL4A2 gene used as splice acceptor site (23Schmidt C. Fischer G. Kadner H. Genersch E. Kühn K. Posch] E. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 1993; 1174: 1-10Crossref PubMed Scopus (37) Google Scholar). The fragment AH was inserted upstream of transcription start sites, resulting in the constructs pAH-NACAT and pAH-BNaSACAT. These constructs were tested by transient transfection assays in HT1080 cells and compared with the constructs pTKCAT and pAH-TKCAT (Table I). Transcription from the HSV-TK (pAH-TKCAT) and the COL4A2 promoter (pAH-NACAT) was strongly inhibited to 8% and 15%, when compared with the activity of the reference constructs (pTKCAT, pNACAT). A weaker inhibitory effect was observed for the transcription in the α1(IV) direction in pAH-BNaSACAT (42%).Table IEffect of the COL4 silencer on different promoters in various cellsPromoterConstructsRelative activity in HT1080SAOF9/–F9/+HSV-TKpTK-CAT100(26)100(38)100(15)100(44)pAH-TKCAT8(3)8%66(15)66%107(24)107%34(22)34%α2(IV)pNACAT287(56)46(27)849(190)5171(1625)pAH-NACAT42(6)15%26(4)56%337(93)40%870(280)17%α1(IV)pBNaSACAT261(32)27(13)932(272)11024(1373)pAH-BNaSACAT110(36)42%22(10)81%574(161)62%792(360)7% Open table in a new tab The same constructs were also transfected to the osteosarcoma cell line SAO not expressing collagen type IV. The activities of the constructs pNACAT and pBNaSACAT are very low, when compared with the activity of the HSV-TK promoter in pTKCAT. Only a moderate decrease in activity was seen with all constructs containing the fragment AH (44%-29%). Therefore, cells not expressing collagen IV are not only less active in transcription from the COL4 promoter but the inhibitory effect of the silencer is diminished. The differentiation of murine teratocarcinoma F9 to parietal endoderm-like cells by treatment with retinoic acid and dibutyryl cAMP is accompanied by the onset of expression of collagen IV, laminin, and nidogen (26Strickland S. Smith K.K. Marotti K.R. Cell. 1980; 21: 347-355Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (593) Google Scholar, 27Rogers M.B. Watkins S.C. Gudas L.J. J. Cell Biol. 1990; 110: 1767-1777Crossref PubMed Scopus (32) Google Scholar). F9 cells were transfected with the same constructs, and activity was determined without (F9/-) or after treatment with retinoic acid/dibutyryl cAMP (F9/+). The activity of the HSV-TK promoter in pTKCAT was found to be very low, whereas the COL4 promoter was transcribed more efficiently, as represented by pNACAT and pBNaSACAT. Transcription in the α1(IV) and α2(IV) direction could be inhibited only partially (60% and 38% inhibition) by the COL4 silencer in F9/– cells. On the other hand, in F9/+ cells, the promoters were more efficiently transcribed, but, in parallel, the silencing effect of the AH fragment results in a stronger inhibition of activity. These data indicate that the COL4 promoter is used more efficiently in cells expressing collagen IV, like HT1080 and F9/+, but this effect is paralleled by a stronger effect of the COL4 silencer. Obviously, the balance of activating elements and the inhibitory COL4 silencer plays an important role in the control of transcription. A Nuclear Factor Binds Specifically to the COL4 Silencer and Mediates the Silencing Effect—The identification and analysis of the cis-acting COL4 silencer stimulated attempts to identify trans-acting nuclear factors potentially involved in mediating the silencing effect. The minimal fragment Sil (see Fig. 1C) was tested for its ability to bind nuclear factors by gel retardation assays (Fig. 2). Nuclear extracts from HeLa cells were used because the COL4 silencer was also shown to exert its negative effect in these cells (see Fig. 5). The conditions for binding to labeled fragment Sil were optimized (data not shown) and resulted in the formation of two well detectable retarded complexes (Fig. 2A). The specificity of these complexes was tested by competition experiments using unlabeled fragments Sil, nonrelated MCS, or a fragment corresponding to the binding site of the factor CTCBF (24Fischer G. Schmidt C. Opitz J. Cully Z. Kühn K. Pöschl E. Biochem. J. 1993; 292: 687-695Crossref PubMed Scopus (40) Google Scholar). Only the slower migrating complex could be specifically competed by the addition of a molar excess of fragment Sil (lanes 2 and 3), but not by nonrelated sequences (lanes 4–7). This complex is therefore formed by the specific interaction with a nuclear factor, which was named SILBF. The faster migrating band represents S nonspecific DNA-protein complex. The binding site of SILBF was defined by footprinting experiments (Fig. 3). The fragment Sil was subcloned (pBS-Sil), and unilaterally labeled fragments were generated by 5′-end-labeling of the upper strand (XbaI) or the lower strand (XhoI). Dideoxy sequencing ladders were generated by using the primers KS and SK (Stratagene) for comparison with the DNase I-generated cleavage products, because 5′-termini of these primers correspond to the termini of the labeled fragments. Full protection of the binding site could only be enabled after enrichment of SILBF by successive chromatographic fractionation on heparin agarose (fraction HA/500, 500 mM KCl eluate) and calf thymus DNA-cellulose (fraction CT/250, 250 mM KCl eluate) (data not shown). Footprinting reactions were performed with increasing amounts of enriched SILBF, and products were separated on sequencing gels (Fig. 3). Two protected regions could be recognized in the coding strand which are separated only by a single base pair (Fig. 3A). The protected region corresponds to position 1429–1450. The noncoding strand revealed a protected region corresponding to position 1427–1449 (Fig. 3β). The sequences involved in interaction with SILBF are marked in Fig. 3 and define the minimal binding site of the factor between positions 1427 and 1450. Comparison of this sequence motif with published sequences in data bases reveal no obvious homologies to known motifs. A partial homology was detected with the binding motif of the negatively acting factor GCF (43Kageyama R. Pastan I. Cell. 1989; 59: 815-825Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (207) Google Scholar), but gel retardation and competition experiments, using the GCF binding motif from the human CANP gene, proved that SILBF is different from GCF (see Fig. 6A). We assume that SILBF represents a novel negatively acting factor. The fragment AH2 (1427–1450), representing the minimal binding site of SILBF, is included in fragment Sil (1412–1484). Comparison of both fragments by gel retardation (Fig. 2) resulted in the formation of similar complexes (Fig. 2, A and B). Only the slower migrating complexes could be competed specifically by unlabeled fragments (lanes 2, 3, and 9), but not by nonrelated sequences, like MCS (lanes 4, 5, and 10). The specific complex formed on fragment AH2 could also be competed by fragment Sil (lane 11). These data indicate that the same nuclear factor, SILBF, interacts spec

1-O-Alkyl-sn-glycerol (alkylglycerol) forms the backbone of complex ether-linked glycerolipids, including biologically active lipids such as platelet-activating factor. Synthetic alkylglycerol itself possesses several potent pharmacological activities and has been shown to inhibit protein kinase C (PKC) in vitro. In spite of these properties, free alkylglycerol has been regarded only as a potential product of the inflammatory degradation of complex ether lipids rather than a natural cell constituent. To explore the possibility that endogenous alkylglycerol functions as a physiological regulator in normal cells, we measured its content, along with related monoglycerides and diglycerides, by high performance liquid chromatography and gas-liquid chromatography in Madin-Darby canine kidney (MDCK) cells. The content of free alkylglycerol increased up to 20-fold during the growth of MDCK cell cultures to a confluent density. The increase was greatest during the log phase of growth, in which the content of alkylglycerol rose from 6.0 ± 1.3 nmol/108 cells in preconfluent cultures to 23.6 ± 3.4 nmol/108 cells in confluent cultures. Analysis of the molecular species of alkylglycerol showed that the higher content in quiescent MDCK cells was due primarily to an increase in 1-O-octadecyl-sn-glycerol. In contrast, the levels of monoacylglycerol and the PKC activator diacylglycerol were lower in confluent, quiescent cultures than in preconfluent, proliferating cultures. A similar pattern of changes in the monoglyceride and diglyceride content was observed in interleukin-3-dependent CFTL-12 mast cells when cell proliferation was blocked by growth factor withdrawal.Growth of MDCK cells to a confluent density resulted in a decrease in particulate PKC enzyme activity to a level that was only 6% of that in proliferating cells. To explore whether the accumulation of cellular alkylglycerol contributes to growth-dependent changes in PKC activity, we examined the effects of adding alkylglycerol to the activity and subcellular distribution of the enzyme in MDCK cells. Treatment of cells with 1-O-dodecyl-en-glycerol resulted in a decrease in the activity of membrane-associated PKC activity and inhibited 12-O-tetradecanoylphorbol-13-acetate-stimulated translocation of PKC from the cytosol to the membrane fraction. Alkylglycerol was also shown to inhibit the activity of purified PKC in vitro when present at levels similar to that of the diacylglycerol activator. We propose that the accumulation of alkylglycerol during the growth of MDCK cells to a confluent density contributes to the decrease in PKC activity. The control of cellular alkylglycerol levels may be a novel mechanism for the regulation of cellular physiology. 1-O-Alkyl-sn-glycerol (alkylglycerol) forms the backbone of complex ether-linked glycerolipids, including biologically active lipids such as platelet-activating factor. Synthetic alkylglycerol itself possesses several potent pharmacological activities and has been shown to inhibit protein kinase C (PKC) in vitro. In spite of these properties, free alkylglycerol has been regarded only as a potential product of the inflammatory degradation of complex ether lipids rather than a natural cell constituent. To explore the possibility that endogenous alkylglycerol functions as a physiological regulator in normal cells, we measured its content, along with related monoglycerides and diglycerides, by high performance liquid chromatography and gas-liquid chromatography in Madin-Darby canine kidney (MDCK) cells. The content of free alkylglycerol increased up to 20-fold during the growth of MDCK cell cultures to a confluent density. The increase was greatest during the log phase of growth, in which the content of alkylglycerol rose from 6.0 ± 1.3 nmol/108 cells in preconfluent cultures to 23.6 ± 3.4 nmol/108 cells in confluent cultures. Analysis of the molecular species of alkylglycerol showed that the higher content in quiescent MDCK cells was due primarily to an increase in 1-O-octadecyl-sn-glycerol. In contrast, the levels of monoacylglycerol and the PKC activator diacylglycerol were lower in confluent, quiescent cultures than in preconfluent, proliferating cultures. A similar pattern of changes in the monoglyceride and diglyceride content was observed in interleukin-3-dependent CFTL-12 mast cells when cell proliferation was blocked by growth factor withdrawal. Growth of MDCK cells to a confluent density resulted in a decrease in particulate PKC enzyme activity to a level that was only 6% of that in proliferating cells. To explore whether the accumulation of cellular alkylglycerol contributes to growth-dependent changes in PKC activity, we examined the effects of adding alkylglycerol to the activity and subcellular distribution of the enzyme in MDCK cells. Treatment of cells with 1-O-dodecyl-en-glycerol resulted in a decrease in the activity of membrane-associated PKC activity and inhibited 12-O-tetradecanoylphorbol-13-acetate-stimulated translocation of PKC from the cytosol to the membrane fraction. Alkylglycerol was also shown to inhibit the activity of purified PKC in vitro when present at levels similar to that of the diacylglycerol activator. We propose that the accumulation of alkylglycerol during the growth of MDCK cells to a confluent density contributes to the decrease in PKC activity. The control of cellular alkylglycerol levels may be a novel mechanism for the regulation of cellular physiology. 1-O-Alkyl-sn-glycerol (alkylglycerol) 1The abbreviations used are: alkylglycerol1-O-Alkyl-sn-glycerolalkylacylglycerol1-O-alkyl-2-acyl-sn-glycerolalkyldiacylglycerol1-O-alkyl-2,3-diacyl-sn-glycerolPKCprotein kinase CMDCKMadin-Darby canine kidneyTPA12-O-tetradecanoylphorbol-13-acetateHPLChigh performance liquid chromatographyGLCgas-liquid chromatographyDMEMDulbecco’s modified Eagle’s mediumILinterleukinBSAbovine serum albumin. forms the backbone of ether-linked glycerolipids such as 1-O-alkyl- and 1-O-alk-1′-enyl-linked choline and ethanolamine phospholipids and 1-O-alkyl-2,3-diacyl-sn-glycerol (alkyldiacylglycerol). These include biologically active lipids such as platelet-activating factor (1-O-alkyl-2-acetyl-sn-glycerophosphocholine) and 1-O-alkyl-2-acylsre-glycerol, which is considered to be an agonist of protein kinase C (PKC) (1Ford D.A. Miyake R. Glaser P.E. Gross R.W. J. Biol. Chem. 1989; 264: 13818-13824Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). In addition to the naturally occurring bioactive compounds, many synthetic alkylglycerol-containing lipids possess pharmacological activity and are of current interest in biomedical research, including compounds with antineoplastic and platelet-activating factor antagonist activity. Unsubstituted alkylglycerol itself evokes a variety of biological responses. 1-O-Dodecylglycerol stimulates antibody production in mice (2Ngwenya B.Z. Foster D.M. Proc. Soc. Exp. Biol. Med. 1991; 196: 69-75Crossref PubMed Scopus (44) Google Scholar) and activates macrophages (3Yamamoto N. St. Clair D.A. Homma S. Ngwenya B.Z. Cancer Res. 1988; 48: 6044-6049PubMed Google Scholar). This form of alkylglycerol also stimulates the differentiation of neurons (4Ved H.S. Gustow E. Pieringer R.A. J. Neurosci. Res. 1991; 30: 353-358Crossref PubMed Scopus (23) Google Scholar) and possesses antitumor activity (5Ando K. Kodama K. Kato A. Tamura G. Arima K. Cancer Res. 1972; 321: 125-129Google Scholar). 1-O-Alkyl-sn-glycerol 1-O-alkyl-2-acyl-sn-glycerol 1-O-alkyl-2,3-diacyl-sn-glycerol protein kinase C Madin-Darby canine kidney 12-O-tetradecanoylphorbol-13-acetate high performance liquid chromatography gas-liquid chromatography Dulbecco’s modified Eagle’s medium interleukin bovine serum albumin. Alkylglycerol has been regarded primarily as a product of the inflammatory degradation of complex ether lipids rather than a constitutive component of normal cells (3Yamamoto N. St. Clair D.A. Homma S. Ngwenya B.Z. Cancer Res. 1988; 48: 6044-6049PubMed Google Scholar, 6Yamamoto N. Ngwenya B.Z. Cancer Res. 1987; 47: 2008-2013PubMed Google Scholar). However, we have detected a substantial level of free alkylglycerol in unstimulated cultured cells (7Warne T.R. Robinson M. Anal. Biochem. 1991; 198: 302-307Crossref PubMed Scopus (9) Google Scholar), raising the possibility that it serves a physiological role in normal tissues. The existence of the free compound in resting cells emphasizes the importance of determining the metabolic basis of the biological activities of alkylglycerol. Although the potency of the synthetic alkylglycerol suggests that its effects are due to metabolic rather than physical processes, little is known concerning its mechanism of action. McNeely et al. (8McNeely T.B. Rosen G. Londer M.V. Turco S.J. Biochem. J. 1991; 259: 601-604Crossref Scopus (116) Google Scholar) observed that alkylglycerol, derived from the hydrolysis products of the lipophosphoglycan of Leishmania donovani, inhibited isolated rat brain PKC in vitro. Our studies show that treatment of Madin-Darby canine kidney (MDCK) cells with synthetic alkylglycerol potently inhibits the release of arachidonic acid and its metabolites during subsequent stimulation with TPA (9Robinson M. Burdine R. Warne T.R. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 1995; (in press)Google Scholar). The ability of alkylglycerol to modulate this signaling pathway in intact MDCK cells, together with its natural occurrence, suggests a potential bioregulatory role for the endogenous compound as a regulator of PKC. PKC plays a central role in a variety of cell processes including the regulation of cell growth (10Nishizuka Y. Science. 1986; 233: 305Crossref PubMed Scopus (4036) Google Scholar, 11Weinstein I.B. Adv. Second Messenger Phosphoprotein Res. 1990; 24: 307-316PubMed Google Scholar). Inhibition of cell growth has been associated with a shift in the activity of PKC from the membrane-associated form to the cytosolic form and thus a decrease in the constitutive activity of the enzyme in nonproliferating cells (12Miloszewska J. Trawiki W. Janik P. Moraczewski J. Przybyszewska M. Szaniawska B. FEBS Lett. 1986; 206: 283-286Crossref PubMed Scopus (22) Google Scholar, 13Halsey D.L. Girard P.R. Kuo J.F. Blackshear P.S. J. Biol. Chem. 1987; 262: 2234-2243Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 14Whatley R.E. Stroud E.D. Bunting M. Zimmerman G.A. McIntyre T.M. Prescott S.M. J. Biol. Chem. 1993; 268: 16130-16138Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Diacylglycerol, an important physiological activator of PKC, is elevated in proliferating as compared with quiescent cells (14Whatley R.E. Stroud E.D. Bunting M. Zimmerman G.A. McIntyre T.M. Prescott S.M. J. Biol. Chem. 1993; 268: 16130-16138Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 15Bocckino S.B. Wilson P.B. Exton J.H. Biochem. Biophys. Res. Commun. 1989; 164: 290-294Crossref PubMed Scopus (13) Google Scholar, 16Banfic H. Zizak M. Divecha N. Irvine R.F. Biochem. J. 1993; 290: 633-636Crossref PubMed Scopus (114) Google Scholar, 17Robinson M. Warne T.R. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 1991; 1085: 63-70Crossref PubMed Scopus (6) Google Scholar), suggesting that its content contributes to the regulation of basal PKC activity during changes in cell growth status. In view of the ability of alkylglycerol to inhibit PKC in vitro and in vivo and its occurrence in unstimulated cells, we explored the possibility that its content contributes to growth-dependent changes in PKC activity. We determined that the content of alkylglycerol is specifically regulated during cell growth and accumulates in growth-inhibited cells. Contact-inhibited MDCK cells have increased levels of alkylglycerol and decreased levels of PKC activity. Furthermore, brief incubation of preconfluent MDCK cells with exogenous alkylglycerol reduces membrane-associated PKC activity and inhibits phorbol ester-stimulated redistribution of PKC. These results support a role for alkylglycerol as an endogenous regulator of PKC. Materials—Solvents were HPLC grade from Burdick and Jackson, Muskegon, MI. Benzene, benzoic anhydride, benzoyl chloride, and pyridine were from Aldrich. Prepacked silica columns (PrepSep-Si, 300 mg of silica) were obtained from Fisher Scientific. [l,2,-3H]Cholesterol (62.0 Ci/mmol) and [3H]arachidonic acid (60–90 Ci/mmol) were obtained from DuPont NEN. [3H]Dihexadecanoyl-sn-glycerol was prepared from l-αdipalmitoyl[2-9,10-3H]phosphatidylcholine (50.0 Ci/mmol, DuPont NEN) by phospholipase C (Bacillus cereus, type XIII, Sigma) hydrolysis (18Mavis R.D. Bell R.M. Vagelos P.R. J. Biol. Chem. 1972; 247: 2835-2841Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). All other lipids, enzymes, and reagents, unless indicated, were from Sigma. Purified PKC from rat brain was from Calbiochem. l-O-Dodecyl-sn-glycerol was prepared by reacting dodecyl methanesulfonate with 2,3-isopropylidene-sn-glycerols by the method of Baumann and Mangold (19Baumann W.J. Mangold H.K. J. Org. Chem. 1964; 29: 3055-3057Crossref Scopus (222) Google Scholar). The alkylglycerol product was purified by preparative TLC in a solvent system of hexane:ether (80:20) and quantified by GLC. The purity was found to be greater than 98% by GLC. Cell Culture—MDCK cells (American Type Culture Collection, Rockville, MD) were grown in Dulbecco’s modified Eagle’s medium (DMEM) with 5% heat-inactivated fetal bovine serum, 5% horse serum, penicillin (100 units/ml), and streptomycin (100 μg/ml) and were passaged by trypsinization. MDCK cells were seeded at a density of 1–5 × 104 cells/cm2 using 10-cm diameter dishes (mass analysis of lipids and PKC determination) and 24-well multiwell plates (arachidonic acid release). The interleukin (IL)-3-dependent mast cell line CFTL-12 (obtained from Dr. J. Pierce, NIH, Bethesda) was cultured in RPMI 1640 supplemented with heat-inactivated fetal bovine serum (10%, v/v), penicillin (100 units/ml), streptomycin (100 µg/ml), and a supernatant (10% v/v) prepared from the culture medium of WEHI-3B cells as a source of IL-3. CFTL-12 cells were passaged by dilution and harvested after 4–6 day of culture (8.0 × 105 cells/ml). Measurement of Monoalkylglycerol, Monoacylglycerol, Alkylacylglycerol, and Diacylglycerol—Cells were rinsed twice with serum-free medium and fixed by the addition of methanol. [3H]Cholesterol (0.35 µCi) and [3H]dihexadecanoylglycerol (0.08 μCi) were added as internal standards and the total lipids extracted by the method of Bligh and Dyer (20Bligh E.G. Dyer W.J. Can. J. Biochem. Physiol. 1959; 37: 627-643Crossref Scopus (42871) Google Scholar). Quantitative determination of cholesterol, alkylacylglycerol, diacylglycerol, monoalkylglycerol, and monoacylglycerol was performed as described previously (7Warne T.R. Robinson M. Anal. Biochem. 1991; 198: 302-307Crossref PubMed Scopus (9) Google Scholar) using solid phase extraction to isolate the combined lipid classes from total lipid extracts, followed by derivatization and separation of the compounds by normal phase HPLC as their benzoate (cholesterol and diglycerides) and dibenzoate (monoglycerides) derivatives. HPLC was performed using a Perkin-Elmer series 410 LC pump and LC-95 UV/visible LC spectrophotometer. For data collection, the detector was interfaced to Maxima 820 Chromatography Workstation on an NEC APCIV computer. The mass of benzoate derivatives was determined from their 230 nm absorbance and corrected for recovery using radiolabeled internal standard cholesterol and dihexadecanoyl-sn-glycerol as described (21Warne T.R. Robinson M. Lipids. 1990; 25: 748-752Crossref PubMed Scopus (9) Google Scholar). For analysis of monoacylglycerol and monoalkylglycerol by GLC, cell lipids were separated by TLC using a solvent system of hexane:diethyl ether:acetic acid (40:60:1). The area corresponding to the combined monoacylglycerols and monoalkylglycerols was scraped and the lipids extracted and converted to 1-radyl-2,3-O-isopropylidine derivatives (22Wykle R.L. Snyder F. J. Biol. Chem. 1970; 245: 3047-3058Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 23Myher J.J. Kuksis A. J. Chromatogr. 1989; 471: 187-204Crossref PubMed Scopus (10) Google Scholar). The 1-alkyl-2,3-O-isopropylidine derivatives were separated from 1-acyl-2,3-O-isopropylidine by TLC using a solvent system of hexane:diethyl ether:acetic acid (80:20:1) and were analyzed by GLC using a DB-23 capillary column (J & W Scientific, Folsom, CA). The initial oven temperature was 180 °C and increased to 230 °C at 3.5 °C/min followed by an increase to 240 °C at 10 °C/min. Peaks were identified by comparison of their retention times with those of isopropylidine derivatives of standard alkylglycerol species. Arachidonic Acid Release—For experiments using MDCK cells grown in 24-well multiwell plates, preconfluent monolayers were trypsinized, and 1 × 105 cells were seeded in each well (15-mm) and used 24 h later when cells were 70–80% confluent. Cell lipids were labeled by incubating the monolayers for 3 h in 210 μl of DMEM containing 0.25% BSA (DMEM-BSA) with 0.5 μCi/ml [3H]arachidonic acid. Cells incorporated 70–85% of the label using this procedure. Cells were treated with alkylglycerol by adding the 1-O-dodecyl-sn-glycerol in 90 μl of DMEM-BSA for the appropriate time prior to stimulation. The medium was then aspirated, and the monolayers were rinsed once with DMEM containing 0.1% BSA and incubated in the same medium for 5 min. TPA in dimethyl sulfoxide (final concentration of dimethyl sulfoxide, 0.1%) was then added at a final TPA concentration of 100 nM, and the cells were incubated for the appropriate time. All incubations were at 37 °C in a humidified atmosphere of 5% CO2. Following incubation, the medium was aspirated and counted in a liquid scintillation counter. Methanol was added to the wells, and the cells were scraped and transferred directly to vials for determination of radioactivity. Arachidonic acid release was determined as the total radioactivity accumulating in the medium as a percent of the total incubation radioactivity (cells plus medium). Measurement of PKC Activity—MDCK cells were homogenized in buffer A (2 mM EDTA, 0.5 mM EGTA, 50 mg/liter phenylmethylsulfonyl fluoride, 2 mM dithiothreitol, and 20 mM Tris-HCl, pH 7.5) containing 0.33 M sucrose and 25 μg/ml leupeptin. The cells were scraped and collected in buffer A and disrupted by sonication. The suspension was separated into a cytosolic and membrane fraction by ultracentrifugation (100,000 × g for 60 min). The pellet (particulate) fraction was suspended in buffer A containing 5 mg/ml Nonidet P-40. Both the supernatant (soluble) and the particulate fractions were applied to DEAE-Sepharose columns, washed with 3 column volumes of buffer A, and the activity was eluted from the columns by adding buffer A containing 150 mM NaCl. The eluant was stored at –80 °C. PKC activity in each fraction was measured by the transfer of phosphorus from [γ-32P]αTP to a synthetic peptide (Pro-Leu-Ser-Arg-Thr-Leu-Ser-Val-Ala-Ala-Lys-Lys). The incubation mixture (120 μl) contained 0.2 μg/μl peptide, 10 μμ [γ-32P]αTP (1,000 cpm/pmol), 10 mM magnesium acetate, 0.5 mM CaCl2, 20 mM Tris-HCl, pH 7.5, 8 μg/ml phosphatidylserine, and 0.8 μg/ml diolein. Liposomes of phosphatidylserine and diolein were prepared by sonication in 20 mM Tris. Incubations were at 30 °C for 5 min and were initiated with 30 μl of column eluate. Reactions were stopped by the addition of 1 m ATP, and the entire mixture was placed on ice. 100 μl of the reaction mixture was spotted onto phosphocellulose P-81 paper that was washed three times in 75 mM phosphoric acid. The amount of radioactivity remaining bound to the paper was determined by scintillation counting. Protein kinase activity was determined as the pmol of phosphorus transferred to peptide per min with the activity in the absence of protein subtracted from each determination. PKC activity was expressed as the difference in activity in the presence and absence of calcium, diacylglycerol, and phosphatidylserine. For studies on the effects of alkylglycerol on the activity of purified PKC, phosphatidylserine and diolein were suspended in detergent micelles by sonication in 0.03% Triton X-100. Micelles containing alkylglycerol were prepared by suspending varying amounts 1-O-dodecyl-racglycerol in a constant volume of 0.03% Triton X-100. The final concentration of Triton X-100 in the assay was 112 μg/ml. Incubations were initiated with the addition of 0.012 μg of purified rat brain PKC. All other conditions and concentrations were as described above. Analysis of the Content of Alkylglycerol and Related Lipids in MDCK Cells—Our previous analysis of the monoradylglycerols and diradylglycerols of MDCK cells revealed the presence of alkylglycerol (7Warne T.R. Robinson M. Anal. Biochem. 1991; 198: 302-307Crossref PubMed Scopus (9) Google Scholar). In light of the biological activity of synthetic alkylglycerol and its ability to inhibit PKC in vitro (8McNeely T.B. Rosen G. Londer M.V. Turco S.J. Biochem. J. 1991; 259: 601-604Crossref Scopus (116) Google Scholar) we performed a detailed characterization of its content, along with related lipids, in MDCK cells. Alkylglycerol was isolated from total lipid extracts of MDCK cells by solid phase extraction and quantified, along with monoacylglycerol, diacylglycerol, alkylacylglycerol, and cholesterol, by normal phase HPLC as the benzoate derivatives (7Warne T.R. Robinson M. Anal. Biochem. 1991; 198: 302-307Crossref PubMed Scopus (9) Google Scholar). We observed that the content of alkylglycerol was highly dependent on the growth status of the cells. Fig. 1 shows a comparison of HPLC profiles from preconfluent, proliferating and confluent, quiescent cultures of MDCK cells. The 1-O-alkyl-2,3-dibenzoylglycerol derivatives of the alkylglycerol species elute from the HPLC as a group of peaks between 8 and 10 min and are greatly elevated in confluent cells. In contrast, diacylglycerol species, whose derivatives elute between 12 and 17 min, are reduced in confluent MDCK cells. The lower level of diacylglycerol in contact-inhibited MDCK cells is consistent with our previous study in which the species of diacylglycerol were analyzed by reversed phase HPLC (21Warne T.R. Robinson M. Lipids. 1990; 25: 748-752Crossref PubMed Scopus (9) Google Scholar). The higher levels of alkylglycerol in confluent cultures did not reflect an overall accumulation of monoglycerides since the content of monoacylglycerol was consistently low in MDCK cells and was reduced in confluent as compared with preconfluent cells. Fig. 2 shows the results of an analysis of the monoglyceride content of MDCK cells throughout the cell growth curve. The alkylglycerol content remained low throughout the initial stages of growth and increased dramatically as the rate of proliferation declined following mid-log phase of growth. The increase in alkylglycerol proceeded until the cultures formed a tight epithelium that was resistant to trypsinization, at which time the level had increased nearly 20-fold over that of low density cultures. Confluent cultures of MDCK cells were viable for several days of culture and maintained a high content of alkylglycerol but became resistant to trypsinization and determination of cell density. Table I compares the content of the monoradylglycerols and diradylglycerols in preconfluent and confluent MDCK cultures. In contrast to alkylglycerol, the monoacylglycerol and diacylglycerol fractions are elevated in preconfluent cultures as compared with confluent cultures. The content of alkylglycerol in the total partial glycerides of MDCK cells increases from less than 1 mol % to greater than 15 mol % in confluent cultures. These results are based on quantitative analysis of the monoglycerides and diglycerides relative to the level of cholesterol, which was quantified along with the partial glycerides as the cholesterol-benzoate derivative. We also measured the content of the monoglycerides and diglycerides relative to the total cell number. Open table in a new tab Analysis of the Content of Alkylglycerol and Related Lipids in CFTL-12 Cells—We wished to determine if the density-dependent changes in alkylglycerol and related lipids observed in MDCK cells also occur in other cell types whose growth can be regulated by means other than through contact inhibition. We therefore compared the content of monoglycerides and diglycerides in proliferating CFTL-12 cells with those in cells that were growth-inhibited by withdrawal from IL-3. CFTL-12 mast cells are derived from fetal mouse liver and are dependent on the continuous presence of the growth factor IL-3 for proliferation (24Brown M.A. Pierce J.H. Watson C.J. Falco J. Ihle J.N. Paul W.E. Cell. 1987; 50: 809-818Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (278) Google Scholar). Culturing CFTL-12 cells in the absence of IL-3 for 48 h resulted in complete inhibition of proliferation without a loss of viability as measured by trypan blue dye exclusion. As shown in Table III, growth inhibition had effects similar to those observed for contact-inhibited MDCK cells. CFTL-12 cells made quiescent by withdrawal from IL-3 possessed 40% more alkylglycerol than proliferating cells. In contrast, the levels of monoacylglycerol and diacylglycerol were both reduced in IL3-depleted, quiescent cells. Thus cell growth inhibition, whether by growth factor withdrawal in CFTL-12 cells or contact inhibition in MDCK cells, was associated with increased levels of a putative PKC inhibitor alkylglycerol and reduced levels of the PKC activator diacylglycerol.Table IIIEffect of cell growth status on the content of partial glycerides in CFTL-12 cellsGrowth statusMonoalkylglycerolMonoacylglycerolAlkylacylglycerolDiacylglycerolnmol/μmol cholesterolProliferating18.6 ± 2.112.6 ± 2.631.2 ± 4.727.1 ± 3.4Quiescent24.7 ± 2.2*7.1 ± 1.2*25.5 ± 4.816.2 ± 1.2** Open table in a new tab Effect of Cell Growth Status on PKC Activity and TPA-stimulated Arachidonic Acid Release in MDCK Cells—Growth-dependent changes in the activity and subcellular distribution of PKC have been demonstrated in several cell types. In order to analyze the structural requirement(s) for proteolytic cleavage, synthetic oligopeptides corresponding to the carboxyl-terminal (COOH-terminal) sequence of the precursor to the D1 protein (pD1) of the photosystem II reaction center, with or without substituted side chain(s) around the cleavage site, were subjected to enzymatic analysis with partially purified processing protease from spinach. The efficiency of action as a competitive inhibitor of the enzymatic cleavage of the COOH-terminal extension, as well as the capacity to serve as a substrate, was used as an indication of effective binding to the protease. Neither a COOH-terminal fragment consisting of the 9 amino acids that are cleaved from pD1 by the protease nor a COOH-terminal fragment of the mature protein consisting of 15 amino acids inhibited the enzymatic processing of pD1. By contrast, a COOH-terminal fragment of pD1 consisting of 24 amino acids, which included the sequences of both the COOH-terminal extension and the COOH-terminal 15 amino acids of the mature protein, was effective both as a competitive inhibitor and as a substrate. This result suggests that the structure formed by linkage between these two parts of the protein moiety is important in the substrate-enzyme interaction. Among substitutions around the cleavage site, the replacement of Leu-343 by Ala (L343A) specifically destroyed the ability of the oligopeptide to serve as either a substrate or an inhibitor, suggesting that the presence of the hydrophobic Leu residue is crucial for the formation of the recognition site. A series of six substitutions at Ala-345 had marked effects on the value of Vmax, without affecting the binding affinity, as represented by Km; the order of substitutions at residue 345 in terms of their effects on Vmax was Ala, Ser, Phe, Cys > Gly > Val ≫ Pro. With a Pro residue at position 345, the oligopeptide was practically inactive as a substrate.
