Nature. 1983; 305: 827-829Crossref PubMed Scopus (306) Google Scholar). human hepatitis β virus duck hepatitis β virus reverse transcriptase phenylmethylsulfonyl fluoride kilobase pair(s). human hepatitis β virus duck hepatitis β virus reverse transcriptase phenylmethylsulfonyl fluoride kilobase pair(s). In contrast to the capsid structure of retroviruses (see Ref. 1Temin H.M. Baltimore D. Adv. Virus Res. 1972; 17: 129-186Crossref PubMed Scopus (251) Google Scholar for review), HBV particles are rather stable and nonionic detergent treatments do not make viral capsids disrupt (13Kaplan P. Greenman R. Gerin J. Purcell R. Robinson W. J. Virol. 1973; 12: 995-1005Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). It was previously found that low pH treatment could make the DHBV cores open to macromolecules without destroying DNA polymerase activity, which could not switch to any of several exogenously supplied templates (20Radziwill G. Zentgraf H. Schaller H. Bosch V. Virology. 1988; 163: 123-132Crossref PubMed Scopus (44) Google Scholar). These properties might result from an exceptionally tight association of the enzyme with its endogenous DNA. Until now, activity gel assay containing in situ denaturation/renaturation step has provided the only means by which hepadnavirus DNA polymerase proteins could be detected in association with enzymatic activities (21Bavand M. Laub O. J. Virol. 1988; 62: 626-628Crossref PubMed Google Scholar, 22Bavand M. Feitelson M. Laub O. J. Virol. 1989; 63: 1019-1021Crossref PubMed Google Scholar, 23Oberhaus S.M. Newbold J.E. J. Virol. 1993; 67: 6558-6566Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). Although a prerequisite for studying HBV DNA polymerase is the availability of a procedure to obtain the soluble protein without loss of its activity, no attempt to solubilize the enzyme had succeeded. Our endeavor to solubilize the enzyme activity from viral particles had previously failed when a liquid-phase denaturation/renaturation process was tested with guanidine hydrochloride or SDS (not shown). We have, however, recently discovered a process involving low pH treatment followed by incubation with a certain protease, which reproducibly achieved the desired effects. These results indicate that this enzyme can be truncated and thus function independently of other viral components. This is the report of the detection and solubilization of the DNA polymerase from natural HBV particles and makes possible new approaches to the study for hepadnaviral replication and its inhibition in vitro. Materials—HBV-infected sera taken from HBV-antigen carriers, in which human immunodeficiency virus and hepatitis C virus antigens were absent, were obtained from the Korean National Red Cross Blood Products Institute. HBV particles were purified from approximately 300 ml of each serum. Antiserum against virus particles, used in immunologic assay, was prepared by injecting the purified HBV particles into albino rabbits. Antiserum, used in Western blot analysis, against a fusion protein containing maltose-binding protein and RNase H domain of the HBV DNA polymerase gene product from Escherichia coli was a kind gift from Jung (24Lee H.J. Kwon Y.T. Rho H.M. Jung G. Biotechnol. Lett. 1993; 15: 821-826Google Scholar). All radioactive [α-32P]dNTPs were purchased from Amersham Inc. Homopolymers as template-primers were obtained from P-L Biochemicals Inc. and DEAE-Sepharose was from Pharmacia Biotech Inc. All other reagents were purchased from Sigma. Preparation of HBV Particles—All steps of the purification scheme were carried out on ice or at 4 °C. The fresh HBV-infected sera were centrifuged in HANIL A50H-6 rotor at 10,000 rpm for 20 min to remove aggregated materials. To remove most of serum proteins, virions in the supernatants were pelleted with 6% (w/v) polyethylene glycol 6000. Following immediate centrifugation in a HANIL A50H-6 rotor at 10,000 rpm for 30 min, the pellets were washed twice with TNE buffer (50 mm Tris-HCl (pH 7.4), 150 mm NaCl, 1 mm EDTA). To disrupt surface proteins, the pellets were suspended in the initial serum volumes of TNE buffer containing 1% Triton X-100. To concentrate cores, 27 ml of suspension solution containing virions was layered onto 6 ml of 20% sucrose in TNE buffer which had been layered on 5 ml of 60% sucrose in TNE buffer. Centrifugation in a SW 28 rotor (Beckman Co.) was performed for 16 h at 25,000 rpm at 4 °C. Fractions (0.5 ml each) were collected and the HBV-positive fractions, identified by endogenous DNA polymerase assay, were pooled and dialyzed against TNE buffer. Pooled samples were layered onto a 15–30% sucrose gradient and centrifuged in a SW 60 rotor for 6 h at 35,000 rpm. The 0.5-ml fractions were collected from the bottom of the tube and analyzed as described below. Fractions from the final sucrose gradient were also analyzed for the presence of core protein and other proteins by SDS-polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis and silver staining as described previously (23Oberhaus S.M. Newbold J.E. J. Virol. 1993; 67: 6558-6566Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). Core particles prepared in this manner (approximately 1011 virions/ml) were concentrated about 100-fold from sera of chronic HBV-antigen carriers and were stored at 4 °C. Endogenous DNA Polymerase Assay—The reaction (50 µl) was carried out in polymerase buffer (50 mm Tris-HCl (pH 7.4), 30 mm NH4C1, 20 mm MgCl2, 0.5% Nonidet P-40, 0.3% 2-mercaptoethanol) containing 10 µm each of dGTP, dCTP, and dATP. Five μl of the particle sample and 1 μCi of [α-32P]dTTP (3000 Ci/mmol) were added subsequently and incubated for 120 min at 37 °C. The reaction mixture was then treated for 1 h at 37 °C with 0.2 mg/ml of proteinase K in the presence of 1% SDS followed by extraction with saturated phenol twice. Radioactivities of the reaction products were measured on DEAE-cellulose (DE-81) paper disks (Whatman Co.) as described previously (25Grandgenett D.P. Rho H.M. J. Virol. 1975; 15: 526-533Crossref PubMed Google Scholar) or analyzed by electrophoresis on 0.8% agarose gels after Sephadex G-50 chromatography. In Situ Activity Gel Assay and Reverse Transcriptase Assay in Liquid Phase—In situ activity gel assay was performed as described previously (22Bavand M. Feitelson M. Laub O. J. Virol. 1989; 63: 1019-1021Crossref PubMed Google Scholar), with a minor modification. Polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis was carried out in the presence of 0.02% SDS with either 120 μg/ml of activated salmon sperm DNA for the detection of DNA-directed DNA synthesis or 130 μg/ml poly(rC)·oligo(dG)12–18 at a molar ratio of 1:10 for the detection of RNA-directed DNA synthesis. Viral preparations, purified to near homogeneity, were mixed with equal volume of 2 × sample buffer (100 mm Tris-HCl (pH 6.8), 10% glycerol, 1.34% SDS, 0.1% 2-mercaptoethanol, 0.66 mm EDTA, 0.002% bromphenol blue, and 2 mm PMSF), and boiled for 2 min before loading. Electrophoresis was carried out for 12~20 h at 15~20 mA at 4 °C. To recover enzymatic activity of the proteins, in situ renaturation was achieved by removing the SDS from the gel after extensive washes with ice-cold renaturation buffer (50 mm Tris-HCl (pH 7.8)). Gels were placed in a sealed bag with a reaction mixture containing 70 mm KCl, 10 mm Tris-HCl (pH 8.0), 10 mm MgCl2, 0.1% 2-mercaptoethanol, 20 μμ aphidicolin, and 1 μCi/ml of [α-32P]dGTP (3000 Ci/mmol) for RT activity gels; or 10 μμ each of dGTP, dCTP, dTTP, and 1 μCi/ml of [α-32P]dATP for DNA-directed DNA polymerase activity gels. The bags were submerged and incubated in water bath with gentle shaking for 20 h at 37 °C. To stop the reaction and remove unincorporated dNTPs, gels were washed extensively with ice-cold 5% trichloroacetic acid containing 1% pyrophosphate. The gels were dried and analyzed by autoradiography. Liquid-phase reverse transcriptase assay, using homopolymers as templates, was carried out as described previously (26Rho H.M. Gallo R.C. Cancer Lett. 1980; 10: 207-221Crossref PubMed Scopus (8) Google Scholar). Solubilization of HBV DNA Polymerase from Viral Particles—Permeabilization of viral particles was performed as described previously (20Radziwill G. Zentgraf H. Schaller H. Bosch V. Virology. 1988; 163: 123-132Crossref PubMed Scopus (44) Google Scholar), with a minor modification. An equal volume of 0.1 m glycine HCl (pH 2.5) was added to the HBV particle preparations which resulted in a pH approximately 3.0 in the solution, incubated at 30 °C for 30 s, and neutralized by addition of an appropriate volume of 1 m Tris-HCl (pH 8.3). At once, permeability of viral particles was tested as described in legend of Fig. 2A (compare lanes 4 and 5). Further solubilization of HBV DNA polymerase from cores was performed by subtilisin-limited proteolysis. Low pH-treated sample (permeable particle) was incubated at 37 °C for 20–60 min in TNE buffer containing 0.5% Nonidet P-40 (omitted as activity gel assay), 0.1% 2-mercaptoethanol, 1.7 μg/ml subtilisin. The reaction was stopped by adding PMSF to a final concentration of 1 mm. All the reaction mixtures were assayed for reverse transcriptase and endogenous DNA polymerase reactions. DEAE-Sepharose Chromatography—The HBV particles treated as above were diluted and loaded on a 0.5 × 2-cm column of DEAE-Sepharose equilibrated with starting buffer (10 mm Tris-HCl (pH 8.0), 10% glycerol, 0.1% 2-mercaptoethanol, 0.01% Nonidet P-40, and 10 mm NaCl). The column was then washed with 10 ml of starting buffer, and the enzyme activity was eluted by raising the sodium chloride concentrations up to 500 mm in the buffer. Fractions (150 μl each) were collected, and 10-μl aliquots of each were assayed for the ability to incorporate [α-32P]dNTP into several substrates with incubating for 2 h at 37 °C. Identification of DNA Polymerase Activity in HBV Particles—In HBV particles, prepared as described under “Experimental Procedures,” the presence of HBV DNA polymerase activity was identified by using the endogenous DNA polymerase reaction, in situ activity gel analysis and Western blotting (Fig. 1). No contaminated DNA polymerase activity was detected in fractions prepared as above, and only in the HBV-positive fractions, two bands were detected in the DNA-dependent DNA polymerase activity gel assay: a very strong band at ~100 kDa and a very faint band at ~70 kDa (the molecular mass of these bands was calculated by extrapolating Klenow fragment and commercial SDS-polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis protein markers) (lane 2). This very faint band at ~70 kDa was not visible without long exposure (data not shown). Also, the two bands detected by RT activity gel assay appear to have the same apparent molecular masses as the two DNA-dependent DNA polymerase active bands (lane 5). These suggest that these two proteins exhibit both DNA- and RNA-dependent DNA polymerase activities, and the majority of DNA polymerase in natural the HBV particle was the ~100 kDa. In addition, none of the HBV particle samples showed DNA polymerase activity without substrate (not shown), and endogenous DNA polymerase reaction product was shown at the top of the separating gel (lane 8). Therefore, viral nucleic acids were unlikely to be used as substrates in the activity gel assay. Effect of Low pH Treatment and Subtilisin Preincubation on HBV DNA Polymerase Activity and Detection of the Solubilized Enzyme—After low pH treatment, in contrast to Nonidet P-40 treatment, the endogenous DNA polymerase activity disappeared in the presence of exogenous DNase I or subtilisin (Fig. 2A), suggesting that viral capsids were open or disrupt and thus allowed DNase I and subtilisin to attack viral DNA and polymerase protein. Also, in situ activity gel analysis showed that ~100-kDa major active band gradually migrated into ~70 kDa by increasing the preincubation time with subtilisin (Fig. 2B). The alteration in the relative activities of ~100 and ~70 kDa suggests that smaller protein is the cleavage product of the ~100-kDa protein and perhaps has polymerase domain and RNase H domain (lane W). To determine whether the DNA polymerase in HBV particles can switch to an exogenous template, several exogenous substrates were tested for their ability to serve as template. Poly(rA)·oligo(dT) and poly(rC)·oligo(dG) were employed as reverse transcriptase substrates and poly(dA)·oligo(dT) as DNA-dependent DNA polymerase substrate (Fig. 3A). Due to absence of three dNTPs under the assay conditions employed, HBV-DNA polymerase was inactive on endogenous DNA template, and no incorporation of isotope into exogenous template occurred in reaction mixture with unmodified HBV particles (data not shown). However, after low pH treatment, as viral particles were preincubated with an appropriate amount of subtilisin, radioactive incorporation into exogenous templates was observed. These indicated that the HBV-DNA polymerase was dissociated from viral particles as a result of subtilisin incubation, and the released form had RT and DNA-dependent DNA polymerase activities. Alternatively, a defined template for DNA polymerase activity (12.5-kb αvaI-digested plasmid), and four dNTPs (dATP, dGTP, dTTP, and [α-32P]dCTP) were added to the reaction mixture and then the radioactive reaction products were separated by electrophoresis on a agarose gel. The HBV-DNA polymerase was active on endogenous DNA template yielding 3.2 kb of radioactive HBV DNA (lower DNA bands on the gel), and incorporation of radioactivity into 12.5 kb exogenous DNA with 5′ protruding ends appeared after 20-min preincubation with subtilisin (upper DNA bands on the gel). Without low pH treatment or subtilisin preincubation, no incorporation of radioactivity into exogenous template was observed, regardless of exposure time (lanes C). These results indicate that HBV-DNA polymerase is probably released from the viral particles, since the 12.5-kb exogenous DNA template is too large to enter the viral particle. DEAE-Sepharose Chromatography of Released HBV-DNA Polymerase from Viral Particles—To confirm that HBV DNA polymerase is released from virus particle, the subtilisin-treated particle solution was carefully diluted and applied to a DEAE-Sepharose column (Fig. 4A). Both DNA-dependent DNA polymerase and RNA-dependent DNA polymerase activities appeared together at 100 mm NaCl and preference of the released enzyme for several templates were similar to that of other retroviral reverse transcriptases (3Will H. Salfeld J. Pfaff E. Manso C. Theilmann L. Schaller H. Science. 1986; 231: 594-596Crossref PubMed Scopus (36) Google Scholar, 27Rho H.M. Gallo R.C. Virology. 1979; 99: 192-196Crossref PubMed Scopus (5) Google Scholar). In addition, RT activity detected in these fractions was inactivated by antiserum against virus particles in immunologic assay (Fig. 4C). When unmodified HBV particle sample solution was also applied to a DEAE-Sepharose column, endogenous DNA polymerase activity was recovered in buffer wash fractions, and DNA polymerase activity on exogenous template was not detected in any fraction (data not shown). In activity gel analysis of the fractions, as shown in Fig. 4B, only ~70 kDa of DNA polymerase activity was observed, and ~100 kDa was not detected in any fraction. These results provide that ~70-kDa protein, a proteolytic product, is probably the solubilized DNA polymerase from the HBV particles and is active on the exogenous templates in liquid-phase. Our endeavor to solubilize the enzyme activity from the viral particles had failed when liquid-phase denaturation/renaturation process was tested with guanidine hydrochloride or SDS. We have, however, discovered a process involving low pH treatment followed by incubation with subtilisin. The data presented here provide several important pieces of information about the DNA polymerase in natural HBV particles. A useful method for purifying large quantities of viral cores without aggregation is devised as shown under “Experimental Procedures.” Previously, Kim et al. (28Kim S.H. Hong S.P. Kim S.K. Lee W.S. Rho H.M. J. Gen. Virol. 1992; 73: 2421-2424Crossref PubMed Scopus (24) Google Scholar) have constructed HepG2-K8 cell producing HBV-like particles in our laboratory. Although the concentration of HBV particles in supernatants from transfected cell cultures is much lower than in sera of virus-infected individuals (29Heermann K.-H. Gerlich W.H. McLachlan A. Molecular Biology of the Hepatitis B Virus. CRC Press, Boca Raton, FL1991: 109-144Google Scholar, 30Kim S.K. Jang S.K. Rho H.M. J. Gen. Virol. 1994; 75: 917-923Crossref PubMed Scopus (11) Google Scholar), the above-mentioned method with minor modification resulting in 2000-fold concentration of virus-like particles has made it possible to detect DNA polymerase. 2H. J. Shin and H. M. Rho, unpublished observations. We have detected major ~ 100-kDa and minor ~70-kDa DNA polymerase activities in activity gel analysis and provided evidence that the ~70-kDa protein is the proteolytic cleavage product of the ~100-kDa DNA polymerase. Although the HBV DNA polymerase gene, if expressed as a single, full-length, unmodified protein, would have a predicted mass of 94 kDa (31Chang L. Pryciak P. Ganem D. Varmus H. Nature. 1989; 337: 364-368Crossref PubMed Scopus (88) Google Scholar, 32Ou J.-H. Bao H. Shih C. Tahara S.M. J. Virol. 1990; 64: 4578-4581Crossref PubMed Google Scholar, 33Rho H.M. Kim K. Hyun S.W. Kim Y.S. Nucleic Acids Res. 1989; 172124Crossref PubMed Scopus (49) Google Scholar, 34Schlicht H.-J. Radziwill G. Schaller H. Cell. 1989; 56: 85-92Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (88) Google Scholar), there have been several reports in which less than full-length P gene product has been detected (22Bavand M. Feitelson M. Laub O. J. Virol. 1989; 63: 1019-1021Crossref PubMed Google Scholar, 23Oberhaus S.M. Newbold J.E. J. Virol. 1993; 67: 6558-6566Crossref PubMed Google Scholar, 35Mack D.H. Bloch W. Nath N. Sninsky J. J. Virol. 1988; 62: 4786-4790Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). We observed that the ratio of the two bands changed at every preparation procedure and that ~70-kDa active band is often negligible. It indicates that these smaller proteins probably are by-products of particle preparation due to instability of putative P gene product or a certain contaminated protease. This study also shows that preincubating the low pH-treated HBV particles with subtilisin solubilize the DNA polymerase activity which can then switch to exogenous templates in liquid phase (Fig. 3). Radziwill et al. (20Radziwill G. Zentgraf H. Schaller H. Bosch V. Virology. 1988; 163: 123-132Crossref PubMed Scopus (44) Google Scholar) demonstrated that core particles are impermeant to exogenous template/primer, and even when they are treated to be permeable to such templates the DNA polymerase will not engage them. We have found that subtilisin-treated HBV particles were active not only on homopolymer templates but also on a large template which cannot enter the low pH-treated particles. The released form appears to be the 70-kDa band on activity gel, and the subtilisin-treated enzyme activity could be eluted by DEAE-Sepharose column. The eluted fractions still retained its polymerase activity, suggesting the possibility of partial purification of this enzyme. In addition, preference of the truncated enzyme for homopolymer templates is similar to that of other retroviral RT. This is supported by homologies between the amino acid sequence of the protein coded by the DNA polymerase gene and RTs of all retroviruses sequenced to date (19Toh H. Hayashida H. Miyata T. Nature. 1983; 305: 827-829Crossref PubMed Scopus (306) Google Scholar, 33Rho H.M. Kim K. Hyun S.W. Kim Y.S. Nucleic Acids Res. 1989; 172124Crossref PubMed Scopus (49) Google Scholar). In this study we introduce an effective method to release the DNA polymerase activity from the HBV particles. Although the nature of the tight association of the enzyme with the core particles is not clearly understood yet, low pH treatment followed by this proteolytic cleavage appears to be more powerful in permeabilizing core particles without destroying the enzymatic activity than low pH treatment alone. Despite the difficulties in studying the hepadnavirus P proteins, we have shown that it is possible to detect and to characterize viral enzyme activities as a soluble form. We thank Dr. Guhung Jung (Department of Biology Education, Seoul National University) for the kind gift of the antiserum against a fusion protein including RNase H domain of the HBV P open reading frame product. We also thank Soo Hee Yoon for critical reading of the manuscript.

Studies with inside-out plasma membrane vesicles from multidrug-resistant (MDR 3) murine erythroleukemia (MEL/VCR-6) cells have provided evidence for down-modulation of P-glycoprotein (P-gp) function by Ca2+-calmodulin (CLM). These studies showed that CLM in the presence or absence of Ca2+ had no effect on binding of [3H]vinblastine (VBL) by P-gp in inside-out plasma membrane vesicles. However, profound inhibition of ATP-dependent [3H]VBL efflux by these vesicles was demonstrated by the addition of subnanomolar concentrations of CLM (IC50 = 0.15 ± 0.02 nm). The addition of 1 mm Ca2+ reduced the inhibition of [3H]VBL efflux by CLM, shifting the concentration required for inhibition to the nM range (IC50 = 2.55 ± 0.35 nm). The inhibition of [3H]VBL efflux by 0.6 nM CLM was reduced with as little as 0.01 mm Ca2+, and no inhibition occurred with concentrations greater than 0.2 mm Ca2+. Binding of CLM, itself, to P-gp was demonstrated in two ways. The P-gp content of detergent-solubilized plasma membrane from MEL/VCR-6 cells could be appreciably depleted by treating this material with CLM-Sepharose beads as shown by SDS-polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis (PAGE) and Western blotting with anti-P-gp antibody (C219) before and after CLM-Sepharose treatment. Also, depletion of P-gp from solution by CLM was less in the presence of 1 mm Ca2+. Blotting of P-gp after SDS-PAGE of plasma membrane from MEL/VCR-6 cells was also obtained using 125I-CLM as a probe. These results strongly suggest that the MDR 3 homolog of P-gp is a CLM-binding protein and that direct interaction of Ca2+-CLM with P-gp, while not affecting its binding of [3H]VBL, down-modulates the translocation of this agent in the presence of ATP. Chem. 1994; 269: 12277-12284Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar) following stable transfection with murine mdr 3 cDNA. These studies have documented temperature-dependent, osmotically sensitive intravesicular internalization of one or more multidrug resistance-related cytotoxic agents that was dependent upon the hydrolysis of ATP. Our own studies with inside-out plasma membrane vesicles from multidrug-resistant, murine erythroleukemia (MEL) cells overexpressing MDR 3 documented (18Schlemmer S.R. Sirotnak F.M. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 31059-31066Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar) additional properties and the kinetics of the interaction of vinblastine with P-gp and provided direct evidence for active P-gp-mediated transport. To further our understanding of P-gp function, we have examined the interaction between P-gp and various cytosolic regulatory proteins using our inside-out vesicle system (18Schlemmer S.R. Sirotnak F.M. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 31059-31066Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). One such interaction involves the Ca2+-binding protein, calmodulin (CLM), which among its many actions (19Cheung W.Y. Science. 1979; 207: 19-27Crossref Scopus (1849) Google Scholar, 20Klee C.B. Crouch T.H. Richman P.G. Annu. Rev. Biochem. 1988; 49: 489-515Crossref Scopus (824) Google Scholar, 21James P. Varherr T. Carafoli E. Trends Biochem. Sci. 1995; 20: 38-42Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (347) Google Scholar, 22Jayanthi L.D. Ramamoorthy S. Mahesh V.B. Leibach F.H. Ganapathy V. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 14424-14429Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 23Liu M. Chen T-Y. Ahamed B. Li J. Yau K-W. Science. 1994; 266: 1348-1354Crossref PubMed Scopus (240) Google Scholar) is known to modulate a number of Ca2+-dependent signal pathways and transport processes in the plasma membrane of mammalian cells. Our results appear to show that this protein markedly down-modulates P-gp function, both in the presence and absence of Ca2+. We also present other evidence to suggest that these effects probably reflect a direct interaction of CLM with P-gp itself. Sources of Cells and Growth and Isolation Procedures—Multidrug-resistant murine MEL/VCR-6 cells were derived (18Schlemmer S.R. Sirotnak F.M. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 31059-31066Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar) in cell culture during growth in the presence of VCR. This cell line had defective inward transport of [3H]VBL and overexpressed MDR 3 P-gp to the extent of 80-fold. For preparation of inside-out plasma membrane vesicles, parental and MEL/VCR-6 cells were obtained as ascites suspensions (18Schlemmer S.R. Sirotnak F.M. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 31059-31066Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar) from BD2F1 mice following growth during VCR treatment (MEL/VCR-6 cells only). Plasma Membrane Vesicle Preparation—Inside-out plasma membrane vesicles were prepared from MEL/VCR-6 cells by a previously described (18Schlemmer S.R. Sirotnak F.M. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 31059-31066Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar) procedure. Approximately 1 mg of vesicles was obtained from 2–2.5 × 109 cells. The inside-out orientation of the vesicles with respect to sidedness was 72% as determined by ecto-enzyme and endoenzyme assays (18Schlemmer S.R. Sirotnak F.M. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 31059-31066Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 24Schlemmer S.R. Sirotnak F.M. J. Biol. Chem. 1992; 267: 14746-14752Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar) in the presence and absence of 0.2% Triton X-100. The purity of the vesicle preparations was determined to be 88–95% from an assessment (18Schlemmer S.R. Sirotnak F.M. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 31059-31066Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 24Schlemmer S.R. Sirotnak F.M. J. Biol. Chem. 1992; 267: 14746-14752Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar) of various organelle-specific enzyme markers and a protein determination (25Peterson G.L. Methods Enzymol. 1983; 91: 95-119Crossref PubMed Scopus (1142) Google Scholar). Intravesicular volume of the vesicles was 2.7 ± 4 μl/mg of protein as determined by standard procedures (26Hissen P.J. Hilf R. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 1978; 508: 401-412Crossref PubMed Scopus (26) Google Scholar). Transport Measurements—The procedure employed for measuring ATP-dependent internalization of [3H]VBL by inside-out plasma membrane vesicles with appropriate controls was the same as that used in our prior (18Schlemmer S.R. Sirotnak F.M. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 31059-31066Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar) studies. Twenty-μl aliquots of vesicles (50–70 µg of membrane protein) were incubated with or without [3H]VBL and 5 mm ATP at 37 °C with 30 μl of transport buffer (100 mm MOPS, 100 mm sucrose plus 5 mm MgCl2, pH 7) with or without a regenerating (13Horio M. Gottesman M.M. Pastan I.H. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1988; 85: 3580-3584Crossref PubMed Scopus (479) Google Scholar) system in siliconized glass tubes. After termination, processing was as described (18Schlemmer S.R. Sirotnak F.M. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 31059-31066Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Blotting Procedures—Plasma membrane proteins were electrophoresed (27Laemmli V.K. Nature. 1970; 227: 680-685Crossref PubMed Scopus (206965) Google Scholar) on a 7.5% polyacrylamide gel and transblotted to a polyvinylidene difluoride membrane (Millipore) using a Bio-Rad Trans Blot Cell (28Towbin B. Staehelin T. Gordon J. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1979; 70: 4350-4354Crossref Scopus (44885) Google Scholar). Western blotting was performed using C-219 monoclonal antibody (Centocor) as described earlier (18Schlemmer S.R. Sirotnak F.M. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 31059-31066Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Following SDS-PAGE (see above) and transblotting, the membrane was also probed with 125I-CLM (bovine CLM) as described previously (23Liu M. Chen T-Y. Ahamed B. Li J. Yau K-W. Science. 1994; 266: 1348-1354Crossref PubMed Scopus (240) Google Scholar) for autoradiography. Chemicals—[3H]VBL was obtained (specific activity, 10–15 Ci/mmol) from Amersham Corp. Calmodulin was obtained from Pharmacia Biotech Inc., and [125I]calmodulin was obtained from NEM Corp. [3H]VBL was repurified (29Kuntebommanahalli N.T. Sehti V.S. Cancer Res. 1985; 45: 5382-5385PubMed Google Scholar) to >98% by high performance liquid chromatography every 3–4 weeks. All other chemicals were reagent grade. Our earlier studies (18Schlemmer S.R. Sirotnak F.M. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 31059-31066Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar) documented a complex time course for ATP-dependent accumulation of [3H]VBL by inside-out plasma membrane vesicles from MEL/VCR-6 cells overexpressing MDR 3 P-gp consisting of both osmotically sensitive and insensitive components. The data were interpreted (18Schlemmer S.R. Sirotnak F.M. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 31059-31066Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar) as rapid binding of [3H]VBL to P-gp and its subsequent transport (efflux) in the presence of ATP as distinctly separate events with the latter representing the rate-limiting step. Both binding and transport exhibited the same temperature dependence and saturability. Although the same rate of binding of [3H]VBL to P-gp occurred in the presence or absence of ATP, internalization of this vinca alkaloid in the form of osmotically sensitive accumulation was strictly dependent upon the hydrolysis of ATP. These properties are depicted by the time courses in Fig. 1A showing that the internalization of [3H]VBL by inside-out vesicles from MEL/VCR-6 cells occurred only in the presence of ATP. Rapid, initial binding of [3H]VBL by P-gp in these vesicles is only illustrated (broken line) in the figure for purposes of comparison. Other data in the figure (Fig. 1A) show that there was no rapid, initial accumulation and little internalization of [3H]VBL in inside-out vesicles prepared from parental MEL cells either in the presence or absence of ATP. In the same experimental system, we examined the effect of CLM on [3H]VBL efflux by inside-out plasma membrane vesicles from MEL/VCR-6 cells. These results are given in Fig. 1B and show profound inhibition of ATP-dependent efflux of [3H]VBL by CLM in the subnanomolar concentration range. Also, the data clearly suggest that the effect of CLM is on mediated transport of [3H]VBL rather than on its binding to P-gp, since unlike the effect of VRP and VBL (also shown in Fig. 1B) there is no characteristic (18Schlemmer S.R. Sirotnak F.M. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 31059-31066Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar) downward dislocation to the origin of the time course plot for efflux in the presence of CLM. The concentration response for CLM inhibition of ATP-dependent efflux of [3H]VBL in these vesicles is shown in Fig. 2. Inhibition is apparent (Fig. 2A) with as little as 0.1 nm CLM, and complete inhibition is seen at a concentration of CLM above 0.6 nM. The addition of 1 mm Ca2+ in the form of CaCl2 along with CLM reduced rather than enhanced the inhibition by CLM on ATP-dependent [3H]VBL efflux and shifted (Fig. 2B) the concentration-response curve for this inhibition to the nM range. In this case, the IC50 value for inhibition by CLM was shifted from 0.15 ± 0.02 nm (no Ca2+) to 2.55 ± 0.35 nM with 1 mm Ca2+. The concentration response for the effect of Ca2+ on the inhibition of [3H]VBL transport by CLM (0.6 nm) is given in Fig. 3. Reduction of inhibition was seen with as little as 0.01 mm Ca2+ (CaCl2) and approached maximum at concentrations above 0.2 mm Ca2+. In light of the above results, we sought to demonstrate a direct interaction of CLM with P-gp, which could account for the down-modulation of this ATPase. In the first experiment, it was shown that treatment of detergent-solubilized plasma membrane protein from MEL/VCR-6 cells with CLM-Sepharose beads removed P-gp from the solution. The solubilized protein was treated with either Sepharose 4B beads or CLM-Sepharose beads in the presence and absence of 1 mm Ca2+ and centrifuged to remove the beads. The data from a Western blot with C219 antibody show (Fig. 4) that treatment of the solubilized protein with Sepharose 4B had no effect on the appearance of the same 140-kDa protein blot found with the control (untreated) material. However, treatment with CLM-Sepharose in the absence of Ca2+ removed almost all of this protein, while treatment in the presence of 1 mm Ca2+ (CaCl2) removed somewhat less. These results are consistent with data from other experiments (Fig. 2) described above, which showed considerably less inhibition of [3H]VBL transport in the presence of Ca2+ and suggest that binding of CLM by P-gp in the presence of Ca2+ is markedly reduced. Second, 125I-CLM was used to probe a transblot of varying amounts of plasma membrane protein from MEL/VCR-6 cells following SDS-PAGE. This blot delineated (Fig. 5) a 140-kDa protein as did a blot of the same protein following SDS-PAGE carried out with C219 anti-P-gp antibody as a control. Also, only a faint protein band was delineated in this 140-kDa region with C219 antibody or with 125I-CLM, except with larger amounts of sample, when a transblot of plasma membrane protein from parental MEL cells (data not shown) was carried out after SDS-PAGE.FIG. 3Concentration dependence for the reversal by Ca2+ of CLM inhibition of ATP-dependent P-gp-mediated efflux of [3H]VBL by vesicles from MEL/VCR-6 cells. The data shown are for one of several typical blots.View Large Image Figure ViewerDownload Hi-res image Download (PPT) The results of all these experiments suggest that Ca2+-CLM binds to P-gp and the function of this plasma membrane protein in the form of [3H]VBL efflux is modulated by Ca2+-CLM. The data also suggest that this modulation is unrelated to any direct effect of bound Ca2+-CLM on the binding of [3H]VBL to P-gp. The data generated here with this inside-out vesicle system identify a property of P-gp hitherto unrevealed. Since the cytosol of tumor cells contains (30Tupper J.T. Zorgniotti F. J. Biol. Chem. 1977; 75: 12-22Google Scholar, 31Tsuruo T. Iida H. Kawabata H. Tsukagoshi S. Sakurai Y. Cancer Res. 1984; 44: 5095-5099PubMed Google Scholar) appreciable (0.1–1 mm) amounts of Ca2+, the effect of CLM demonstrated during these studies that would seem most relevant to its effect in situ is that measured in the presence of this divalent cation. As little as 0.01 mm Ca2+ added to this vesicle system significantly reduced the inhibition of [3H]VBL efflux by CLM. Overall, these results suggest that transport mediated by P-gp could be perturbed by a variation in the cytosolic concentration of either or both CLM and Ca2+. The increase in CLM or decrease in Ca2+ would down-modulate this function while a decrease in CLM or increase in Ca2+ would up-modulate. Both positive and negative regulatory effects of Ca2+ -CLM have been identified (19Cheung W.Y. Science. 1979; 207: 19-27Crossref Scopus (1849) Google Scholar, 20Klee C.B. Crouch T.H. Richman P.G. Annu. Rev. Biochem. 1988; 49: 489-515Crossref Scopus (824) Google Scholar, 21James P. Varherr T. Carafoli E. Trends Biochem. Sci. 1995; 20: 38-42Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (347) Google Scholar, 22Jayanthi L.D. Ramamoorthy S. Mahesh V.B. Leibach F.H. Ganapathy V. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 14424-14429Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 23Liu M. Chen T-Y. Ahamed B. Li J. Yau K-W. Science. 1994; 266: 1348-1354Crossref PubMed Scopus (240) Google Scholar) for a variety of transport processes in the plasma membrane of mammalian cells. The results presented here suggest that Ca2+-CLM acts as a negative regulator of P-gp function in that the rate of transport of [3H]VBL by P-gp in the presence of CLM or Ca2+-CLM never exceeds that of P-gp alone, at least in this vesicle system. Our results take on additional meaning in light of an earlier report (31Tsuruo T. Iida H. Kawabata H. Tsukagoshi S. Sakurai Y. Cancer Res. 1984; 44: 5095-5099PubMed Google Scholar) documenting upward perturbation in Ca2+ levels in P-gp overexpressing MDR cells. Such perturbations in these cells could further enhance P-gp function through the interaction of Ca2+ with CLM as shown here. These results have other implications. For instance, the effect of many Ca2+ antagonists on MDR shown (3Beck W.T. Biochem. Pharmacol. 1987; 26: 2879-2887Crossref Scopus (345) Google Scholar, 4Gottesman M.M. Pastan I. Annu. Rev. Biochem. 1993; 62: 385-427Crossref PubMed Scopus (3556) Google Scholar, 5Gros P. Ben-Neriah Y. Croop J.M. Housman D.E. Nature. 1986; 323: 728-731Crossref PubMed Scopus (698) Google Scholar, 6Roninson I.B. Chin J.E. Choi K. Gros P. Housman D.E. Fojo A. Shen D-W. Gotesman M.M. Pastan I. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1986; 83: 4538-4542Crossref PubMed Scopus (586) Google Scholar, 32Ford J.M. Hait W.N. Pharmacol. Rev. 1990; 42: 155-199PubMed Google Scholar) to interact directly with P-gp might in part reflect their interaction with CLM. On the other hand, the reversal by many Ca2+ antagonists of MDR has not been shown (32Ford J.M. Hait W.N. Pharmacol. Rev. 1990; 42: 155-199PubMed Google Scholar) to relate directly to their interaction with P-gp. Therefore, the effect of some of these may be accounted for by their interaction with CLM. Further work will be required to clarify these issues and to elucidate specific details of the interaction of Ca2+-CLM with P-gp.

The early region 1A 52R polypeptide, a protein expressed exclusively by the in vivo oncogenic adenovirus subtype 12, represses the trans-activating function of the cellular transcription factor complex AP-1 consisting of c-Jun-c-Jun homodimers. In this report we demonstrate that the repression in vivo correlates with a direct physical interaction of the adenovirus protein with c-Jun in vitro. Interestingly, the 52R protein binds to the bZIP domain of c-Jun essential for dimerization and DNA binding but not to the c-Jun activation domain. This interaction does not prevent the promoter binding of c-Jun/AP-1. Moreover, the physical association between c-Jun and the TATA box-binding protein TBP is not disturbed by the 52R polypeptide. In fact, we show evidence that down-regulation of c-Jun activity by the adenoviral protein is due to the inhibition of phosphorylation of the c-Jun trans-activation domain. In vivo phosphorylation of the c-Jun activation domain is necessary for the interaction of c-Jun with specific cofactors such as CBP and therefore a prerequisite for the activation of target genes. Due to these results we propose a model in which the 52R protein represses the trans-activating function of c-Jun by preventing its phosphorylation through a specific kinase necessary for the activation of the cellular transcription factor. Region E1A of the in vivo oncogenic serotype Ad12 has a very complex expression pattern. Alternative splicing of a common precursor results in the generation of six mRNAs (13, 12, 11, 10, 9.5, and 9 S) which give rise to five different proteins (266R, 235R, 106R, 52R, and 53R) (Perricaudet et al., 1980Perricaudet M. Le Moullec J.-M. Tiollais P. Pettersson U. Nature. 1980; 288: 174-176Crossref PubMed Scopus (35) Google Scholar; Sawada and Fujinaga, 1980Sawada Y. Fujinaga K. J. Virol. 1980; 36: 639-651Crossref PubMed Google Scholar; Brockmann et al., 1990Brockmann D. Tries B. Esche H. Virology. 1990; 179: 585-590Crossref PubMed Scopus (12) Google Scholar). All proteins have identical amino-terminal ends but differ in their carboxyl termini due to the excision of different introns and/or frameshifts with the beginning of the respective second exon. Therefore, neither the 106R protein of the 11/10 S mRNAs nor the 52R protein of the 9.5 S mRNA, which are both unique for the highly oncogenic Ad12 (Brockmann et al., 1994Brockmann D. Feng L. Kröner G. Tries B. Esche H. Virology. 1994; 198: 717-723Crossref PubMed Scopus (10) Google Scholar), contain any of the conserved regions (CR1, CR2, CR3) which are thought, in combination with the very amino terminus, to be essential for the trans-regulatory functions of the two larger E1A proteins (Lillie et al., 1986Lillie J.W. Lowenstein P.M. Green M.R. Green M. Cell. 1986; 50: 1091-1100Abstract Full Text PDF Scopus (151) Google Scholar; Schneider et al., 1987Schneider J.F. Fisher F. Goding C.R. Jones N.C. EMBO J. 1987; 6: 2053-2060Crossref PubMed Scopus (100) Google Scholar; Jelsma et al., 1989Jelsma T.N. Howe J.S. Mymryk J.S. Evelegh C.M. Cunnif N.F.A. Bayley S.T. Virology. 1989; 170: 120-130Crossref Scopus (93) Google Scholar; Rochette-Egly et al., 1990Rochette-Egly C. Fromental C. Chambon P. Genes & Dev. 1990; 4: 137-150Crossref PubMed Scopus (48) Google Scholar; Stein et al., 1990Stein R.W. Corrigan M. Yaciuk P. Whelan J. Moran E. J. Virol. 1990; 64: 4421-4427Crossref PubMed Google Scholar; Wang et al., 1993Wang H.-G.H. Rikitake Y. Carter M.C. Yaciuk P. Abraham S.E. Zerler B. Moran E. J. Virol. 1993; 67: 476-488Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). Although the physiological roles of the 52R protein are still unclear, the study of its function(s) is of particular interest as Ad12 E1A virus mutants unable to express the 52R protein lose their transforming capacity. For example, the Ad12 host range mutant CS-1, which is adapted to efficient replication in Ad12 semipermissive simian Vero cells, is unable to transform primary rat embryo fibroblasts and to generate tumors in newborn hamsters. Due to the loss of the splice acceptor site, a functional 52R protein cannot be expressed from Ad12 CS-1 (Murphy et al., 1987Murphy M. Opalka B. Sajaczkowski R. Schulte Holthausen H. Virology. 1987; 159: 49-56Crossref PubMed Scopus (16) Google Scholar; Opalka et al., 1992Opalka B. Reith-Witowski M. Roy A. Gnauck J. Schulte Holthausen H. Intervirology. 1992; 33: 211-216Crossref PubMed Scopus (2) Google Scholar). Chimeric Ad5/Ad12 E1 genes are tumorigenic on condition that the Ad12 E1A amino terminus is included up to the leftmost border of CR3 (Jelinek et al., 1994Jelinek T. Pereira D.S. Graham F.L. J. Virol. 1994; 68: 888-896Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). Jelinek and co-workers speculate that a so-called spacer segment, an Ad12 E1A-unique region of 60 nucleotides located between CR2 and CR3, may be involved in tumorigenicity. Interestingly, this spacer codes for the carboxyl-terminal end of the 52R protein (Brockmann et al., 1994Brockmann D. Feng L. Kröner G. Tries B. Esche H. Virology. 1994; 198: 717-723Crossref PubMed Scopus (10) Google Scholar). The importance of the spacer region is shown in an additional report of Telling and Williams, 1994Telling G.C. Williams J. J. Virol. 1994; 68: 877-887Crossref PubMed Google Scholar. These authors could show that hybrid Ad12 viruses, in which nucleotides 814-964 of the E1A gene (containing the spacer) were exchanged for the respective region of Ad5 E1A (containing no spacer), display wild-type transformation frequencies on baby rat and mouse kidney cells, but show a greatly reduced oncogenic capacity, as measured by tumor induction following virus inoculation in Hooded Lister rats. From these and other results the researchers drew the conclusion that the unique spacer region of Ad12 E1A is an oncogenic determinant of this virus. Since mutations in the spacer region also affect the 52R protein we started to characterize this Ad12 E1A-specific protein in detail. First characterization of the 52R protein revealed that it contains a striking structure in its second exon: a basic region showing a high homology with one of the DNA binding subregions of the proteins of the Fos family (Brockmann et al., 1993Brockmann D. Kröner G. Lehmann J. Esche H. Life Sci. Adv. 1993; 12: 13-22Google Scholar), followed by a cysteine-rich motif of the type C XC X3C XC (C = cysteine, X = other amino acid). We have shown that the 52R protein has a nonspecific DNA-binding activity for which both domains are essential (Brockmann et al., 1993Brockmann D. Kröner G. Lehmann J. Esche H. Life Sci. Adv. 1993; 12: 13-22Google Scholar). Moreover, using transient expression assays we could demonstrate that the 52R protein represses the trans-activating function of the cellular transcription factor AP-1 (Brockmann et al., 1994Brockmann D. Feng L. Kröner G. Tries B. Esche H. Virology. 1994; 198: 717-723Crossref PubMed Scopus (10) Google Scholar). The AP-1 complex consists mainly of proteins encoded by the different genes of the jun and fos families (for reviews, see Curran and Franza, 1988Curran T. Franza Jr., B.R. Cell. 1988; 55: 395-397Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (1304) Google Scholar and Angel and Karin, 1991Angel P. Karin M. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 1991; 1072: 129-157Crossref PubMed Scopus (3219) Google Scholar). After forming homo- (Jun-Jun; c-Jun/AP-1) or heterodimers (Jun-Fos; c-Jun-c-Fos/AP-1) they bind to the TRE elements in the promoter regions of specific target genes (e.g. the human collagenase gene) and induce their expression (Angel et al., 1987Angel P. Imagawa M. Chiu R. Stein B. Imbra R.J. Rahmsdorf H.J. Jonat C. Herrlich P. Karin M. Cell. 1987; 49: 729-739Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (2143) Google Scholar; Abate and Curran, 1990Abate C. Curran T. Semin. Cancer Biol. 1990; 1: 19-26PubMed Google Scholar). For transcriptional activity c-Jun has to be stimulated by phosphorylation at two sites which are located in its trans-activation domain: Ser-63 and Ser-73 (Binetruy et al., 1991Binetruy B. Smeal T. Karin M. Nature. 1991; 351:: 122-127Crossref PubMed Scopus (505) Google Scholar; Smeal et al., 1991Smeal T. Binetruy B. Mercola D. Birrer M. Karin M. Nature. 1991; 354: 494-496Crossref PubMed Scopus (690) Google Scholar, Smeal et al., 1992Smeal T. Binetruy B. Mercola D. Grover-Bardwick A. Heidecker G. Rapp U.R. Karin M. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1992; 12: 3507-3513Crossref PubMed Scopus (304) Google Scholar). Two specific enzymes belonging to the MAP kinase group, termed JNK1 and JNK2, are responsible for this phosphorylation (Hibi et al., 1993Hibi M. Lin A. Smeal T. Minden A. Karin M. Genes & Dev. 1993; 7: 2135-2148Crossref PubMed Scopus (1692) Google Scholar). Depending on its composition, the activity of the AP-1 complex can be differentially regulated by two E1A proteins. The protein product of the 12 S mRNA represses the trans-activating activity of c-Jun-c-Jun and c-Jun-c-Fos dimers (Offringa et al., 1990Offringa R. Gebel S. van Dam H. Timmers M. Smits A. Zwart R. Stein B. Bos J.L. van der Eb A.J. Herrlich P. Cell. 1990; 62: 527-538Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (99) Google Scholar), whereas the Ad12 E1A 52R protein represses selectively the activity of c-Jun homodimers (Brockmann et al., 1994Brockmann D. Feng L. Kröner G. Tries B. Esche H. Virology. 1994; 198: 717-723Crossref PubMed Scopus (10) Google Scholar). Down-regulation mediated by the protein translated from the 12 S mRNA depends on CR1 and is due to the inhibition of the binding of the transcription factor to its target sequence (Offringa et al., 1990Offringa R. Gebel S. van Dam H. Timmers M. Smits A. Zwart R. Stein B. Bos J.L. van der Eb A.J. Herrlich P. Cell. 1990; 62: 527-538Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (99) Google Scholar; Hagmeyer et al., 1993Hagmeyer B.M. König H. Herr I. Offringa R. Zantema A. van der Eb A.J. Herrlich P. Angel P. EMBO J. 1993; 12: 3559-3572Crossref PubMed Scopus (88) Google Scholar). The 52R protein of Ad12 E1A does not contain CR1, indicating that the repression mechanism has to be different. Consistent with this assumption, band shift as well as in vitro footprint analyses have shown that the promoter binding of c-Jun homodimers is not prevented by the 52R protein (Brockmann et al., 1994Brockmann D. Feng L. Kröner G. Tries B. Esche H. Virology. 1994; 198: 717-723Crossref PubMed Scopus (10) Google Scholar). Therefore we have analyzed whether the 52R protein blocks the trans-activating activity of c-Jun by interacting physically with the transcription factor complex. In this report we demonstrate that the Ad12-unique E1A 52R protein binds to all three members of the Jun family of transcription factors (c-Jun, JunB, and JunD). The 52R protein associates with the bZIP regions of the Jun proteins containing the basic DNA-binding domain and the leucine zipper structure. Furthermore, our results show that the 52R protein prevents the phosphorylation of the c-Jun trans-activation domain in vitro, suggesting that the 52R protein regulates c-Jun activity by disturbing its interaction with a specific kinase(s). The isolation of the Ad12 E1A-specific 52R protein and the generation of the plasmid pGEX-52R expressing the 52R protein (GST-52R) as fusion protein consisting of the glutathione S-transferase from Schistosoma japonicum (NH2 terminus) as protein leader sequence and the 52R protein (COOH terminus) was described earlier (Brockmann et al., 1990Brockmann D. Tries B. Esche H. Virology. 1990; 179: 585-590Crossref PubMed Scopus (12) Google Scholar, 1993). The c- jun gene, which was obtained from A. J. van der Eb, Laboratory for Molecular Carcinogenesis, University of Leiden, Leiden, The Netherlands, was subcloned into the vector pGEX-2T (Pharmacia Biotech Inc.) to generate the plasmid pGEX-c- jun. The mutant pGEX-c- junTAD (amino acids 1-130), which expresses the c-Jun acidic trans-activation domain as GST fusion protein but which lacks the DNA-binding region and the leucine zipper, was generated by polymerase chain reaction using primers corresponding to nucleotides 1-27 (5’-end) and to nucleotides 371-391 (3’-end, complementary sequence) of the c- jun open reading frame. The c- jun subfragment was cloned via BamHI restriction sites, which were synthesized on the 5’-ends of both primers, into the BamHI cloning site of the vector pGEX-2T. The mutant pGEX-c- junbZIP (amino acids 233-331), which contains the basic region necessary for DNA-binding and the leucine zipper involved in dimerization but which lacks the acidic trans-activation domain of c-Jun, was obtained by isolating an AvaI (nucleotide 1108 of the c- jun gene) (Angel et al., 1988Angel P. Allegretto E.A. Okino S.T. Hattori K. Boyle W.J. Hunter T. Karin M. Nature. 1988; 332: 166-171Crossref PubMed Scopus (680) Google Scholar)/BamHI fragment from pGEX-c- jun. After generating blunt ends the subfragment was cloned into the BamHI site of the vector pGem-3Z (Promega), which was filled in using dNTPs and the Klenow fragment of Escherichia coli DNA polymerase I (Maniatis et al., 1982Maniatis T. Fritsch E.F. Sambrook J. Molecular Cloning: A Laboratory Manual. Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory, Cold Spring Harbor, NY1982Google Scholar). From pGem-3Z-c- junbZIP a SmaI/AccI fragment was isolated and, after generating blunt ends, cloned into the filled in EcoRI site of the vector pGEX-2T. pGEX-c- junLZ, which expresses the c-Jun leucine zipper as GST fusion protein, was cloned by polymerase chain reaction using primers corresponding to nucleotides 832-858 (5’-end) and to nucleotides 969-996 (3’-end, complementary sequence; amino acids 278-331) of the c- jun open reading frame. pGEX-c- junDB expressing the basic DNA-binding domain of c-Jun as GST fusion protein was cloned in the same way using primers corresponding to nucleotides 748-765 (5’-end) and to nucleotides 816-837 (3’-end; complementary sequence; amino acids 250-279). The 3’-end primer carries two stop codons at its end. The human junB and the mouse junD genes were obtained from J. Schütte, University of Essen Medical School, Essen, FRG. The plasmids pGEX-c-Jun1/223Ala and pGEX-c-Jun56/223 were a gift of M. Hibi and M. Karin, University of California, San Diego, CA. The vector pGEX-(128/129) was a gift of M. A. Blanar, University of California, San Francisco, CA. This vector is a derivat of pGEX-2T and expresses a fusion protein consisting of the GST leader sequence, the recognition site for the anti-FLAG antibody (FLAG) and the recognition element for the catalytic domain of HMK which allows efficient phosphorylation of fusion proteins by HMK (Blanar and Rutter, 1992Blanar M.A. Rutter W.J. Science. 1992; 256: 1014-1018Crossref PubMed Scopus (273) Google Scholar; Ron and Dressler, 1992Ron D. Dressler H. BioTechniques. 1992; 13: 866-869PubMed Google Scholar). To obtain pGEX-(128/129)-52R the cDNA of the 52R protein was cloned in frame in the single EcoRI site following the coding region for the recognition element of the HMK. To obtain the fusion protein 6xHis-52R, which contains 6 histidine residues in front of the 52R protein, the 9.5 S cDNA was cloned into the BamHI site of the vector pQE-8 (Qiagen). Induction of the fusion protein expression and its purification via nickel-chelate affinity chromatography were performed as described by Qiagen. pTM-hTFIID, coding for the human TATA box-binding protein TBP, was a gift of A. Berk, University of California, Los Angeles, CA. The correct reading frame of the 52R fusion protein as well as of the Jun mutants was confirmed by sequencing using the automated laser fluorescent DNA sequencer of Pharmacia. HeLa cells and F9 embryonal carcinoma stem cells were grown in Dulbecco's modified Eagle's medium supplemented with 10% fetal calf serum. Jurkat cells were grown in RPMI 1640 supplemented with 10% fetal calf serum. Whole cell extract of TPA-treated Jurkat cells (50 ng/ml, 30 min) was prepared as described by Hibi et al. (1993). For transfection of F9 embryonal carcinoma stem cells, Petri dishes were precoated with 0.2% gelatin. 24 h after seeding the cells, cells were transfected (Graham and van der Eb, 1973Graham F.L. van der Eb A.J. Virology. 1973; 52: 456-467Crossref PubMed Scopus (6450) Google Scholar; Parker and Stark, 1979Parker B.A. Stark G.R. J. Virol. 1979; 31: 360-369Crossref PubMed Google Scholar) with 2 μg of the reporter plasmid, 2 μg of a mouse c- jun expression plasmid (pRc/RSV-m-c- jun), and up to 6 μg of the 52R expression plasmid (pRc/RSV-9.5S). 40 h after transfection, cells were harvested and lysed by freeze-thaw treatments. The protein concentration of the cellular extracts was measured using the Bradford, 1976Bradford M.M. Anal. Biochem. 1976; 72: 248-254Crossref PubMed Scopus (209427) Google Scholar method. Equal amounts of proteins were used to determine CAT activity (Gorman et al., 1982Gorman C.M. Moffat L.F. Howard B.H. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1982; 2: 1044-1051Crossref PubMed Scopus (5283) Google Scholar). CAT activity was quantified by liquid scintillation counting of the 14C spots on thin-layer chromatography plates. In vitro transcription/translation was performed using the TNT-coupled reticulocyte lysate system of Promega and T7 or SP6 RNA polymerase, depending on the vector and orientation of the cloned insert. Crude extracts prepared from 1 ml of bacteria culture expressing the respective GST fusion protein were separated on 12.5% SDS-polyacrylamide gels. After gel electrophoresis proteins were electroblotted (Harlow and Lane, 1988Harlow E. Lane D. Antibodies: A Laboratory Manual. Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory, Cold Spring Harbor, NY1988Google Scholar) onto Hybond-C membranes (Amersham Corp.). Denaturing, renaturing, hybridization, and washing was performed as described by Ron and Dressler, 1992Ron D. Dressler H. BioTechniques. 1992; 13: 866-869PubMed Google Scholar. As radioactively labeled probe, the 52R protein, which was cloned into the vector pGEX-(128/129), was used. For kinasing (Blanar and Rutter, 1992Blanar M.A. Rutter W.J. Science. 1992; 256: 1014-1018Crossref PubMed Scopus (273) Google Scholar; Ron and Dressler, 1992Ron D. Dressler H. BioTechniques. 1992; 13: 866-869PubMed Google Scholar) GST-(128/129) or GST-(128/129)-52R were purified as described earlier (Brockmann et al., 1993Brockmann D. Kröner G. Lehmann J. Esche H. Life Sci. Adv. 1993; 12: 13-22Google Scholar). Thereafter the glutathione-Sepharose-bound fusion proteins (10 μg) were incubated for 1 h at 37°C in 60 μl of HMK buffer (20 mM Tris/HCl, pH 7.5, 1 mM dithiothreitol, 0.1 M NaCl, 12 mM MgCl2), containing 6 μl of [γ-32P]ATP (>185 TBq/mmol, Amersham) and 30 units of heart muscle kinase (Sigma). Free radioactivity and HMK were removed by washing three times with 1 ml of phosphate-buffered saline containing 5 mM NaF. Radioactively labeled fusion proteins were eluted two times with 150 μl of elution buffer (50 mM Tris/HCl, pH 8.0, 10 mM reduced glutathione, 1 mM dithiothreitol, 5 mM NaF, 1 mM EDTA, 1 mM phenylmethylsulfonyl fluoride, 0.5 mg/ml bovine serum albumin) by rocking for 30 min at room temperature. Usually 1 × 106 cpm of the labeled fusion proteins were used for 1 ml of hybridization solution. Equal molar amounts of the different fusion proteins were used for the binding assays. The GST fusion proteins were coupled to glutathione-Sepharose 4B beads (Pharmacia) and incubated with up to 1 × 105 cpm of in vitro translated Jun or TBP in incubation buffer (10 mM Tris/HCl, pH 7.4, 5 mM MgCl2, 50 mM NaCl, 0.5% Nonidet P-40, 0.1 mM phenylmethylsulfonyl fluoride, 2 μg/ml aprotinin) containing 1.8 μg/μl bovine serum albumin. After 1 h at 4°C the beads were washed five times with 500 μl of lysis buffer. For analysis of bound proteins, the beads were boiled in 1 × Laemmli sample buffer and loaded onto 12.5% SDS-polyacrylamide gels (Laemmli, 1970Laemmli U.K. Nature. 1970; 227: 680-685Crossref PubMed Scopus (204686) Google Scholar). Labeled proteins were visualized by fluorography. For protein binding inhibition experiments, the protein binding assays were performed in the presence of a 10-fold molar excess of 6xHis-52R (compared to GST-c-Jun). Bovine serum albumin was added to the control reactions to keep the protein concentration constant in each assay. The solid-phase kinase assays were performed as described by Hibi et al. (1993). For kinase inhibition experiments the fusion protein 6xHis-52R was added at 20-fold molar excess to the reaction solution (compared to GST-c-Jun). Bovine serum albumin was added to the control reactions to keep the protein concentration constant in each assay. We have shown recently that the 52R protein down-regulates the trans-activation function of the cellular transcription factor c-Jun (Brockmann et al., 1994Brockmann D. Feng L. Kröner G. Tries B. Esche H. Virology. 1994; 198: 717-723Crossref PubMed Scopus (10) Google Scholar). To study the repression in more detail we performed transient expression assays in F9 mouse embryonal carcinoma cells lacking endogenous c-Jun activity (Chiu et al., 1988Chiu R. Boyle W.J. Meek J. Smeal T. Hunter T. Karin M. Cell. 1988; 54: 541-552Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (997) Google Scholar, Chiu et al., 1989Chiu R. Angel P. Karin M. Cell. 1989; 59: 979-986Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (575) Google Scholar). Consequently, the expression of a reporter plasmid, whose expression is driven by the c-Jun binding site of the human collagenase promoter (Col-TRE/TK-CAT; Fig. 1A) is undetectable in these cells (Fig. 1 B). Co-transfection of 2 μg of the mouse c- jun expression plasmid pRc/RSV-m-c- jun results in a 12-fold activation of the TRE-mediated CAT-enzyme activity (Fig. 1 B). This trans-activation function of c-Jun is repressed by the 52R protein (Fig. 1 B) after co-transfection of a respective expression vector (pRc/RSV-9.5S; Fig. 1A). Down-regulation of c-Jun activity is dosage-dependent. In the highest concentration used (6 μg pRc/RSV-9.5S) the c-Jun-dependent CAT enzyme expression is repressed approximately 5-fold (Fig. 1 B). pRc/RSV lacking the 52R cDNA has no influence on CAT expression from the reporter plasmid Col-TRE/TK-CAT (Fig. 1 B). Studying the repression mechanism we found that the 52R protein does not prevent the binding of c-Jun to its promoter target sequence (Brockmann et al., 1994Brockmann D. Feng L. Kröner G. Tries B. Esche H. Virology. 1994; 198: 717-723Crossref PubMed Scopus (10) Google Scholar). Therefore we speculated that the 52R protein might associate directly with c-Jun and disturb in this way the interaction between c-Jun and factors essential for transcriptional activation. To examine this possibility we performed far Western blot analyses. Protein lysates prepared from bacteria expressing the fusion protein GST-c-Jun (Fig. 2 B, lane 5) or the leader sequence GST (Fig. 2 B, lane 3) were resolved on a 12.5% SDS-polyacrylamide gel and blotted onto a nitrocellulose membrane. Bacterial lysates which do not contain the GST leader sequence or the GST-c-Jun fusion protein were used as controls (Fig. 2 B, lanes 2 and 4). Hybridization was performed with the 32P-labeled probe GST-(128/129)-52R. GST-(128/129) is a derivat of pGEX-2T and expresses a fusion protein consisting of the GST leader sequence and the phosphorylation site for HMK, which allows efficient phosphorylation of fusion proteins by HMK (Blanar and Rutter, 1992Blanar M.A. Rutter W.J. Science. 1992; 256: 1014-1018Crossref PubMed Scopus (273) Google Scholar; Ron and Dressler, 1992Ron D. Dressler H. BioTechniques. 1992; 13: 866-869PubMed Google Scholar). Control gels revealed that the affinity-purified probes were more than 95% pure (Fig. 2 D, lanes 4 and 7). As shown in Fig. 2 C, GST-(128/129)-52R hybridizes to the GST-c-Jun fusion protein (lane 5) but not to the GST leader sequence (lane 3) or to lysate proteins obtained from uninduced bacteria (lanes 2 and 4), indicating that the interaction is due to a specific association of the 52R protein with c-Jun. To exclude completely that the GST leader sequence is somehow involved in this interaction, we performed a far Western blot with radioactively labeled GST-(128/129) protein. No hybridization signals were obtained in these experiments (data not shown). These results clearly show that the 52R protein is able to bind directly and specifically to the cellular transcription factor c-Jun. To identify the domain of c-Jun involved in the association with the 52R protein we hybridized a far Western blot carrying two c-Jun deletion mutants (GST-c-JunTAD, GST-c-JunbZIP; Fig. 2 A) with GST-(128/129)-52R. GST-c-JunTAD expresses the acidic trans-activation domain of c-Jun while GST-c-JunbZIP contains the basic DNA-binding domain and the leucine zippe

Expression of the muscle-specific 2a isoform of the sarco/endoplasmic reticulum Ca2+ ATPase (SERCA2) requires activation of an otherwise inefficient splicing process at the 3’-end of the primary gene transcript. The sequence and topology requirements for this regulated splicing event were studied in the BC3H1 myogenic cell line using a minigene containing the 3’-end of the SERCA2 gene. In undifferentiated BC3H1 cells, the splice process is made inefficient by the presence of a weak muscle-type 5’-donor site (5’D1) and a long terminal intron. Both optimizing the 5’D1 and decreasing the length of the muscle-specific intron, induced muscle-type splicing in undifferentiated myogenic cells. Moreover, the induction of muscle-type transcripts was only observed when two competing processing sites, the polyadenylation site (pAu) used in non-muscle cells and the second neuronal 5’-donor site (5’D2), were weak. Indeed, making 5’D2 consensus induced neuronal-type splicing in undifferentiated myocytes and prevented the appearance of muscle-type transcripts. Similarly, replacing the polyadenylation site (pAu) with a strong site almost completely inhibited muscle-type splicing after myogenic differentiation. We conclude that weak processing sites and a long terminal intron are required for tissue-dependent mRNA processing of the SERCA2 transcript. The Ca2+-transport ATPases of the sarcoplasmic or endoplasmic reticulum mediate the uptake of Ca2+ into intracellular stores, such as the sarcoplasmic or endoplasmic reticulum. Casteels R. Ann. N. Y. Acad. Sci. 1992; 671: 82-91Crossref PubMed Scopus (48) Google Scholar). Chem. 1987; 262: 3768-3774Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 3Korczak B. Zarain-Herzberg A. Brandl C. Ingles C. Green N. MacLennan D. J. Biol. Lompré A. FEBS Lett. 1988; 229: 45-48Crossref PubMed Scopus (34) Google Scholar, 5Eggermont J. Wuytack F. Casteels R. Biochem. J. 1990; 266: 901-907PubMed Google Scholar, 6Gunteski-Hamblin A. This divergence in the C-terminal part of the protein is responsible for a functional difference between SERCA2a and SERCA2b (8Lytton J. Westlin M. Burk S.E. Shull G.E. MacLennan D.H. J. Biol.
